Excelente breja da Stone, essa american Strong ale é uma porrada desde o começo! Com cor escuro, vermelho-couro, espuma bege e aroma intenso de lúpulo, malte. No paladar, desce com bom corpo, e rapidamente o gosto do malte, alcoólico, vai preenchendo os sentidos. Na seqüência, uma explosão de amargor, intenso e herbáceo, que vai se equilibrando com o maltado. Final seco e alcoólico. Retrogosto amargo, ótimo. Excelente breja!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Superb clear dark rich amber appearance.  Not to much on the nose but first sip reveals a big hop presence on top of a big malt base.  Sweetness and bitterness balanced well and I enjoyed it.  Was expecting a great beer and that was what I got.  Looking forward to a couple more of these.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2014 I remember having this beer many years, before I started taking notes and entering reviews.  I didnt like it then but was still surprised to find I dont like it now either.  In general, Im a big fan of Stone Brewing and my tastes have expanded to include many extreme and big ales.  This revisit started well enough, with an attractive red-amber ale topped by a small but durable tan head.  The aroma was a slightly boozy mix of medium malt and herbal/earthy hops.  The main impression made by the flavor is, unfortunately, the overly bitter aftertaste.  

M: medium body and carbonation.

O: too challenging.
Was excited to try this, especially in California,  very bold beer, strong yet hoppu and full unfortunately for me didnt live up to all the hype. but still very good beer.
Sweet front with hoppy bitter finish. Tastes of caramel in finish with bite back. Very grassy nose.
Bomber.  Pours dark reddish brown.  Off white dissipating head.  Big, grassy nose.  Strong, nicely balanced.  A hint of coconut in the finish.  Outstanding as usual from Stone.

Half Pint of tap at Craft Beer Co, Farringdon, London (£4.50):
Fresh hops with strong caramel notes and further grassy hops. There is a lot of sugar upfront and some sweetness along with hints of toffee and a generally quite rich aroma. There is some roasted malts as well but overall it is the hops with some citrus that dominates.

Deep ruby amber to copper colour in the glass with a thin white lacing on top and around the sides.

Caramel and rich, sweet flavours with grassy hops from the smell and a lot of bitterness. There is some grapefruit coming through and a lot of sweetness. Surprisingly refreshing and had a pleasant alcohol kick to it that went down well.

Smooth with a medium to full body and a lot of carbonation. There bitterness levels were very in your face and the mouthfeel was complimented by some sweet malts too.

An exceptional beer and one that did not disappoint in any way, shape or form upon first trying it. The beer was insanely hoppy with lots of bitterness. Surprisingly easy to drink and went down well with the mouthfeel complimented the taste and smell quite well. A must try.

Finally tried this after hearing all the hype. Aroma was pleasant and cloying with hop. Beautiful red-brown color. Smooth and balanced with a great hop bite at the end. A big but balanced beer - very good if you are a hop lover.
Pours brown with white head and nice lacing.  Aroma of grassy hops and bread.  Taste is bitter but balanced with a solid malt and Carmel backbone.  Great beer.

I have long planned to try this, and was bracing for a hop explosion from the great description, but this beer is good and smooth. Pours a clear brownish-red color, like a darker amber, with good creamy looking head. Aroma of hops and pine, some malts, but taste is not overly hoppy. Has a semi-sweet toffee sense to it. The finish is bitter, with a taste of the alcohol, I think. Good beer. Cant wait to try other ones. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: APR 22, 2016 Bomber.  Had this many times but have never gotten around to rating it.  Pours a clear amber color with a nice 1 finger head that fades slowly and never seems to completely go away.  Awesome appearance.  Fairly complex aroma, nice balance of hops and malt.  Pine, flowers, grapefruit, toasted malt, and lightly burnt caramel.  Taste is awesome.  So smooth and balanced.  Pine and citrus hops complements the toasted malt the whole way through.  Light sweetness and moderate bitterness.  Smooth, spicy, bready finish.  Light to medium body.  Overall, I go back to this all the time because it seems appropriate for any type of weather or mood Im in.  And its hard to beat the price too.

Dark Red with a fluffy 4 finger head. Has an aroma of sweet caramel & toffee with some mild piney hops. Flavor has some sweet caramel & licorice notes with some piney hops to back it up. Heavy bodied with some fairly strong carbonation, this is more of a sipper. Overall a great strong ale

After reading the hilarious description, I honestly expected to suffer from a hop overload, but this beer is amazing! Pours with a thick, creamy beige head, which has a nutty, sweet flavor. The beer is darker than expected, a deep dark red and bubbly with carbonation. Nutty, grassy, caramel/coffee notes in the forground, enough to entertain the palate but not enough to knock you over the head, and a pleasantly bitter sweet finish.
UPDATED: NOV 16, 2013 Draught. Poured amber brown with creamy head. Hoppy aromas. Very nice balanced between hops and malts.

The head is strong. It has a clear dark amber color. The taste is slight beer and very pleasing. The aroma is strong without an over domination of one ingredient over another. This is one of the best beers as consistency and taste go.

(on tap @ Craft Beer Company Clerkenwell) Pours a clear, dark copper with medium, dense, tan head. Aroma is both hoppy and malty and has notes of herbs, tea and caramel. Creamy palate, full body, medium carbonation and a sweet yet hopped finish. Very well composed and balanced. It tastes like the brewer has managed to pack a lot of complementary flavours into this beer, which in the end manage to hold each other in check in their rivalry for the dominance of my palate. Big amounts of toffee sweetness, a considerate amount of herbal hops and a hint of something that seems a bit smoked to me. Very pleasant and well executed. The ABV is well-masked, making this beer dangerously drinkable.
Sampled at the Texas Craft Brew fest, my score is based off of some incoherent notes and a 2 oz sample.

Pours amber with a one finger white fluffy head. Hops at first on the nose but with malts taking over over time. Was a little surprised with this one, I was expecting another excellent Stone beer, but it fell a little short. Still a solid beer, but the bitterness seemed to take over by then end.

Appearance is deep red amber with creamy tan foam cap. Aroma is deep caramel malt and fruit. Slight hint of poem and raisin. Taste is several layers complex layers of roasted, nutty, and caramel malt but not overwhelming.  Sharp hop bite on the finish that balances everything. Nice but of carbonation with a crisp, clean finish.  Overall great beer.

A - Pours a cloudy dark amber copper with a 2 finger foamy off-white head with excellent retention.

S - Fresh grapefruit citrus, earthy pine, plums, toasted malt

T - A bounty of fresh grapefruit rushes in with huge flavor and bitterness. A resiny pine shows up towards the finish. The caramel malt has a roasted fruit character and provides just enough sweetness to counteract the complex hops. Aftertaste is nutty and bitter with the malt still lingering on the palate.

M - Full bodied with good carbonation.

A citrus wonderland along with a carameled fruit malt makes mouth happy. Complex hop profile that keep going and going. Just an awesome brew.

Serving type: bottle

11-13-2010
Hoppy bitter dark brew with a clean finish.reminds me of surly furious. Good depth and quickly dissipating head.

Great frothy head, followed by a brilliant nose of (slight) caramel and red fruit. Good body and huge offensive slap in the face of grapefruit rind. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bomber pour.  Classicly great strong ale with some power and bit behind it.

March 2013 - draught at Craft Beer Co Islington.  They also had the oaked version but I went for this one instead.  Rich sweet caramel malts, rose water, sharp astringent floral bitterness which is marked but Ive had a lot stronger.  Coffee in the aftertaste.  Overall I think the flavour is a bit confused.  Not a big fan.

Bottle. Loved this dark brew right from the frothy starting pour. The head is solid, small bubbles with lots plenty of life and staying power. A sweet, resinous flow over the tongue leaves a piquant aftertaste with bitterness that mellows after a short time leaving a full sensation of the flavor on the tongue. Inviting. Beguiling. Delightful. This is a brew you want to spend some time with.

Bomber. Pours deep reddish brown with huge off-white head and plenty of lacing. Aroma is caramel, pine resin, some red fruit and nutty notes. Taste gives a big rich caramel hit, nutty malt, thick pine resin, some bitter pithy grapefruit, and red fruit. Lasting, mouthcoating pine resin and rich malt flavours. Medium/full mouthfeel. Big and bold: lives up to its name.
Bottle. Dark but very clear amber color. Good head. Not much aroma. Not as malty tasting as it looks. Not bad at all for a change of pace.

22 oz. bottle from local grocery store. Dark brown color with foamy head that quickly dissipated to some bubbles. Hoppy aroma. Boy, some solid hops -- bitter taste with a piney finish that lasts. Really enjoyable (if you a hop monster).

Pours a deep mahogany color with a tan frothy head. Smells of malts and underlying hops. Taste is a bitter malty taste with lots of piney hops to balance it out. Smooth with a bitter finish. Overall a very strong but good ale.
Draft. Very tasty, bitter, light foamy head. Smells like dry hops. Dark opaque amber. Low carbonation.

Great hoppy aroma. Always clean and refreshing with a bit of bitter citrus. A go to beer and is always in stock in my fridge. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Garnet color, lacking head but leaves nice lacing. Hoppy, biscuity nose. Taste gives off malt, citrus, spicy pine, and plenty bitter. Wonderful beer, and bitterness sticks to your teeth just how it should!
Dark in color, with tan head and hoppy aroma. Bold hoppy flavor with barley, malt, and coffee notes. Excellent beer, looks great and tastes even better!

Uploading old reviews that were missing comments. One of the earliest craft beers I ever tries. Massive hops. Almost overwhelming. Tough to get through the whole bomber but leaves you with quite the sense of accomplishment. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Good example of an American IPA, hope you like hops.  Its balanced well has a rose amber hue and is very very resinous on the palate and the nose.  Nice go to for anyone looking for a beer to help progress their palate.
Très bonne biere. Elle est noir sur un temps et elle goute le charbon. Je vais dire comme eux, si tes pas faites pour, tu laimeras pas

Pours a dark amber with a rocky white head. Aromas are not as pronounced as I was hoping, some citrus, some resin. Appearance is wonderful, nice color, nice head that leaves lacing that sticks as the beer disappears. Taste, like they tell you is aggressive, great hop bitterness balanced with a malty sweetness. Palate is well bodied and thick. This is a must try, so well balanced, so well put together. Drinking this beer compared to my beer is like my second grader teaching me things I should know. Both embarrass me.

Bottle To tulip. Starts quite anonymas with not much of Aroma and a very Shy head, but is thereafter more aggressive with nice bitterness and some sourness.

22oz bomber.  Nice, clear, mahogany pour...bubbly, persistent, khaki head.  Laces pretty well.  Sweet taste at the beginning, hoppy at the end.  Its much more complex than that, but if you havent had this yet, punch yourself, then shell out $5 for a pint or bottle.
Boom! Wow. Rich malts, oily almost. The sweetness hits first, but then the hops come through, and stay, and stay.

I love the name; has a nice aroma to it. I went in drinking before hand with the idea that it would be strong in bitterness, and very hopsy. It was a little too strong for me! I feel like theres too many a mixture of flavours that really loses the heart of its selling point and overall taste. I wouldnt consider it worth the money theyre asking to buy one of these bottles, but it is a much better quality Ale than others on the market. If youre not concerned about money, and want something of better quality than most, buy this; if youd like to save some money and buy something equally as tasteful, try another cheaper Ale.
Amber with tan hean. Sweet citrus and hoppy on the nose. Similar taste with strong bitter hop bite. Very good beer.
A hop punch in the face, followed up by a nice nutty malt finish. A classic. Little alcohol flavor.
Love this beer, its my go to if all else fails. Usually about $5.75 for a bottle of it. But so worth it.

Pours a dark amber with a creamy head. Fantastic aroma, with citrus and floral characters that are then replaced by piney qualities. Smooth and velvety on the palate. Very nicely balanced, although the hops come on a bit strong at the end for my taste. Resinous, bitter finish is certainly present, but its not overwhelming.

On tap from rattle and Hum NY. pours very dark...small off white head. strong smell of hopps and a hint of cherry. very heavy taste of malt which almost magically turns into a malty but almost coffee/chocolate taste. this would probably be the first time I ever described something as a "desert beer" Nice for what it is but one is enough as far as drink-ability.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2014 Pours clear copper brown, with a small creamy head. In the nose lots of  caramel malts and piney, resiny , citrus hop. Very aggressive malt and hop profile and packed with flavour. Slick in the mouth, full bodied, Finish is bitter with a juicy hop aftertaste
Despite the this is actually a very  nice ale with lots of hop bitterness.
Dark amber, almost brown with beige head. Aroma is a combination of sweet malt, caramel and pine. Flavors of pine, wood and a bit of roasted malt. Lots hop bitterness. Solid hoppy strong ale.

Bottles over the years, this review is from 2011. Pours chestnut amber with medium khaki head. Aromas and taste of heavy bitter hops, sweet malts, and more bitter grains. Just so overly aggressive and unbalanced in my opinion. Bad mouthfeel. Lets get one thing straight here, I love me some hoppy brews but thing is like drinking hop extract, and the hops arent that great so theres no point. Nice gimmick beer from Stone, Ill stick to something juicy and balanced.

Pours dark almost black with small off white head on tap. Great hoppy aroma and taste. Great beer!

Just a great smooth beer. Bastard!  Wow!  What a great beer. Stone really created the perfect beer. Intense, yet smooth. 

MKH---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours dark copper brown with a white head. Malt aroma. Tastes of toffee and grapefruit. Lingering bitterness. Great beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2015 I get so caught up in finding new IPAs these days, that I forget how good this beer is - even though its not an IPA. Pours a clear dark reddish-brown. Huge malt aroma, with just enough hop presence to sorta remind me why I truly love this beer. Its so complex but so balanced at the same time... although the balance is in abundance. Its a huge beer. Finishes really well. Almost perfect.

This is certainly not for the faint of heart, but I love it. The aroma is full of malty goodness, but the secret is after you take a drink. There's nothing small about this beer. It's all about big hops, lots of malt, and attitude. Pours a super dark reddish brown, with moderate lacing on the sides of the glass as you drink it.

Though at first the taste is bitter, very bitter. This beer is an acquired taste. After the first bottle though it went down smooth. The packaging is fantastic!
A huge beer.  Either youre going to love it or hate it.  If youre an IPA fan, youll probably enjoy it.  Coppery aroma, with tart citrus

Pours dark red with one finger white head that leaves some soapy lacing.  The aroma is mostly hops with some nice citrus/grapefruit notes, similar to an IPA.  The taste follows the aroma with citrus hops most prominent and malts hidden underneath.  It starts out fairly well balanced and then fades to a nice lingering bitterness.
Decent ale with amazingly thick head and strong hoppy aroma. Unfortunately the taste is too bitter for my palate. I prefer the 2012 Vertical Epic from Stone Brewery.

A finger of head on a dark straw colored body.
The aroma is fairly malty/grainy with a big dose of lemon.
The taste is bold and strong. An excellent malt bill with a healthy lemon bitterness. The balance is great.
The texture is smooth and soft with moderate carbonation. 
The balance on this beer allows it to be big and bold, yet still quite drinkable. An amazing ale.

Awesome beer. Strong, rich, complex and did i mention strong. This one has it all. Lots of malt, super balanced in all categories. I am not going to describe this one because there are two kinds of people. The ones who have tried this already and those who have trying to find this one. Get some

22 oz bottle.  Deep reddish-brown with a massive, rocky, light tan head that dissipates very slowly and leaves plenty of lacing.  The aroma is hops, spruce, citrus fruit, caramelized malts and toasted grains.  Medium body with a rich and complex flavor.  The toasted and caramel malts hit first, but are quickly wiped out with an assertive hop bitterness.  Finish is dry, lingering and lightly sweet.  Flavor smooths out and develops as it warms, where the malts become more prevalent.  Interesting and complex.  One of a kind.

The appearance of this beer is beautiful, for it is a dark auburn color with a tan and prominent head; furthermore, the aroma of this beer is subtle, but hints of dough and hops do come through. Once sipped, the bold bitterness hits you suddenly and stays with you for quite awhile. Additionally, the  medium body, average carbonation, and oily texture combine nicely.

This a very strong beer.  Strong on alcohol, hops, and flavor.  Pours very dark yellow in color.  Another great beer from stone 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2013 Dark amber color with very sticky lacing. Extremely strong and bitter hops smell/taste with bits of pine and lemon. Yes, that sounds like furniture polish, but its a great one if Im in the mood for bitter beer.
This is my go to beer when a bar has it. Good combo of bitterness to hops very drinkable.
This brew is solid. Just plain solid. Cant ever go wrong with ABA! Its balanced and tasty!
This is what beer is meant to be. Hoppy, bitter, relatively high alcohol content, but very drinkable.

Poured a medium dark brown. Scent is very strong in hops as usual with most Stone Beer. Has a very heavy malt and hops taste to it. It was blended together very well to make a great complex sipping beer. Another very tasty beer to try on tap!

Bomber shared, pours dark red to almost brown with a light tan colored head that just lingers. Nice big malt aroma backed by hops. The flavor burst open a big hop splash followed by a strong malty backbone. Whos not worthy? Just a wonderful strong ale with lots of hops. What could be better.

Bomber bottle. Aroma is carmel and hoppy. The appearance is a dark bronze with some nice lacing. The taste starts hoppy, but is nicely balanced. Palate is ok. Overall, a good beer. Will buy again.

Bright hoppy aroma with notes of citrus and spruce.
Thick pillowy off-white head on the pour; dies down to thin foam with copious lacing. Deep burnt red color. 
Pungent hoppy flavor is dominant. Light raisin-like sweetness with a good medium to heavy hop bitterness.
Lively carbonation; lightly creamy mouthfeel.
Although this is not my go-to style of beer, this is a very worthy ale. I certainly wouldnt turn one down.
UPDATED: JAN 29, 2013 One of my favorites. I absolutely love every chance i get to have this beer. The hops overpower giving it a dragon-thrust. Im definitely worthy.
Very good beer with the biggest head Ive ever had! Good flavor of hops and very strong, so you only need a few.
Such a good beer... has everything you could ask for. Amazing smell. Thick creamy head. Deep dark ale color. And the taste is where its at. Hoppy and amazing. Nuf said

Dark amber/cider color; Medium body; Aroma of caramel malt, spicy hops, & some citrus; Flavor of slight sweet malt, caramel/toffee, spicy hops, and citrus; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Overall, a classic - very good.
Bottle.  Pours reddish brown.  Notes of pine resin mixed with caramel malt.  Fairly astringent on the finish, quite a bit of hop kick.  Rests a bit boozy after the swallow.

Dark amber with good head and lacing.  Blend of citrus and pine hop aroma with caramel malt also.  Sweet caramel flavor at first and then the citrus and pine hop hits adding bitterness that lingers a bit but good carbonation scrubs it away.  Surprisingly full mouthfeel.  Better than expected.

Pours a red/brown amber with good size tan head. Good lacing.  Smell is citrus/grassy hops with roasted malt in the back. Taste is bitter herbal hops with malty caramel undertones  with some sweetness that help balance the bitter.  Light syrup mouthfeel. Good for a bitter beer.  Not my favorite style but could drink again.

Botle shared with Shaun.Clear,dark amber pour under a large off white head.Hop aroma.Sweetish caramel malt taste with vanilla and some hoppiness.Balanced well,easy drinking,nice drop of beer.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2013 It pours a mahogany red. Deep like good wood. Clear.   Not as much head as I thought it should have and not much retention down to a thin cap and even that  disappeared.  Smell is sweet carmel malt and hops bitterness.  Because I wanted to try it so much I just dove right in.  Lacing nicely and up front is full on hops.  The citrus  becomes more evident on the nose and in the finish.  Nice long finish, medium carbonation and medium body.  You would think to look at this beer that it would be heavy but its surprisingly light.  Its fully loaded with hops and strong malt backbone realizing a rich deep flavor that is not complex but rather assertive and in your face arrogant.

The name is very fitting! Although its clearly a superb brew, the colour, head, aroma, palate are all superb. its just soooo bitter. I expected it to bitter but DAMN this thing is just too in your face!!
Pours a reddish brown. Very nice lacing. Aromas and flavours are piney and hoppy. Bitter, strong and good.
Dark and hoppy with some complex sweet notes in here somewhere. Pretty excellent beverage.

Pours much darker than expected, fairly dark for a strong ale. Bitterness in this ale is fairly unprecedented, more delightfully bitter than most any other beer Ive ever had. Full of flavor, a little sourness, and a nice malt balance.

Pours a deep clear amber/ruby with 2 fingers of off-white pillowy head. Aroma is big on the grapefruits and pine. Taste is some subtle malts that are hidden behind the hops. Long, clean bitter finish. Truth be told, if you blindfolded me and gave me this beer, I would say I was drinking an IPA. Bitterness is more intense than most IPAs, even. The bottle is right in that this is not for beginners, even though this is Stones de facto flagship beer. Reasonably priced at 3.99-4.99 a 22oz bomber.
A good hoppy strong ale with a nice aroma. Stone Brewing 7.2% The draft is the beer I rated.
I was expecting a lot from this one, but I think I prefer the oaked version more. This really just felt like a big hoppy beer without the vanilla tones. Still, pretty darn delicious.
Pours a clear dark amber, almost cola color with a full off white head.  Maple syrup and hop aroma.  Taste is sweet caramel malt, vanilla, maple syrup and hop oil bitterness.  Quite good.

Pours a deep amber with a sudsy off-white head. Aromas of pine, cherries, earthy hops and some alcohol. Flavor is big time hoppy with a slight amount of the malts coming through to a bitter and fairly dry finish. One of the beers that got me into craft brews and still one of my all time staples, so it holds a special place in my heart. Cheers!
Has a roasty aroma with Red amber coloring, frothy head, very bitter, full bodied beer, that is filling and has strong hops standing out.
deep amber color. Tobacco, apricot, a touch of caramel. Actually fairly malty. Med full body. Very well balanced burnt raisins. Tobacco. Moderate bitterness. Definitive American strong ale
Strong. First sip is a bit harsh but it smoothes out and tastes delightful after a few more sips.

Shared bomber with sherm1016.  This one has been in the fridge for a year or so...maybe 2...has aged the edge off of it...actually better than a fresh one I tasted a year or so ago... But with still the hoppy / Caramel flavor I like...tasty

Plum color with a dense head and some lacing. Hoppy nose. Malty intro with a mildly-carbonated mouthfeel and a sweet, grapefruit finish.
Tap. Amber with white head. Smells malty, fresh. Tastes bitter, chocolate, very bitter finish. Good.
Amber brown with a thin white head. Aroma is very sweet, honey, apples, pears, along with bitter hops and rich malts. Crisp and astringent finish.

Finally getting around to reviewing this legendary beer.

The beer appears a gorgeous hue of ruby tinged sunburst orange. The head is off white and measures a fingers width, leaving some sticky lacing on the sides of the goblet. 65 cl bottle @ home, Enjoy by 16.04.2012

Well, it seems that I got and old bottle but this is good anyway. Perhaps the hops could have been more aggressive

Very strong, very hoppy taste.  Leaves a good flavor in your mouth.  Smells of caramel and almost a little chocolate or coffee.  Design and label always get good looks.  Reasonable price.  Great buy, I constantly go back.
Bottle. Pours a hazy dark red/copper. Aroma is sweet caramel and hops. Flavor is caramel with a nice backbone that finishes with hops. Very nice.

i have waited to rate this one for a while, i go back to it so i can see if im better off mixing this beer with a weaker beer to enjoy it better, and i do, its good and diffrent in its own way,,,,,, so be it,,,,,,,,,

From a 22 oz bottle shared at home.  Pours a deep amber with an off white head.  Citrus and pine nose.  Complex flavors of grtapefruit zest, pine and hints of caramel.  Nice DIPA!

This is my favorite beer right now, ever since I tried it a few years ago.  Unfortunately, I cant always afford to buy it, but when I do its always heavenly.  I am so impressed by everything about this Ale I would never let my fridge run out of it if possible.
Pours a honey-red with a thick 3-fingered tan head.  Smells of citrus, spruce, caramel - very rich.  Taste is bitter and mildly sweet, grapefruit, pine, walnut.

Dark brown with an thin off-white head, lasts fairly well. Sweet caramel and toasted malt nose with hints of soya. Nice malt character in the flavour, more toasted malt, bread, wood, coffee and nuts. Soft carbonation. Big body but drinkable. Hop character shows up in the long finish. Very nice.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2017 Dark red colour with lasting head. Aroma and flavour have some piney hop and caramel malts. Leaves a furry bitter taste on the palate. _______ Original rate:4.1 Light brown. Has a caramel sweet, malty aroma. Toasted malty flavour with a nice level of hoppiness. Great balance of bitter and sweet.

Arrogant Bastard has become a right of passage into craft beer. Its a good introduction to hopped up brews. I like the character and body imparted by the malt-bill. The hops provide a strong but not over-powering aroma. The mouthfeel is thick but still drinkable. This brew is meant to be sipped, savored, and pondered.

On tap at Stone in Oceanside. Clean aroma with a crisp malty sweetness and hoppy citrus. Taste is very hop forward with notes of pine resin, spice, and citrus. Finish is hoppy and slightly astringent. A good choice for any discerning drinker.
Amazing. On tap at Pizza Port in Niagara Falls. So full and big but also drinkable and great with food. Always lives up to expectations.
Clear clean chestnutty brown which is tooped by a dense multi layered cake. Left some very thuck waving. Resiny on the nose and tongue with a burnt almost rubber edge

On tap at Duke's Alehouse Crystal Lake, Illinois in tulip glass. Poured thick red bordering on brown with dense two finger head that quickly faded and left a lot of lacing. Aroma is malty, sweet, American hops grassy. Big dose of sweet malt with equally big bitterness throughout and some alcohol heat. "Balanced" by both malt and hop over the top. Mouthfeel is medium thick and low carbonation. Overall a red ale gone wild but sweetness slightly cloying due to low carb off tap.

Tap. Poured an intriguing reddish brown with a nice tan head and good lacing. Caramel and hops in the aroma. Great flavors with the pronounced hop profile, caramel and a good malt balance. Good bitterness on the finish - not too much but definitely strong.

Pours a deep copper color with a light tan head that laces decently.  Oh wow.  Smells overwhelmingly hopping, resin and pine abounding.  Lots of grapefruit flavor--hops, hops, hops!  Theres actualy a complex malt backbone here, too, but it sometimes gets lost in the hoppiness. This is, as advertised, a very aggressively hoppy beer, but its got a lot more going for it than just hops.  If you can get through the huge IBU blast, youll enjoy this one, but I know I cant do more than one or two at a time.
This has a nice balance of flavors, but as others have commented, it does have a bitterness to it.  Its probably the heartiest beer youll find it most grocery stores.

I'm not fond of bitter beer, and this is really a bitter beer. But, the complexity of the taste, and the spice of the bitterness make this beer stand out.

I won't drink this beer often, but I will enjoy it when I do.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle (22 oz). Share by Raphaël, thanks! Murky brown with a small beige head and some lacing. Aroma is full of caramel with resinous hops and vanilla. Taste of malt and caramel but most of the place is taken by resinous hops. Sticky resinous mouthfeel. Slight alcohol presence. I think this beer is pretty unidimensional (caramel/hops) and not refined and complex... but im probably just not worthy of it.

This was actually my very first craft beer, almost twelve years ago. Back then, I felt it was extreme, but now, having had a whole range of ridiculously hopped beers, this one seems tame by comparison. Amazing how our tastes change!

A mans brew for sure. Watching someone inexperienced take their first sip of an Arrogant Bastard is like watching a boy become a man. Dark appearance, full bitter flavor and deeply aromatic. Women need not try it.

22 oz. bottle poured into tulip glass. Nice dark burgundy copper color. Decent tan head. Bitter flavor upfront followed by well blended notes of grass, floral and coffee. Super great beer, always a favorite.

Draft at lucky lab.  Pours deep copper with a small pillow head.  The aroma is hoppy with some caramel balance.  This is a nice bitter beer with a little extra roughness on the finish.  the alcohol is well hidden.

Pours a deep copper color with a thin head that has good retention. The hops are bitter and full of citrus with less flowery aroma and taste than other popular style IPAs. More of a malty pallet than most others of this style.

On tap @ProofBrewing. Pours a dark gold, almost amber color with thin white foam head. Mouthful is of citrus hops, grassy, off-sweet caramel malt. Good strong ale, and having it on special for $3 makes it a great find.

It's a hearty beer whose taste evolves with every sip. Highly recommended as a drink to be shared with other beer aficionados. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Superbe bière cuivrée, très légèrement voilée et où flotte un léger voile déposant au verre une mince dentelle.  Des arômes au profil anglais où on note un malt biscuit au beurre, une levure légèrement lactée et des houblons aux puissantes notes de pamplemousse blanc.  Très amère, une trace de sucres non fermentiscibles et une minéralité à peine perceptible.  Très  costaude, braquée,  elle est de texture huileuse,  moyennement effervescente, elle donne une finale très aromatique et sétire sur une interminable amertume.  Superbe bière!  Gracieusement offerte: merci Ben!

A classic strong ale; and a classic Stone beer.  Not one of my favorites per se, but if you're looking for hops and sweetness, this definitely fits the bill.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bomber->snifter.  Dark amber, decent head.  Aroma is malt over hops and spice.  Strong hop taste with good malt balance.  Great mouthfeel.  Very good strong ale.
Truly delish. Got me started on arrogant beverages and still the go to for single serving hop blasting. Not my favourite, but close
Bottled, 65 cl. Pours deep amber with a small tan head. Quite malty, grains or biscuits on the nose with some bitter hops. Pine bitter and quite malty in taste. Pleasant malty aftertaste.

Bomber---> snifter.  Pours deep red/brown with a thick tan head that laces like crazy.  Aroma is roasted caramel and super piney hops.  Taste is bitter floral hop with a good deal of bready malt to support it, and a little bit of spice.  Bitterness lasts through the whole drink.  Medium palate.  As bitter as this beer is, its still incredibly balanced.  Very nice beer to drink every so often and the price is right as well.
This beer has it all. Explosive aroma and full taste with plenty of hoppiness. Not my favorite but couldnt justify a lower rating.
Love the name, beer was kind of a letdown. I didnt think it was as intense as advertised.
UPDATED: NOV 13, 2012 Bottle. Aggressive beer indeed. Some maltiness but plenty of hop to grab you. Not the smoothest drinker, but damn goot all the same.

Pours a deep ruby/brown with a tan head, which at first is quite thick but soon settles into a thin but consistent head. Lovely smell of citrusy hops and biscuity malt which is a sign of things to come. The taste hits you with the malt, lots of biscuit, caramel, then the hops, with bitterness and quite a lot of citrus notes. Absolutely fantastically balanced. Lovely, well bodied mouthfeel, medium carbonation, leaving a beatiful bitter finish. Excellent, excellent beer.

Solid drinking beer, a little weak in flavor, not much to stand out, smooth with the very tiny spice, not a bad beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Just right every time. For me. For my pallet. Dont really care what others think about this fine brew. My fave, all mine..."
Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; I like bold beers and this is a big bold beer, pours dark brown, a bit of smoke, heavy malt, slight hop. Bring it on you bastard.

gorgeous mahogany colour with reddish latte coloured head. Crystal malt, amber and apricot aromas along with redwood, sweet figs and toffee brittle. I could go on... I will go on: spruce and pine resin. To taste there is an immediate FARK! noise as I realise what Ive put in my mouth. There was a full-on blast of competing flavours like an explosion at a caramel factory with apricot, glace orange peel, resin, chlorophyll and just every available adjective to describe American hops. This is just an excelsis of malt, hops and anger. It has the remarkable effect of numbing the back of the tongue like a throat lolly. To be fair, the label does suggest it will be an aggessive ale. 
"This beer hangs on to the parts of the mouth you dont expect them to and then gives you a thump." said my learned off-sider Ari.
Theres just so much more that could be written about this remarkable, remarkable ale. 
This just describes for me the American ethos of bigger, better, faster. Remarkable.

Pours a reddish-brown, big foamy long-lasting/non-lacing head. Aroma is bread, grass, roasted malt. Taste is heavily grassy at first, then citrus, hops, and a little of the roasted malt. Little bit of an alcohol bite at the end.
Nice red/golden color on the pour and the aroma is fantastic. I would not call it a piney taste... I would say its more like drinking cold, smooth pine sap.

Pours reddish with soft head. Aroma is bready, caramel, hops. Taste has nice caramel and booze flavor, with a hop bitter finish. A complex and strong beer. Very nice, but not for the Coors Light drinker!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
My go to in a bar if I cant decide. A little bread and roasted malt aroma with a sweet malt and  deep hop taste. Medium body.
Dark beer with a beautiful tinted head. Aromas of cereal and grass, leather. It has a nice weight on the palate and the sweet roasted malts and rich hop flavors actually work really well together.

Huge fat lasting lacy head. Wonderfully huge malty caramel nose with pronounced grassy piny overtones. Huge thickness leads pretty quickly to the hops which hit way over and before the malts. The finish is very long and piny with rich bitterness. 

---That dog will hunt!

Had this on draft at Emersons Ale House. Served in a pint glass.

A: Pours a deep purple color with some dark ruby edges where the light catches it. Very thin off white had that subsided to some little resting wisps and a thin collar that leaves some splotchy lace behind.

S: Some citrus fruit smells, mostly light grapefruit. A caramel malt presence with a light grassy hop undertone rounds it out.

T: A toasted malt body with a slight sweet caramel makes up the body of this beer. There are nice citrus grapefruit and grassy-like hop undertones that brings the beer together. Slight bitterness on the finish. Very good.

M: Full bodied with good carbonation and a bready malt aftertaste. Very drinkable.

O: The oaked version is much better in terms of the complexity the barrel adds, but this is right up there with that version and it is just as drinkable.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 12-11-2011
Sweet and tart citrus aroma. Orange amber with off white head that dissipates quickly. Lots of grapefruit hops and not much else.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2015 Pours an excellent deep amber with lasting beige head and great lacing.   Aroma is caramel, toffee, slight chocolate, earthy, woody.  Taste is sweet at first, quickly turning bitter, drying out to bring crispness and a lightly roasted, piney resin.  Good stuff all around.  +1 appearance, -1 overall.
Complex and smooth, with a piney aroma and a hoppy bite thats a little roasty.  An enjoyable, lingering bitter finish.  Very good.  8+4+8+5+17=4.2 (10/7/12)

Poured vigorously from a 22oz bottle into a Spiegelau tulip glass forming a thick sustained off-white bubbly head. 

Aroma is slightly floral hops with hints of pine and a roasty malt. Color is a deep clear  amber lightening to a burnt orange around the edges. Head is all but gone at this point and lacing is non-existent. 

Taste is slightly bitter with some malt finish - comparable to some medium English ales. Light carbonation that leads to a bitter finish that doesnt linger. 

Overall, very smooth for a 7.2% alc, but lacking a memorable note that would drive me to buy another bottle.
Bottle from BrewDog Glasgow. Dark brown colour, decent foamy head. Big sweet pine toffee malt aroma & flavour. Bitter sweet aftertaste. Good but not great.

Aroma: A smell of fresh brown bread, eggs, milk chocolate.Appearance: A clear brown ale with ruby nuances, a warm tan head with good lacing and good curtains.Taste: Starting sweet caramel and toffee, muffin batter, brown bread, chocolate, sherry and raisins.Palate: Little carbonation, soft and sticky, a huge body with a smooth sessionable dry finish.Overall: Nice, balanced, a great beer.Note: Bottle 650 ml (KM) Reviewed 2012-04-21.

Bomber bottle poured clear amber ~ red tinted hue with a frothy tan head mostly lasting. Moderate citrus hop aroma w/ hint of biscuit and caramel. Initial flavor is a mix of the malt sweetness matched with bold hop flavor, finishes dry. Medium to full bodied, lively carbonation. A fully hopped ale with a creamy texture and a long lasting bite.
Not for everyone as the bottle more eloquently states.  Full hoppy flavor, my go to beer.

Well just bought this from Trembling Madness in York and couldnt wait to get home and try this one. I am a Stone virgin as I have found it hard to get hold of it in the UK. This is an aggressive beer not for the feint hearted. I love it what more can I say.

Pours a chestnut brown with a tan head. Aroma is caramel, dried fruit, syrup, nuts. Full bodied with a sweet body, and a lingering bitter finish. The alcohol comes out a bit at the end as well as a dried fruity type sweetness that cuts in to the bitterness. Quite nice.

Piney hop aromas on the nose, along with some hints of caramel. Nice maltiness cuts down on the citrus/resin hop bitterness, very drinkable. The bitter finish lingers for a while, I enjoy it quite a bit. Definitely one of my go-to beers.

I found Self Righteous at Burgers and Brews as a sampler and I told my boss about how good it was and he told me to try Arrogant Bastard.  So I found that one at Total Wine on Arden and that one took me to where I wanted to be.  So I think I found my brew.  Thank you for coming out with this one.  Its all me!  Thank you Stone Brewerys I live in Sacramento and am making plans to see the brewery soon

Beautiful looking beer- dark amber with a thick, creamy, long lasting head.
Medium bodied, bitter to the finish. Nice!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Deep ruby chestnut with a frothy head fills my glass.  The predominant aroma is bready caramel malt (Victory?), with subdued hints of grassy/earthy hops.  The arrogance appears in the first sip with a hit of resiny bitterness that settles into a harmony of balanced flavors: to burnt toast, chocolate, caramel, and an under tone of citrussy hops that remind me of orange/grapefruit rind.  Big body, and a bitterness that is very noticeable but in no way unpleasant.  Finish is smooth and bitter with lingering flavors of burnt toast and grapefruit rind.  This would pair insanely well with some Arrogantly sharp cheese: aged gouda or cheddar.

Enjoy by: 09-03-12. Uh oh, its a week past that. 97 days old!

A - Dark brown almost red body with a frothy one finger light tan head. Decent lacing and retention. 

S - Piney and citrusy hops with a large sweetened caramel malt backbone. Basic but inviting. 

T - Again, a nice balance of citrus and pine hops with a dominant bready caramel malt backbone. Great balance of flavors and quite drinkable. Mouth feel is medium bodied, almost creamy, with great carbonation.

O - Not groundbreaking. All the marketing (Youre not worthy!) aside, its somewhat of a staple to the craft beer world. Kind of a stepping stone past SNPA and Boston Lager. Its a damn tasty hopped up beer with a great malt backbone and it doesnt have to be super fresh to be enjoyed either. Ive always been a fan of this beer and will continue to pick up a bomber from time to time.

Bottle, bomber sized. Birthday beer.. happy birthday to me!!! This is awesome. It pours out nothing like Im used for American styled beers. Clear, dark amber colour with a firm, off white two finger head that last very long. Aroma has roasted barley, some chocolate and toffee notes, as well as a hoppy undertone, full of resin and citric fruits. Flavour is medium bitter, tough the bitterness lingers on for quite a bit, making the one hell of a sipper. Flavour ends with a sweet, malty touch for a split second, only to get back into being bitter. Like I said, this is awesome!!

Long time lurker, first review.  Starting with the beer that got me started on craft brews.  Delightful; stands the test of time.  Deep reddish brown, clear pour with a persistent tan head and nice lacing.  Caramel malt over bitter hops produces a pleasant, persistent soapy twist on the back of the tongue.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

S: Great, like a light barley wine in its way - lots of toasted caramel and toffee, pine/spruce/resin hops and a touch of alcohol, yeast clearly present too
A: Beautiful dark ruby red - almost brown.  Full foamy cream colored head
T: Bitter and malty - heavy toasted caramel and the pine, spruce, and resin hop character comes through really well.  
P: Medium to full bodied, fizzy carbonation.  Finishes well leaving a taste in your mouth for a while 
O: This a consistently solid brew at a great price.  When I start raking in the cash there is no doubt that ABA will fill my fridge at all times.  I can only imagine how good double bastard, oaked and bourbon aged are.

This seems to be one of the staples for craft beer. P: Brown reddish hazy color with a white head. Taste of both hops and big caramel malt. It has the piney and herbal hops, some with a strong caramel backbone and hinnts of chocolate. The taste seems to stick there awhile and of course this is bitter. Didnt enjoy this one as much as I used to but it is still a solid brew.

Bottle. Thick reddish mahogny, hazy. Super caramel malts, resinous, piney. Body is full, thickish, full of munich malty roasted tones. Soft mouthfeel. Good backing bitterness. Excellent, flavorful ale.-- bb/h
Poured from bottle dark brown ans off white head. Aroma with caramel malts and some chocolate flavors. Little bitter finish.

Appearance was reddish brown with lasting creamy tannish 2 finger head, lacing throughout.  Aromas are sweet caramel malts upfront with pine, citrus fruit and resinous hops. Taste are hoppy resin, lemon, orange, pine with a sweet matly backbone. Palate was creamy smooth CO2 with meduim body, then hoppy resinous citrusy long balanced finish.  Goooooddddd...

Ahhhh ABA. One of a kind, never duplicated. If you haven't had one, get one, sack up, and try it. Solid brew to never disappoint.

Stone does not know how to make a bad beer, with that said, no description necessary. It you havent had ABA yet your missing out.

An all-time classic, and one of the first craft beers that got me started. Deep reddish brown, with soapy foam head. Rich malt bite with some alc coming through. Very tasty, it has been eclipsed by some beers in my past, but Ill always have a soft spot for this.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2013 Draft at Bull Run Tap House. Pours dark brown with a lot of khaki foam that leaves a lot of lacing. Notes of pine and grass on the nose. Lots of bitterness on the finish but hey the beer is called "Arrogant Bastard".

Reddish pour. Thick foamy head. GRainy and earthy. Some sweet caramel. Bitter yet soft. Each sip is a bit different. Very well made

The strong bitter flavor hits you hard on the first sip and it is hard to taste much else. If you keep drinking though you pick up on some more subtle tastes of virus and caramel. The taste sticks with you for quite a while.

Bouteille 22 oz achetée chez IGA de Potsdam. Couleur brune rougeâtre foncée, mousse beige. Arôme de caramel et houblons...malt. En bouche, malt caramel et houblon. Finale de caramel brulé et amertume. Amertume persistante qui sallonge. Excellente.

Aroma: A deep rich bouquet of hey, oats, Grain grain hops reminiscent of artisan bakeries, Farms and of course fantastic breweries/

Appearance: Deep dark amber tinges of red and orange when held to light, long lasting tan head

Taste: Fantastic and classic, nothing fancy our out of the ordinary just straight craftsmanship. How all ale should taste.

Plate: Moderate in all regards, nicely balanced

Overall: Fantastic balance, a definite essay on what good beer is only drank as opposed to read.

It is smoth and easy to drink with a great aroma looks smokey but not over dark, very palate able the blend of hops and herbs was done with great care and skill cootoes to the brew master very good job.

Location/Date:Bottle on August 10th, 2012.
Appearance: Pours dark orange brown. 
Aroma: Aroma is heavy on caramel malt.
Taste: Medium high bitterness, caramel malt.
Palate:Medium body, lingering aftertaste.
Summary: Aggressive and enjoyable brew!

Tap. Pours dark brown with an amber tint and average, fizzy off-white head; decent retention and lacing. Aroma is roast and caramel malt, earthy hops, figs, dates, and light spice. Flavor is roast and sweet malt forward, good supporting hops (medium bitterness), and faint fruit esters; dry, hoppy finish with faint smoke. Medium body, carbonation, and warmth.
Dark brown color in the glass with a small head. It has malts and a woodsy leather aroma. Taste is big with malts and earthy notes. Long bitter finish.
Bottle. Om nom. Nom nom nom. this was awesome. NIce and strong, dark, roasted, and bitter (a little too bitter as it warmed up).
Color of fine mahogany.  Aroma of caramel malt with chocolates.  Tastes of thick coffee and caramel.  Close to perfect.  Favorite.

Dark beer with a beautiful tinted head.  Aromas of cereal and grass, leather.  It has a nice weight on the palate and the sweet roasted malts and rich hop flavors actually work really well together, neither really seeming like it is fighting for the top spot but both very prominent.  Finishes kind of yeasty but lasts nice and long.  The lacing on the glass will still be there tomorrow.  Definite buy.
Definitely lives up to its claim. Big and heavy, unapologetic alcohol. Malty but quite bitter.

Bomber. Pours a deep amber, almost brownish, with nice slightly off white head. Aroma is citrusy and hops. Taste is more of the same. Nice slight malt character with aggressive citrusy, floral hops. Bravo Stone!!

Brownish red pour with head that is brown and goes away quick. Syrup 
Maple and brown sugar smell (is that possible?). Great taste like not many beers I have had.  Mild hops bitterness and malts. Smooth. Great beer overall

Monster brew! Sunburst rootbeer color, caremel hops citrus mose, faint nose for me. Taste is a tinge bitter on the tail but flavor is maybe too complex at this Point of the game for me. Amazing beer forsure! Smooth and delicious ;)
Very similar to the black ipa which tastes like a mix between a spot and an ipa. Good beer
This is heavy beer, and a good one.  Lots of caramel malts and some chocolate flavors and its one tasty brew!

On tap at Stone, this pours a nice brown with a khaki foam. Aroma is typical piney and citrus hop character but has a nice malt underlay. Flavor of toasted malts and caramel with medium body. Hops show themselves again in the finish leaving some residual bitterness. Pretty interesting.

Pours dark amber brown with a nice head. Nose is malt and chocolate, smells like a stout. Taste is malty, with caramel and chocolate, again tastes
more like a light stout. Full of taste with a nice sweet finish. Quaff Score 8 / 10

Pours a dark red with a beige head and aroma of fruits and malt. Taste is complex, of caramel, fruits, malt, and finishing hops that come together nicely with a long, warming finish. Great tasting, drinkable, and balanced brew from Stone.

It has a good Full body flavor.  The malt gives a caramel taste with the hop aftertaste which is delicious.

On draft at Primantis, Mt. Lebanon. Poured dark mahogany with khaki head. Big and malty with dark fruits, resinous pine, and citrus. Full bodied and complex.

Many brewers talk smack to their consumers...and then there is Stone. Unfortunately, the not worth bit only make me think of Waynes World. It starts with a resinous, pine tarred IPA, though one can feel some malts struggling beneath. Nearly crimson color with tan head. Surprisingly, the flavor is toasted, dirty, and malty. Mind you, it still packs maybe 60 BUs. Rival Lagunitas makes a beer like this, but less extreme so I cant remember the name right now. The balance of this beer give it a chalky, grinding palate feel that does not let up. This beer is as cocky as Lebron at a midget convention. Oddly, I dont hate it.

750 ml bottle. Pours an orange brown with a short-lasting white head. Tastes very malty, cereals, and milk chocolate. Very sharp, hoppy finish. Earthy mouthfeel. Watery. Very good, tasty beer. Never had one quite like it before.

Bottle. Dark brown color. Small tan head. Rich aroma of candy and estery hops. Malty nutty base to the nose as well. Flavors of brandy and nutty malts mixed with dark fruits, but the hop structure surfaces with a kick of bitterness to the palate. Not my favorite beer style, but I really appreciate what they did to give this beer some strong body, and above all, balance.

This really is a great beer, not too hoppy, not too malty, bang in the middle. great balance. never had a young bottle of this due to it coming slowly across the pond, its meant to be better then, if so i cant imagine by how much. really great beer.

Beautiful ruby pour with thick white head. Aroma is potent, can smell the hops right up front. Palates well, smooth with a malt nose and dry bitter finish. One of the better beers I've had

Pours a deep amber with a thick off white head. Aroma is nice and malty with some spice and then the hop character comes through as well. Flavor is rich and full bodied with a hop bitterness, there is some astringency and alcohol, the malt has some roasty notes as well that adds some complexity. Overall I was thinking this beer was gonna be more than what it was but it is sill not a bad representation of an American strong ale.
Malty flavor. Clear ruby red pour with white head.  Dry finish.  Not real hoppy but some bitter bite.  Overall, just real solid, well blended.
Huge fan of this beer. Would have rated it higher but I love the Oaked Arrogant Bastard better.

Pours a ruby brown with a medium, creamy, tan head and some lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, caramel, and hops. Flavor is toasty malt, nuts, caramel, licorice, and light, earthy hops. Medium body with low to medium carbonation. Superb brew.

so I guess I should say I love stone brewing to begin with arrogant bastard was 1 that the first time I tried it I didnt like it when I tried it again and it is hands down 1 of my favorite beers I would not put ruination nor the 10th anniversary ruination below this but if you  are looking for a good beer to try just do it

Reddish-brown pour with a nice tan head. Aroma is light fruit, nuts, sweet. Its assertive, not aggressive - nicely balanced hops with a little sweetness. Flavors of malt, hops, some nuts. Nice long bitter finish.
I may lack taste and sophistication but I still like this beer.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2012 Hmmm.......smooth, but bitter.  On tap at Blue 5.  Previously avoided this beer.....now im confused as to why!....It?s 2nd to Ruination.....but a decent brew.  Hail Stone!
This was is not as good as ST 2XIPA. Less of a strong character IPA than I like. Wouldnt get it again if 2x is there.
Draught: Reddish, brown color, off white creamy head. Flavor is full of hop, intensive notes of resin, herbal, aroma and bitter hops.
Bomber to pint (from notes).  Looks good; copper with decent head and carbonation.  Smells and tastes of a balance of malt and hops (in that order).  Good on the palate.  Good beer.
Aroma is malty with a perfect head. Taste is somewhat toasty with dark crystal flavors, over all I would say this is a perfect beer. Balanced!

1 Pt. 6 Fl. Oz. bottle from Citys Choice, San Francisco, CA,. Pours a gorgeous dark ruby-crimson color crowned by a fine white foam that sticks to the sides of the glass. Aroma is strong and well-balanced between agressive hops and intense liquorish malts. There are notes of wood, nuts, caramel and liquor mixed with piney and grapefruity scents in a wonderful manner. Taste is intense and explosive with the bitter hoppy flavors trying to outshine the sweet hints from the caramel malts. Rounded and with a decided alcoholic punch. Its an arrogant bastard... it wouldnt want to hide it. Full bodied. The finish has a slight burn sensation. Long nutty aftertaste. A sipper. I waited years to try this Ale and this trip to San Francisco allowed me to do so.
Nice dark brown poor, nice coast of foam, good hops smell, nice taste similar to the smell, good on any occasion

Intriguing aroma and deep brown pour leads to a bold but smooth taste and satisfying mouthfeel.

This is a pretty good beer. You are worthy. It has a solid mouthfeel. Some malts but notably stronger hops (than its Oaked cousin). There is a bit of a bitter finish

Pours nicely dark brown. Initial hint of spiced malt gives way to hops just a touch brighter than I prefer. Hilarious text on bottle.

One of my favourite beers. Dark brown pour, perfect proportion of sweetness with a great long finish. Good for a winter day and even refreshing with bbq on a hot summer day.

Bottle from Kroger. Hop nose and light mouthfeel. Hip burst balanced by some sweet undertones. Good beer with some steak I think. Hearty and full
Bodied.

Just an outstanding beer.  Hoppy, with very sophisticated and complex flavors beneath.

On of my all time favorites, and one of the best out there. Pours a dark copper, with two fingers of healthy off white head. Aroma is malty caramel, piney and citrus hops. Perfect mouthfeel. Incredible balance between aggressive bitterness and malt. Lingering bitter malty flavor. Love this beer.

Pours silky brown. Roasted cereal, brown sugar and nutty malt flavor. Tastes progress throughout the beer. Agree with their assessment that this is an aggressive beer. One of the best American ales Ive had.
Excellent ale. Glad to see more restaurants carry this awesome beer. A dark amber beer with a pine bitter flavor and a bold after taste.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2013 Pours a dark amber with a dirty head.  Looks like it will tast like an amber, but instead a wonderful and powerful hoppiness attacks the palate.  Not as much aroma as I would have thought, but nice caramel notes without the attendant burnt malt flavor that usually accompanies caramel malts.   Hints of pine and citrus.  Full bodied.  A great beer.

Update, 4/11/13: Just bought another 22oz. bottle, and this is a VERY different beer - not dark amber, but almost as dark as a porter.  And strong notes of a toasty malt.  Although the bitterness is still there, this bottle of AB is MUCH darker than any other I have had.  Must have been a bad batch.  I would rate this as a 3.0 overall,

Great representation of an American Craft beer.  Pours very dark amber with a large dark tan head.  Aroma of caramel, pine and citrus. Taste is caramel, pine and some fruit sweetness. Full bodied with some nice complex flavor. Thick feel, average carbonation, long finish. This beer never disappoints me. Great "go to" beer.

Bomber, poured in a shaker.  Pours a deep, dark amber color with some definite ruby-red shining through.  Small bubbles race up to a large, frothy head of about 3cm of beige.  The head lingers and leaves thick lacing on the glass; a thin film of head remains throughout and leaves a ring to the bottom of the glass.  I love the nose of this beer.  The hops are by far the dominant force with bright citrusy smells of grapefruit and maybe a touch of orange along with resiny pine.  There right behind it, is a backbone of caramel malt, very sweet and definitely very present.  I loved taking deep wafts of this one.  The taste was hops forward; more citrus and pine note, like on the nose, and blooming on your palate.  As the hops develop, there is a good balance with the sweet malts that keep the hops ever so slightly in check.  The mouthfeel is almost creamy, but not quite, maybe a touch oily with a long bitter finish.  Overall, I have had this beer (along with many others) before I found this site, so I waited till I got it again to give it justice.  I think I had it before I had really developed my palate, because I had not remembered this one as good as I found it today.  I think it is another example of a beer that makes use of very aggressive hops with good balance with the malt.  Very tasty and I will buy it everytime I see it.

To me this generally sets the standard for a solid, hoppy ale. Foamy, fluffy head, with a feint yet distinct pine aroma. Warm, rounded mouth feel; bitter, hoppy, yet balanced flavor. Though I have to admit, Ive been to the brewery a few times, so Im a little biased in favor of Stone.

Bottle from Good Beer NYC.  Pours a clear, deep copper hue with a thick light tan head; solid lacing around the glass.  Aroma struck me as quite unique; picking up the bready, nutty, and caramel tones as in an English brown ale, interlaced with resinous and earthy hops.  Flavor is a very balanced mingling of the malts and hops, with a pleasant bitter finish.  Moderate carbonation lends a smooth mouth feel and surprising drinkability.  Glad I brought this one across the border!

Bomber poured into Stone Arrogant Bastard tumbler!  Pours a gorgeous copper/red with a finger-high beige head.  Aroma is of caramel/cereal malt with a bit of resinous hops.  Taste is a balanced bittersweet, blending brown ale, pale ale, and IPA all at the same time...!  Well alas, thats what I perceive.  Body is medium, texture is creamy-slick, and carbonation is pretty soft.  Medium-low bitter finish which is relatively long, but nothing compared to the Ruination IPA for example.  Overall an excellent beer.  Stone never has deceived me.  This is the second Bastard Ive had and the experience remains consistent.  It really sucks that we dont have this in Canada.  Damn you Canada liquor boards.  Damn you SAQ!

Was not expeting the aroma on this one. Smelled very strongly of caramel and toffee, with a slight hint of bitterness, perhaps some citrus tones.  Appearance was darker than i expected, almost like a brown ale, about a finger of head.  Taste was good, just not what i was expecting.  Didnt think it was that "agressive".  Had some bourbon flavors, and maybe some hints of oak.  Not that bitter to me, maybe my bottle was a bit old.

Love this stuff!   Pours dark, has a tan head.  Just the right bitterness.  Almost a coffee-caramel taste to it to me.  Pours nice & thick in the glass!  Laces the glass nicely.  Bought a growler of this, I always need to taste beer on tap over packaged.   Definitely getting this again soon!

Draft. Pours very dark brown with a foamy tan head. Big dark caramel malt flavors. Burned hops. Dark plums. Tastes like a great mix of a strong brown ale balanced with a black IPA. Draft has a creamier feel than the bottle. Good stuff. Like a burned campfire marshmallow.
One of the greatest beers Ive ever tasted. Bitter and strong, the Bastard is thick and rich. Some of my fondest memories involve this beer.
Spicy smell, alcohol not very well masked despite the strong malts.  Tasted on tap at Brooklyn Waterfront Beer Festival, 6/16/2012.

Pours a dark brown with a nice lasting tan head. Citru hops fills the nose. The taste is hoppy- hints of grapefruit- with a strong astrigent aftertaste. The mouthfeel is light-medium with a crisp hit of carbination. Very tasty on a hot Texas afternoon. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours an opalescent amber with a thick, rocky head. Stunning lacing. Delicate hoppy scent, accompanied by shoe leather and vanilla. Brilliant catty flavor, with overtones of bubblegum and sour milk. Hearty yet effervescent mouthfeel and hoppy finish.

Probably not the best way to put it but if you want the best of a regular/normal american beer this is what you want. Big bold quasi-IPA taste. Lacks anything stand out "interesting" but a great solid beer thats far under-priced.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2015 650 ml bottle. Pours a red/brown with little head. 

 Aromas of caramel and roasted malt with a hint of citrus. Flavors of toffee and orange. Definite Beligian influence. Somewhat creamy. Well balanced.

Bottle. Pours amber thin head. Aroma is floral, dark fruits, pine. Mild sweet flavor. Medium body, ave. carbonation, great balance of bitter and malt. Not quite as good as the Oaked version but excellent overall.
Chinook bomb coming to your pallete! Always a great craft beer go to, another great offering from the Stone brewery!

Pours a deep mahogany color with a frothy three finger off white head that sticks to the glass. Aromas are piney, floral with touches of dark malts, citrus and grapefruit. On the palate its a big beer for sure.  Robust beer with ripe hop flavors of earthy cedar, floral, and grapefruit.  To balance the hops there is a deep burnt caramel background that iingers nicely with rich bitterness in the finish.

Great, easily accessible beer. Perfect for some reluctant to only buy one bottle. Clear amberish pour with solid amount of head. Interesting aroma of hops, lemongrass, and caramel malts. Taste follows as a big red ale with a lot of complexity. Floral notes upfront that get overtaken by toffee or caramel sweetness. Some bitterness and dryness at the end. Good mouthfeel, very drinkable for a big beer.

Pours a dark amber...reddish with a thin, quickly vanishing tan head. Aroma is strongly hoppy, a bit of dark fruit. Taste is even More hoppy, strongly bitter, piney, earthy.... More alcohol creeps up as it warms, plus caramel and spice scents/tastes.. Once the initial assault to your senses is assimilated, it starts to get more and more complex in tones, even some hints of sweetness.... The Logo and Motto pretty much sum it up!
Some solid swill. A great strong ale. Hops are very present and matched with a malty sweetness. Sweet front to a balanced middle with a bitter finish. A new favorite for sure.
toast, citrus, floral, amber, white foam, medium sweetness, very bitter, medium body, creamy, average carbonation, bitter,

Aroma a madera, frutas, vino y alcohol... Todo intensamente..... Final maltoso, Definitivamente perfecto..
A la vista, cerveza de cuerpo medio, carbonatación casi nula, color rubi con tonos rojizos a la luz, corona de espuma ligera y de larga permanencia.
En boca, cremosa, elegante y bien estructurada, con ligeras notas de amargor.
Al paladar, simplemente extraordinaria. Un sabor increible y único. La cremosidad sede completamente a un sabor amargo, pero sabroso. Es de un final pronunciado y astringente.
En general, una cerveza completamente diferente, única en su estilo, amarga pero elegante... La cual se debe tomar con respeto...

Arrogant bastard first hit my lips at Tantalum in Long Beach. I fell in love with the strong flavor and bitterness of this beer. Recently tried oaked arrogant bastard and its very good also with a slight oak flavor.  You can find us @ 
www.beerdrinkerunion.com
Really nice basterd will get again awesome. ..................................................
Bottle. Pours golden orange brown with a thin white head and good lacing. The taste is hoppy, but mild, fairly easy drinking with a bitter finish.
A beautifully balanced strong ale.  One of the best made beers in America.  nice strong caramel and nuttiness with a solid floral finish

Smells like a rich creamy blend of raisins, piney hops, grass, bread and slightly sweet. Poured a deep, clear mahogany with a big light tan head. Taste is immediately a sweet raisin taste which is followed by that pine hops that smelled before, nice yeasty taste too. Feels medium to full bodied with a creamy texture and a bitter finish.

Good. The nose is intensely hoppy in the citrus and pine range, but still maintains enough of a toast and caramel malt base to keep the beer balanced. The beer pours out a hazy orange with a disapating white foamy head. The taste is predominantly resin hops with a large contribution of ciitrus flavor in the orange range. The beer is medium to full bodied with a very long bitter finish.
Keg at Euston Tap. 31st May 2012.  Good flavorsome ale, nice bite to it, would have again.

Found an old tasting note:
big brew. delivers on its name. very hoppy, citrus and pine cones. the palate is more of the same. it has a crazy long bitter finish. Ive always been a fan!

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2012 Poured from 22 oz. bottle that was aged for 6 months.  

Hazy, dark mahogany with a large buff head and excellent lacing.  (When fresh, the sister bottle of this beer was clear, not hazy.)

Aroma of pine and floral hops balanced nicely by biscuity malt, sweet dark fruit and a milk chocolate.  (When I tasted the sister bottle of this beer that had not been aged, I had not picked up dark fruit or chocolate aromas.)

Taste of pine, citrus and floral hops with an ample backbone of caramel malt, milk chocolate, toffee and sweet, dark fruit. (When fresh, the sister bottle of this beer had tons of delicious bitter flavor from first sip through finish.  After aging, the bitter hops give way to a slightly sweet, malty finish.  The hops still dominate but have mellowed enough to allow complex malt flavors room to play.  There is also a chocolate malt flavor that I had not noticed when tasting the bottle that had not been aged.)

Medium body and medium carbonation with nice creamy mouthfeel.  ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Another goodie by Stone.  Aroma is floral and malty, if somewhat muted.  Pours mid brown-orange with little fluffy head.  Flavor is nutty, bready/malty, crisp hops, and finishes clean and slurpy-good.  Ive also had the oaked version of this - recall the aroma being more interesting, but taste-wise, Id have to revisit it again.  At any rate, try this one.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2016 Clear, deep red, brown colour and some tan lacing. Aroma has malts, sweet brown sugar and a bit of sourness. Somewhat dry taste, lingering bitter finish. Semi rich body, low carbonation, soft mouthfeel. Well balanced, good strong ale.

Draft in a tulip. A nice deep amber color with good head. The aroma is intense with a lot of malt. The taste is intense as well, but in a good way. Dangerously high in alcohol, but easy to drink. A strong ale to measure others against. Leaves a little bit of a bitter aftertaste is the only downfall. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap.  Pours a darkish brown.  The aroma is of hops.  The taste is hop flavor with mild citrus and pine notes.  The bitterness isnt overpowering.  Good all around.

I got this beer for 3 dollars a pint at the new Bar Louie in Nashville TN.  Haha.  Taste is exceptionally malty with a sturdy hop presence.  The beer is as advertised.   Loads of malts, tons of hops, amber/dark brown in color, and medium to heavy bodied.  This one is a winner.

Pours the color of a quality birch beer soda, with a deep rich reddish brown and a near creamy head.  Hints of coffee, very slight vanilla and well bittered malts.  Nicely built ale without the overwhelming full mouthfeel of other strongs......a well managed medium body with a little sweetness but very crisp.  Nice job.

Aroma is sweet caramel, pine and floral hops, some citrus. Taste is plenty of rich sweet caramel, bitter pine and grapefruit. Maybe some cherry. Slightly thick palate with nice amount of carbonation  Not too complex but very well executed. Plenty of flavor. This beer was fitting to be called an American strong ale.

Pours a nice dark brown on tap with solid tan head and good lacing. Aroma is malty up front, with sweet and roasted notes, and piney on the back end. Taste follows smell, but it ends a little bitter. Clean and well balanced.
Nice example of a very strong American ale, well done Stone...again. Nice job.
Bottle at bar. Dark brown color, beige head. Strong taste with alcohol, caramel. Lingering highly bitter finish. Good brew.

Citrus, caramel, floral, and mild roast.  Reddish brown with tan head, nice lacing.  Citrus, caramel, mild roast flavor.  Well balanced, sessionable, with  mild bitterness.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2013 Bottled Pours clear  mahogany with an average sized beige head with a fair lace. Nose of roasted malt, caramel and citrus fruits and piney notes. Markedly sweet flavor of caramel, grapefruit and again citrus. Medium to full bodied, syrupy texture and soft CO2. Ends up with a nice bitterness. A great one.
★★★★

Tawny red/deep copper pour; thick pillowy off white head.  Hops mixed in the nose with roasted malt.  Butterscotch and malt across the tongue, full bodied without being too heavy, and a sustained attack of flavoring and bittering hops.  The hops are much stronger in the body than the bouquet suggests.  powerful and satisfying brew.

Dark garnet/ruby color clear off white beige rings of sticky lacing ... aroma of caramel malts, subtle earthy hops and faint citrus hops ..... Taste is the same earthy hops, caramel malts, light citrusy hops with a decent citrusy bite..... Very smooth and clean nice spicy hop bite that lingers into the finish ... Mouthfeel is oily ... Sessionable abv hidden well

Dark ruby color with light brown foam lacing to the glass. Smells like wood, initial taste is wood, then changin to some sweet fruit and caramel, then changing to bitter. Bitter taste lasts long. Although I am not worthy according to the text on the bottle I will for sure have this one again. (Houston 201205)
UPDATED: NOV 29, 2014 Solid brew, love the AB, great head and wonderfully beautiful, nice amber hue, small white head, nose and taste are caramel, bitter, hops, coffee.

Tap. Pours brown with slight reddish notes. Medium off-white head with good staying power and lacing. Bitter hoppy aroma, with notes of pine as well as roasted malt and caramel. Nice malty caramel flavor with some floral and piney hops notes. Lightly bitter finish. A full bodied, tasty beer.

One of my all time favorites! Story behind the beer is a good one too that I think gives it a bit more character. Specifically, the ruby red pour combined with the fruity notes and oaky barrel notes make this beer a must try.Bitter and dry notes that settles in the mouth. Great Ale.

Originally reviewed: 11/13/09. Grabbed a bomber of this at my local grocery while getting some ingredients for dinner.

Pours a dirty copper with a HUGE tan head on top. Minimal bubbles rising through. Excellent retention - this looks like a milk shake. Leaves tons of sticky lace and webbing all over the glass. The scent is a little underwhelming. Im trying to get something out of this, but its being quite abstinent. Some mild toffee and strawberry Twizzlers is about all I can grasp. 

The body is a little slick and oily. Carbonation level is moderate. On to the flavor. Mmmm. Hops! Nice bittering hops right away, but not overly so; this is balanced like crazy. Lots of sweet toffee and caramel even the contest. Theres a bit of a charred bread on the finish. Leaves a mildly bitter aftertaste. This is a great strong ale. Why did it take me so long to try this one?!

Pours a deep ruby color with a medium tan head.  Aroma has some bready and fruity malts and nice hoppiness.  Flavor is very bitter and hoppy...earthy almost oaky...light underlying caramel and fruity malts.  Mouthfeel is full and the finish is bitter and dry.

Pours a deep deep red with a tight bubbled khaki head. Nose is big pine and citrus, very hop forward yet a large caramel malt presence persists. Taste is very bitter but more sweet than youd think. Palate is nice, not heavy, with a substantial tingly bitterness. Ill definitely grab one of these again. Id say its close to a barleywine with just the massive amount malt and hops, but at 7.2% its a much easier drinker. Pretty impressive.

Poured from a bottle into a snifter. Nice dark appearance with brown head. Aroma of citrus, pine, hops and notes of caramel. Taste was mostly bitter with some very light sweetness. Not my favorite, but not bad.
Pours a hazy dark brown color and a tan head. Aroma of grapefruit, caramel, toffee, dark fruits, and alcohol. Taste is very similar notes. Medium body.
I had it on tap out of a plastic cup.  I was expecting something great due to the reputation.  However, I got a beer that was simply off putting.

Really? I havent rated this? Oh well....Pours a very clear, deep mahogany color with a bubbly tan head that fades fast. Forefront on the nose I get chewy caramel maltiness with toffee aspects with underlying citrus and pine hops. Main flavor component is chewy, toffee, sweet potato bread malts then mid palate through finish is the bitter pine hops. Maybe I havent tasted this in some time but its coming off way more sweet than I remember.
A lot darker than I was expecting on the pour.  Hop-hoppy aroma and not to resiny on the palate.  Good length of flavours and lacks that dry bitterness big IPAs can have.
Gedronken in moeder lambic in Brussel samen met Dutchdrebus, Benzai en Joes. Kleur is bruin en helder, sterk, bitter, apart, schuim is een beetje bruin

Big hoppy aroma, smelled incredible. Rich dark brown color with a creamy head. Bold hop flavor with a nice bitterness and char- like finish. Full bodied big beer feel. Loved this beer. Had it on draft at BJs in Orlando, FL. Easily a new favorite

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2013 Tap @ Millers Ale House, Town Square, Las Vegas 18/04/2012. Pours a very dark amber with a large, dark tan head. Aroma is caramel, pine and pith. Taste is much of the same, begins with the pith and caramel with the pine and pith slowly taking over and caramel being in the background. Fortunately not stuffy, especially when it gets warmer it gets even better. It was served ice cold of course. Palate is quite full, stingy, lots of carbonation.

This beer is indeed aggressive. Once you tie one on its kewl. 

22 from tjs

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

May 2010: My third and final beer at Pour 24 (New York, New York), Las Vegas.

I did say Id never have this again after my bottle review, but seeing it on-tap I thought Id do the decent thing and give it another go.

Looked like the bottle version, ruby red and with an off-white head, thin covering and very little lacing.

The smell was sweetish caramel, malts and a splattering of hops.

Still not a huge fan, the flavours dont blend too well in my opinion, the hops dont like the malts and vice versa.

Glad Ive had it from a tap and it is still the only Strong American Ale Ive reviewed so far. For what its worth: heres my bottle versions write-up from Nov 2009: .
The pint and 6Fl Oz bottle, came to me via Prague, thanks Fred, you know who you are!

Poured into a huge Judas glass and a palm tulip glass, didnt know what to expect, hence the two glasses ready.

A dull ruby red body that had a slight haze to it filled the glasses, a creamy tan coloured head sat on top of each glass, foamy and thick.

Waves of hops and yeast aromas hit my nose, nothing else could get through the strenght of those two ingediants.

The bitterness in the taste from the hops was too much for my wife, I just found it a little overpowering and hid whatever other flavours might have been present.

Glad Ive tried one, will not be bothering with another, it reminded me of a flat Belgian beer I had a few years ago, didnt like that much either!
BOTTLE: Pour is ruby/amber with a tan head and decent lacing. Aroma of caramel, malt, citrus and some pine hops. Taste is caramel, grapefruit, sweet, and bitter at the same time.

Consumed on 4/15/12 - best before 5/22/12 - standard pint glass.Aroma is grapefruit and plenty of it.. The beer is a clear amber color - off white head - sheet of lacing. the taste has great balance, so good. The beer is medium bodied with a silky smooth feel. Overall - fantastic beer!
Bottle: Clear deep red colour,, almost no head. Aroma is dominated of caramelly, sirup, alcy ,sugar. Flavor: Caramelly, sugar, brown sugar mixed caramelly medium finish. Medium body. Werry nice!
