Bottle from brewdog nottingham. Tasty. Very malty and that delightful stone taste. Lovely.

Appearance: crystal clear dark red in color, minimal head
Aroma: Smells of grapefruit and caramel
Taste: leads off with intense bitterness that subsides into a pretty malty boozy finish
Overall: Great strong ale. Think my last arrogant bastard was older as this one has a much more prominent bitterness to it.
This ruined my palate! Such a strong beer! Had to try it at least once, now I cant taste any other beer! Good for a person who can handle a really heavy beer!
Bottle with SED and KMD. Clear ruby colour with a frothy head. Aroma is gentler than I expected, light winter berry. Flavour is even fruit hop, medium bitter.

Bottle. Dark red amber pour. Hops, of course, provide an exceptionally bitter taste from beginning through finish. Malt, rotten light fruits, some roast, some sweetness, citrus. Medium-low carbonation, bitterness gives the palate something to work with, texture is sticky after initial roughness. Need to have it chilled. This is the beer I think of when I think of American Strong Ales.

A brief write-up, I had this one twice, the first time, it was served bone cold, and while it was a touch too boozy, it had a great sweetness combined with a strong bitter kick (cant call it balanced, so maybe schizophrenic is the right term?) The second time, it was served a little warmer, and I didnt like it - far too hard to drink, one note, and generically bitter. Ill give this benefit of the doubt anyways, and still give it another chance due to it being relatively inexpensive. (first try 4.22, second try 2.7)

Very strong, dry, bitter and malty. It announces itself right out of the bottle, with a deep, bronze body and an aroma that hits you a mile away. Then the taste really clobbers you. Strong, bitter hops throughout, and rich malt. Tones of citrus and rye.  Its rare that I find something this dry that I think tastes delicious, but Arrogant Bastard delivers.
Aroma and taste of sweet caramel malt and alcohol ..... too much sweet caramel malt and alcohol .... do not like this!

Biscuit aroma with mild bitterness. Taste is initially more malty, biscuit, caramel sweetness which is quickly following into a dry, mineral, bitterness although the chewy malt continues to provide a potent backbone. Perhaps not worthy of the arrogance but a nice brew nonetheless.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2012 The first time I had this beer, maybe 5-6 years ago, I was not worthy.  It was the most bitter, least appetizing beer I had ever had.  Fast forward to today and after trying a sip, my first thought was "caramelly, fairly sweet!"  The bitterness wipes that away and it ends up a touch dry, but a great beer to sip and enjoy.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2012 Ruby in color. Strong aroma of cherry. Head is quite visible, not that much though, but very good lacing. Taste is really strong-- a strong combination woody nutty and a very very dominating roasted smoked taste with a few hints of caramel. Too much hype on this beer.
UPDATED: MAY 13, 2016 Somehow I managed to forget to rate this one. I have had it several times. Just a great hoppy beer with a lot of malt depth but not too sweet for the abv.

Pours a dark brown color with a cream color head. Smell is of sweet malts, toffee, and gapefruit. Alcohol is evident on the nose as well. Taste is dark fruits, toffee, and finishes grapefruit and citrus hops. Medium bodied.

Purchased a growler through Craft Beer Exchange. Pour was a dark amber with a thick tan head. Aroma had strong citrus notes with hints of the high alcohol content. Cant comment to much on the taste because my palate was overwhelmed very quickly by the bitter finish. Like chewing on a grapefruit rind. My palate could not detect any other taste once the initial aftertaste set in. Not sure what all the hype is about; Ive had much better.

Flaske: Lige ovenpå bitter monk falder denne øl lidt igennem. Samtidig er den heller ikke frisk. Mørk orange øl med et fint skumhoed. Duft af stone, hvilket er mere og mere tydeligt efterhånden som de 4 stone øl bliver drukket i løbet af aftenen. Smagen er godt balanceret med en god bitterhed. Helt sikkert en rigtig god øl hvis humlen er frisk.
Darker pour with a decent head, its got a bit of a bite that lingers for a while. A nice slightly hoppy beer.

22 ounce bottle into tulip glass, best by 2/28/2012.  Pours slightly hazy brick red color with a nice 2 finger dense dark cream colored head with fantastic retention that reduces to a nice cap that lasts.  Some nice spotty lacing on the glass.  Aromas of big caramel, pine, toasted grain, biscuit, grapefruit, light chocolate, herbal, and a touch of dark fruit.  Fantastic aromas here with great balance.  Taste of big caramel, biscuit, pine, grapefruit, light chocolate, toasted malt, herbal hops, and some dark fruit.  Nice amount of bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, biscuit, toasted malt, pine, chocolate, and citrus on the finish for a good bit.  Fantastic flavor balance with the bitterness.  Medium carbonation and body; with a nice creamy and slightly slick mouthfeel.  Very smooth and easy to drink, but is still a bit of a sipper.  Alcohol is very well hidden; with hardly any warming noticed on the finish.  Overall this is a fantastic brew from Stone.  I have not had this in a while, but it impressed me much more this time around.  Excellent balance; with nice flavor complexity.

Well Ive had this beer several times now, but this is the first time ive had such a good experience that Ive been able to rate it. Great big resinous hoppy aroma and flavor.  Lots of caramel for balance, but overall just a big hoppy bottle of goodness.  Syrupy, but in a good way.  This beer really put me off when I first started drinking good beer, but now, I think im arrogant enough to enjoy it properly.

Pours a dark amber...reddish with a thin, quickly vanishing  tan head.
Aroma is strongly hoppy, a bit of dark fruit.
Taste is even More hoppy, strongly bitter, piney, earthy....
More alcohol creeps up as it warms, plus caramel and spice scents/tastes..
Once the initial assault to your senses is assimilated, it starts to get more and more complex in tones, even some hints of sweetness....
The Logo and Motto pretty much sum it up!

#1381 bottle; Nose is raisins, rotten fruit, gum, some velvet alcohol, mediummellow roasted malt, decent mold, feel is watery, carb is low, taste is sweet malt, rotten fruit, little leaves, some late sweet menthol

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours clear crimson/dark amber with small beige head that dissapates quickly.  Little lacing, thick body, resinous texture, medium carbonation, and nice aromatic hops.  Taste is caramel malt, some sour grapefruit, some pine, and finishes bitter hops.  I would call this an imperial red ale, not a fan of the pine, but still pretty good.

Reddish brown with a slight off-white head that hangs around for awhile and leaves a good deal of lacing. The aroma is heavy on the piney hops and the caramel malt. The flavor is very hoppy and high in alcohol.

Dark copper color with a rusty head. Rich malt scent which is enhanced with the presence of beautiful citrous hops. Taste is sweet caramel and bread with a slight roast characterstic, plus a powerful hop bite of brite citrus grapefruit and lemon. Very nicely balanced.

pours dark amber with light brown medium head
aromas of fudge, bread, caramel malts and some tropical fruits
bruned brown sugar in taste. palate is a bit mild, but the burnyness stays in the mouth. quite sweet flavours mixed with some bitterness
Good. Ale i would have to say its a strong ale? Maybe idk its good has the dark characterictics.. good beer
Tap - good size thick head, medium amber color, nice high malt/high hop balance - I prefer the "Oaked" version, but this regular version is still awfully good

Tap. Pours a reddish brown with tan head (at least in the dim bar lighting). Aroma of sweet malts, licorice, candied fruit, and citrus hops. Flavor has plenty of hop bitterness and has a clean finish. Not bad.
Dark amber with a tan head. Lightly hop scented and light carbination. Very hoppy beer with good bitterness. Tastes of toffee and caramel, burnt toast, little bit of licorice. Full bodied.

22 oz. bomber, 15 March, 2012 and on draft a few times. Nose is nice, bready malt with low amounts of citrus and pine hops. Subtle. Color reddish brown. Very good retention with lace in the snifter. Caramel malt up front of the sip leading into a citrus, grassy and weak pine hop near the backend. Fresh bottles and on draft I get large amounts of bitterness though-out. Decent lingering bitter finish, lasting long afterwards. ABV is masked real well.  Overall thoughts--- On draught or in a bottle, it is an aggressively hopped beer that really should please any Hop Head or big beer lover. Very well done ale no matter how you dissect it, should NOT disappoint.

bottle at Side bar in west chester.  Pours a golden . straw color with some head . nose is slight citrus with cumquat and lime. first sip is nice balance of pale malt and hoppy. finish is nice with flavors of lemon grass

Hoppy aromas.
Medium body and high complexity
Well integrated powerful and balanced hops

I really enjoyed this great beer!
Dark amber.  Thin head.  Very well balanced.  Malt hides the alcohol content nicely.  This is a real good beer.

poured from bottle, appears amber with foamy head.  aroma is of grass and hops.  good lacing and light carbonation, very bitter, strong hoppiness, earthy and floral notes.  hoppy finish.  very good beer

Poured from a bottle, Japan. Smells of citrusy hops, caramel malt. The appearance is a deep brownish-red, that for my pour almost looked like a black-and-tan. The head was strong and looked rich. Powerful bitterness that scorches the throat and goes down warm. Sour, floral hoppiness. Good beer, maybe a bit overrated.
Dark amber with an off white head. The nose shows orange peel and pine. Full bodied with baking spices, pine resin and grapefruit. Massive hop finish. Great beer.

Tasted at the old mohawk cafe in Columbus, Ohio.  Pours a deep ruby.  Aroma is sweet but understated.  Taste is very malty with hints of brown sugar. A very complex beer, the alcohol does hit you on the finish.  Very good beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark brownish-ruby. Offwhite head is thick at first but settles down after a few sips from the glass. Sweet aromas of cinnamon and caramel. Different taste than I expected after the smell. Hops dominate up front but are quickly rounded out by the sweet maltiness.
I just aint good at all then word usings that most people have. The beer drank pretty good is all.

Ive heard the stories about this one. The aroma punches you right in the face yet, apologizes to you with a thick head, a beautiful light copper color, and vibrant clarity. For a strong Pale Ale its bitterness wasnt what I thought it would be, it was better! One of my new favorites.

Dark brown with a big, thick head. Smells sweet with toasted malts. A little brown sugar. Hoppy upfront with a very nice sweet finish, a lot of spices in there. Mouthfeel is great with very little carbonation, alcohol does linger some though. Good beer.

The beer that initiated my craft beer tasting frenzy...have not gone back to light beer since. Pours red, very heady with bitterness and strength throughout. Stones advertising is inviting... they have the craft beer market down to a T.

Style et résumé: Américain strong ale qui a révolutionné le style. 
Comment: Bouteille de 660ml. 
Description: Bière cuivrée rouge avec une belle mousse beige. Le nez est bien sucré, le malt et très présent. Il y a du sucre dorge par-dessus le marché. La bouche est ronde, sucrée, lalcool est peu présent ce qui est bien. Les saveurs sont profondes avec du bon chocolat. Une amertume non désagréable apparait en fin de bouche. La version copeaux de bois est à mon avis un peu meilleure.  
Note:  8/10

On tap in a tulip.  Pours brownish-copper with a lacy, off-white head.  Aroma strong of piney and citrusy hops, some caramel and bread malts, and a little spiciness.  Flavor strong on the hops.  Thicker texture.  A really good beer.
Aroma of pine resin, malts and slight citrus.  Pours red with a good yeasty head.  Taste is bitter with Sharp pine but a nice malty backbone.  Gulpable yet manly.

The most annoying thing about this beer is its condescending advertising.  A well known brewery dares folks like us to try it and assumes we will prefer heavily-advertised macro lagers instead.  Despite its hype, its a good in-your-face strong ale.  Pours a cloudy brown with medium off-white head and good lacing.  Smells of malts and floral hops.  Aroma is pretty much the same.  Taste is bitter and hoppy.  Medium to full body with a slightly oily texture.   Not as expensive as much of its competition, either.  Well worth a try or three (but not all at once).
22 oz bomber pours amber with a tan head.  Aroma is floral hops and malts.  Taste is much the same.  Nice bitterness, nice beer

Draught at Public House Las Vegas. This one was a big deep copper colour, bronzed and almost red and carried a light tan foam cap,looked great. There was some sweet notes in the aroma and a full on hop flavour, resinous and sticky in the mouth. The hops give you a big whack in the face.

Pours copper-brown, redish. Nice foam becomes thin and persistant. Aromas of toasted caramel, nut, grass and floral hops. Taste medium sweetness, medium-heady bitterness, caramel, nut, alcool at the end. Medium bodied, bitter finish last long. Really good beer.
Appearance is a small brown head with deep amber. Aroma is a sweet yet alcohol malt. Taste is surprisingly hoppy with some sweet caramel. Overall a good blend.

Pours a cloudy dark amber - light brown. Smells sweet with light alcohol notes. Tastes of a robust porter with almost a caramel undertone. The palate feel is a bit dry leaving me with a slight thirst. For the price, this is an excellent beer with a cool name and an even cooler description.

a: dark brown amber, decent 1/2" head that retains well

s: carmel, pine, 

t: sweet malt with a nice hop bitterness underneath provided by pine and grapefruit.

m&d: medium bodied beer, finishes slightly dry
Great ale with excellent color and aroma with in your face flavor. Highly recommend trying it.

Stone Arrogant Bastard has a thick, beige head, a clear, amber appearance, and lots of lacing left behind. The aroma is of hops, sweetness, and syrup. Taste is of medium-roasted barley malt, a high level hop bitterness, syrup, bread, sweetness, and the backwash of ones breath brings in a menthol aspect. Mouthfeel is medium and syrupy, and Stone Arrogant Bastard finishes heavy, sweet, and dry. Overall, this is a most excellent beer. RJT
aroma caramel, bread. looks hazy red brown. caramel sweet expertly balanced with bitter finish and slick mouth coating, a dash of salt. sticky and creamy. enjoyable strong ale!
There isnt a better beer out there. Its why I drink beer. Not for everyone, but those who like it never forget it

Pours a dark, dark reddish brown color with a nice tan head that lasts. There is a dominant spicy smell here along with toasted hops and a sweetness which is not as apparent in the taste, where the toasted flavours dominate a complex flavour scheme that does have that sweet but slightly bitter finish to it.

Nice medium brown amber color. 2 finger head and great lacing. The aroma is hoppy with a rich caramel nutty tone. Dark fruit rings through as well. The flavor is somewhat extreme but well balanced. The strong hop bitterness mixes well with a sweet malty caramel that sticks to your mouth. It is finished by a somewhat strong alcoholic kick. It gets better as you let it settle towards cellar temperatures.  This is a great American Strong Ale.

Bottle. Poured a red color with a tiny white head. Aroma was dark fruit and molasses. Dark fruit was present. Along with a lot of malt. Flavor was a lot of the same with caramel and some alcohol hops. Very good beer.
A very deep amber/red colored beer that forms a decent head. It has an interesting flavor to it. A heavy taste of alcohol however remains in your mouth. Overall I am worthy of it.

Oddly I have had Double Bastard several times, but this is the first for the original. Poured from bomber to snifter. Pours coppery red with a thin off white head. Aroma of spicy and floral hops. Lovely. Flavor is nicely malty at first with a great hoppy finish. Complex and changes as it warms.
Has a nice thick head with tight bubbles, and an aroma that smells coffee like.  The flavor is malty with a bitter end.  Nice and strong.
Bottle. Pours copper with a medium head. Aroma american hops. Lingering oak taste, and not in a good way. Not Bad.

From notes.  First reviewed 12/13/2008.  Poured from a 22 oz. bottle into a pint glass.

Being from Chicago, when I was in San Diego I knew that it was imperative to try out some good local brews, especially from Stone Brewery. I saw this one at a liquor store the first night I was in town, and I read the label:  "This is an aggressive beer. You probably wont like it. It is quite doubtful that you have the taste of sophistication to be able to appreciate an ale of this quality and depth..."  Wow, I would have gotten it based on the name, the gargoyle, or the first line, but this beer is actually daring me to drink it. Ok, I said, lets get a 22 oz bottle and see if I can handle it.

Well, needless to say I was quite impressed. This beer kicks your ass and wonders why you are being such a wuss while taking your beating. 
The color is a deep, dark amber with a thick off-white head that goes absolutely nowhere. As you sip it down the lace reminds you of every level the beer had been at previously. Wow, its hard to make a beer look any better.

Strong hops, a bit of alcohol, strong roasted malt. I definitely smell and advanced bouquet of spices and fruit, with just a floral hint as well. A very complex aroma.

Bam! Arrogant bastard hits you with an assault of roasted malt, bringing a strong flash of caramel at first. The malt also brings forth some chocolate flavors, with just a hint of vanilla as well. Just before the alcohol kicks in, I can taste a bite of cloves, which is a nice touch. From the middle on out, the hops clearly dominate. There is a citrusy fruit taste I cant quite distinguish exactly, but the bitterness is clearly there. Right at the end there is a slight, mild sweetness, with the hops still carrying the flavor.

Although medium bodied, this packs such a punch. The malt adds a chewy aspect to the feel. 

I wish you could session this one. It might take you 20 or so of these to figure out all of the smells and flavors.  As mentioned above, the brewers are not lying when they say this is not for the faint of heart. Dont give this to your friend who you are trying to ween off Miller Lite.

En lätt dimmig rödbrun öl med ett gräddigt skum. En komplex doft där jag särskiljer mörka frukter, maltighet och en humlebeska lite åt tallbarr. 
Samma går igen i smaken. En komplex och intressant öl som är svår att placera i en typ.

Crazy amount of flavor in this complex beer. Overwhelms the palate of this newbie. Sweet, yet smokey. Hop aroma from the very beginning, yet you dont get the hops in the taste until near the end. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Im still a newbie.
Awesome bitter taster, not too sharp, not too weak. I could have a more bitter beer. I can taste a roasty flavor, not coffee or chocolate at all, not near a stout, or not like an IPA at all.
dark coper ruby color, aroma is sweet citrus hops, toffee, roasted malt, flavor is citrus hops, toffee, roasted malt, some dark fruits, nice amount of bitterness, and a kind of smoky finish

The name says it all. This is a very interesting brew because it it not an IPA and not just an Ale. Pours a beautiful color close to that of brewed tea. A generous off white nutty head. Plenty of Hops that is balance well with the malts. I get a very smokey maltiness closer to the finish almost like a very good stout. A sweetness from the start until the hops shows up to let you know its there. Not sure why I rated this beer because none of us are worthy. This will make it on the list of brews to put on tap. Loved it and would recommend if you havent yet tried this one that you run out now and get a bottle.

Keg, The Sheffield Tap, Sheffield. Hazy dark mahogany, thin creamy head. Brown sugar and clove aroma, sweet with a sharp hoppiness, a mint infused pepper finish with caramel and fruit. Mouth puckering bitter as the glass goes.

Appearance
Deep brown, a little hazy, pours a creamy head that lasts.

Aroma
Hoppy, reminds me of a strong pale ale, a hint of iron?

Taste
Hoppy bitterness, IPA-like characteristics, not much malt at all, although one might expect it from looking at the beer. It is nevertheless quite smooth.

Overall
Ive had the Arrogant Bastard from tap before, and I recall quite liking it. Its hoppier than I remembered, and indeed youd think that this is a particularly bitter IPA from just tasting it. The strange thing is that it looks like a brown ale, and the creamy head would suggest something completely different than what you get: in your face hoppy intensity. Stone Brewing makes a case for this beer being something alternative that not many people will like, but actually I think that this comes quite close to some of the stronger and bolder IPAs or maybe Double Pale Ales that are not uncommon in the US.

The aroma on this monster says beer.  Not skunky, not beerey, not what you would get at the yellow beet keg on the lake.  But true beer, an entity in and of its self.  Something you could make love to.

To look at it is to look into the eyes of the beer god.  Dark caramel, clear as glass yet with the mystery of the perfect brew.

Slightly sweet, mostly bitter, a bit salty...  A fizzy yellow beer drinker would be offended.  It overtakes your pallet and offers no apologies.

Full bodied, creamy with just the right amount of carbonation.

The finish is long as the night is dark.  You will be able to enjoy this brew long after the bottle is empty.
Sympatiska dofter av kola och sura körsbär kommer från denna rödbruna öl. Smakerna är talrika, men frukter och kola ligger längst fram. Ett väldigt gott öl.

Bottle. Pours a deep bronze body with a slight red hue and a medium off-white head which disappears rapidly. Nose is strawberries, pine and hints of dark malts. Kind of faint. Taste, however, is not faint: pronounced licorice and pine, dry grassy hops and hints of spruce, grapefruit and pineapple. Long, dry-bitter aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium carbonation. Surprisingly subtle for a Stone ale; this is a fairly good ASA but I honestly thought one of Stones most famous beers would somehow be...better than this. Still, this is a pretty good brew, dont get me wrong.

Forgot to rate this a loooooong time ago. Bottle into tulip. Body is dark brown/red with a decent head. Nose is a bit hoppy with some slighty caramel and roasted notes. Taste is dark fruits with some nice hop bitters that make this one finish more on the dry side while malts dominate up front. Great and complex brew.
Big hops with a nice sweet backbone. Beautiful red color. What a great beer.

22oz bomber into a pint glass.

Pours a hazy dark copper with a smallish tan head that quickly fades into a thin cap.

Aroma of piny hops along with some caramel, toasted malt, and dark fruit such as raisins and figs.

Taste is a nice mix of hop and malt. Piny hop flavors up front along with some toasty caramel malt. Dark fruit quickly follows and dominate the middle of the taste. Some roastiness again follows this along with a strong hop bitterness. The finish is quite crisp and a bit sticky.

Overall this is a top notch beer and a classic. One that I always love to indulge in.

Half pint at Sheffield Tap.  Dark red with a creamy head.  Well hopped, lightly bitter, very smooth.  Doesnt really taste 7.2%.  A little zesty with some red fruit, a bit of raisin with the hops.  Very pleasany fruity aroma, aromatic and fruity.

At first I was a little underwhelmed but it grew on me the more I had.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a beige head.  Aroma is fairly hoppy with notes of grapefruit, sweeter citrus fruits like orange, herbal and floral notes, caramel and sweet malt. Flavor is fairly bitter, with lots of grapefruit and orange, herbal notes and floral notes along with sweet and caramel malts and some toasted notes. The body is medium with a dry mouthfeel. Overall a pretty awesome brew!

Bomber. Like scoring a date with the hot girl you knew was out of your league. The aroma hits hard with hops then settles into a mellow malty almost bread undertone, but dont mistake me: its the floral hops ruling this one. The appearance with a frothy amber pour that settles into a dense head, average dissolve into a resilient film that just slimes the glass as you drink leaving a crazy thick lacing - gorgeous! The palate was a lot lighter than I expected, a light body for sure, but a nice sticky texture settles on your tongue. Then the hops come in... bam, this bastard sucker punches you. Tastes of floral hops have a unique mix with a bready/caramel hint of malt. Its the hops show, but their sidekick, the malts, make them who they are. Get me? Eh, whatever. If you dont, youre not worthy.

Awesome ale. Great taste. Really smooth bitter taste to it. Wonderful. I usually drink this excellent ale straight from the bottle since I am like that.  When it says you are not worthy, unless you like ales like this, you truly arent
pours gold with a medium head. Has a spicy caramel malt flavor followed up by an earthy hop finish. touch of pine.

Tap at BrewDog Camden. Pours a muddy brown with a thin off-white creamy head. The aroma is bready with malt, neat vodka and a little sourness. The beer hurries quickly over the palate in a crashing dark fruit wave. Initial taste is sweet treacle, date and brown sugar but this dries quickly into a lingering fruitcake crumb. A dark fruit richness is apparent in the aftertaste but also a little too much sweetness for my palate.
This is a big, in-your-face beer.  Had it on draft, not from the bottle.  It is a lovely dark caramel color with a lot of roasted malt flavor and a nice touch of hops.  Seriously good.

Aroma is mild sweet caramel mineral as well as a bit of citrus hop aroma. Appearance is hazy brown with small tan head. Taste is bright sweet malt forward. Direct, unique and impressive. Hops bitterness very present, keeping malt in check. Molasses and toffee. Something with the hops is setting off the very unique and bright malt. Palate is bright caramel toffee that lingers nicely with hop bitterness. Hint of butter. Overall a very unique beer that is a nice drinker. Boring aroma and appearance kill the total rating, but a completely unique beer regardless.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Dark amber red.. big off-white head.. 

S: Piney and grapefruit hops... but not quite in a ipa way.. good malt base..

T: Good hop character... sweet caramel malts.. roasted and toasted grains.. some fruity tones too..

M: Smooth. good hop bitterness finish. crisp and enjoyable..

I think most over rate this beer because of its name. On the other hand it lives up 
to Stones excellent reputation

This has long been my favorite ale.  As a huge fan of hoppy bears and this being the king of hoppy ales its hard to do much better.  

Years ago I used to arrogantly stick to only European (primarily Belgium ales) but this was one of the beers that changed my tune and thankfully so as the proliferation of shockingly thrillingly hoppy beers coming out of smaller U.S. brewers has been incredible the past decade.

Tonight Im comparing it to another ale and it may have finally met its match... the double bastard.
Bottle.  Pours a dark amber with a decent biege head.  Aroma of malt, hops, and citrus.  Taste is caramel malt, citrus, pine, and florals.  Great balance.  Great beer!

14/I/2012 1Pt. 6Fl. Oz. bottle  @ RBBWG 2012 - BB: n/a (2012-55) Thanks to Benzai for bringing the bottle!
Clear dark amber to reddish beer, nice creamy yellowish head, unstable, little adhesive. Aroma: very fruity, passion fruits, bit piny, touch of wood. MF: soft carbon, full body. Taste: pretty fruity, pineapple, resin, very bitter, bit of lychee, some sweet malts. Aftertaste: bitter and very dry. Meh. You dont make a beer better by just adding more hops. It simply doesnt work like that.

[Rated 10/10/2009] Bottle. Pours dark red with a thin head. While aroma is very soft, flavor is rough, very hoppy. Somehow it feels a little overhopped, not the kind thats too bitter, but rather overbrewed and acidic. That is not to say that flavor is dull, just a little different. Overall I am not too impressed, given that its made by Stone Im willing to give it another try some day.

Ive had this brew several times, and I dont think Ive ever actually sat down to evaluate it.  So, here goes

The distinctive 22oz painted bottle sticks out on the shelf like a sore thumb.  The gargoyle catches your eye immediately.  If you take the time to read the back of the bottle, you endure a few insults, insinuations, and some other comical anecdotes. 

The Arrogant Bastard pours a dark rusty color, and fairly opaque.  The foam is heavy at first, but subsides relatively quickly.  The almond-colored foam leaves behind a fairly heavy lacing.  There is very little, if any, carbonation rising from the bottom of the glass, which surprises me.  At 7.2% abv, I expected more visible carbonation.

Putting my nose in the glass, Im getting some hops, but nothing over-whelming.  Its not nearly as hoppy in the nose as the Lagunitas Hop Stoopid I had last night.  Im also getting a bit of malts, but very roasty, almost burnt malts. 

Once I take a sip, I remember why I never review this beer.  It really is just like they describe on the bottle!  The Arrogant Bastard is mildly hoppy, but well "balanced" with some dark roasted (burnt) malts.  I say "balanced" because the two dont really seem to balance either other at all.  Its as if you took the oil and vinegar and through them into a pot in exactly the same proportions.  Just because its equal, doesnt mean its balanced.

The malt sweetness is definitely present, but very short-lived.  The hops seem to stick to my tongue for hours.  The brew overall is kind-of rough, strong, and I dont know, the exact opposite of mellow, smooth and balanced?!
UPDATED: JAN 13, 2012 En bouteille. Nez genereux et frais de houblon. Le houblon confere une belle amertume en bouche et le tout est supporte par un leger gout de malt. Bonne biere; a racheter.

Dark red amber,solid creamy light tan head good lacing.
 Aroma of candied hops,with fresh pine light floral herbal. NIce overall hoppy fresh aroma.
Good thick creamy mouthfeel,with dark roasted malt,dark almost tangy toffe like, candied hop flavor mellow hop flavor butsuper piney on the finish and  piney bitter even spice like.With dark roasted bittersweet toffe underneath the pine.
Malt, bread, caramel/toffee in the aroma.  Flavor starts with toffee, bread, and vanilla, then finishes with a piney hop bite.  One of my favorite beers.

650ml bottle. Pours dark amber with a red hue. There is a generous head. The nose has chocolate digestive biscuits. The taste has toffee and ginger biscuits with a pine finish. The palate is medium to large structured with a good creamy texture and a dry refreshing finish. Overall, a good beer, perhaps an imperial bitter in my opinion.

pours dark amber thick and hazy. Can taste the hops, but its not overwhelming, actually this is one of the smoother high alc % beers I have tasted, coming from San Diego where there is currently an IPA overload, this is real refreshing. Overall a real delecious brew

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2012 Pours bright amber with thick tan head. Aroma is honey, clean crystal malt, very sweet hop backbone. Flavour is robust caramel and liquorice malt, progressing top more radiated flavours and finishing with an enduring treacle and pine finish. Body is thick and decadent, and overall this is excellent stuff.
Pours dark amber with a medium head. Aroma malts, fruits and hops. Flavor is roasted malts, vanilla, dark fruits and lots of hops. Very nice.

Very bitter with hoppy smell...bit of a strong after taste. Slightly cloudy color.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma- big malt and hop bill, oak presence, funk
Appearance- dark brown, eggshell, creamy as hell head
Taste- big malts upfront, huge hop center with a slight hint of funk at the end
Palate- medium, very creamy, mouthfeel
Overall- Such a different brew from Stone.  Yes it is West Coast, yes it is hoppy and malty as hell, but it is also very dry and super pungent for 7 percent.  I like it but it is not very drinkable for a 7 percent brew,
UPDATED: SEP 3, 2013 An American amber ale with an extra kick. Bitter and aggressive hop profile. Lots of pine and an herbal quality. Lots of malt backbone, but still decidedly hop forward.

Absolutely fantastic beer here.  Great color, deep amber and clear, nice head and lace.  Wonderful aroma and taste, tons of caramel malts but well balanced with the perfect amount of hops.  Body is medium and goes down so smoothly.  This is one of my favorite beers of all time and a huge value too.

Date: December 20, 2011 Mode: Draft Source: Valley Tap House Description: Semi-opaque brown with some head and nice lacing.  Faint malty aroma and taste had a pepper and spice kick to it.  Smooth and creamy with a bitter aftertaste.

Pours dark amber with a filtered clairty and lasting head, like i like... Aromas of Amarillo hops Carmel, Munich and Bisciut malts.  Taste is malty with balanced west coast style hop profile and bigish body. Overall a bigger style American Amber Ale with a little somthing special.  I have had almost all of Stones beers and this one is the most consistant and soild offering by Stone brewing.
Bottle, pours brown which thick tan head. Aroma of hops, caramel. Excellent finish, keep on reaching back for more.
UPDATED: JUL 31, 2015 Pours dark brown with a foamy tan head thats leaves sticky lacing. Big nutty, caramel and grapefruit aroma.  Nice bitterness and malty sweetness, and citrus notes.
Bottle. Color brown with big white head. Aroma malt, roasted, caramel, hop, grapefruit, citrus. Taste malt, bitter, herbs, grass, hop, grapefruit.
bottle, caramel, floral, orange, clear, white foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, average carbonation, long finish,
UPDATED: OCT 12, 2013 Very spicy hops in the aroma.  Intensely biting hops with a great maltiness make this ale huge and very thick.  Everything I was hoping and more, awesome ale.
Draft. Hoppy assertivenessup front. Strong malts in the nose.  Good beer. Fuck it im drunk.
Excelent brew, aroma has notes of citrusy and tropical fruits, the flavor has intensified notes of hop, and some notes of roasted malt

Didnt think Id like this one, but was pleasantly surprised.  I picked up notes of caramel malt, grapefruit, nuts and wood.  Im guessing they use citra hops.  It isnt oak aged, but I think they toss a few wood chips in the boil.  It has a little bit of brown sugar sweetness.  All the flavor elements are well balanced.  It has a robust hop presence, but it doesnt approach the lingering bitterness of a hop heavy IPA.  Overall very good, despite its ridiculous marketing nomenclature.

Pours a muddy reddish brown with medium foamy off-white head.  Nice hop bouquet on the nose with plenty of citrus, grapefruit, some tangerine, and a hint of caramel.  Taste is very hoppy with citrus and grapefruit that is well supported by caramel and aggressive hop bitterness.  Delicious brew!

On tap at Cloverleaf.  Pour an amber red brown color with a white foam head.  Aroma of caramel, citrus, and earthiness.  Sweet toasty caramel with a big hop hit.  Damn tasty.  Some similarities to 90 minute in terms of hop/malt balance.

Do I really have to rate this? really?  Fortunately though I had it on tap just yesterday so it can still be fresh in my mind.  Draft versions of this beer far outway the bottle version.  Theres a definite hint of blackberry in the hops, Northern Brewer perhaps?  I mean really, besides what everyone else has been writing about this beer, what more is there to say?  Compare it though to some of the extreme hopped beers that we see today and AB is rather tame and quite frankly mundane.  The malt-hop balance though is well done and for once Im not left with the catty sensation of piney stick stuck on my tongue.  This is a superior beer...the best? that has yet to be determined.

Aroma is nice citrus hops with caramel malts with light roasted coffee undertones. Appearance is a very darkened amber with a light foam head. Taste is leafy hops and slight malt background. The finish is a nice fruity bitterness with some carbonation. Spectacular complex flavors with a full body. Overall, this is a massive brew filled with leafy/earthy hops, caramel/roasty malts and nice, subtle fruitiness. Id give this an A+ rating.
Pours a cloudy reddish brown. Aroma is very faint earthy citrus. Strong bitter taste but smooth. Overall a very good beer.

Draught @ BrewDog Bar, Edinburgh.
Rated on 20110727.
Pours deep ruby red colour with medium head. Aroma of plums, raisin, ripe fruits, some caramel and toffee. Flavour of caramel malts, plums and raisins, ripe fruits and some notes of wood.
5315

Bottle from Moeder Lambic, Brussels. Hazy dark red with a tanned head. Nose : Great citrus fruity hops. It smells bitter grapefruit times 10 ! I can sense some roasted coffee beans too. Little banana. Sip : Very oily with a small carbonation. Bitter hops and roasted bitter malts makes it a grapefruit coffee taste that dominates from beginning to the end. Coffee aromas might be mistaken for dark chocolate ones. That is a really good beer ! Unless you cant take bitterness....

Sampled at SBWF. Stockholm, September 30th, 2011. 

Aromas of grassy, slightly fruity hops, caramels, dry paper. Bitter with a big malty sweetness. Round taste and pretty fruity. Finishes with a note of spices and nuts.

Pours deep orange red with a sizable off white head. Leaves plenty of lace. Aroma is lemony and resinous hops. Taste is very smooth. low carbonation, creamy malt backbone, and a moderate bitter hop. no hint of the high abv. Spicyness hops become more distinct as you drink.

On tap at The Public. Poured a bright and deep orange/amber with minimal head. Medium body. More hops than malt, an aggressive beer with a bit of a bitter and astringent finish. Good for drinking slowly.
On tap at Oskar Blues.  One of my favorite beers from an excellent brewery.

Pours an amber brown with a nice tan head.  Big aroma with notes of malt, caramel, and citrus.  Flavor of grapefruit, toasted malts, and caramel.  Finishes a little rougher than I was expecting with a lasting bitterness.  But overall a good and solid beer.
an amazing hoppy malty beer well ballanced too, pours dark brown with an amazing aroma ,hops hit first then  the malt slides straight in .not a chugger but something to savour
Bottle. Creamy tan head. Red tinted amber color. Aroma strong on citrus and herbs (thymey). Flavor is nicely bitter, with a balancing sweetness. Palate was clean, but a little too astringent.
Always my go to Ale." I am always worthy" for this GREAT creation.
Bomber @ "Dive Bar" Wexford, Pa.  Pours very dark amber, great "light" version of "Sublimely Self Ritious".  Cant go wrong with Stone!
UPDATED: JUN 1, 2012 Very beautiful color with a strong bite and bitter after taste. Strong citrus tones. But can be a bit over bearing.

Unrelenting, sticky beige head, real hop power in the nose with some malt breadiness behind it. A big kick from the hops up front followed by spicy black pepper, sweet bread, and a dry, grassy, excessively bitter finish.

Its so aggressive, but I cant stop drinking it. All around, its an outstanding beer with bold, complex flavors and Stone, as always, provides the perfect attitude.

I feel it gets overlooked sometimes by some of the rarer and seasonal beers, but its one of the best out there. Perhaps its becoming ubiquitous in the craft beer world. However, you cant go wrong with Arrogant Bastard.

Poured from a draft into a pint glass. Color was reddish brown. Probably an inch of head. Lots of lacing on the top. Also lots of film on the sides.

Smelled citrusy first, more than anything else. Got some roasty malts and caramel in there, too.

Couldnt put the finger on the taste, but Id go with toasty and roasty malts leading the way. Caramel bread comes in there as well. Smooth, but bitter.

Medium body. Lively carbonation. Sticky syrupy texture. Smooth finish.

Surprisingly  this was my first time trying this beer. Not too bad, though.
Aroma mainly of hops and malts. Taste is dominated by hop flavours. Some malts as well but the hops are overpowering.

Brown beer, cola colour. Beige head. Caramel and malts in the nose, somewhat sweet, liquorice, some smoke. Light spicy. Flavour quite bitter, light sweetness, liquorice. 
(65cL -1pint 6oz- bottle @ DRBM 2011)

Ah, a classic beer--and brand--in American craft. This pours a deep, dark, alluring ruby-brown with a nice head. This beer is so fantastically bitter, and--having it now as a more seasoned drinker--so much more bitter than the subdued hop aroma would indicate, that it really is surprising. The bitter notes stick around forever in the finish, but theres also a nice brown sugar or caramel sweetness that prevails. Flavor really is distinctive--so very bitter, but somehow stays sweet. I havent had this in a long time, and its fun to do the official review for it. Unique in any context.

Cannot add any observations not already touched upon. Other than my encouragement to any craft beer lover to obtain this beer if you havent already. Considered to be a benchmark, if not a high watermark, in the style category.
Really enjoyed this beer with two of my colleagues in LA. :-) excellent taste, nice colour.. Simply a very good ale.

22 oz. bottle pours a kind of murky dark brown with fairly thick light tan head.
Medium carbonation and good lacing.  Big hop aroma with more than a hint of malt on the nose as well.  Medium to thick body and big hop flavor but also a roasted malt bitterness is present.  A very good ale with what has to be the best literature to be found on a bottle.

Huh for some reason I never had this, the oaked version was good though!  Pour out of bomber is nice and dark reddish brown with creamy and lasting khaki head.  Aroma brings notes of pine, orange, grapefruit, hints of biscuit, toffee, and some grassy earthy notes.  Taste is aggressive for sure, but after having the double bastard and oaked its not quite like that...but still pretty intense.  Initial big notes of biting pine and grass notes leads into some slight orange and grapefruit, even a hint of tangerine, leading into toffee, biscuit notes that ever so slightly sweeten it up a bit, finishing dry, bitter and slightly spicy.  This is a nice brew!
Bottle. Pours dark amber with 4 finger head (tasting glass). Nose of caramel, grapefruit and some cherry wood.

650mL bomber poured a brownish red color with a decent beige head and some nice lacing.  Aroma is roasted malts and hops with a hint of chocolate and coffee.  Taste is roasted malty sweetness balanced nicely with some wicked hop bitterness.  This brew packs quite a punch and is a very good beer.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2012 Clean golden brown ale, creamy brown head. Hoppy, floral, some malts of rye in the back. Brilliant bitterness. End is dry. Very smooth. One of the meetings best for me. (DRbM 2011) (Rating re-indexed)

Pour mahogany with beige head good lace. Aroma caramel, wood, pine, sweet malt, earthy, resinous hops. Taste butterscotch, caramel, resiny hops, earthy, sweet, pine. MF medium stick body with good carb. Excellent flavor with a good balance between sweet and bitter.
Dark brown pour with good size tan head. As everyone else has said, its a high quality beer. Caramel, roasted malts and refreshing.

Bottle @ drbm. Aroma is slight smoke, roast, caramel.
flavour is quite bitter, medium hops, faint smoke. Nice one.r
Bottle at UDRBM. Clear copper pour, thick off-white head. Aroma is hoppy with tea and grassy hops. Flavor is bitter, fresh hops, some sweet malts. Nice balance. Good beer.
Pour is abeautiful deep copper with thick lacy head. Aroma is very hop foward roasted malts resin. Taste is hoppy bitter with an almost sweet caramel finish and a dry bitter clean piney finish.

A thick brown head with lots of lacing and a deep, reddish brown color.  The aroma is largely toasted malt and barley, with caramel and a bit of coffee/chocolate and strong hops.  The flavor is largely toasted malt, but the hops are right behind that.  It has a smooth and slightly fizzy body.
Finalmente lho bevuta e non mi ha deluso minimamente. Luppolatura perfetta con il malto che funge solo da spalla, beverinità assurda e sapore mondiale. Peccato che ne ho solo 2 bottiglie!!!!

On tap at Mellow Mushroom. Pours dark brown with a medium, rocky, off-white head and thorough lacing. The aroma is caramel, roasted malts, and earthy and resin hops. The flavor is strong sweetness and bitterness throughout, with neither outweighing the other. The palate is very heavy, chewy and sticky. The aftertaste is strong and bitter, and will not go away. Overall, this is a heavy, strong, and incredibly flavorful beer. If you are looking for something delicate and subtle, youve picked the wrong beer.

Bomber from Peppinos in Grand Rapids. They had to dig it out from the back and the bottle date was 9 months old, so this should be "aged Arrogant". Pours very brown with a yellowish tinge. Very low carbonation. Aroma is overripe fruit and caramel. Taste is thick syrupy fruit and a cacophony of hop layers. Alcohol quite present. Finishes strong and kicking. My memory of this beer is that it is quite rough, but smoother and tastier than this one was, so I will be curious to find another to see.
Pours dark brown, lots of head an carbonation. This is a hoppy beer, but not overly so. Hops balance the malt, and taste is complex but not heavy or sweet. Great beer.

Ported from BA.

Appearance:
Very red amberish color. An inch or so of head with good retention and an eventual sticky lacing. Bubbly.

Smell: Hops. It smells just like fresh hops. Somewhat citrusy, but mostly you just get a wave of pure hop aroma.

Taste: Hop forward, for sure. As the hop flavor recedes, you get a good mouthful of toasted malt before the hops hit you again for a bitter finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied, with some alcohol joining the carbonation as it hits your tongue.

Drinkability: Good for a strong ale. It might be good to switch to a lower ABV beer after a while to let yourself cool off, but the taste is something you can keep running with.

Tasted from bottle into pint glass at Meshuggah, St Louis, Missouri, USA. Pours brilliant amber color with lasting off-white head, some lacing. Assertive American hops aroma hits you immediately, but upon tasting it you realize theres plenty of rich malty sweetness to compliment the bitterness. Finishes with that subtle fruity snap of English ale yeast. Remarkably balanced, much like a standard American Pale Ale "but these go to eleven." Complete with cool, oversized painted bottle. If you like good (hoppy) beer, you cant help but like Stone Brewery. Once youve fallen in love with their beers, as you surely must, the hilarious off-putting statements on the packaging will stroke your ego. An extremely well-crafted beer. Highly recommended.
Bomber and on tap. One of my favorites. Great bitter taste throughout and yet very smooth. Very tasty.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ vs. Moeder: red amber with an off-white head, smell is grapefruit hops with some light fruit, taste is very in your face bitter grapefruit hops, definite presence of malt, slight floral hops, hint of herbs & caramel, light fruits, nice

On the bottle, Youre Not Worthy; oh yes I am!! Gotta love a good strong ale! Assertive hops with just enough malts to smooth off the bite just a tad makes for an awesome brew to savor! The Stone line of brews continues to impress and is definitely a line-up of brews that one can come to appreciate for the long run! Can definitely tell the results of quality workmanship.

I would normally have something to criticize in just about every beer.  After thinking about this one for a couple of days, I cannot find anything.  At the time I had it I was under the impression I was drinking an IPA.  Bitter at first, A/B does not finish bitter like an IPA, it instead finishes with a fruity floral aftertaste that is very hard to pin-point.  High alcohol content and noticeable but not overbearing mouthfeel round out one of the best beers I have had.
65cl, American brew, from Geers Oostakker, complex brew, bitter/fruity and slightly malty/roasted, not too heavy, balanced, clear, small head, good brew, yet expensive

Draught @ Moeder Lambic during the Stone vs Moeder Lambic event. Light brown colour with a big white head. Smells hoppy, some food and herbs. Good bitterness in the taste, fruity and hoppy. Great mouthfeel, medium body.

Une énorme tête beige flotte sur un liquide rouge rubis.  Une solide dentelle décore le verre.  Au nez, des houblons baignés dans la douceur rencontrent des malts en caramel et en bonbon.  Des parfums de noisette se fondent parmi les fruits rouges.  Au goût, les céréales maltées perdent des sucres qui se choquent à des houblons aromatiques et amérisants.  En bouche, le liquide est très musclé : le doux pétillement contribue à rendre la texture très moelleuse, épaisse et riche.  En finale, les houblons sont parfumés et sexpriment par de belles et longues morsures.

Draught at Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas during the three day Stone Event, 16-18 september 2011. Clear amber / brown colored beer. Rough, creamy white head. Smell nicely hops, but also something a little weird, dont know what it is. Taste is nicely hoppy again, without any weird side-taste. Nice carbonation, medium to full body.

The little brother of Double Bastard. Pours a deep mahogany with an off white head. Nose and taste is of dark malts, dried fruits, and booze. If the booze were masked better this would be a world class beer.
Tasting at beer temple.  Clear brown pour with tan head.  Aroma of malts and hops.  Same aspect in flavour with a thick mouthfeel and lasting bitterness.  Excellent beer

@ beer tasting at the beer temple, Amsterdam
Decent off white head.  Clear amber pour.  Nice bitterness. Top notch script on the label!! Funny.
From a bomber to a pint glass.  Pours a copper/brown with cream colored head that sticks around.  More pale ale than I expected.  Hoppy with a nice bitter finish.  Stone keeps the hits coming.
Keg at Cask. Dark amber colour with medium sized creamy beige head. Aroma is spicy, but ginger. Nice but nothing that special, especially compared to the oaked version.
Citrus aroma and very bitter hops.  Hops almost punch you in the face with the bitterness.  Did I say bitter hops.

An extremely dark brown beer with a tint of red and a medium beige head.  The aroma is mild but pleasant with notes of grapefruit, orange, and grass.  The flavor has a malty sweet background with a boatload of bitterness up front.  The bitterness borders on too much, but doesnt quite get there.  The body is nice and heavy, a little oily, and coats the tongue nicely.
22 oz from PCC in Redmond WA. Pours copper color with a off white head. Aroma is caramel and hoppy spices. Very bitter, and a feels like a punch in the face of hops
Tried this in a 22 oz into one of my mugs.  Only had one and should try again to properly review.  I remeber it being a very good IPA

Pours a nice dark red copper with a nice light tan head and some lace.  Aroma is of Califonia hops, caramel, spices and resin.  Very bitter, lots of hops, some caramel, spices and smoke flavour.  Very unique flavour that surprises me every time.

Pours a nice ruby color with thin silky layer of light brown head. Aroma is nice and hoppy-bitter. The beer just smells good and sticky. The flavor of this beer is very strong but well balanced between bitterness of the hops and the sweet malty thickness. This beer is like a heavily-hopped Irish red.

Draftthis beer is definitely in your face.  Amber/brown pour, tan head, and well-balanced.  Aroma of caramel and some spices.  Thick mouthful of a beer, almost like chewing gum, nice hoppy flavor, a little heavy of a brew.  Roasted malts flavored, long bitter finish.  One of these is usually enough for me.  A definite must try.

Bottle from 9th Ave Vintner enjoyed with the roomies and Erica as we hunker down for Hurricane Irene in 47B. Deep muddy pour with some sediment and medium tan head. Sweet, malty aroma and rich, full--bodied taste with hints of chocolate, smoke, spice - no flavor dominates and this makes the beer enjoyable and sessionable. Not a ton of alcohol on the palate given the 7.2%.

Pours a red/brown color with a white head.  Some fruit/hops aroma, but mainly yeast and bread.  Taste is somewhat sweet, but otherwise typical for a brown ale.  Finish is simple, no lingering taste or bitterness.  Fancy rhetoric and neat bottle aside, this is a good beer, but should not be getting scores of 4.6. I cant say I would seek out this beer again, but wouldnt turn it down if it was offered to me.

It smells sweet of caramel malts and a little bit of resiny hop in the back.  It pours a dark amber body with a light tan head that leaves behind ridiculous lacing.  It tastes somewhat sweet with a bit of a bitter bite in the back.  It is smooth almost too smooth for a beer of this size.  Overall I love this beer, I love Stone Brewing.  This is a great beer that is popular in the craft beer crowd for a reason.  I cant really find anything offputting in this beer besides that it will get you too drunk too quick.
Poured amber. Smells like hops and malt. Fruit underneath it all. It is, of course, pretty bitter. Lots of hoppiness as well. A personal favorite; the go-to beer.
22 oz bomber pours a dark amber color with a nice white head.  Great aromas of malt, caramel, with citrus and hops.  incredibly well balanced between hops and malt, just a great beer

pours dark red/amber. smells of hops and caramel malt, with a slightly roasty smell. taste is strong up front of hops and some sort of berry? leads into citrus, grapefruit, caramel malt and slight roasted choclate. the body is a tad oily, slightly thick. this is an awsome beer, not for you fizzy pale lager drinkers though :P. but the label warns as so. in all seriousness this beer is  world class. stone does not dissapoint.
UPDATED: MAY 25, 2012 Its true. We arent worthy.  What did we do to deserve such a magnificent beer?

Pours brownish amber with a 1/2" thick tan head that fades to just a halo in the glass. Smells of caramel, grapefruit, a touch of pine and some spice note cant quite place it maybe clove or cinnamon. Taste of dark roasted malts some chocolate, coffee, very in your face hop profile which I like, some grapefruit, and definate pine. Mouthfeel is some what thick and the finish is long and bitter with a touch roasted malts.

On tap at petrol station. Pours a clear deep amber with a yellowish brown head that lasts throughout the beer and laces slightly. Aroma is full of resinous pine and a bit of backing grapefruit. Flavor is simIlar with lots of resinous pine and grapefruit backed by cookies. Nice and smooth.

22 oz bomber. Pours deep orange red with a sizable off white head. Leaves plenty of lace. Aroma is lemony and resinous hops. Taste is very smooth. low carbonation, creamy malt backbone, and a moderate bitter hop. no hint of the high abv. Spicyness hops become more distinct as you drink.

From notes. 16oz draft pint from Old Chicago. Pours a dark red almost purple color. About 2 fingers of thick tan head. Aroma is strongly hops. Mostly resin. Also a little bit of sweet malt. Taste is medium bitter and lightly sweet. You can totally taste the hops in this one. Medium bodied with a creamy texture and a long bitter finish. Overall, this is a damn good beer. Something I will most definitely but again. I think it is much better than their "Oaked version.
Nice sweet aroma.  Layered caramel flavour gives way to good hop flavour and bitterness.  Great ale.

22oz bottle.  Pours a card amber/coke color.  Yellowish frothy head.

Malty slightly sweet, moist hay aroma.

Taste is malty.  Very pleasing mouthfeel and density.

Clean finish.
Awesome dark color, made me thirsty on the first view, alot of hops which really added to the flavor.
Dark pour with off white head. Aroma of malts, hops and wood. Taste is quite hoppy up front with roasted malts and a nutty taste in the background. A little overrated I think but still a good beer.
Looks like a coke. Smells hoppy and lightly smoked. Lightly hoppy with long light finish. Nice!

22oz bottle. Hazy reddish color, thin fading tan head, some lacing. Very dry texture. Bitter hops taste, but the malty, cherry, mildly alcoholic aroma is dominant. Strong aftertaste, some sweet after the finish. Delicious and interesting, but kind of painful for 7.2% ABV. When I rated the Oaked version a long time ago, I seemed to love it, however. I may need to revisit that and see if its stood the test of time... I realize that these Arrogant Bastards taste 3x better with a meal though. That could have added .2 or so, Id imagine
Muy buena cerveza,carácter mas tirando a malta pero con gran carga de lúpulo,agresiva....recomendada!

Rating must not have saved last time...great stuff, dark brown read with off white cream head.  Huge hops in the front which totally attack your palate.  Nose kicks ass in itself.  As you drink your tounge gets a full assault of hop, and a big back.  Finishes hugely bitter.
Good beer. Nice bitterness, mixed with a good malt depth. Simply too hoppy for my palate... I just dont like hops! :(

Im really warming up to Stone the more of their beer Im having! This is yet another winner. Pours brown with a reddish hue, fairly small head for me (poor glass) but nice lingering lacing. Aroma is hoppy but not in a floral IPA way, theres roasted barley with a bit of nuts, some spices. Very nice. In the taste, the hops come through more with a bit of pine, malt is also there and maybe a bit of nutty caramel. Very nice bitterness thats fairly short but it does have a lingering pleasant aftertaste. The body is the only part I dont love, its still good but a bit light for the beer.

Finally this brewery has come to my area and I was able to try this awesome beer.  This has a caramel flavor with some hints of coffee along with a nice citrisy taking hop flavor.  Definitely recommed if you want a in your face beer.
Beer is very bitter up front with tons of hops. It has excellent flavor and smell. Beer warms you up as you drink it. Great beer

22oz bottle. Redish color when poured with a decent head. Aroma of malts, hops and roasted nuts. Has a roasted taste of malts with a hoppy taste to it - not a fruit hops flavor though. Has a nice balanced flavor overall. Really enjoyed the beer.  7.2% alcohol.

Found this is the bottle the other day. Ive had it before, but Im reviewing now so I thought I would mention it. Its everything everyone is making it out to be a big, aggressive beer that you have to be a craft beer drinker to enjoy. Dont think this is the kind of beer that a bud or miller drinker would enjoy. But, if you love craft beer, it belongs in a category of its own.

Year-old bottle aged in perfect cellar conditions pours rich ruby-amber with an off-white 1 finger head with incredible retention.  Aroma is toast, caramel, earthy and spicy hops, dark fruit, and arrogance.  Taste is still quite hoppy after a year, but the toffee, dried fruit, caramel, and spice dominate the flavor profile.  On the palate it is full bodied with just a bit too much carbonation and a kinda dry, bitter and spicy finish. Has a bit too  much of a bite for me to award it full points for body and flavor.  Overall, a great go-to beer when youre in the mood for a (self-advertised) aggressive beer.

very hoppy grapefruit aroma with some malt and other fruit notes.  very attractive red-brown color.  piney/floral/grapefruity hop flavor with some bread, caramel, and toasted malt. quite bitter and warming. a fantastic beer.

Pours deep red with well retained head. Smells malty, notes are hard to place. Has a very harmonious malt character with a slight hop presence and a very bitter finish. Quite a harsh aggressive ale but very tasty

Ive tried this several times and now its time to rate! The pour is an incredible and bubbly (lightly hazy) brown. The head is thick and stiff, also sticking to the glass as you consume. The aroma is intense and thick... spicy... sweet... yeah. Notes of dark fruits, super hops, caramel and barley. Tasted greatly of hops, spices and barley (almost nutty) and had a robust warm finish. The flavor is intense and in your face for the entirety of its consumption. Quite the taste, and one Ive had yet to come across in other brews.

It has a dark reddish-brown collor with a tan head that leaves some beautiful lacing, quite attractive. Its scent is a compination of piney and somewhat floral hops with a caramel sweetness with some brown sugar and a very slight maple scent. The taste follows the nose with two contradictions of piney floral hops and a caramel malt living together in pure harmony. The beers palate is quite good its very smooth, not quite as thick as Id like but very good. All in all this is an excellent beer that Im glad I can get it anytime I want.

On tap at US Beerfest, North Bar, Leeds. Pours a lovely deep reddish amber, medium-sized, foamy head. Aroma is very impressive, hops, a bit of roasted malt, with caramel and pine. Taste is aggressive - hops and pine notes attack the short sweet start and make it run away, leaving you with a full bodied strong hoppy taste, not as rounded as the aroma suggests. Finish is bitter and fairly short. Very accomplished.

Draught @ Iron Monkey, Jersey City, NJ
Pours cloudy amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel and alcohol. Taste is heavy sweet and light to medium bitter. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Draft at Alchemy.  Deep, foggy amber brown.  Solid, thick rusty orange beige head.  Piny, big, sticky, this might be the quintessential ASA.  Woody, nutty, chewy toffee tones, with a solid West Coast hop level.  Just screams out to be oak aged, but the freshness that jumps out at you is quite nice as well.  Expertly crafted.
650ml bottle.  Pours dark caramel with a large, frothy head.  Aroma is sticky toffee pudding, raisin, barley wine-esque.  Taste has a little caramel to start.  Strong piney bitter finish.

The last sample on the tray at Blue Star, Seattle 19.Dec.2008 with Stefan. I think I was getting too arrogant or maybe too tipsy to write much about it. Amber coloured body. I like it and will drink it again! Simple and straightforward:-)

drank at mondial 2011 in mtl. more of a bw. pours dark golden orange, nice off-white head. tons of caramel, sugar candy and a load of hops - grassy and piney. still, a relatively short astringent finish. medium body, average carbonation.
Great ale. Good hoppy taste but nice floral finish. Love this red ale. For the hop drinker.
One of Stone Brewings crowing achievements.  Head the warning, you may not be worthy.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2011 The appearance is great; this is the kind of beer that screams "drink me," whether you feel like sipping or otherwise. The aroma is tantalizing, with fresh hops and some slight, roasted sweetness. The taste is not as mellow and complex as the aroma; it is mostly piney and bitter, with less of a roasted-malt backbone than I had imagined. It is still good and full, but based on the aroma I was expecting a lot more. The aftertaste overstays its welcome and is, unfortunately, a bit unidimensional. Great, assertive beer, no doubt, but not one of my favorites.

Pours a hazy / cloudy deep amber colour, with a small beige head that eventually disappears. Aroma is full of hops, pine scents, and some caramel malts for the most part. Taste is somewhat sweet throughout but has a bitterness that becomes more intense from start to finish. Medium-full body, smooth mouth feel and strongly carbonated. Overall an awesome beer, one of the best Ive had in a long time.

22oz bottle.  I first had Arrogant Bastard ~a decade ago, when my beer palate was Corona and Coors Light.  This was my first craft beer and my last for quite a while...I wasnt worthy.  Living in SD, this beer is everywhere, from your local supermarket to kegs at house parties.  Ive had it many times, but this is my first in at least a couple years.  This is definitely not the best beer in the world, even though it thinks it is.  It has all of the hard-to-get-right details down: dark ruby pour; nice foamy head; full bodied; thick, sticky texture; bitter finish...it is a pioneer for a reason.  However, the initial aroma is not at all inviting, Ill call it pungent.  There is something in the hop profile that just doesnt appeal to me (overripe fruit, perhaps).  Whatever it is, it makes its way to the tongue and even to the aftertaste a bit, and it ruins the whole experience.  Oh well.  If you hand me this beer, Ill happily drink it, Ill even enjoy it; I love what Arrogant Bastard represents, I love Arrogant Bastard.  There are just way too many better beers out there that wasting my time on this is just that: a waste of time.

Amber color pour. An off white head that was very thick. Some great, lacing that sticks.Smell of caramel, malts, and hops. The flavor was dark fruit, malty and little piny with the sweetness of caramel to round it out. A very bold beer with a lot going on but very easy to drink and enjoy. A well done brew!

One of my favorites. Gorgeous deep gold with a nice head and great lacing. Smell is hoppy and refreshing. Sweet malty taste perfectly balanced by the hop bitterness and a dry finish. Great sticky mouthfeel with good carbonation. Absolutely wonderful. My go-to strong ale.

All around, this is a good beer. A lovely deep brown/red, backed by a subtle aroma. Whilst not as bitter and hoppy as I enjoy, the taste is well balanced, with malts and hops sharing the centre stage is harmony.

1 pint 6 oz bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown color with a huge off-white almost tan head. It has a nice pine, resin, citrus and floral hop aroma. Wow. This beer is extremely complex, and wonderfully so.  It has a strong pine hop flavor with a resin, caramel, citrus, grass flavor and some bread flavor. The hop flavor is almost overpowering and really lingers. Good stuff, Id definitely drink this one again.

How have I not rated this yet? Drank one with a damn good buffalo chicken sandwich. Pours a bright maroon with medium beige head. Its so obnoxious of pine/spruce hops that I dont get much else of anything. Some slight caramel malt, but its prickly and bitter pine needles from start to finish. I apparently do not have the taste or sophistication to appreciate an ale of this quality and depth.
Liquid nectar of the Gods.  Bitter from the get go, Arrogant Bastard is one of my favorites.  It hits you over the head with hops but is so easy to drink.  Simply put, I love this ale.
A deep amber pour with a tan head.  It has a pine hop aroma with some faint caramel.  The medium body has a creamy texture with lively carbonation.  The taste is bitter from start to finish.
It poured a murky chestnut brown color. The aroma was good amounts of fruit and some sweetness. The taste was bitter and tangy.

Pours a nice dark amber. Fairly good-sized head. Lots of citrus and bitter hops in aroma and flavor. Bitterness almost a bit too pronounced. Could use some other flavors for balance. Not quite up to the level of their promos of it, but it isnt bad.

the bottle really roped me into this one, and I am not dissapointed! smells strongly of hops and pine with hints of citrus, taste follows suit very well. Really nice dark coloring of amber and brown, great lacing with about a 3 finger head aqggressively poured. I drank this beer immediately after a surly furious, my favorite beer hands down, and this stone ale really held up well. Will most definately get this brew again and thier other ale varities for sure!
im not worthy. well an average beer to a well seasoned palate compared to their slogan.  but a good craft beer for anyone starting trying to adventure into aggressive beers

Bottle. Hazy coppery dark brown with a light tan head. Toffee, light gapefruit, some sweet malts, dark fruits, and booze in the aroma. Quite balanced, and leans maltier with substantial dark fruitiness, toffee, but finishes pretty dry with iight grapefruit and grassy hops.  Medium body with spritzier carbonation.

This beer is not worthy!! Again, total bitter hop-domination, front of tongue to finish, with a mouth feel like battery acid. 
I LOVE strong hop craft-beers, but not Stones! (cept their Old Guardian)

Bottle.  Dark amber/brown with a tan head and decent lacing throughout.  Smells of earthy hops, rasins, roasted malts and a little oak.  Taste is a delicious mix of hops and malts that blends together for a fairly complex and "agressive" brew with hints of caramel, roasted malts, florally hops with just a touch of alcohol.  I enjoyed this like I enjoy a nice scotch -- cellar temp, no ice.  I rated this the same as the Oaked version, but I have to say that this just slightly beats it out.
Great beer! Initial malty sweetness of dark fruit, maybe a bit of molasses. Bitter finish. Great oily mouth, all around great beer.
Pours a very nice amber color with long lasting head. Aroma wasnt strong, what was there was nice, some caramel, floral, and some peach. Some bitterness, very nice mouth feel.
Reddish orange with a creamy orange colored head. Floral hops, sugary and kind of a bitter peach on the aroma. Balanced moderate sweetness and bitterness. Foamy, medium body.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2011 Dark red beer with aggressive fruity aromaof cinnamon and hops. Taste of citrus, cinnamon, strong bitter hops and a slight sweetness. Not an easy one. Heavy and rich mouthfeel. Lovely aggressive beer, cheeky and confident and with a good punch. Tasted in California and then brought home in a suitcase. Why is it so hard to get in DK?
pours hazy orange, nose is very hoppy. taste starts sweet and malty then goes to a bitter orange/ grapefruit rind flavor but the bitterness does not linger or overpower.

Beautifully deep reddy brown ale. Chocolate malt aroma. from the first taste its a pretty extreme and aggressive take no prisoners beer. Highly hopped with an overpoweringly bitter finish. Flavours of black sugar, caramel, grapefruit coming through.

Pours a clear, dark copper with a tall, chunky khaki head that has excellent retention and leaves decent lacing. Aroma is big on caramel, grapefruit, grass and pine, dark fruit and grain. Flavor is rich sweet caramel, grapefruit, planty hops, black tea, a touch of sweet dark fruit, husky grain and woody hops to the finish. Palate is on the heavy side of medium bodied, syrupy on entry, medium carbonation dry finish. Pretty damn good.

660 ml bottle. Thanks tiong!
Pours a dark reddish brown colour with a small lacy head. Aroma of grassy hops, caramel and grass. Flavour of grassy hops, raisins, caramel malts and oak. Quite complex. Medium bodied with a slick mouthfeel and a dry, bitterish finish. Very good.

660ml bottle from Whole Foods Columbus Circle, NY

Pours dark brown with a foamy head. Aroma has hints of oak, berries and raisin. Taste is malty and strong with hints of oak and raisin. Nice bitter finish. Well balanced and tasty ale.

Pour is a dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma is of big sweet malts with some dark fruit.  Flavor is some strong dark malts with a little sugar and dark fruit.  Oly hops are left on the tounge as this goes down.  After 2700 ratings there is not much else to say.  An enjoyable sipper.

What a classic!  This is one big assualt on my taste bubs and I love it.  Not a early afternoon beer.  Lots of citrus and malt aroma.  Strong bitter with a good backup from the malt.  Finishes very hoppy and dry.
The only thing slight about this beer is the fruit undertone. The pour and aroma is in your face. Off white head and heavy hops. Smooth n dark.
Keg at BrewDog Edinburgh. Copper colour, medium off-white head. Fruity, hoppy nose. Slight pine note. Taste is big, rich and bitter. Very slight fruity sweetness. Sticky hop finish. Very nice.

I feel like i was prepared for this beer by boulevard nutcracker. The juxtaposition of hops and malt reminded me of the nutcracker but stone does everything that nutcracker doesnt to make is a year round drinker. out of market for 4 more days or so until stone week here in kc. will rereview when very drunk of copious tap portions.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2011 22 oz. bomber. A fierce beer that mostly lives up to its reputation. One whiff of the heavy hops concentration in this ale might knock over less seasoned beer drinkers. The taste, is obviously heavy on the hops end with notes of caramel and citrus mixed in. Its a complex beer and it will kick your ass if you take it lightly. Very enjoyable when Im in the mood for an unconventional ale with attitude to spare.

Bottle.  Dark brown pour, lasting carbonation and aroma of caramel sweetness and hops.  Flavor has a solid malt backbone, more caramel, some bitter citrus and finishes with a bit of spicy hops.  Very good, and decently priced.

garnet/ruby pour with a thick off white head.
aroma is light caramel and chocolate maltiness, brown bread, and some fruitiness, hint of citrusy hop. 
some woodiness in the flavour. burnt caramel maltiness, herbal bitterness.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2011 You will like this ale,just do not smell it,it smells like a cat pissed in a pine forest.Very over-rated cali swill,never again.p.s.think again before you open a new market with bottles that expire in less than 2 months.

Amazing beer here. From the beginning you can smell the hops from about a foot away. You get that huge kick from the hops right when you take a sip from it as well, but it has a nice malty finish so its not to overwhelming.
You can really smell the hops on this beer and the taste is rather strong of hops/bitterness. But it fades quickly and makes it rather enjoyable.

22 oz. Bottle to snifter. Dark clear ruby color with a frothy kahki head that dissipates to a film. Aroma sweet spice malt and some noticable spruce hops. Taste is very hop foward and then follows with malt and spice with some sweet caramel notes. Palate is medium and creamy with a chaulky dry finish. Very good, though I feel the hops really take over this beer. Still enjoyed very much.

Very dark pour, copper, almost wine red. No head. Aroma of fruit, pommegranite, citrus hops. Flavor is intense grapefruit, tart and bitter. Really like drinking a glass of pink grapefruit juice that you would have for breakfast. Not picking up much more than that- wishing for more complexity. Nice beer but I must not be worthy.

Consistently great, always a solid go to beer, one of the best ales out there, and the price is also right.  Great pour, nice head, smells sweet and fruity, taste is strong, sweet, nice hop profile and some big malts backing it up, very smooth, very well balanced, the perfect beer for me, anytime.  One of the go to staples in my fridge.

Fantastic beer.  Dark Amber color with thick white head and incredibly aroma of hops typical of Stone products.  Perfect blend of malt and hops flavor with a fizzy and light texture .  Bitter finish that leaves you wanting more.

It pours a medium clear amber with a light tan head. There are about 2 fingers of head that have great retention and lacing. The head is chunky and pillowy clouds.

The aroma is very strong with hops and mixture of spice dominating.

The flavor is just hoppy to me, nothing complex to wrap your palate around. The beer itself is very strong and bitter and almost burns your lips as you drink it. 

The mouthfeel is heavy but the beer is not very drinkable.

On tap at Adams Ribs in Chester.  Dark opaque amber pour with medium head.  Definitely a lot of flavor.  Solid hop characteristic.  I dont like overly hoppy beers, but this one is well balanced.  Strong flavors, but very good.  Not something you could drink all day though.

22 mar 2011 - on keg
dark ruby, faintly hazy, no bubbles, decent lacing
oddly enough, im getting mango on the nose. not much else.
med body and mildly fizzy.
great! no oak but fruity mango/passion fruit hops. i really like this. much better than bottled.

Aroma: Hints of caramel malts with lots of floral and citrus hops.
Appearance: Dark, dark amber, almost black, with a thick tan head.
Taste: Medium bitterness with hints of sweetness in the finish.
Palate: Full body, creamy, slick texture, average carbonation, and a long finish.
Overall: This is a very finely balanced ale with a nice interplay between its hoppy aggressiveness and its malty undertones.

Mahogany beer with off-white, two-finger head.  Creamy with good lacing.

Big hop aroma--tropical fruits and flowers.  And a huge, dry malt surge behind it.  Thick rye toast and dehydrated caramel.

Huge, fruity hops lead the taste with definite herbal and floral tastes as well.  Right behind the hops is a surge of malts.  Sweet and dry.  Great and complex range of flavors.  Caramel, dense toast, toffee, oats, tea, and some milk chocolate.  

This beer drinks bigger than it actually is.  Its a great presentation of a unique beer.  Not a black ipa, not a double ipa, more than a big brown ale or double amber.  Its a lot of ingredients that are blended together well to create a stand alone flavor.

Pint bottle at the Piccadilly. It pours a deep brown/ruby colour with a thick foamy beige head. The nose is caramel, wood, nut, old socks and some menthol notes. The taste is smokey, caramel, charcoal, milk and dark chocolate, tobacco, wood, nut, marshmallow, vanilla and some cherry. The underlying caramel sweetness balances out the rough and ready bitterness. Surprisingly easy to drink and enjoyable.

Very beautiful amber/copper color with some burnt orange highlights at the bottom.  An off white head that was very pronounced.  Fluffy and creamy.  Very nice retention and some great, great lacing.  The body is mostly hazy also.  Wonderful aromas of sweet caramel.  Dark fruit swirling around on the nose also.  Hop notes and malt character.  Resinous aromas.  Even a bit of peach in there.
