The taste was a wonderful piney, resinous flavor.  Some grapefruit type flavors with a very small alcohol bite.  Enough bitterness to satisfy most anyone.  Caramel sweetness follows to round out this very well balanced taste.  Medium/full mouthfeel.  Smooth and chewy.  A slight bit of "slickness" makes it glide down easy.  Some alcohol warmth right at the back of the throat in the finish.  Really covers the palate well.  Nicely dry in the mouthfeel also.  Man!!!!  This beer is really, really good.  Unbelievably easy to drink considering the bold characteristics and the high ABV.  I dont know how or why I havent tried this yet considering how popular it is.  I definitely wont pass this up ever again.  A very, very nice and well made beer.

Beer pours a rich deep dark cinnamin brown color. Dark, dark brown, but not black. Creamy head that doesnt blow up huge in the glass but manges to last forever. Nose is hoppy and malty. Smells very balanced. Notes of toffee, caramel, sweet alcohol, gingerbread. Palate is firm but not over the top. Nice bitterness. Dried malt. Spice. Slightly meltalic. Its a very very good beer. Not sure that its as good as the ratebeer average, but its still pretty fing good.
Ah nice, its the ruination ale fixed. Strong malts flavors add to the firece attack of hops. Good beer

Pours a clear ruby red with a thick, off-white head. It smelt like very dark roasted malt and citrusy hops. The taste was of very dry, bitter malt and lots of citrusy hops. The hops were very overpowering when combined with the malt, and I think that this beer just didnt work. Not the worst beer, but just kind of blah.

Poured into a snifter. The oaked version of this was my first true love. Back then, a beer like this was as rich and flavorful as they come. Seems like those days are over though. The last Oaked AB I had didnt have the effect it did those years ago given the amount of good beer Ive put down and the growth of my palate since.

4.5 A: Clear deep amber/mahogany color. Nearly three fingers of beige creamy/frothy hybrid head. Average to good retention and plentiful nonuniform lacing.

3.5 S: Caramel, brown sugar, and even a touch of nuttiness. Hops add pine, orangy citrus, and a touch of flowers.

3.5 T: The taste is still aggressive enough to warrant a name like Arrogant Bastard. The first thing I noticed was a decent hop bitterness punch. Orange, grapefruit, and piney hop flavor. Good amount of caramel and toffee malt flavor with a general biscuity maltiness.

3.5 M: Medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Smooth, but could be creamier.

4.0 D: I was glad I had a bomber. AB is a solid beer and a good introduction into the world of higher ABV, more flavorful beers. While now it doesnt impress me like it once did, drinking it again takes me down memory lane when craft beer could not have been any more exciting.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-27-2011 05:45:12

So how can you not like this. Im not sophisticated but I get this brew for sure. Pours dark and a slight red tint. The smell is floral and malty as is the taste. The took the best of the malt world and best of the hop world and brought them together in perfect unity. I cant exclaim the perfection of balance in this beer. The malts are toasty, dark, molasses and carmel. And the  finish is really dry with a good amount of floral hoppiness. Its almost a perfect ending. The transition from front to the back of the experience is rather smooth except one bump in the back. But thats when you taste the oaked arrogant and its perfect through and through.

Red brown with a beige head. Great big hop aromas of citrus, floral & pine over some caramel malt. Sure enough theres lots of bitterness but I expected that this would be a kick in the teeth but it was surprisingly smooth, with a great malt backbone. Just a fantastic mouthfeel. We done get many of the cult beers from the US here so it was a real treat to be able to share this one with friends.

Bottle @ home. Dark orange/brown appearance with a two finger tan head. Caramel/brown malty nose with some nuttiness, toastiness, and quite hoppy. Big toasty caramel malty with a big hoppiness. Sweet hoppy finish. Big beer while still easy drinking.
Draft. Pours brown. Tan head. Nose of toffee, caramel malts and bread. Taste of toffee, brown sugar, caramel and tons of malt. Alcohol is noticeable in the finish.

Bottle; clear dark red to brown with medium tan head; aroma-someone said pine/floral, completely agree- some caramel and molasses; taste- well, dont drink this cold as it would be a waste of money, my first sip was awful but the beer was colder that it should have been. As it warmed up to room temperature, it was a completely different experience-moderate sweetness and light carbonation throughout with medium bitter finish.  Great beer but NOT my favorite so I guess this means I am not worthy

What a great beer.  Arrogant Bastard tempers a mighty sweet center with enormous amounts of hops, attacking your tongue like Billy and Jimmy from the old Double Dragon games.   Pours a beautiful red-brown, frothy beige head, yet the smell is lacking, kinda drab when considered against the flavors within.  Who cares, though, because this beer tastes like the definition of a west coast American Strong Ale.

Bomber.

Ar: Piney hops dominate the foreground, with notes of toffee and molasses.
Ap: Served in snifter at 55F.  Deep hazy mahogany pour with a 3/4" manila head.  A bit of head retention, pretty good lace.
T:  Burnt toffee up front is drowned out by piney hops.  The finish is all piney hop, with little to no alcohol burn.
P: Medium-thick body with medium carbonation.

O:  This is very good, but I dont find it exceptional.

Bottle.  Pours a dark orangey amber with a medium off white head.  Aroma and flavor are dominated by the piney hops, but theres quite a bit of caramel malt and some dark fruit.  Doesnt achieve a balance -- its too bitter for that -- but it is complex and interesting.  Long bitter finish.  Thick, resinous mouthfeel.

Poured from a 1pt plus 6oz bottle.  Pours a deep orange/brown with a medium dark head.  Aroma of malt and a bit like ice tea.  Tastes of malt with a little bit of sweetness to it on the end.  A nice bitter finish.  Overall its a pretty good beer......the label is pretty sweet as well.

Extremely dark amber red with a creamy head that doesnt fade away. It had a distinctive hoppy malty smell. It had a powerful roasty taste and an aftertaste that lasts for quite some time. I was totally impressed by this beer.
Pours a copper color with a medium head. VERY strong and hoppy. Some sweet notes to counter the aggressiveness.

Pours a deep red with khaki head.  There is no question this is a hop heavy brew with pine and some citrus coming through.  I also noted a smooth malt aroma.  There is a sweet taste that fades and a nice bitterness from the hops comes through that is sustained.  This beer becomes quite smooth the further I get into it.
deep mahogany pour.  a strong malty brew, with candy flavors, brown sugar and raisins.  nice hoppy kick at the end.  a hearty beer, but hard to resist a second.  very good.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2011 Amazing beer. The pour is mahogany with bright ruby highlights. The aroma is strong. Arrogance for sure. Huge hop with a lot of dark malts, candied sugars, alcohol and hop finish. The taste is deep with a sweet roasty malt middle and a hop bomb which becomes a moderate alcohol burn. A great beer overall.
Strong and hoppy, easy to mistake for IPA.  Smells malty. Taste the bitter hops first, malts come afterwards with some brown sugar. Dry finish that would be good with some spicy shrimp.

Aroma - Smells like beer
Appearance - nice and dark, good frothy head
Taste - A very solid ale, medium to intense
Palate - good carb, a little bitter
Overall - In the format of the brewery, you really shouldnt waste your time reading my review; I have the intellegence of a 3 year old, even worse when I have been drinking.  But, if you have read this far, it is a solid beer, not solid like a rock solid, but solid like good solid.  Got it?

22 oz rocket. Pours a opaque, hazy, copper. Medium light tan head w/medium lacing. Nice & fragrant aroma with citrus, fresh pine present. Slightly yeasty & malty. Mouthfeel is nice and smooth with a crisp, bitter finish. A great beer. Though its 7.2% abv, no alcohol aroma. Very drinkable.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2011 Ive had this several times but have never reviewed it before. Bomber poured into a pint glass.  Pours a rich mahogany red color, clear and translucent, but dark. Tan, 1/4" head fades a bit but doesnd disappear. Nice lacing.  Aroma is citrusy and piney. Smells great. Tastes great too with a nice malty backbone under all the hops.  A nice, thick, sticky mouthfeel rounds out a great experience.  Outstanding beer with a great balance.

The beer pours a dark brown color with a tan head. The aroma is heavy on the piney hops and the caramel malt. The flavor is very hoppy and high in alcohol. I get a lot of pine and orange, as well as some caramel malt. Still, this beer is all about the hops and the bitterness is about medium. Fairly boozy overall. Low carbonation and medium mouthfeel.

Dude, its Arrogant Bastard.  If you need a review of Arrogant Bastard, maybe start with something with less of an edge and work your way up.  Its hoppy, its tasty,  and reading the bottle makes you feel like you are better than everyone else.  Wins all around.

22oz bomber and on tap.
Ive had this beer many, many times - one of the first to get me into craft beer.  I was intrigued by the name alone, anything with bastard in the title is right up my alley.  Deep red color with wonderful lacing.  Incredible pine and citrus bitter hop aroma and flavor - pefrectly bitter.  Scary drinkable - a great example of what good beer can be.

Pours dark,hazy amber with a medium reddish-brown head.  Heavy alcohol and hops aroma.  Medium to heavy bitterness.  Somewhat heavy body with a slightly thick texture.  The finish is bitter but doesnt hang around long.  This is an aggressive beer as the label suggests.  I wouldnt buy this on a regular basis but its a good beer after hard day.

This beer is fucking awesome.

If you describe it any other way, you should probably not be drinking it.  You are probably a pussy.

Long live The Bastards.

What an OUTSTANDING ALE! Super hoppy head with a nice carmel/toffee malt fbody and finish. I LIKE it. Im a HOP HEAD so, this beer fits in right with what I like. I like super hoppy beers with a touch of malt quality and this one shines. Highly recommended.
I dont really know what all is in here. Ok. This I do know. I like it and it gets feeling feisty.

Bottle. Clear mahogany red pour with a lasting, fluffy tan head. Aroma is quite hoppy with grapefruit, lime, melon, tangerine and pine notes but also has a healthy amount of malty toffee, nuts, honey and spice. Sweet nutty, toffee malt notes are even more dominant in the flavour and while there is a little less fruitiness from the hops there is still lots of piney grassiness and nice dose of bitterness. Slightly oily mouthfeel with prickly carbonation and some noticeable but well integrated alcohol. I suppose this beer does come across as kind of arrogant but in an oddly endearing way. Very nice and very easy to drink, even sessionable, despite the abv.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2012 Pours a deep opaque red with a medium off white head. Aromas of dark fruits matched with piney hops. Some sweetness cuts through as well. Aroma is replicated in the mouth. Sweet caramel cuts through the drak fruits. Balanced out by a great hoppy bitterness. Mouthfeel is good, creamy. A very good brew overrall. Just found out that it is the biggest selling craft beer in 650 ml bottles throughout the US

Deep Copper with small tan head.
Nose is roasty and caramel malt.
Medium body. Resiny hops +roasted Malts. Hint of dark fruit.
Lingering bitter finish.

always a good go-to.
Pour is  deep ruby red with a large off white head. Nose is mostly of caramel, and distinctly sweet with some notes of dark fruits. Taste is predominately of caramel and very sweet considering.

220z bottle poured into a tulip glass. Enjoy by date is 2/14/11. Pours an opaque reddish brown with three fingers of frothy foam. Good lacing. Nose is a bit subtle. Syrupy sweet roasted malt with a bit of bite from the hops. Full bodied with low carbonation. Drinks like a breast. Not too rich or syrupy in texture though. Nice, resiny hops cut the malty sweetness to make it more drinkable. Nice roasted, almost nutty flavors play on the palate before a wave of hop bitterness cuts through all that to the point that you think your palate might be ruined for the next sip. Bright, bitter hops linger on the finish. Every time I have this I am reminded how good it is. This is the definition of a classic microbrew.

S-smells great! full of hops but at the same time fruity. 
A-amber, hazy with one finger of whittish head that recedes quickly. 
T-Boom! its bitter, very bitter, but in a great way! Spicy and sweet, like theres caramel in it. This will be a great beer to pair with so many foods. 
M-medium bodied, hop will hit you right away but goes away smoothly. Cant even stop drinking once I took my first sip. 
D-so drinkable, and will drink again.

On tap at Stone brewing with many friends. Dark reddish brown pour with a moderate fast disappating head. Aromas of California hops and sweet roasted malts. Smells of grapefruit with piney resins. At first sip or sniff the hops dominate the senses. Taste grows more complex with additional  sips and as the beer warms. Incredible how the strong hop flavors can be so well balanced with the stiff malt backbone. Not for the uninitiated or those who dont appreciate the hoppiness of California microbrews. This brew is worthy!
Bought in Wisconsin.  They told me they were no longer distributing in WI area and this was their last bottle.  Too bad, cause id buy again
Pours dark red with an excellent, lingering head. Hoparific, but not without a very sweet aroma. Taste is extremely complex, a little grassy.
Strong and good. A beer that destroy the mouth in a good sense. Not for the faint of heart.

Bottle pour in Lake Tahoe. As the bottle clearly states, this beer is not for wusses. It claims to be everything other beers arent - bold, bitter, in your face - and delivers. Loved the big, lingering head and full body, but the bitterness drowned out the other flavors and is a little much for my palate
First tasted this at Bonefish Grill, loved it.  Have had it since at the same joint.  Now I will be looking for it at Crown Liquor.
Awesome!!!!!!  A favorite micro form back when I started drinking micros!!!

Deep chestnut brown with amber tinges. Aroma is grapefruit, fig, and pine. Taste  is dominated by American Cascade hops. A little bit of sweet malt, and then pure IBUs. Extra long dry finish, but also straight forward.  I am a certified hop head, and this is a good beer, but it lacks that lively hop complexity that I love in IPAs and strong ales from the Pacific Northwest. The hops just kind of hit your palate, hang out for a minute, then leave. They dont dance on your tongue like Stone IPA. Oh yeah, let this one warm up to at least 50 - 55 degrees, it really opens up when it is a little warmer.
Very well made beer,  lots of crystal malt taste without too much crystal mouth feel.  Bitterness lingers a little bit in the mouth for me, but Id have another one.
This beer has a good hop flavor and after taste. It scores more points than McNabb and lasts longer than my cell battery.

peach like aroma is the only way i can describe it full flavored thin off white head pours dark brown, first taste i get slight coffee flavor, slight fruit like flavor, with some bitterness but pretty dry beer overall very good beer not overpowering the least bit good balance of flavor

Powerful and real quality beer.  Big aroma of resin and grapefruit bitterness and some gentle malt sweetness. Assertice flavour, big fruity citric bitterness, some restrained caramel and a little warming alcohol, which is surprising to detect at 7% over all those hops. Big body and slightly oily texture.  I mightnt "have the taste or sophistication to appreciate an ale of this quality", but I certainly like it.

Dark caramel malts aggressively balanced by classic american hops. Assertive bitterness balances the significant sweetness and gravity. Not a session beer but a good example of a distinctly American taste.

Appearance: Murky chestnut brown. Some off-white head.
Aroma: Good amounts of fruit. Some sweetness.
Taste: Wow, much more bitter than I expected. Tangy. Not for me.
Info: 650ml bottle, 19/11-2010

Aroma: a lot going on here, sugary dough and bread, figs, and maybe hazelnut, Appearance: kind of a murky reddish brown to be honest, not much of a head upon pour, Taste: absolutely awesome, immediately confronted by the resiny and juniper hops, which you dont get much of in the aroma, but you certainly get plenty of in the taste, you also get that burnt sugar, caramel flavor from the malt, this is one of those beers that does a really, really good job at balancing the hops with the malt; Palate: sweet and bitter aftertaste, good carbonation, doesnt offend with any particular flavor overpowering the other, perfectly balanced and wonderfully drinkable; Overall: I love this beer, one of the best that Ive had from Stone (Ive had several even though I havent rated them all), I will definately be bringing this one home to my brothers and my dad over Christmas this year, Id recommend it to anyone
Nose is malt, citrus, caramel, grapefruit, resinous hop character. Taste is the same and super bitter with hop and caramel character. Great. what got me liking good beer.

An amazing Beer, so very heavy in hops it kicks you right in the mouth in a tasty Hops explosion!It pours a Reddish-brown color with a good head. The aroma has hints of roasted malts, caramel, Heavy hops, piney, just a very strong and Delicious beer for those interested in a good quality in-your-face taste.
The smell of this beer is great. The taste was less robust than I assumed though. Anormal tasting ale with a decent amount of hoppiness.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2011 Pours brown with a slight tinge of red, with a light brown head. Smell is of hops. Taste is again hops, with a hint of citrus. Overall a delicious beer that will be stoked in my house regularly.

Bottle from the evil empire of beer on the prairies. Pours a nice dark amber with a lasting thin head. Caramel, floral hops, pine hops, sweet and resiny with hidden fresh malts. Oh god, its all I hoped it would be. Taste is similar to aromas, lots of hops. Pine,floral and caramel. Plenty of sweetness all balanced to near perfection, This is what beer should taste like. $15 well spent.
Botte @ Hotelroom, Denver, Co. pours deep amber with nice light brown head. Caramel, malt, hops with grapefruit, pine, even a resinlike tone. Taste caramel and malt, hops, fruit. Medium body. 041210

Pours a reddish-hued brown with a nice head and plenty of lacing. The aroma starts out with plenty of bitter, resinous hops as well as some toasted malt and accompanying sweetness. Good caramel scent, which follows through into the flavor with a bit of toffee. Some floral hops alongside the bitter piney hops. Medium-bodied and well carbonated; very drinkable.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 01-17-2010

22oz bottle.  Dark mahogany color.  Small head, leaves a lot of lacing.  Get a lot of hops in the aroma, but my sinuses are pretty stuffed so Im having trouble picking anything else out.  Starts off sweet with caramel and roasted malt and balances off by ending with a -lot- of hops.  Nice chewy body.
Brown of color with a beige head. An aroma of malt, bread and hops. A flavor of hops, toffee, grapefruit and pines
I have had this several times and it has been great every one. Once you get used to the huge amount of hoppiness it is really enjoyable.
Color is dark brown with a lasting light brown head.  Aroma is of slight toffee, alcohol, burnt leaves.  Taste is of toasted caramel, malt, alcohol, and some hops.

Bomber in shaker.  Medium dark brown with reddish hints. light tan head that faded to a ring after a while. smell of dried red cherries and bitter roasted malt. grapefruit. long finish. tasty, complex. big. bitter. nicely balanced.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2015 Dark reddish-brown with an off white head. Aroma of caramel, dark fruit, toast, and citrusy hops. Taste is really nicely balanced; plenty sweet and with nice bitter and spicy hops. Somewhat dry, a little sticky, medium bodied. Nice. One of the most well balanced beers around.

For some reason even before I bought this beer I new I was gonna love it. You open it pour it or sip out the bottle and ur first thought is how how hoppy and strong it is and within in a second you Just accept this is a amazing beer. Smells great, pours a beautiful hazy brown and taste great. definatly on my top 5 favs

22oz bottle. Poured a murky deep copper with a touch of brown. Sticky caramel, toasted malt, raison bread, and hop make the nose. On mouth this ale is full bodied while creating a nice chewy malt coating with a hop cleansing finish.
Beautiful aroma with notes of citrus and caramel, to name a few.  Tasteful  West Coast style beer with a creamy-bitterness that lasts.

Pours  deep ruby copper color with nice tanned thick head. Aroma well hoppy, caramel, malts and fruits. Flavor is fruity citrus, hoppy and a bit sweet, very good indeed.  Nice sweetish palate feel. Finish is great hoppy to balance out the sweet beginning.

650mL bottle.  Pours hazy dark amber with a medium tan head that settles to a thick ring and light surface covering and leaves a small amount of lacing.  Aromas of caramel, toffee, honey, pine and citrus.  Medium sweetness, a fair amount of malt, medium bitterness.  Aroma and flavour both a bit muddled.  Medium body, soft carbonation, fairly slick with a lingering bitter finish.

Pours Medium Dark red-orange amber with 2 finger lite brown foarmy head. sparse lacing. Smell is mildly floral and fruity, malts, hops. Taste is Bid biting bitter Hops up front with the malts and fruity sweet esters taking a back seat. Medium body, medium carbonation, Hops bite and dryness with some alcohol warmth. If you like Big Hops buy this. The malts and sweet esters and citrus come out more as it warms, I like hops as my rating shows!

22 oz bottle. So happy to have Stone in Chicago, have had the oaked arrogant bastard already, now trying the regular version. Pours a dark copper brown color with a small bubbly tan head. Smells of caramel, citrus, hops, toffee, and alcohol. Tastes fairly similar, with the caramel providing a bit of bite to it, and the alcohol only providing a light warming sensation at the end. Great body and character to it, with an aftertaste that sticks around. Very impressive beer, and I think I enjoy it more than the oaked version.

Masterful head on top of a dark ruby red pour a check on the carbonation tis medium aroma caramel honey earthy dark fruit citrus plum cherry flavour honey cherry sweetness caramel dark toffee very smooth ale  plum a good bitter flavour raisin like taste the aftertaste bitter mildly sweet and lasting

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2017 [10/10] Bottle. Dark reddish amber with a large beige head. Aroma has pine and grapefruit with nectarines, passionfruit and caramel. Assertive bitterness with some stone fruit, caramel and chocolate mostly obscured behind it. Bitter but not dry finish with some surprisingly raw alcohol for 7ish%. Lovely fresh hop aroma, but after that its mainly loud - although its not overflavoured, its as though everything is trying to be louder than everything else. Its not the phaal of beers I thought it might be but neither is it the crude rambunctious charmer I hoped it might be. OK, if a little irritating in an adolescent sort of a way. [3.4][10/09] Havent come around on this at all - Looks good, smells good but is all presence in the mouth. 8 4 6 2 14 [2/17] Can. Still "as though everything is trying to be louder than everything else. Its not the phaal of beers I thought it might be but neither is it the crude rambunctious charmer I hoped it might be" but eh, its tasty enough.

A deep, red, cloudy pour. Its got a faint, yeasty, malty smell to it. Its a dry, hoppy, tangy taste with a foamy head. Its got a slightly sweet but bitter aftertaste. Its not that different from the Ruination IPA, but not as good. Stick with Ruination.
Bomber at Charmichaels Steakhouse. Waitress poured into frozen mug before I could stop her. Argh. Caramel aroma; flavor is same plus some piney hoppiness and a bit of alcoholic warmth. Nice beer.

Clear dark copper with a small head that holds well.  Great looking beer.  Sweet caramel, piney hops and honey on the nose.  Complex.  Woah, strong palate that is super aggressive.  Bitter yet controlled, sweet yet balanced.  Strong bite on the finish with more caramel, honey and spice flavours. Big drink but a great beer.

Indeed, I am not worthy.  This arrogant ale epitomizes the essence of the new (or recently new) craft brewer. Nose is floral, alpha hops in your face with notes of roasted malt; pour is lush, rich amber with beige protein-frothed head. Taste is a nice but aggressive combo of bittering and flavoring hops with a serious malt backbone; the best Ive had from Stone.

Aroma was nice but not powerfull (but the beer might have been to cold). The beer was beautiful, and especially the head was impressive. Malty flavour with tons of hops - nice. A fantastic beer which at the time I drank it was almost to powerful - I am not worthy.

Bottle from Tiffanys Kalamazoo. Dark copper colour, white head. Nose is caramel malts, fruits, very hoppy. Taste of caramel malts, dark fruits, hops, orange, citrus, resin. Strong malty backbone. Nice bitter finish. Excellent stuff.

Poured into a pint glass. Appearance is a clear amber with a white head that dissipates relatively quickly. Aroma is of banana nut bread. Taste is malty with a bit of a bitter hop finish. Smooth mouthfeel and very easy to drink. I understand why this is called Arrogant Bastard. A great brew from a great brewery.

22 oz bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, served in a snifter. Pours clear mahogany with a tall off-white head. The head remains and leaves copious dense lace. The nose has aromas of grapefruit, pine, resin, caramel and molasses. The flavour is moderately bitter up front and becomes more so towards the end. There are strong notes of resin, citrus and caramel. The finish is long and intensely bitter. On the palate, it is full in body with a dry texture and lively carbonation. Overall, this is an excellent ale. It pours beautifully, has a delicious West Coast hop aroma, fresh malts and a long, intensely bitter finish. Another triumph from Escondido! 2010-10-16
Bottle. Pours a nice copper color with a tan head. Aroma has a good bit of hops. Flavor is nice and hoppy. The alcohol does not come through very much at all. Very nice offering.
This beer is quite tasty.  Nice hop flavor but not overpowering.  The alcohol content is definitely present in the flavor, but not dominant.  Smooth texture and mouthfeel.  Nice lacing as well.

I poured a pint from a 22, and I gotta say, it was bitter, very bitter. While I got the other flavors from it, it just was bitter, add had a very dry bitter after taste. I have been a fan of the oaked version of this beer, which I found to be a lot smoother, I have to chalk this experience up to the beer being old or slightly skunked. That being said, I still enjoyed the flavor while drinking the brew.

Pours amber with a nice sized tan head. Slightly bitter like an IPA. Taste is caramel, citrus, and hops. Relatively smooth with a dry finish. Very enjoyable. 

K-2.7
S-3.8

22oz bottle.Pours a dark copper with a huge off white head.Nose is citrus hops,caramel and bready yeasty malts.Taste is citrus,pine and chalky hops with a sweet malty backbone.Very big yet balanced beer.Ive tried this beer many times and it never disappoints!

Awesome brew that tasted better than expected and went down smooth.  
Poured from 22oz bottle into pint glass.  
A-  Large off-white head and beautiful copper color
S-  Strong complex smell I cant put my finger on
T-  Carmel and malt with hint of hops
D-  Extremely smooth but has a nice kick.  Drinkable for a strong ale.
Bottle had 10/24/10 drink by date, drank on 10/03/10 and beer was still extremely fresh.
Im trying just about every Stone beer this month.  So far everything has been excellent.
this brew gave me aids then turned around and cured it thanks !!!!!!!!

This is probably the beer that most people know Stone for in my area, mostly due to its name. This is a great beer that has the hop complexity that I enjoy. Overall, I would buy this beer again and recommend it to all

Bottle 750 ml. Dark amber with a rocky head. Tiny bubbles. Aroma is resin with a small touch of citrus and caramel. Taste is caramel, malty, herbs. Not too bitter, well balance. Good, better than the oak age version.

I had this on numerous occasions so it time to review it . The glass has a nice tan colored head that fades slowly to a thick lace. The body of the brew is almost a ruby red in color.

Its a stone product for sure when it comes to the hopping and that is the first thing you get in the nose big old pine and citrus hops. The pretty much dominate the nose. The flavor is not as one dimensional as one would expect from Stone. They sometimes forget the malts in their products I think but this brew is more balanced. You get a nice malt sweetness from it I find myself at times thinking maybe it is a little too sweet. The brew had medium body and carbonation to it.

A great beer that I never second guess about grabbing or ordering on tap and one is never enough

bottle poured into tulip glass.hoppy apricot aroma which was pleasing. Head wasnt very large, On my second glass I actually poured pretty aggresively to give it a larger. A ruddy amber in appearance. For the taste is starts out pretty hoppy and developed a sort of sweet taste with an extremely bitter aftertaste. I would say that it is clean in h sense that it kept my mouth tingling. Overall I would say that this is a good beer but not a great beer. I felt like the complexities and the pleasures in the taste were somewhat diminished by the discomfort caused by the bitterness. I think the description on the back of the beer is put there so that people will try to ignore that discomfort so they can believe they are sophisticated.

On Tap at Proof for $5, Ive had it plenty, just first review. Poured into Pint glass, thick head, dark ruby color. First sip is hop heavy, followed by a citrus aftertaste and a deep dry malty finish. The alcohol is present but not overbearing. The perfect beer to sit around and drink with old friends, but not too quickly.

Living in Kansas, I dont often have the opportunity to get great fresh beer from the coasts.  Sure, we have access to big breweries like Sierra Nevada, Rogue, and Samuel Adams, but we dont have access to those "chic" breweries.  One such name is Stone, a brewery that Ive always admired from afar but never had the opportunity to sample.  On a recent trip to Denver I made it a point to seek out a bevy of beers that I just cant get here locally, including several from Stone.  For tonight, I figured that I may as well start with the beer that is arguably Stones most famous, Arrogant Bastard.  I have to admit that Im both nervous and excited to try this beer.    This one is a 22 ounce bomber, with the famous Stone Gargoyle on the front.  As if I wasnt intimidated enough theres the phrase Youre Not Worthy greeting me as I crack the bottle open.  

Im treating this beer as I would a Belgian, as surprisingly outside the name I know very little about it.  So that means that Im using my Chimay chalice.  Blasphemy you say?  Well, considering the name is Arrogant Bastard, I figured it appropriate.  Pours similarly to a Belgian beer as well, a deep amber color.  The color is the first thing that surprises me about this beer, as its much darker, bordering on brown, than I expected.  Half inch head that dissipates but leaves a fine bubbly lacing along the sides of the glass.  Nice.  

Aroma is surprisingly malty.  Considering Stones profile (i.e. California, I was expecting this to be quite hoppy, but again thats not the case.  Its a complex smell, and my first thought was of pretzels, like the big soft pretzels you can get on a street corner.  Theres some sweetness to the malt aroma as well, kind of like a French loaf or something similar.  I want to say that there are some faint fruit aromas, like figs or other dark fruits.  This aroma is just fantastic.  I could smell it all day.  

Mouthfeel is pretty tremendous.  Its thick without being syrupy, full without being sticky.  While the hops were not present in the nose theres this super huge lingering bitterness that smothers your palate, choking it from the front to the back with your first drink.  And again, the Arrogant Bastard surprises me, as it tastes like nothing I was expecting.  Theres this huge, full-on malt sweetness up front, which gives way to a dryness before heading into the bitterness at the end.  I attribute the middle dryness to house character that seems to be present in all of Stones beers.  When tasting the beer Im surprised at how fruity it really is, as I get these huge hits of raisin and fig on my palate.  Whats amazing is how the sweetness just evaporates in the middle, giving way to this dryness and then the big bitterness.  Its a really incredible feat to move from the sweet to dry realm so quickly.  

This is a Belgian beer without the Belgian yeast.  Arrogant Bastard only gets better the longer you let it warm up.  The fruit flavors and malt profile are amplified the closer that it gets to room temperature.  Its a delicious beer, and I can easily see why so many people enjoy it.  Overall Im quite impressed with it, and I have absolutely nothing to add but wow.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2011 Poured from 22 oz bottle, enjoyed during the wake of a soon-to-be-epic late summer Chicago storm.  Ive had this before, plus Ive had the Oaked version, so I knew what I was expecting.  Oaked version seems to have more aroma, this is relatively faint with a nice malt character and a small portion of dark fruit.  Appearance is a cloudy caramel with a good sized head.  Taste is a great balance of grapefruit and malt with a fantastic hop presence.  Awesome beer.

Pours a dark amber with minimal off-white head. Aroma of pineapple and citrus, specifically grapefruit. Taste is bitter grapefruit with some toasty malt notes. Aftertaste is bitter grapefruit rind. Smooth mouthfeel. Nice beer. Very affordable and good tasting.

On atap at Maggies on the River, Watertown, NY. Dark mahogany color with a small thick head that fades to lacing. Malt & grain aroma with a trace of citrus mixed in. Starts with a nice crispness & moves to a nice malt with come citrus taste. Has a nice bitter finish with a slight nutty aftertaste. Medium body, quite smooth and the 7.2 ABV peeking through not overpowering. Good Brew, nice for the style. Nicely balanced, a really good sipper when kicking back.

Hazy brown pour with a frothy brown head that persists and leaves a heavy lace. Resinous hops in the nose and mouth, strong malt character keeps pace with the hops. Earthy and wood tones with spruce hops make this an aggressively flavored beer. Balanced with great mouth feel tending to oiliness and a long bitter finish that is pleasant. Ive had this in bottle and on tap all over the States and its never disappointed. Still stands up to the best Strong Ales.

Poured from a 22 ounce bomber into a Samuel Adams Perfect Pint glass. Enjoy by 11 07 10 printed on bottle.

Appearance: Pours a deep mahogany brown with hints of ruby and a fluffy tan 3 finger head. Great head retention. Very nice lacing throughout.

Smell: Floral and piney hops with hints of pineapple and toasted malt.

Taste: Grapefruit and sweet citrus up front followed by toasted malt in the middle then bitter citrus and alcohol at the finish. Aftertaste is bitter lemon rind. The alcohol really comes out as the beer warms up.

Mouthfeel: Medium-to-full-bodied with a moderate amount of carbonation.

Drinkability: Very good drinkability. You could knock a few back over the course of an evening.

Overall: Excellent beer overall. I would highly recommend this one.
22 oz bottle. Smells of hops and alcohol. Dark brown color, strong head. It has a strong hops taste throughout and ends very bitter. A good beer but can get rather tiring.

Pours out a drownish orange, very deep in color, with a frothy sticky ivory head that literally lasted until the end of the 1 pint 6 oz.  The odors I detected were leather, grapefruit, and a bit of citrusy hops.  Taste is mighty powerful, hard to grasp, and hard to enjoy.  But truthfully, once it warms up a little, its actually pretty outstanding.  Tastes included a bit of grassy hops with a forceful ammount of grapefruit.  My wife said it was basically fermented grapefruit juice.  Towards the finish, a bit of malt sweetness pokes through, but fades into a bit of sour finish.  Not so bad once it warms and you get used to it, but boy, that was a long pint to finish.

nice copper tinted head.  Faint hops on the nose.  Full-bodied!  Abundant hops on the tongue!  palate is bitter grapefruit and some fruit - apple or melon?  Great beer and I am not surprised at the high ratings, but seems to sacrifice flavor for bitterness which leads to a lower rating from me.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2012 Brown coloured beer with some average carbonation and a large off-white head. Fruity (passionfruits?) caramel malty and hoppy hinted aroma. Full creamy palate. Finish is bitter hoppy with some extreme bitter and malty caramel roasted ending. Medium. Rerated bottle @ RBBWG 2012

Pours medium brown with 2-inch head in a trappist glass.  Smells of hops and chocolate.  More bitter than anything else.  Not as much sweetness as I excepted.  Flavors is a mild coffee.  Palate is super smooth and fairly well carbonated.  Too bitter for my taste but can see why people enjoy it.

Pour a dark amber color with an almost tan head.The aroma is a blend of malt and floral hoppyness.The flavor is a strong hoppy bitterness with malty sweetness and a tinge of booze.Gose down real smooth and the aftertaste is a strong bitterness that gets stronger as you drink.Overall this is a beer that lives up to its name which Im proud to say I love.
22 oz bottle. Pours a deep reddish brown. A toasty caramel aroma with spices and citrus. Quite bitter with some sweetness. A very good, complex beer- the more I drink it, the better it gets.

Dark amber, almost brown, it formed a thick tan head with fine bubbles that stayed.  It has a citrus and earthy aroma and a caramel malt flavor accented by a mild bitterness.  It has a heavy body but a creamy and smooth mouth feel.

Clear, dark amber pour with a sweet malty aroma of medium intensity from a good head sustained throughout the drink.  Very full-bodied and complex liquor that was almost simultaneously bitter, sweet and alcoholic AND with a nicely balanced hop/malt profile.  

This is a complex, intense beer with a long finish. At a recent tasting of about fifteen friends the general consensus was evenly divided:  the ale clearly was liked or not liked by the drinker; no taster needed to reserve judgment and mull over a response.

Bomber. Pours a cloudy dark amber color with a thick, bubbly layer of light brown head. The aroma is caramel malt, herbal hops and orange citrus. The taste kicks off with lots of toasted malt and caramel flavors followed by intense bitterness, resinous hops and sour grapefruit. Mouthfeel is full-bodied and creamy with a citrusy, alcohol warming finish. The hops are assertive and aggressive throughout but are always kept in check by the malt. Well-balanced and highly drinkable although you probably dont want to drink more than one bomber of this stuff.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2010 Shared with Carrie, Jodi, John, Deante and Ella. Smells better than it tastes. Smells smooth - sweet. Cloudy red color with immediate hard that dissipates quickly. Sharp, metallic bite in the first sip, with nutty undertones on the aftertaste. Takes time to smooth out.

I may not be worthy, but Ill take it whenever and wherever I can find it.

Beautiful mahogany ale with a tannish head. Roasted malts on the nose and some subtle sweetness to battle with the hoppiness.  Talk about nicely balanced.

Smooth and strong, bitter yet slightly sweet.

Bottle. Saved this for my 100th review.. as I have often been referred to likewise. Pours a delectable burnished amber with a strong hop explosion in the nose. The creamy head does not last.. but leaves a decent amount of lace down the glass. The flavor is a crisp, spicy hops with a distinct sweet malting. Mild acidic taste, but that is balanced well with the hops. The body is full and rich with a crisp clean feel. A faintly sweet, mostly bitter somewhat dry finish. A great brew.
Great product that certainly lives up to its name. My only real complaint would be that hops and alcohol just over power the subtler flavor notes. Still super good though!

22oz bottle.  Again another solid offering from stone that Ive had many a time.  Little bit of a dark golden color on the pour, notes of some booze, but citrus and some pine as expected.  Palate is heavy and hoppy but that stone flavor profile is present lots of citrus and a hell of a bite.  Its solid and Id drink it, but not my favorite Stone offering.
Pours a nice light brown with a tightly laced head.  Aroma of hops and sweet malt.  Pretty medium bodied with nicely toasted malt and herbal hops dominated the taste with some nice spice.  Very good.

Im a n00b to beer ratings, but dammit, Jim...it seems like people can put pipe sludge into a bottle, call it a craft beer, and sell it by the metric fuckton. Ive drunk craft ale that I swear tasted like bong water.

This is, without a doubt, the finest beer on the market.  The ONLY reason I didnt give it a 5.0 is because the bomber bottle taste falls a little flat to me (as opposed to draught).  Get this from the tap and you will stay until last call.  Ruby color, awesome gorgeous creamy head....i almost feel like im sinking my face into a loaf of crustless pumpernickel bread when I drink it.  

This beer hits you you like a ton of bricks. I urge you to sit down in a nice soft easy chair as you imbibe this lovely brew.  

Belgian Monks would be proud of this double stout.

Ive already had this beer a couple times, but have never had the chance to rate it. Pours mahogany with pretty head, hoppy and malty and lightly sweet on the nose. Some resin? Alcohol? Whatever. Tastes good, of course, a little citrus, pine and caramel to compliment the nice lingering hoppy aftertaste. Dry enough. 

I mean, its not the best beer Ive ever had, but its so much more economical than some of the other things Im fond of... solid.

22oz bomber poured into a tulip.

Pours a deep, hazy amber brown, very cola-ish, with a small thick beige head that recedes to a hefty cap and leaves some clings streaks of lacing.

The aroma is very hoppy with bright citrus, including lemons and tangerines, and some floral pine.  There is a light malty sweetness in the background but the hops are dominant in the nose.

The hops lead the charge in the taste as well with bitter/tart lemon zest up front.  The backbone is malty with lots of caramel and toasted malts.  But the sweetness is swept away again in the finish, which leaves a dry hoppy bitterness.

The mouthfeel is bitter, dry and prickly with the bright citrus leaving a nice coating on the tongue.  Moderate carbonation and medium body overall.

This is a very tasty beer, especially given its relatively low ABV, and the hops are the main attraction here.  Id probably prefer it a little more balanced but thats not exactly Stones style.

I dont want to get into the details of such a complex beer, but I love this beer, its one of the best beers in the world. Everyone should try it once. It has an amazing flavor, a good texture, nice look and smell.

wow!  ive never rated the bastard before?  as one of the brews that got me into enjoying craft beer, and since i happen to be drinking one right now, what better for my 200th rating?

pours a beautiful red amber, with a thick light tan head that fades into pillows and leaves great lacing all over the glass.  ive always considered this one of the prettiest beers available.  deep, grand smell of piney and citrusy hops mixed with a great, complex malt character, featuring a nutty bread but mingled with a roasty character.  taste is kind of like that, but a bit fruitier, with a grape character and an earthy note joining the complex malt and hop interplay.  finishes moderately bitter with a perfect lightly sweet malt balance.  medium thick of body, great, abundant, big carbonation (not champagne big, but not exactly creamy, either), that makes it feel bubbly and tingly.  this has the features of some of my favorite stand-bys (e.g. great lakes burning river), but the crystal is toned down, and theres a dark malt note that really shapes this one.  stone sure does know how to make a beer!  this is a favorite, and i must make it a point to drink more of it!
UPDATED: MAY 13, 2011 Sweet on the front with a slightly bitter (dry) aftertaste, good balance but its more bitter than even most double ipas. A little watery. Decent, if nothing great.
Bottle: Pours a dark amber, with moderate tan head. nice lacing. Smells a little like sweet bread. Flavors are similar, with a hoppy bite and a malty finish. I enjoyed my first american strong ale.

22oz in Kwak glass.  Clearish red-brown with lasting buff head and silly lacing.  Woody, piney, grapefruit, and pineapple nose; a bit of nacho cheedum shows up too.  Flavor is brisk, bitter, herbal and resinous, but also a bit sweet, soothing, and rustic; comes off a bit like a homemade cough syrup.  Pretty substantial body and long, coating finish.

Had with Katie at my house. Pour is a clear Burgundy. Lacing head that is just a little off white.  Aroma is alcohol, malts, and some caramel. Flavor is complex mix of sweet malts, alcohol and raisins. Nice brew indeed.

Pour form a 22 oz bottle. Deep amber brew with tan head. Fine aroma dominated by resin and citrus hops. Flavor leans to the sweet side  cloyingly sweet ultimately. Sound hoppiness offsets the sweetness, not bad at all.

Pours dark red.  Off white creamy head.  Did not get a lot of hop citrus aromas.  Some malt.  Definitely taste the bitterness of the hops balanced well with the malt flavors.  A bitter finish that is left with you for several seconds.  Excellent beer.

Very good on the nose, malts mixed with piney, resiny hops, and some caramel. Large off-white head that has staying power and knows how to lace a glass, dark amber with ruby highlights.  medium+ body with a bitter, dry aftertaste.  The taste is well balanced between the malts and the hops.  A very nice beer.
Wonderful balanced roast/hop aroma.  A deep reddish-brown with a tanish head.  A robust  hap/grain flavor.  Thick and almost chewy.  Great coating, lasting flavor.  Nice roasty finish.

Bottle. Pours ruby-brown with dense beige head. Aroma is has lemon and orange zest, mango, candied fruit, light tartness, a little pine and a little prickly alcohol in the background. Very full palate, pleasantly thick, medium carbonation. Flavor is a little on the sweet side, quite a bit of pine-resiny and mild citrus-like bitterness, along with some soil-like hop resin notes, starting in the middle and lingering into a long finish along with a good deal of astringent alcohol bite.
Pours a dark red/amber color with a large white head, has aroma full of malt and alcohol, very strong malt backbone with a hint of hops to it, Stone sure knows how to brew!

Arrogant Bastard Ale...are you worthy? Well, most of us arent but luckily Im part of the group that loves this brew. Pours out a nice deep red color with a slight haziness to it with a nice sizable head with good retention and strong lacing. I loved that aspect of the beer. The aroma was great as well. Mostly malts and hops with a slight pine and citrus component in the background. Its flavor is what you would expect from an Arrogant, it has a dry bitter taste offered by the hops on a low carbonated body and dry finish although its not the smoothest beer but its still shines. Amazing.

Biscuity malt aroma, also chocolate, fantastic nutty texture to the malt, great bitterness, gorgeous dark brown colour, crystal malts, leather, sweet malts, good drinkability considering the abv. A solid beer. Tap, the Rake. p.s. this was a little tired.....

Bottle.  Aggressive as suggested but not over-extreme, just rightly-extreme.  Strong malty medium-body caramelized maltiness counterstriked by a citrusy, slighlty piny and resinous powerful hopping.  Quite peppery.  Highly enjoyable.

This is a terrible beer. There is nothing subtle about it.  It is massive bitterness which destroys the ability to taste anything else in this beer and anything that comes afterward.  I suppose it could be a sipper, but even sipping a microliter of this by using a nano-straw provides too much bitterness.  This is the 5th or 6th time Ive tried this beer, each time with a 22 oz bomber, and each time I cant make it through the 22 ounces.   I dont know why I keep buying it.  Im either fooled by the advertising strategy, or fooled by the high ratings this beer keeps getting.

Had this on tap.  It is strong.  Strong in color, aroma and taste.  It was dark red with a blend of rich caramel, toast and bitterness in both the aroma and flavor.  It lingered and remained bitter.  I like this as a sipping beer.
This is good. Really good. Arrogant Bastard is loaded with flavor... bitter, caramel, roasty. Did I mention I like Stone? Yeah Stone makes great beer, this is no exception.

Got in draught. Is a dark rich reddish brown. Medium sized light brown head. Smells of caramel and a bit earthy. Taste fairly strong of hops, fruits, and caramelly at the finish. A bit bitter. Quite tasty.
Im not worthy because this beer is awesome. heave flavor with a thick  body.
Pine hops aroma with a cloudy orange brown color.  Assertive hops bitterness upfront.  Fascinating malty tobacco aftertaste.   Clean and easy drinking... overall, good stuff!

Draught at the Pub, Monte Carlo Hotel, LV. Rich and loaded with flavour. Another beer that the term liquid fruit cake could be applied to. Pronounced hop flower taste that catches in the throat and lingers well. Powerful, full-bodied and another fine Stone brew.
Bottle. Pours brown with a modest tan head. Flavor is hops, citrus, caramel, and burnt malts. A very nice beer.

Malty, roasted hazelnut aroma. Copper-brown color, with small off white head. Very bitter flavors...best enjoyed on the warmer side. More ruinous to your tastebuds than Stone Ruinition. Smoky, roasted malts are backed with a intense, bitter hop flavors. Sipping beer best enjoyed with a cigar (?).
Great strong ale. Deep red-brown in color. Dances across the palate and ends with a long bitter finish. Will definitely drink again.

Bomber.  Going away present from great friend Kyle.  Deep reddish pour, reddish tan pillowy head.  Hoppy, malty, citrusy on the nose.  Balanced and smooth.  Bitter and sweet.  Charred malts.  Caramel.  Digging it.  Settles into picture perfect 1/2 head above beautiful burgundy balance.  Seems to get better with every sip.  Nice sendoff.

Bomber. Pours a dark brown with a fluffy off white head. Aroma is hoppy first and foremost with some toasted bread and nuttiness that rounds it out. A little bit of a sharpness from the roasted grains, some spiciness. Flavor starts with some sweet caramel and fruitiness, a touch of sweet bread before gaining a heavy hoppiness and sharp bitterness in the finish. Medium to full sticky body. Nice beer
A really pleasant tasting, sweet beer. Well balanced. A bit of citric taste. Ill look for more

A deep dark brown beer coats the glass leaving small traces of foam. A roasty malt starts to hit the nose and followed by a pine like ending. The taste is medium in body with a soft bitter note. This beer is feared by many and should be cherrished by all!

Arrogant for sure! Poured deep gem-like ruby color and a beige foam that reduced quickly to a lacing one. Spices, soap, honey, cinnemon, rum and lots of hops. Sweet taste balanced with extreme bitterness. Dense body, just heavy, oily and low in carbonation. Sweet but also bitter aftertaste that stays. Excellent.
Love the marketing/artwork for this brand, but I was just disappointed in this beer.

First thing I noticed was the great, thick head. The ale is a orange / dark amber. Great aroma of burnt sugar. raisin & hoppy smelling.  Taste is a very hoppy and fruity mix of kick you in the ass alcohol. Palate is bitter and lingering just a little to much bitter on the finish but thatis just me.. A very nice beer and one that I could enjoy a little more often. Now that I drank this one I have to ride my bike to the car 6 miles away.
raisins - yes, I wrote "raisins"; harsh; bitter; malt bomb; slight floral hop presence - its more about the bitter sweet

Im rating this from memory so forgive the briefness, this beer desrves more detail really.  Pours out a divine deep amber with a nice dense white head.  the nose is intense & complex, lovely fruit, some burnt caramel, resin, sweet bread, just lovely.  The body of the beer is smashing, nice and rounded and creamy, good depth, spot on conditioning.  Lovely complex flavours, fruit, caramel, loads going on & obviously lots of bittering hops but tempered by sweetness.  great balnce & a whopping long finish.  Top beer you really have to love this stuff

aroma is of burnt sugar and grapefruity hops along with roasted malts and a honey/earthy funk that is the only unpleasant aspect to this beer..appearance excellent with red color light notes of orange and tan head with plenty of retention and lacing...taste really hits the spot..great blending of citrusy and piney hops with honey like malts..tingly on the palate long bitter aftertaste very drinkable overall its arrogance is tolerable because of its substance
Im a fan of the style, this one is very well balanced and worth everyone giving it a shot.  You can expect a moderate hop finish.
thick tan head and abundant lace on a nice reddish brown pour. medium bitter and a little sweet, with a nice, long finish, (and quality label text, too!)

Bottle from CrackedKettle, shared with Balazs, thanks.
Poured clear deep reddish-amber with a small creamy delcious tan head. Fruity and spicy aroma with figs, grape and raisins, and of course a huge amount of resiny hop, some woods. Starts with a sweet malty caramel base with some cocoabut after a second comes the hop with fruits like citrusses and grape.  The honeyish body is balanced with a grassy-herbal-floral hop-clone attack that stays long in the dry aftertaste. Both in the aroma and flavor is some identifiable fruity and spicy character....Nice and arrogant

bomber; thanks Dad!!  pours dark copper with thick eggy tan head; caramel spicy hops with some boozy spice too; dry malt sticky dry bitterness; malty caramel very dry mouthfeel; rich bitterness and a little harsh up front; has a nice thickish creamy feel to it though; strong and bitter; nice be dry though on the end and not too sweet; orange, pine hops; quite aggressive obviously and no nuance like the many other beers on this trip; visited my Dad on fathers day and he picked up some brews for me; while he enjoyed the Stone IPA, he dumped his sample of this pretty quick

Wow if you are looking for a light beer look elsewhere.  Pours a dark carmel color with nice lacing.  Strong hoppy notes w/ hints of espresso.  Very nice finish.  Great beer w/ even better availability.

Presentation: It was poured from brown 1pt. 6oz bottle into a pint glass. The bottle has the abv at 7.2%, there is no freshness date and there is an amusing description arrogance, there beer and there brewery.

Appearance: The beer has a beautiful dark ruby red hue with good clarity and a creamy light tan head. The thick creamy head has good retention and slowly fades to a thin cap of frothy foam. From this head I get lots of cool lacing and lace rings on the glass.

Smell: It has a big juicy citrusy hop presence over nice bready maltiness in the background. 

Taste/Palate: There is a good solid mix of bready, caramely, grainy malt with loads of juicy of citrusy, grapefruity, lemony, and piney hop notes. The hops bring solid bitterness which slowly fades off the tongue deep into the finish. The palate has a firm yet still easy drinking texture with active carbonation and a good solid medium to full body.

Notes: This is one very tasty, well crafted flagship beer.

On draft at The Thirsty Moose in Lake Hopatcong, NJ.  Ive had this before in the bottle and draft is even better!  Recommend searching this out if or request draft at a decent pub. No need to restate the characteristics of this highly rated beer.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2011 i was feeling that this beer was worthy of a 3.6, but after reading the "Youre Not Worthy" notation, i said fuck that. this beer is pretty solid, but its not very bold. off the top of my head a brooklyn monster or founders dirty bastard would crush this thing. of course, those are higher abv.. this beer is solid, borderline session beer. UPDATED: upped from 3.5 to 3.7

Purchased on my trip to Nashville. Pours a clean copper colour with a very nice creamy off-white head that dissipates slowly and leaves thick lacing. I was expecting a hopbomb from the description and all the writing on the bottle. Nope. Yes, hop is present everywhere, but I have tasted IPA hoppier than this. I guess it is more on the alcohol content. Yes, this beer is smooth for 7.2% ABV with no burns. Hoppy here, hoppy there, but not in a dry way. Kind of watery mouthfeel. Maybe a little tart. Still refreshing overall and worth trying.

This red ale is tough on bar patrons with an untrained palate, and by tough I mean a kick in the teeth.  I had this beer for the name alone my first go around, and I hadnt had many high-hops beer at that point, so I experienced the taste bud equivalent to burning your mouth with coffee.  Now, as an experienced beer man, I can tell you this beer is a great way to introduce your friends with a weaker palate to how good beer is supposed to taste.  I typically have one as my starter drink at Flanagans on Bardstown Road, and everyone always wants a sip. Cheers!
Pretty nice but didnt think it had the kind of complexity hinted at by the bottle - rich and malty but not overly exciting or something Id hunt down.

Brownish-red in color, clear, 1-inch cream-colored head, leaves outstanding lacing. Aromas of caramel malt and piney hops. The palate is smooth, medium in body, lightly carbonated. The taste is sweet with caramel malt, but balanced with a piney-leafy bitterness in the finish. A really well-balanced beer. An excellent strong ale. Great choice!

This beer is quite complex for the small price it boasts on the shelf (for all those that think it is expensive, you are as the bottle reads).  The slightly toasty caramel malt backbone is superbly balanced with grapefruit citrus hops.  Ages well, although I enjoy mine fresh

Serving: 22 oz. bottle from Total Wine Sterling. 
It pours a deep, lightly hazy amber with a nice , creamy, light tan head.  Great lacing and good head retention.  The nose is lighter than expected with a bit of fruit, a little honey, spicy hops, and slight roasted notes.  The taste is full of big, bitter, pine hops.  Honey, toasted malt and big resin notes lurk in there too.  Very hop forward but tastefully done.  Medium to rich mouthfeel with medium carbonation and a long, bitter finish.  A very solid, hop heavy strong ale.  I would definitely have this again.

upon the first time you put your nose in the glass you know " youre not worthy". big floral,citrus notes bang your cilia up into your sinuses. pours deep amber with creamy head. huge toasty caramel malt backbone rounded out with that arrogant hop flavor that stone is SO famous for.

SD trip, sample but had many times beforer: I still dont know the fascination with this beer except that it has a great name. Medium to dark copper/red body and thin white head with notable bitterness in the nose and flavor; hops for sure but also a bit metallic and alcohol.

This one pours a nice, clear, dark amber/light brown with a good, smooth, off-white head that fades slowly, leaving nice lacing. Nose is a big hop profile: dominated by citrus and pine, but also spicy hops, and a strong backbone of sweet amber malt. In the mouth is an excellent balance leading with sweet, bicuity malts  and a quickly developing spicy, grassy hop kick that really come through on the swallow with lingering piney hop bitterness. As it warms, it develops a nice fruity character and maybe even hints of chocolate and tobacco. The perfect example of an American Strong Ale?

This superb brew poured a dark red with a fingers worth of very frothy foam. The head retention was quite good. Aroma has hops surging out in a high alpha acid assault. There is also a fair amount of sweet dough on the nose. Taste has a strong blend of agressively malty sweetness blended with some resin-like hoppy bitterness. The bitterness come across as very strong in lemon peel like citrus. One of the first beers that got me into microbrew beer. Stil enjoyable after all these years.
Deep coppery color with a tannish head. Malty strong aroma. Very full flavor of spices, malts, fruits, and alcohol. A power beer

tasted at the mondial de la bière in Montréal. pours a dark red with a nice off white head that leaves beautiful lacing on the glass. the nose is domintated by hops and dark malts. taste is bitter, VERY bitter! some caramel and nut flavours are present as well. somewhat of a creamy mouthfeel, this beer is full bodied. very tasty.
Im worthy. Simply a strong malty brew, with a strong hop bitterness and influence. Simply, great!

head: normal , firm 
colour: deep red amber , clear
smell: sweet, bitter , hops , yeast, peach , pineapple
taste: heavy bitter start, fruity flavor, hops, yeast , nice good flow in the flavours , aftertaste is grassy/earthy , a very fine brew , maybe even better with a little more alcohol ?
Easily one of the best beers I have ever had. Year to year this beer is the strongest local beers on the market, until they release Double Bastard.

Pours dark red with a nice, lasting off white head.  Aroma is hops and dark malt.    Full, almost creamy mouthfeel.  Bitterness is well balanced against caramel and nut flavors.  finish is intense but enjoyable.  hops and molasses linger.  This is a classic. A true go to for the craft enthusiast and a uniquely American brew.  Im not worthy.
UPDATED: MAY 29, 2010 Bought the 22 oz. bottle on the strength of the gargoyle and the name. "Arrogant Bastard" is incredibly apt.
Pours a beautiful brick red with a thick off-white head. Aromas of caramel and pine. Flavors of caramel up front with a nice hoppy middle and bitter finish. An excellent ale with amazing balance.

Aroma of hay, grass, grapes, citrus.  Ruby Red pour, nice dense, creamy head, leaves lacing.  Very fruity flavor, grapefruit and orange flavors dominate, earthy herbal and tobacco notes and a little smoke.  Quite bitter but manageable...I used to think this was really intense but now it seems "normal."  Full bodied, oily texture, soft carbonation, bitter and astringent finish.  One of the kings of craft beer, you have to respect the bastard!

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2010 Arrogant motherfucker: 6fl 0Z bottle (bought from Beers Of Europe): .  .Im migraing  to California .  American HOPS are the redemption. Piney  hops giving boozy grapefruit  ..intertwined with prononuced malty conceitedness.Im worthy so shut your face and ill enjoy another bottle.
Clear reddish brown pour with off white head.  Rich and robust!  Smooth to bitter in the mouth with strong roasted malt flavor and the tinge of alcohol.  Excellent strong ale.

66cl Bottle via trade with Lithy, thanks Justin! Hazy reddish copper colour, yellowish off white head. Aroma of caramel, toasted malts, hops. Flavour is light sweet, malt and caramel at first, fruity, bit of peach and citrus, then very hoppy bitter, grapefruit and grass. Medium bodied, finish is a bit watery but the bitterness lingers. Good.

Bottle tasting on mothers day... I looked this up just to be sure, and cant believe I never got around to rating this earlier.  One of the first true craft beers that got me started on my road down the dark and dangerous path that is the craft beer movement.  This along with New Hollands Dragons Milk will always hold a special spot in my heart.  Like all of stones products, this bad boy is just as fun to read the back description as it is drinking it.  Do yourself a favor and give their entire line a try.  On second thought, dont bother... "Youre Not Worthy."

Had this beer many a time, but finally got around to taking notes on it during a recent trip to Winking Lizard Crosswoods. 22oz bottle. Pours a clear red with a huge tan head. Crisp nose of piney hops and caramel malt. Caramel malt flavor with citrusy and grassy hops staying all the way through to the bitter lasting finish.
Has quite a nice bite to it. The aroma  of hops really jumps out at you from the first whiff. The coloration is a little bit red, but is also a little brown. A very good one.
Pours a crisp ruby with a few fingers of beige head.  Light sweet hop odor.    Light sweet beginning with a strong hop bitterness finish

ruddy dark copper, huge puffy head with thick, prominent lacing as it fades. a big blast of piney, citrusy hops on the nose with a good roastiness that helps to balance it a bit. ditto on the taste: beaucoup hops, some grassiness and resin in with the pine and citrus, just enough malt to hold it together. thin, biting mouthfeel with a long dry bitter finish.
San Diego classic.  In bottle/on tap countless times.  Formidable hops content with well-balanced malt, some pine, and a satisfying, thick finish.   Definitely worth a buy.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2010 This is a very dark beer and had a sweet aroma to it. Very little head but good lacing. Felt heavy and smooth on the palate. Taste was great, creamy, roasted and hoppy. I was very pleased with this beer.

This beer fill expectations, dark amber body, hoppy nose with malts instantly  the bottle its open, taste its a well balance of hops and malts concentrated with grapefruit, pine taste finishing with a pleasant bitterness. Superb Beer.

Deep brown body with a thick tan head that leaves considerable lacing.  Malty sweet aroma with notes of caramel, brown sugar, and a hint of hops.  Smooth and creamy mouthfeel.  Very engaging flavor and ever-changing.  Throughout, the caramel and brown sugar sweetness is there.  Then theres hints of dark fruit, burnt sugar, and finally pine and bitter grapefruit at the end.  I hope Im good enough for this beer because I like it.

You have to have a lot of respect for a beer that flatly states on the bottle Youre not worthy and You probably wont like it. As someone who has be ensconced into the craft beer scene over the last year I understand where Arrogant Bastard Ale by the Stone Brewing Company, is coming from. It is indeed a strong beer for discriminating tastes and if you can appreciate good beer youre bond to love it.POUR, COLOR AND AROMASince this is only available in 22oz bomber bottles, the beer pours rather rough with plenty of kickback. It forms a beautiful shade of clear but dark maroon with little carbonation noticeable. Its complimented by a thick, frothy, tan head which lasts throughout the life of the beer and leaves generous amounts of lacing on the glass. The aroma is surprisingly subdued with hints of a strong hop presence with some floral notes but also a distinct maltiness as well.TASTEI have never experienced a beer with such a continually-changing flavor as I have with Arrogant Bastard Ale. Upon my first swig I noticed a taste of deep sweetness like caramel and chocolate  reminiscent of a doppelbock. However, on the finish I noticed a distinct hop bite with a mild citrus and pine flavor. This was very unusual and pleasantly surprising since it seemed to be a combination of the best of both worlds: sweet malts and bitter hops.This beer is classified as an American Strong Ale, which I suppose would make it an American take on the Belgian strong ale style. Whatever the case may be I definitely enjoyed it since there was a strong presence of everything here  malts, hops, sweetness, bitterness and more. Although, the more I drank the more I noticed the beer began to take on the qualities of an India Pale Ale with a strong citrusy taste and a wicked bitter bite. As something of a hop head myself I really enjoyed this, but couldnt help but wonder what happened to that rich caramel sweetness from the beginning.FINISHWith a name like Arrogant Bastard Ale, you might assume this is going to be a difficult beer to drink, but nothing could be further from the truth. With a very soft, gentle mouthfeel and a rather thick composition, this is actually a very easy-drinking beer. The only caveat is the strong, dry, chalky aftertaste not unlike flour. BODYThis is a heft beer to be sure. At 7.2% ABV and a slogan that tells you that youre not worthy, its no surprise that Arrogant Bastard Ale packs a punch. I drank my bomber after dinner and still felt its effects. This is definitely not a beer for lightweights.FINAL THOUGHTSWhile I wouldnt consider Stone Arrogant Bastard Ale one of my all-time favorites, or even among the best of the best, it definitely does live up to its name and reputation. As an amateur connoisseur I could definitely appreciate the craftsmanship that went into this brew as well as the strong, complex, and delicious palate. In fact, I might even take some pride in knowing how much I really like this beer. Perhaps the name is meant to describe those who like it more than the beer itself.NOTE: Watch the video version of this review at:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=de4RzKp1FpE

Dark crimson hue with a big thick slowly dissipating head.  Big hop aroma on the nose, thick on the palate.  The strong hop character attacks the taste buds initially and is balanced out by the deep slightly smoky caramelly malt.  One big, strong, complex bastard.  Magnificent.

22 ounce bottle.  Pours a clear, red brown with a thin, clingy, tan head that fades rather slowly.  Taste is of resin, hops, grass, citrus, some malt, and alcohol.  Aroma of malt and hops.  Slight bitterness and dryness in the finish.  Has an oily and watery body.  Both the aroma and taste are rather mellow and subdued.  It isnt nearly as arrogant or as aggressive as they claim it to be.  Way overpriced for what it is and not that great.  Really convinces me to stay away from their other brews.
I dont have the taste or sophistication to appreciate an ale of this quality and depth.  Im not worthy.  At least it was only $5.

A- Nice deep red/amber body with thick creamy head.

S- very malty with hints of hops. I thought the smell was rather pungent.

T- I had a bomber of this and everytime I sipped I noticed something different. There was obviously a hoppy finish that remained on the palate. The hops all together were good but the aftertaste was a bit unpleasant. There are subtle hints of dark fruit and chocolate and of course a nice malt backing. What I liked the best about this brew was a nice spicy flavor that lasts thrroughout it. Carmel can be noticed when there is a great length between sips.

P- well done. medium carbonation and medium weight body. Feels good in the mouth.

O- it was different. Not an everyday thing for me. One bomber is enough for at least the next month.

This beer is above average overall-but a little bit over hyped. There are hoppier, more complex, not for the "faint of heart" brews out there. This just didnt live up to my expectations. I will probably have it again. I do not hate it nor am I in love with it.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-03-2007 03:18:29

Aroma of currant, licorice, dark grapefruit and earthy hops. Appearance is opaque reddish brown with tan head. Flavor of burnt toffee, brown sugar, licorice and hops. Palate is lively and bubbly. A gold standard beer.

Another Stone beer dinner selection at BJs Brew house. Wow. I had expected this one to be a little softer than the Oaked AB but I assumed backwards. Big beer, big aromas, big complex flavors...spicy, toasted malt, hoppy...dont judge off the first taste!! let the tastebud shock settle and go again.
Lighter than expected with a great mouth feel and almost sweet follow. Definitely tastier on tap than bottled
Spicy explosive hop aroma, pours a little on the pale yellow side.  The sweetness of the malt does a decent job of keeping all those hops in check.  The Bastard is what others want to be.

Appearance: dark amber color looks appetizing!
Aroma: Roasted malt aroma with hints of coffee and caramel
Taste: medium bitter taste and body delivers a punch
Palate:  Medium body brew has a long bitter finish
Overall:  I love this beer.  It goes down smooth and has a great balance of bitterness and flavor.

On tap at Brixies in Brookfield, IL. and dispensed with a hazy, brown/mahogany color, a foamy, light tan head, and coating waves of lacing. The aroma was toasty/roasty rich malt, caramel, and some hints of dark fruit. The flavor added to these some alcohol presense, and a substantial hop bitterness that lasted well through the finish. Sipping required to appreciate this well crafted beer!.

Rich ruby copper-brown color with off-white head. Aroma is rich caramel malt, hints of vanilla, aggressive pine, citrus hops with dark fruits and wood. Tastes as though a silky flavor-bomb detonated in my mouth, layers of rich hoppy complexity, a big malty body and piquant, dried fruit character. Sharp, smooth, full mouthfeel with a lasting finish. Pair with anything rich or drink alone.

I got a wonderful snout full of yeast when I opened the bottle, and each sip gave me the intense pleasure of sweet malt akin to a Belgian dubbel. Unfortunately, like so many west coast beers, this is hopped to death. Each sweet mouthful finished with pervasive bitterness. Tasty and certainly worth trying on my San Diego sojourn, but I would prefer more balance and less wallop.
MMM now this is what I go for when I want something real strong and real good to go with dinner. One glass and I was instantly a fanboy. Dont even think about buying it, just buy it.

Draft sampler at Finnegans, Plainfield. Deep mahagony color with a light layer of foam. Darkest of the AB samples (+Oaked & Dry Hopped) before me. Hard to manage more than a small mouthful at a time, it IS that aggressive. Caramel malts way in back of a big, bitter hopheads paradise. But work on that sip a little more, and it will slide down my throat just like a cola. Everything they claim and more.

(Bottle) rich orange amber, light tan head and great lacing. Nose of big citrus fruits, caramel, huge aromatic hops. Taste of very bitter citrus oils, this is not balanced in the least. Some malt backbone but very little. This is all bitter hops. Creamy and oily mouthfeel buy extremely bitter finish.

1pt 6oz bottle. I had one of these several months ago... thought I had already rated it. Aroma: mild roasted & caramel malts, some fruit, citrus, hops. Taste: roasted & caramel malts, hops, fruits, citrus, notes of pine. Finish has some bitterness. Medium body with some depth, good balance. Overall a good beer for a great price.

Is there a reson this doesnt come up as "Stone" Arrogant Bastard Ale? [A] Very simple. Caramel. Citrus hops. Some fruitiness. [A] A very nice looking pour. Amber brown body with tan head. [F] Lots of citrus and crystal malt. Hoppiness overpowers most of the body here. Some fruit. [P] Hoppy. And not hard to drink. I wouldnt call this a session beer. But the bitter would keep me coming back. Mild-bodied. Smooth, yet prickly mouth. [O] Overall, I dont really feel this is a "great" ale. It is nice. But lacking complexity. Just a bitter bomb from the west coast.
UPDATED: JUN 7, 2010 from a taster from bj and stone tasting night,red, white foam, hoppy and malty,great beer strongly recommend

For any younger drinkers (Im 21) that appreciate some good beer for their buck, I have to suggest trying this or even the Double Bastard. At 22 ozs and 7.9 alc% its basically like drinking 4 cheap domestics for the same price...except guess what?! Youre not drinking some watery, piss yellow budweiser! This beer is delicious, affordable, and easy to appreciate.

Bottle. Copper with a creamy beige head. Rich toffee malts and aggressive hops on the nose. Flavour is toffee, citrus, berry, pine and caramel. Solid bitterness. Damn tasty beer. Good hoppy bitterness that lingers in the finish. A classic.

Tap @ the Brickhouse BBQ - Pours rosy amber with a foamy cream head. Smells sweet and hoppy--kind of reminds me of Bigfoot, but not so hop-forward. Tastes caramelly and nutty, with grassy, herbal hops. Deep and bold taste with a creaminess and sweetness that never overpowers. Very impressive.

Tried both the draft and bottle versions of this beer. Draft: On tap at the PUB at monte carlo casino. Pours dark amber and hazy with a minimal head. Perhaps this was the glassware or the serving pressure as the bottle version displayed a rather vivacious head. Aroma on draft was quite underwhelming, however the bottle version displays to a further extent; sweet dark and roasted malts with some zesty hop aromas. Flavour is less complex than the oaked arrogant bastard, however still exceeds in the quality department showcasing spicy, sweet malt flavours with a lingering bitterness and light-medium mouth feel which is quite pleasing to the palate. Definitely a great beer for its availability.

Poured deep amber brown. Good 1 1/2" head. Excellent lacing. Aroma was mild hops ,sweet malts and caramel. In the taste I found mild hops/sweet malt/ chocolate and something else I just couldnt pin point. It was pretty tasty but the semi earthy roasted bitter finish was somewhat of a let down. Not bad but IMO over rated. Cool label though.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2015 Pours beautiful amber brown color, almost glowing.  Light head that collapses.  Aroma is light hops, dark fruit, some sweetness/caramel.  Roasted malts up front with dry hoppy flavor on the end,  Some dark fruit, alcohol, wood, sweetness.  Smooth with a lingering bitterness.  This is very complex as stated.  Medium to full palate. Excellent. Reality re-rate:  first time having this 5 years.  What a difference good beer makes.  This is a solid hoppy red ale.  Middle road at best. -7

I drank this while watching the gold medal hockey game with savvy1982. Pours a deep red with a large tan head. The aroma is extremely floral. Some fruitiness and a hint of roastiness on the nose.
