The flavor is jam packed with hops. Very floral again. Soft fruit, roasted barley, grapefruit rind, spice and a chewy gnarly bitterness that lingers. Very good.
UPDATED: NOV 26, 2014 coffee and maple aroma.  Pours  a hazy amber with lots of creamy head and lacing. Malty, alcohol at first with hoppy bitternes to follow. Not a bad drink.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2012 22 oz. bottle, pours dark golden amber with a moderate head. Fantastic aroma of maple syrup, caramel malt, brown sugar and bitterness. Flavour follows accordingly. Very nice beer, though a bit unbalanced towards the hops.

Pours dark and syrupy with a moderate head. The nose is both bitter and bittersweet and quite strong. As the name indicates, this beer is quite strong and presents a very bitter, crisp hops character along with a noticable bittersweet malt, combining for a complex character. Alcohol is also noticable but does not detract. Overall a very good- and quite strong- American micro brewed ale.

OMFG!  Im the 2484th person to rate this beer!!!  Holy mutha!  I wonder how many people can rate this beer.  I love this beer.  Dont drink it very often cause its EVERYWHERE, but that definitely doesnt discount the fact that it rocks.  I mean, the advertising is just...damn straight.  Haaaa!

pours a deep blood red, looks awesome. Small head which dissipates rather quickly. Laces okay. Heavy alcohol smell with some oak and hops. Nice medium going down. The taste just blows you away. Sweet malt and caramel and good hops balance. I recommend to all.
Bomber. Pours dark amber with a slight but persistent creamy head that hangs on throughout. Equal big hop and big malt tastes. Excellent stuff. Prefer this one over the oaked version.
I had tried the Stone IPA and was impressed, so I also tried their Arrogant Bastard. Talk about hitting the spot! Now I just have to find it here in NC.
Not for guzzling.  This is a substantial beer,  Thin but persistent head.  Great malty flavor with stong american hop balance.  Lots of caramel in the finish.  No off flavors noted.

now this was a beauty of a beer, t is is what I was expecting. nice dark amber copper color and about a half inch bubbly head. aroma and flavor having some nice sweet malt and citrus and pine hops. medium mouthfeel and the hops and malt stick around in the aftertaste. very nice.

2007: This is a deep and dark red colored ale. Huge, puffy head. No haze, but deep and murky. Big spiderweb of lace. 

Magnificently balanced smell. Has a deep, dark ale smell. Deep, excellent oaky smell with bitter hops underneath. Wonderful strong ale smell. Very woody, heavy alcohol smell.. 

Excellent oak-barrelled flavor. Very alcohol-ish, strong. Woody and powerful. Very strong, but outstanding. A very special strong ale. 

Thick yet also thirst-quenching. A strong, "wet ale." Creamy and good. So drinkable for such a strong ale. Oaky, alcohol-y, strong, rich.
Bottle. Pours a very nice reddish hue. Aroma is slightly hoppy. Malt is still noticeable. Balanced nicely actually. Sweet. Taste is the same. Very good with dinner.

Bomber from my main man Eddie at Express Liquor in PB.  Pours a deep, dark red...somewhere between Guiness and Hop Head Red.  One finger cappucino head which dissipates, leaving behind some significant lacing.  This is one helluva good looking beer.  This beers reputation precedes it, but with good reason.  Nose is hops and some subtle coffee and caramel notes.  Palate is a right hook to the kisser of sweet, delicious hops with an even sweeter malt backbone.  Some toffee notes round out this aggressive yet totally enjoyable strong ale.  Yellow, fizzy beer is for wusses indeed.  I want another.

Excellent all around ale. Significant hops aroma.  Deep amber color, clear, minimal head.   Some bitterness, medium body, soft carbonation, clean finish.  Not overpowering in any way, just a solid go-to beer.
Super Hoppy.  Nice aroma and excellant taste.  If you are an Ale fan, this one will change your life.

Geat thx to Bianca and Thierry. For tasting day 20.02.2010. Also this special bottle. 
Dark brown color, with a beige head. Aroma roasted malts, spice, american hops. Medium to full body. Taste oakes, sweet, roasted malts, hopsbitterness, bit spice.
Amber pour from bottle.  Light head.  Huge taste of pine, hops and some light smoke.  Warm finish with some decent kick.  Solid stuff.

Bottle, pours clear red/amber, medium white head that reduces to a persistent ring. Floral nose, super-rank hops along with nice crystal malt character. Mouthfeel belies the alcohol present in this brew, roasted barley, mild smoke, flavor is all about the hops, seamlessly integrated, sticky, hops. Vera nice!

Fairly common in liquor stores, this is what American beer should be. Massive hop taste, lingering malts, nice colour. Head retention is substantial for a beer of this strength. Its a brew that works well either with grilled meats or on its own. Not quite as smooth as its oaked counterpart, nor as godly as the annual Double Bastard, this is still an old standby.

Deep amber with a medium beige head. Medium retention. Aroma is caramel with toasted malt, citrus and floral hops and a touch of alcohol. Flavor is caramel, citrusy, piny hops, alcohol and a bit of wood Well balanced bitter and sweet aftertaste. Medium body. Very good.
dark brown pour light brown head .This is super hoppy and bitter a really wonderful beer.Taste of pine, citrus,floral, woody,
Drank from the tap at Murphys Pub (R.I.P.) in Cortland, NY, youch this beer is bitter!  From start to finish this beer packs a vicious bite with an undertone of brown sugar/caramel.

This is very good. No. Great. Nice deep red/brown/orange color. Well balanced with sweetness and bitterness. Citrus with a strong spruce/pine overtone. Very woody. Undertones of warm brown sugar. Very strong, yet calm and collected character.
Bottle.  Dark amber with medium tan head.  Hoppy, citrus, floral, caramel and dark fruit.  Some sweetness, fruit with a nice bitter finish.  Overall a great ale.

Man oh man, I really loved drinking this bottle down. I like the aroma a whole lot, a dark, sweet smell without being overpowering. Unfortunately I just drank it out of the bottle, never got to pour this one so I really dont know about head details or color, but it is determinately a dark brew. The taste is a great one, a very bitter, slightly(very slightly)chocolate taste, finishing a tiny bit fruity. An acquired taste, but one worth experiencing. And the bottle is a great read.
Brown with a tan creamy head. Smells of citrus, and tastes very, very hoppy. A delicious, delicious beer with a loltastic bottle and name.

Gravity pour at Churchkey.  Labeled as dry-hopped/Simcoe.
Clear copper, three-bubble head, no carbonation.  Aroma of smoke, oak, bourbon, flowers.  Taste has caramel, a smoky edge and a bitter finish.  Great character.  Easily the best beer of the night.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2011 On tap into shaker.  Pours a dark amber with moderate beige head.  Malts and hops on the nose (caramel, vanilla, a bit of citrus).  The taste is simply awesome - this is a great beer!  Very well balanced with medium body and dry, bitter finish.  Wow! I only wish I could have enjoyed it in a tulip or more flavor-friendly glass.  Will look for this beer again, that is for certain.

Dark amber with a thin white head.  Oh baby are there some hops in this thing!  The aroma smacks you right in the nose.  Citrus predominates in the aroma.  The taste has hops in the front, hops in the middle, and hops in the back, but suddenly I get just a hint of malty sweetness in the aftertaste.  Certainly lives up to its labeling as an aggressive beer.  Mouthfeel is medium-bodied and fizzy.  Very long finish.  Definitely will delight hop-heads, but I couldve used a bit more balance.

soy sauce, resin, maple syrup wrapped up into one earthy soil . I think the one I got was a bit skunky but still exceptionally complex. This was a renaissance faire classic with a turkey drumstick in one hand and the bastard the other hand.

Bomber 
Appearance : Clear amber small foamy and creamy head. Extensive lacing

Aroma : Hoppy, resinous, piny and red fruits. Some brown sugar also. Quite sweet to the nose.

Taste : Hoppy, some sugar. Quite fruity. Some alcohol.

Finish :  Bitter and hoppy. Some alcohol

Overall : Solid beer !!
1pt 6oz bottle. pours dark with a yellowish-beige head. Nose of malt and cascade hops. Strong hops flavour. Over all an excellent strong ale, but not as hoppy as some of their other efforts.

This might look like too high of a score. But Arrogant Bastard is perfect. Its the beer that plunged me into the craft beer world. The first great beer I tried, and my introduction to Stones beer. Neck and neck with my favorite beer, Ruination IPA. They switch off depending my mood. I love this beer, thank you Greg Koch. Anyways...
 Pt. Bottle, pours a dark, ruby red, crystal clear. Has a 2 finger frothy, tan head with nice, lazy lacing. Aroma has strong floral and citrus hop notes, resin, caramel malts, and delicious perfection. Taste starts smooth and sweet with slight fruit, biscuit undertones, pine, which spikes an instant eagerness for the deliciously bitter hop finish. Palate is medium/oily/sticky. Good carbonation. Overall a perfect beer. Taste, drinkability, EVERYTHING. A staple in my diet. Go Stone!!!!!!
This taste lingers.  Lots of hop floral then the bitterness really kicks in and stays there.  Almost like a light barleywine.

A: Very dark brown with some reddish tints (in the right light), "off-white" foam.

S: Not as intense an aroma as you might expect. Some dark fruit, caramel, and hops.

T: The first thing you notice is the intense bitterness, which I love. There are some subtler caramel flavor.

M: Great mouth feel: good amount of carbonation. The bitterness comes into play here as it lingers.

D: A great beer, but I would not call it very "drinkable". Something Id recommend trying, however.

this stuff is awesome. yeah, everybody on earth has had one by now, but that shouldnt hurt its rep. its malty, grassy-citrus-pineneedly-hoptastic astringent flavor goes well with the sticky assed mouth feel and the way it laces the glass like the aliens covered that compound on Aliens

22oz bottle poured into Trappist glass. Pours very dark copper, almost brown, with a creamy potato colored head. The smell is very sweet with a definite floral component. Taste is basically your normal IPA, but with tons of hops, both for flavoring and bittering. Hops, hops hops.
Id expect nothing less from Stone

22 oz. bottle from a friend. Ive had this many times now and just have not got around to rating it. This beer played a big part in my interest in craft brews. Smells citrus-hoppy and carmelly with a big hop push on first sip. Just finished off an FBC Abominable and this tastes a tad watery in comparison (not how I traditionally remember it). Anyway, this is a great ale for the hop-minded and one of my go-tos at the local pub.

22oz bomber from Central Market.  Pours a dark umber body with red highlights, topped with a tan head leaving a bit of lacing.  Aroma of chocolate malts, caramel, raisin and strong floral/citrus hops.  Light malt sweetness, medium bitter hops and hint of plums.  Lively carbonation, medium mouthfeel.  Lengthy bitter finish.

This beer is pretty good. Of all the Stone beers Ive had this one didnt seem to leave AS MUCH of an impression on me but its great stuff none-the-less. Nicely bitter, strong flavor and highly complex. This beer finally makes me proud of a popular beer. Youre not worthy
Excellent well balanced beer.  Nice citrussy hop aroma and perfect bitterness.  Good body, good color.

What can I possibly add to other reviews of this beer?  Its fantastic stuff, the kind of beer that converts normal folk into beer geeks.  The combination of big citric hops and sweet caramel malt makes a mockery of style guidelines while still feeling utterly natural and refined.  The flavor is balanced - big hops, big malt, big flavor.  Arrogant Bastard has become a defining beer of the American craft movement and sits as the flagship of one of the best known and most loved craft breweries.  All hail Greg Koch.

Pours dark amber with a red tint.  The thin white head nicely laced the glass.  A very powerful hop aroma was evident immediately upon pouring.  Floral hops and freshly cut grass aromas wafted from the glass.  Massive hops dominated the flavor, with floral and grassy notes.  The finish was bitter and lip-puckering dry.  The hop aftertaste lingered.  No balancing act here, this beer is all about the hops.  I liked it though. I felt it offered something outside the norm.

Bottle. Dark ruby color with slight tan head. Aroma of cinnamon, dried fruit, and bitter hops. Tastes of toasted marshmallow, syrup, ripe fruits,  bitter hops and citrus. Oily slightly thick mouthfeel. Really great agressive flavor and overall great beer.
Great grassy hop aromas and flavors.  Medium levels of caramel and roasted malt flavors.  Medium carbonation.  Dry finish.
on draft at Grillsmith in N Tampa.  Very complex and slighlty smokey.  Hints of wood, sweet and smokey malt, and molasses.  tfull of body and flavor.

22oz bomber from 16th St.Liquor in West Van. Thank God this was brought in as a limited offering and I was lucky enough to get some. I have had it before, back in the days I didnt rate, but its lovely to re-visit. Arrogant Bastard is a crystal-clear mahogany ale that is quite sparkling and is adorned with a small, rocky, light coloured head that is mostly diminishing and leaves thin lacing all the way down the glass. The aroma is mostly of grapefruit from the hops, followed by rich malt that is slightly sweet. There are hints of nuts, resin, plum, honey and vanilla. It is medium-to-full bodied with slightly soft carbonation. It is ever so smooth. It is well-bittered, lightly sweet. It starts citrusy and turns wooden. The aftertaste is on the long side and exhibits notes of oak, pine and juniper. The balance is superb. This really hit the spot. Its a great representation of how an American strong ale can be.

Pours a deep rich brown color.  Aroma of spice, and caramel.  A bitter tasting beer, with an aftertaste of mocha and slight coffee.  If you dont like aggressive tasting beer, then dont try this one.
lives up to its reputation as one of the great american beers. it will forever be a trusty "stand-by" brew for me!

Picked up the 22oz size at the supermarket on the way back from a hike in the Marin Headlands just north of SF.  The guys in North County SD can do no wrong!  Dont let the attitude scare you away- this is a highly drinkable ale with a big malt flavor balanced by an assertive hop hit.  Stone Brewing has a flawless track record (3 for 3) in my limited experience.  Ill be back for more of their other concoctions.

Bomber pours deep, dark red-brown with little to no retaining head into a snifter; nice lacing.  Plenty of caramel malt in the aroma, vanilla, plumb, raising (overripe fruits really), lemon/orange hops.  Very similar in the tastes; sweet caramel malts and overripe fruits dominate, balanced by lemony hops and a touch of pine; a bit earthy.  Dry finish with perceptible booze.  Mellows and becomes smoother as it warms.  Velvety mouthfeel with low carbonation, full body.  Rich, complex, and in your face, Arrogant Bastard is not for the weak.

Wow! Aggressive is too weak a word to describe this ale. Poured into pint glass nice dark amber color. The floral aroma punches you in the nose and the 7.2 abv kicks your ass. Very smooth mouthfeel for all those hops. The complexity of flavors pop out as it warms up a little. Great beer!

220z bomber.  pours a dark amber with red tints, as to be expected due to hops.  great hop aroma and bitters in aroma and palate.  smooth mouth feel fermented dry but well balanced with hops.    GREAT BEER!!
The bottles great, so far the best lable Ive read. I could drink this all day. I really like this brew, I just think $4.99 at Albertsons is messed up.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2010 Draught at Mcloughlins. Pretty reddish brown color. Big hop aroma. Big hop bitterness lets some caramel malt come through. I loved this beer the first time I had it, but now it just comes across as big and sloppy. Ok, but not special.

Pours out a dark, deep reddish brown. The head is tan and foamy and lingers for quite a while. The mouthfeel is good and it has a smooth malty taste that finishes with a hoppy kick. Great brew from Stone.

Stone Brewing Company--Arrogant Bastard Ale--2000 Release--22 oz. Bottle--7.20% ABV.  (4.5 / 5.0)  Barleywine?--Hazy rich copper amber color.  Nice floral hop fruit amber front.  Rich yeasty caramel malt body.  Rich lacy head.  Light sweetness and creamy texture.  Finishes smooth and creamy.  Hoppy--no Bite.  Sampled  5/5/2000.
8th December 2008. Hazy orange - brown beer. Tangy, peachy, oranges and a little tea. A touch of hop bitterness. All riding over a smooth malt base. Semi dry and semi bitter finish.

Draught @ Brew Garden, Clearwater, FL: Pours deep amber, good white head and great lacing straight to the bottom. The aroma is strong with pine with some brown sugar. That first sip is a pine hop wallop, but quickly makes way for bread, grass, and light brown sugar for balance. Very nice.

Pours  deep red, almost brown. Aroma is wonderful, some hop, some biscuit malt and a little chocolate. Carbonation is high, perhaps too high. The beer first reveals bready malt and sharp hop bitterness, and finishes very distinctly with chocolate.

Pours out a deep ruby red with a thin beige head.  Smells like an IPA, very hoppy floral notes.  On the taste its major hops with hints of fruit.  Ends with strong bitterness, the label was not lying when it said this is an aggressive beer.

Stone Brewing
Arrogant Bastard Ale pitcher on tap
Pours a deep reddish brown with a thick creamy head that leaves lots of lacing on the glass. Aroma of cherries, stone fruit, honey, hops and slight yeast, but mostly yummy hops. Flavor of cherries and bitter hops with a long finish and slight alcohol burn. Somewhat sweet, but a very full-bodied flavor. Bitter hops with a thick taste/mouthfeel. On tap at the local pizza parlor this is better than usual. Yummy. Looks great in the pitcher with a nice red color to it.

Couldnt believe I hadnt rated this before as its one of the few craft beers at my super market.  Anyways I like it, was drawn in pre-beer geek days due to label.  But its hoppy and malty and well balanced and a refreshing beer that isnt as difficult as back of bottle suggests.  In fact pretty decent beer that most people should like.
Nice caramel malt flavor and a cirtus twist to this beer. Well balanced ale and wonderful lacing. Stones never disappoints!!
hoppy, but not happy enough. looking for more punch from an ale. wrinkles my nose/upper lip a bit.

Great beer that has some hop to it, balanced very nicely. I sense a faint coffeeish smell and aftertaste.  Beautiful amber color.  Dances onto the tongue that sparks the sweet taste buds.  Overall this is a very good ale, it is indeed worthy of repeated drinkings.  Stone has hit a homerun.  I look forward to the double bastard that has quietly been insulting me whenever I open the closet.

Boy this is one tasty malty hoppy brew! Hits on all cylinders. I really love their beer labels. There are many people out there ignorant to the beauty and complexity of beer. Their labels explain this perfectly.

Shocked I hadnt rated this.  Ive had it many times including at the brewery.  Red-brown pour with a big beige head.  Big but pleasant aroma of burnt malts and citrus hops.  Tastes of roasted caramel and woody hop bite.  Medium slick and drinkable texture.  Finishes up with a lasting bitterness.  Always a pleasure.

A little hazy red/brown colored beer with a thick foamy beige head. The aroma of bitterness of several hops, with fruits and spices in the back. The taste of bitter hop with spices, hints of liquorice juice with fruits. The aftertaste is dry bitter and spicey.

For all the build up and warnings, this is a very well made, balanced beer. No taste bud jihad here, lots of malty flavor with intense hop and a lingering finish. Woods, earthy with deep maltiness. I love this beer.
What an insanely unique bitter beer. Herbal hoppiness combines with burnt wood, fruit skins, and malty goodness in a way that lingers on the palate for hours. My maximum intake is two pints.

Pours a very dark brown with a thick, creamy, tan head.  Smells very malty for a strong ale.  Taste is out of this world good - very complex, strong malt character, but with a crisp refreshing hoppiness as well.  Absolutely delicious.

A strong aroma of caramel, hops, and alcohol. Flavor is initially of smooth bitter hops (with a small hint of caramel); a secondary malty character emerges later. The two predominant flavors are well balanced. An enjoyable brew.

Bottle. Pour is dark golden brown with a short lasting light tan head. Aroma is of aggressive caramel malt, light bitter hops, and alcohol. Flavor is well balanced with a nice malt bill balanced with a medium smooth bitter hop character. Very nice brew.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2010 (br-btl rd//wt-painted-lbl, 22oz a few times, $4.59, "youre not worthy")

lct-mhgy, ^eff, lasting-creamy-tan-head, patches of lace, low-med-co2, sticky-med-full-body.

aroma:  deep earthy fruity(sweet-grapefruit, §pineapple) §sweet-bready-malt fresh-citrus-hops ^hop-resin.

flavor:  fruity bready-malt leafy-hops fresh-dark-citrus(like grapefruit peel soaked in molases) T1, creamy dark-malty-sweet sour-grapefruit tobacco-leaf-^hops §smokey-yeast T2, grapefruit-§wine creamy-hops hop-§bitter filmy T3, malty hop-bitter grapefruit-seed Tf.

i like to drink it rather quickly, maybe it helps to blend the flavors better on the palate, or keeps the palate from getting stressed out, or maybe just because its so darn good.

Pours with a great copper color and clear. Head is big and beige, lasting long. 

This is a well balanced beer with malts and bitter hops on the nose.  

Taste is full mouthfeel and has a strong bitter bite on the front. 

While the hops are pronounced, there is still nice balance and the malts throughout the taste.

Bomber.  Pours a dark reddish brown with a nice thick beige head with thick lacing.  Nose is heavy on the hops, pine, and caramel touch.  Taste is also heavy on the hops to start, gives way to a nice pine and citrus middle, followed by a slightly sweet but dry finish.  Very bitter all the way through.  Brutal on the palate, the hop bitterness really packs a wallop, alcohol is well hidden.  Always one of my favs, cant believe I havent rated this yet.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2012 Growler. Well, I really liked this beer. Pours a rich, amber-red with a strong, white head. Nice, hoppy aroma with strong pine notes. Some detectable malts on the nose. Flavor is a big, cocky blend of elements. Heavy on the hops, this beer rings with citrus and piney, resiney flavors. Underneath, some good, earthy malts give the brew some considerable depth. Slight bread flavor adds to the medium to large body. Lingering, mildy bitter aftertaste. A great session ale for heavy drinkers.4/3/2010 Update: Had a pint last night at The Pony Bar. I just marveled at the intense balance. Potent, deep sweet flavors of dark fruits a malt, right alongside some outrageous hoppiness. Wild stuff.4/17/2010 Update: Had some this boy on cask. Yep, its still great.

This is one of my absolute favorite beers. I first drank it in a fishermans bar in Alaska. There is no doubt about it.... this was my gateway beer, it sent me in search of other true "craft" brews.

A: A nice mahogany red in color. Big thick 3 finger head at the initial pour. There is nice lacing left behind as I pounded this one.

S: Very nice and hoppy. There is definite pine and citrus with hints of caramel and molasses.

T: This is where this beer shines. At first swallow I taste the pine, very resiny. Then the hops come on the scene. It finishes very malty bready almost with the taste of hops still lingering. Perfectly Balanced.

M: Medium bodied and ever so smooth and creamy.
deep reddish brown pour. aroma is roasted malts, hops and slight celery undertone. tastes like a massive malt hop pile drive. and celery salt. in a good way. aggressive and unrelenting.
Amazing beer.  SImply the best thing Ive had from Stone.  Its like an IPA on steroids. I highly recommend it for anyone who likes this style of beer.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2010 Slightly reddish brown color in the glass.  Aromas smell faintly of citrus fruit.  This is a pretty hoppy beer on the palate, I agree with the bottle description of "aggressive hops".  Definitely a well-made brew though.
Enough malt flavor to carry the bitterness.  Held head throughout glass.  Carbonation was fizzy and the hops flavor and bitterness had a long finish.
Not one of my favorites as Im not drawn in by the overly hoppy.  Surprised its a 99. Solid ale though.

22oz bottle 11/26/09-Pours an orangish amber with a small covering for a head. Aroma of alcohol, plums, malt, caramel, and slight hops. Taste of the same with more hops and sweetness coming through in the taste. This full bodied brew is very smooth and balanced. Nice job.

On draught at Plan B (Simsbury, CT): Pours reddish brown into a chalice. Head recedes into a halo with brilliant lacing. Nose is of malts, creamy/thickness, hops, and citrusy. Tastes of rich caramel, vanilla, ripe plum, toast, and sweet malts. Full-bodied yet smooth all around. Alcohol is hidden extremely well amist its multidimensional characteristics. Drinkability: Pleasurable. Rebuy: Definitely. #217 on 24112009, DG.

A red beer with a nice frothy head. The aroma is very nice fruity & hoppy. The taste is very fruity with berries coming out the most with a nice bitterness being smoothed out in the end. If you call yourself a man & drink nothing but light beers then I challenge you to man up & drink a glass of Viking beer, Arrogant Bastard Ale.
(1 pint bottle) aroma is hoppy.  Taste is citrusy and hoppy.  Clean hoppy finish.  Perfect blend of hops and malt.  Lightly carbonated.  Damn good beer.
Bottle split with Tony. Pours a dark, ruby red body. Aroma is beautiful stone hop complexity. Its not overdone, but its just sweet enough to lure you in for a taste. The hops present
I love this beer, but not one I can drink all of the time. I usually drink a few a month...

Pours a nice dark brown/amber. Medium pour produces a good two-finger head of lightly tan foam. Retention is very good and lacing is slightly impressive.

Nice, big caramely malt notes. Citrus hops notes, mostly grapefruit. Very bready.
For such a big beer, I expected a bigger nose.

Starts with a kiss of sweet caramel and brown sugar on top of some dark fruits. Just before you can get into that, though, it blasts you with the bitter bite of big citrusy hops.
Needs to be a touch more balanced. The hops overpower everything else.

Good body. Its at the higher end of medium, on the scale. Almost gets into full-bodied, but not quite.

Its very good, but could be so much better with more balance. Not my favorite from Stone, although it is their flagship brew.

First thing I noticed was the great, thick head.  The ale is a dark amber.  As head disappears, nice lacing is left behind. Great aroma.  Very hoppy smelling, reminds me a little of the Ruination.  Not as strong as the Ruination but still a nice hop aroma.  Taste is a very hoppy and fruity mix of kick you in the ass alcohol.  Palate is bitter and lingering.  A very nice beer and one that I could enjoy as a session.

pours out burnt amber with a finger thick head that was still and bubbly with the color of an off white beige.  the body is a deep amber maroon that is pretty dark.  hte aromas are strong malt and apple, with pine, citrus, and strong hop hints throughout the entire nose.  it is a little sweet on the tip of the tongue with a sense of savoriness on the sides of the tongue with a nice, strong hoppy presence throughout the palate.  i get the flavors of hops, malts, lightly roasted malts, sugar, chives, pine, wood, and dried grass.  it leaves a strong, unforgetable aftertaste that lingers for a little while but is really enjoyable for me.  there is also some really decent lacing all throughout the glass and has a thin cap all the way down.

Poured a cloudy dark orange red with a beautiful thick off white head that lingers for quite some time before fading to a slightly chunky covering. Lacing is nice. Not too thin, but not chunky either. Nice appearance!

Smell is all over the place. Sweet malts, raisin and date, pine, citrus, orange, and woody.

Taste is amazing! Sweet roasted malt, pine, oaky, hints of lemon and orange peel. Raisin and date again. Im really digging this combination of flavors.

Mouthfeel is great. Carbonation leaves a bit of a flavor masking sting. Thats the only reason i deducted a half point here.

Drinkability is good for this big of a beer. I could drink this all night. But its probably not the best of ideas. =P

22oz bottle 
Appearance: Pours dark copper with a large off white head and lots of lace left in the glass. 
Aroma: Citrus, pine and earthy hops 
Taste: Citrus and pine hop flavor with a nice malt backbone. 
Overall: I really like this beer. Does that make me an Arrogant Bastard!
Bottle in Massachusetts. Reddish body with big head. Malty nose, with citrus. Rich tastes of caramel, malts and vanilla. Smooth and full-bodied. Very nice.

Tap @ The White Horse:

A big nicotine stained head.  A lightly cheesy aroma and rich cheesy flavour. An excellent texture/carbonation ratio.  Totally drinkable.

Bottle.  Pours amberish with white head.  Taste of a typical American Ale.  It was good but I dont see what all the hype is.  I guess you ddont have the sophistication to appreciate my palate, you fucking puke, hahaha.

12 oz bottle, university market, 2.79. i have had regular bastard and i dont remember it being this good. the first thing i taste is vanilla, good malt taste nice bitter, very well balanced. very good stuff and i didnt mouth the words as i read it.

This is a pretty good looking ale. It pours out nice and transparent with a golden/reddish color. The golden head was very full as well - even in my glass. One good whiff and you get a nice hint of hops. There was also a slight bit of fruit in it as well. I couldnt really detect what fruit it was but it seemed like a neutral fruit like apples. When you taste it, the frothy head is the first flavor to hit you with a followup of hops. In the middle, you get a hint of barley and it finishes off with the hops again. I didnt get the taste of fruit like I initially smelled. The aftertaste of the brew is pretty alcoholic, though. I did not perceive the texture as very smooth. The flow of the textures and tastes didnt really transition that well and I thought it was a pretty generic beer.

Reddish brown body with very low carbonation and a thin head that is gone is a matter of seconds. Lace is also quite minimal, and the beer has very still appearance in general. Aroma is on the sweetish side with flowery hops and malts that smell like honey. I can also detect a fair bit of grain on the nose with hints on vanilla and oak.

This American strong ale pours a reddish brown hue with a small golden head. Upon inspection it gives off a noticeable aroma of hops, different kinds of malt, and a hint of sour fruit (possibly green apples?). The taste is quite strong and is exactly what i would expect from a beer made by an arrogant bastard; its bitter, dry, and hops-filled. It leaves a nice bitter aftertaste as well, the whole experience is not very smooth, but still quite enjoyable... if your not a yellow-fizz drikin wuss like the bottle says.

Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Slightly hazy burnt red with lasting head and layers of lacing down the glass. Very pretty.

Aroma of mostly dry malts and pine, some citrus and fruit.

Semi-sweet fruity malts upfront, which quickly turns to a very flavorful pine and citrus hop middle, before ending with waves of bitterness. Detect some spiciness from the hops at the end as well.

Low carbonation with a full, very smooth body. Finishes quite dry.

My first American Strong Ale, but I really like this and want more. Good thing its a bomber and I am only half done.

I know American Strong Ale is a catch-all, but this one seems halfway between an IPA and an American Barleywine. Also somewhat reminds me of Furious.

Pours dark red-brown with a frothy head. I love the way it smells. Very fruity, with apricots and oranges. There is an underlying piney hop aroma that just kicks the aroma up a notch. I also fancy that I smell a bit of vanilla in there as well. The flavor is dominated by caramelized fruit flavors of peaches and figs. There is plenty of bitterness to go around as well, but it is well balanced by the fruit. Smooth yet astringent finish. Im surprised that I havent tried this before.

Intense Hop. Great beer.

The bottle is also great if you used to reading beer labels

Rusty amber pour with a fluffy and persistent head.  Rich toasty malty nose.  Very full of flavor with fully bodied malty caramel flavor with a perfectly balanced bite of hop to back it up.  Smooth finish of lingering caramel and hop.  Delicious.

Bomber. Nothing new can be said about this, but it deserves its reputation. Brown-red pour, big soft head. Plenty of malt, but not too sweet. Creamy texture. NW hops that, by todays standards, are almost restrained. Great beer from a cocky brewery.
On Tap, I was very impressed with this beer. Nicely balanced, with great flavor.

Bottle. Muddy brown pour with nice offwhite head with good lacing. Aromas of green grapes and citrus and sweet malt. Slightly sweet up front with evergreen hops and a lingering bitterness. Smooth mouthfeel.

I remember getting a bottle of this at a beer shop in Erie Pa. It was malty with a hop backbone. I remember how much I liked it, and how it was one of the first good micro brews I had ever had. It was my "calling" beer to convert me to the other side of beer. The side everyone who drinks beer needs to see. This beer opened up many doors for me. Maybe it was the labeling on the beer that intrigued me to buy it.....

22oz bottle.  Poured a beautiful amber with a thick, frothy cream colored head with great retention and great sticky lacing.  Smells of bready caramel malts, some plum, and brown sugar along with a little hoppiness.   Taste has a hoppy fruitiness up front with a nice transition to the malt flavor as it sits on the pallet. It finishes leaving a nice delicious bitterness.   A nice big balanced beer.
the first craft beer i ever tasted.   very good!!!  well balanced, nice head,  and easy to drink.
Bottle at Cardinal, Stavanger. Brown color, nice tan head. Aroma is sweet malty and very hoppy. Flavor is fruity and floral hops, sweet malt. Very much bitterness and very dry finish.
I like this. The malt and hops balance is very good. Flavor is full bodied and smooth. I need more.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2010 Dark amber body with a toasty colored head.  Aroma is notably hop heavy with an abundance of pine, earth and a little sweet toast.  Nice bitter, earthy flavors, slightly grassy.  Finishes out with a slightly toasty bitter flavor.  Overall a great beer, love this with a big steak.
From a bottle.  dark amber color.  Earthy and fruity in taste also sweet.  Nice bite.  A good sipping beer, would not want more than a couple in a session.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2013 A forceful, decadant cavalcade of hops and unabridged bitterness. This ale is removed of any spices or sweetness, and contains a boastful, toasty bite. Arrogant Bastard blooms with extreme simplicity and a double-barreled knock back taste.
A nice toasted malt flavor yields quickly to an aggressive hop finish. Very njoyable for those who are hop heads. This beer is definatly Arrogant!

Floral and pine on aroma. Pours a bit thick. Pretty hefty, frothy head. Deep orange/red color. Taste is quite something- complex, raisins, a bit of chocolate(?)(or am I confusing it with something else?) spicy. Aftertaste lingers and is of bitterness.

1 pint 6 oz. Bottle. Pours ruby and lightly cloudy; head is off-white and very long lasting. Aroma: Fruits and yeast dominate the nostrils. Extreamely fizzy and moderately bitter, but the finish is slick and somewhat alcoholic. The flavor tingles through the swallow; a mixture of fruits and hops persuade me to take another taste. Excellant Beer...

Bottle. Dark amber color, with a long lasting white head.

Wonderful fragrance, nice fruity flavor and lovely bitter. Great body and a nice feeling. Good and long aftertaste Thick mouthfeel, very good beer.
pretty good but not nearly as arrogant today as when first released I think. sweet, malty, bready, stonefruity, moderate bitterness and hop caracter.
Dark brown color.  Aroma is full of floral hops.  Taste is strong with hops.  Nice bite in the end.  Good stuff!!

Poured from a 22oz bottle, to a moderately dark amber color. Smells of malt for the most part with maybe a hint of something else hidden in there at times. Flavor is malt and hop split relatively even. Little  carbonation for the long rung and head was ok and dissipated quickly. Little holding the flavor in your mouth all that long. Overall its a decent beer that Ive had before and will probably have again but its not that special to me in comparison to others in the style.

Pours a dark brown with a reddish tint.  Head is generous and is slow to dissipate.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is very subtle.  Hints of malt and..."plastic."  Taste is complex.  The taste changes as it passes down the old gullet.  First its crisp and bubbly with a very light malty flavor then turns very bitter as it goes down....Oh, and it "burps" nice later on.... Very easy drinking and pleasurable!

Hazy, dark amber with a white head.  Has an caramel aroma with a hint of haisins and a very small hint of alcohol.  Bitter beginning with a very nice hop and malt balance in the flavor with a mellower finish than I expected.  Alcohol does not come out as much as I would expect.  Thick in the palate.  Overall a great beer.

pours a very thick caramel color with great head retention. smells of peanut butter, an assortment of nuts, and also spices. tastes of raisins, grapefruit, weak caramel, an unknown amount of spices, and something else i cant put my finger on. hints of sweetness at the same time. to me, a very complex beer, and very bitter finish. the initial taste is very pleasurable and will have you satisfied. its not for me at any regularity as i prefer a slightly less strong beer. i wont forget it and will definetly drink one once in a while.

On tap at the Englander. Very dark amber color with a small off white head. The aroma is sweet with caramel and leafy hops. The flavor is the same with a nice balance between the sweet malts and strong hops. I picked up a little bit of a berry flavor to go along with the caramel and leafy bitter finish. A little lighter on the palate than expected, but still a good beer Ill have again.

Dark red color, thick foamy long lasting white head with very nice lacing.  The alcohol is very present in both the aroma and flavor.  Hoppy aroma with some nice citrus notes.  Thick mouthfeel, malty hoppy flavor, notes of caramel and a nice smooth finish.

650ml bottle. Slightly hazy amber body with a fine tan head. Aroma is citric, grapefruit, pine and some caramel. Flavor is slightly sweet malt delicately balanced with a fair amount of fruity hops. Its refreshing, its tasty, its nice  love it.
Light brown pour with notes of toasted hops and some deep sweet nptes (malt).  The finish was long and showed the 7% alc...finish.

It poured a hazy golden-brown liquid with a small foam that left no lacing. It had a smell of caramell and warm alcohol. Tasted of caramell, hops with an warm alcoholic finnish. Medium-high bitterness. A very nice beer but the oak aged version is better.

Had two pints at the Falling Rock Tap House in downtown Denver. Reminded me of another ale that I have really enjoyed but I cant remember which one (Bells Hopslam?). Im not into paying big money for single bottles of beer but if you are this would certainly be worth trying.
Everything an ale should be with an interesting  citrus note on the finish. The alcohol comes through a tad to strong for my taste otherwise a great brew.

From a bomber into a pint glass.  Pours a dark red/brown with a ton of thick head which never totally disappears.  Smell is of hops.  Taste is of hops, alcohol, cherry with minimal, but present malt.  Very satisfying ale.  A little too much alcohol burn but that subsides with time.  Would drink again.

This beer pours a beautiful deep amber with a thick foamy head.  It leaves incredibly great lacing on the glass as you drink it.  You can small the malt and raisin or prunish odors in here.  A very good beer.  I was surprised, I thought it was going to be too strong, but Id definitely drink it regularly if I could buy it by me.

One of the best ales Ive ever had.  Deep Dark Ruby with a tan head that sticks around for a while.  Nice lacing on the glass.  Strong hop sensation of the palate to offset the amount of malt.  Nice filling finish.
UPDATED: SEP 22, 2009 For some reason I thought this was awesome. Great taste and pour with nice aroma. Initial sip is like a chop in the throat, though.
US Trip Aug/Sept 2009 - Notes from tasting indicate pours dark with light citrus notes, malty and bitter, complex.

Red brown with a middling beige head.  Aroma is very hoppy and a touch sweet.  Flavor is very bold.  Theres some sweet, grainy, brown sugar malt flavor up front.  Has a strong, complex, somewhat spicy citrus hop presence.  Finishes quite bitter and dry.

Pours cloudy mahogany with a small head.  Aroma is mostly hops and brown sugar sweetness.  Mouth feel is thick and sticky.  Flavor is about as in you face as possible with bold bitterness a sickly amount of sweet and some nice earthy flavors in the background.   Was too sweet and bitter to really be enjoyed.  Proof that a big beer is not necessarily a great beer.

Pint draft from Mulligans in Cincinnati.  Pours reddish brown with a small light tan head that leaves rings of lace behind after each drink.  Aroma of hops, malts, brown sugar, raisins, wood, and herbal/earthy notes.  Flavor is bitter hops, caramel, roasted malts, and a bit of fruit.  Sweet and bitter.  Medium body, complex and satisfyingly balanced.  What can I say that others havent?  Stone just cant seem to miss.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2011 Re-rated (1/14/11)  Poured from 22oz bombsaway - Quite hoppy brew.  I like the hop selection.  Perhaps a little too hoppy.  Malts are a bit buried, but pleasant.  Overall a good brew that will not receive my top marks.

Deep amber brown color with ruby hints and a small tan head with moderate lacing.  Malty aroma with hints of wood/smoke and some hops.  Well attenuated mouthfeel with hop bitterness and some alcohol detectable.

Tap @ Brennans.  Murky mahogany, tan head.  Nose is a big bitter green hop herbalness, lots of malt, brown sugar, cocoa, dark fruits & caramel.  Flavor is big caramel, harsh bitterness, borderline burnt sugar.  Fruit/grapeyness comes forward in the finish with a slightly harsh hop bitterness and cocoa malt.  That harshness grows as the pint continues.

From a bottle I obtained in 2005.  Pour is a ruby-brown,  with a nice fruity and citrus and heavy, inviting maltiness.  Palate is on the heavy side of medium and soft.  There is no alcohol heat .  The carmelly, almost coffee/toffee notes with the malt sweetness, balance by the bitterness is very nice.  The flavor fades to a bitter earthy sweetness -- Hoppiness is tempered by time in this bottle, and it is a mellow, autumnal, kind of brew.  Really nice.  I can now say that this is a beer that is even better after a few years in the cellar.
Arrogant Bastard was my introduction to craft beers, and it remains among my very favorites.  This is a truly great beer.

22 oz bottle.  Copper colored, smells of raisins.  Pours an awesome head that retains itself throughout.  "This is an aggressive brew"...you know the rest.  Is there anything more badass than this beer?  Though I love the attitude, I can think of many greater brews.  Still, this beer is a pioneer in the Strong Ale category, and will always be world-class.  Nobody messes with this beer, and for good reason.
Come nice caramel, toffee and dark fruit flavours, but a bit one dimensional

My 100th rating had to be this great brew. Ive had this many times but now is the time to rate it. 

The pour is a dark reddish copper with a great tan head, with nice lace. The aroma is a beautiful caramel malt blended with just the right amount of piney hops. The taste is out-of-this-world fantastic. There is a great balance of rich malt flavor blended with the citrus/piney hops. There is pleanty of malt base with caramel, crystal, and toffee characters to hold up
to the bitterness of the hops used. A smooth creamy full bodied beer.

I am proud to say I am one of the "few" to love this beer.

Bottle.  Finally rating this brew.  One of the first stones I tried some 4-5 years ago.  Nose is sharp, hoppy, some caramel, and some hotness.  Flavor is pretty similar to the aroma- agressively hopped, some caramel, and a big alcohol presence.  In my younger days I really valued the alcohol, but now its just a distraction.  Ill always have a special place for AB and Stone in my heart.

Ahh, the old classic bastard. I have had this beer many times and it was one of the first "big" beers I ever had.It is a dark ruby red color with a generous fluffy tan head. This is a good looking beer that borders between a n Amber and a Brown ale in color. The smell is hoppy and malty at the same time. The taste is like a battle between citrus hops and caramel tasting malt flavors. This is very good stuff fresh but if you get a bottle out of date you will not get the full experience on this one; the hops really fade. Too bad Stone cant produce this in six packs at a reasonable price.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-20-2007 15:53:58

22 ounce bottle poured into a tulip glass produced a lovely tan head with a reddish, amber body.  Aroma was fruity and the flavors of citrus, raisins, and wood.  Long lasting aftertaste on the palate.
Bottle. Bronze  with a small head. Nutty and fruity with a medium body. easy to drink but quite powerful at the same time. Impressive.
dark reddish brown pour with a small offwhite head...nice balance of hop and malt...nice

On Tap at Shallos. Pours slight reddish brown with foamy beige head. Problem here is the nose is so darn inviting, I cant wait for the head to fade! Nose is the freshest citrus, grapefruit, piney hops and slight malt. Flavor is the most uniquely excellent blend of fresh, fruity, floral hops and a perfect touch of malt backing. I would call this something more like a Dark Malt DIPA! SO fruity and citrusy and inviting...it is hard to keep in the glass!!! Also hard to believe you have to be an Arrogant Bastard to like this stuff, though I will not excuse a UM alum who doesnt!!!
(Had this many times from bottle...once on tap in Escondido at Stone...finally rating from fresh keg tap)

Not sure why I never rated this beer. Ive had it over 50 times and never took the time to rate it. NIce brown pour with a medium off white head to it. Nice nutty caramely smell that is also present in the taste nice syrupy feel to it. Its like a thick brown ale real nice. There, I did it.

Big bottle served at a comfortable drinking temperature. Nice, lasting off-white head over a mahogany coloured body, with only a slight haze. Aroma of dry malts and dark fruits. Complex taste profile that starts malty and develops into a blend of berries and pine hoppiness. Bitter ending with hints of yeast. Alcohol taste was mild. Very good beer.
Average head hounded by a sweet brown sugar and malty aroma with a fit balance flavor.
One of the greats. Not quite as good as the Oaked Arrogant Bastard but delicious nonetheless. Enough malt to balance the bitterness.
Bottle. A modern classic! Lots of malt, malt of hops, lots of taste. Extremely complex. Sweet hoppy aswell as a burnt maltiness. A balanced unbalance...

Bottle at Oliver Twist, Stockholm.

Pours deep red with a small head that easily resurects from a spin of the glass.

Burnt malt and raisin in the aroma.
Lots of malts and some sweetness in the taste, finishes a bit burned. 
Quite balanced and uniform brew, but still complex!

Had a couple drafts at the local Cajun joint, and found it ample enough to hold its own against the complex flavors of the spicy food. It has a nice creamy head and smooth taste, with a swift kick of bitterness at the end. Will have again.
UPDATED: OCT 3, 2012 Poured a dark amber. Hops hit first with a succulent grapefruit punch. Malt barely noticeable, but still apparent. Good one to sip on all night long.
Poured into a snifter, a dense half inch beige head formed atop the reddish brown ale.  Good malt and hop balance in the aroma and flavor, with a lingering depth after each sip.  Excellent ale!
I like this one. Thought it was a bit rough at first taste but it has grown on me. Nice bite to it.

Poured from a bottle into a pint glass

The color is a deep red almost a maroon color with a foamy white, brownish head.

The smell is of oats, strong and bitter, hard to place but the outgoing main aroma.

The taste is bitter, strong bitterness taste the first taste buds and throws them for a wallop. The hops in the background sit on the already busy tongue till it bring about tastes that were never expected from a beer such as this.

The real puzzle that is Arrogant Bastard is the taste. It is hard by sweet at the same time. Hard going down but sweet till the last drop. Just the experience a good micro fan must have.

12 pack of bombers.  Poured dark brown, almost reminded me of a stout.  Had a serious bite, and the abv had me sweating by the time I finished the bottle.  This is one that I will share with a friend next time I crack one open.
Its rough. This Ale will put hair on your chest. Smooth is not a word I would use to describe the after taste as it lingers on your tongue. This is a good cold weather beverage.
Oh this is good! A solid balance of malt and hops that is way more approachable than the label suggests! Subtle hints of citrus and caramel.

Pleasant, but not as "arrogant" as the label makes it out to be. Good solid bitterness dominates after a very sweet and sticky initial hit. Theres a hot alcohol component too. Maybe Im being pickier because this is so highly rated, but while its a good solid beer, and one Id love to have again, Im just not sure its a "99" as the stats say.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2009 bottle. floral aroma with a hint of honey. Dark red amber color. Heavy on the bitterness, my friends guess the IBU for this one at 90 Id love to know its score. Creamy texture that works beautifully against the bitterness.
ambrato carico  buona schiuma discreta persistenza note maltate biscottate leggera tostature  luppoli americani in bocca intensa buon corpo maltature e decisa luppolatura

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2009 Bottle from the GBBF 2009. Well Ive heard a lot about this beer. It looks pretty much close to perfect in the glass, I know its hard to give appearance a 5, but in this case I had to as I cant imagine many beers looking as appertising. The colour is lovely red/amber and glows invitingly like burning embers, the head is big and creamy and sits a god half inch above the top of the glass without falling over the side. The first thing Im struck by is the maltiness of the aroma, after hearing how hoppy this Bastard was meant to be, I was surprised. The aroma is malty, roasty and heavy with bread and also with some delicious citrus creeping through, then in to floral hops tasty. The flavour is absolutely delicious, however, I am blown away, and I mean BLOWN AWAY by how controlled the hop action is... The hops ride along playfully on a tidal wave of biscuity red malt only ever becoming bitter as it reaches the back of your tongue. Amazingly well balanced! But the characteristic I adore most is its sensual, soft, creamy full body. Stupendous beer and far more elegant than I had anticipated from this well known brewery.

Bottle, from Utobeer, 29th July 09. Finally got round to rating this great beer, as I tend to enjoy it too much to bother writing a rate! Rich deep russet colour, slightly hazy, small beige head. Full bodied and ever so flavoursome - lots of strong hops along with a robust caramel malt backbone.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a beautiful, deep, reddish-brown with a medium tan head.  Medium lacing.  Hoppy, medium malt, and caramel.  Some citrus aromas.  Starts off bitter and evolves into a smooth, but complex beer.  A real treat, but probably not for the timid  as the name (and hilarious label reading) imply.
On tap at Pour 24.  Caramel and hop in the aroma.  Taste is sweet with hop and caramel.  Really a pleasant beer.

22 oz bottle. Dark ruddy brown color with light brown head. Light citric nose. Head is light and wispy upon sipping. Sweet tobacco and caramel notes. Very dry finish but the head gives it a light fluffy dimension to the finish.  Very well balanced. Crystalline lacing. A real sipper.

Pours reddish brown and dark.  Caramel malts and dominating hopping.  I dont think I could drink this easily without a couple of other beers or liquor in me already, but as it was, this went down with a palatable flavor profile.  Still though I often wonder if even strong ale needs to be this bitter and how extremely bitter, high IBU ales get rated so highly again and again.

pours very dark, initial aroma was candy sugar and a fruitiness like sour cherry - as it sat a bit, the aroma became more subtle and with less of the sour fruit. Flavor is, as noted, an assault on the palate. Pleasant fruit and malt with a hint of chocolate and a noticeable burst of alcohol to start and then bitter, bitter bomb of hops on the roof of the mouth to finish. As it warmed, the booziness was more focused and less pleasantly integrated to where it overwhelmed. Interesting effort, but Not my favorite.

Deep brown with a lasting off-white head, leaving lace. Aroma of caramel, malt, toffee and citrus hops. Rich malty biscuit and toffee flavour, quite sweet with a solid bitter finish - not much hop flavour though.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2009 Bottled. Strong hoppy aroma with hints of fruit sweetness. Redish amber/brown color; beautiful. Lasting beige head that starts thick and stays around. hop dominate flavor with prevalent, unmasked alcoholic flavor. Bitter finish as expected by the dominate hops but not as unbalanced as maybe expected. A  lot to handle

I know Im late to the party but, give me a break Im just starting out in my serious craft journey.

Poured from a awesome looking bomber. That insulted me several times while reading the back story. I loved it. Its a deep red brown color with a wee bit of head. I was expecting more head but, Im not that concerned about. The aroma is faint but,there. I really had to get my nose in this one. It smells of citrus and hops. The taste was wonderful. Theres the initial bite of the citrus hops and nice caramel smoothness that makes this very drinkable. The mouth feel is pleasant with a decent heartyness moderate carbonation. 

Overall this is a winner in my book. Im not a hop head by any means but, if this the gateway to bigger and stronger hop flavors. The door has been kicked wide open my friends.

Pours a light re-brown with good dense tan head.   Strong and assertive aromas of appetizing hops, and dark burnt malt.  Full bodied, almost oily, with good carbonation.  The taste starts innocently enough with sweat dark malty flavors but the gives way to a giant tidal wave of hop bitterness with a long, lingering strong black coffee and bitter baking chocolate finish.  Not for the faint of heart.  This is an all hops goliath.  Not sure what foods will go with this, this beer pretty much overpowers and bullies everything else.
A typical beer from stone...  Flavor is dominated by West Coast hops, but it isnt overly citrusy.  Medium caramel malt backbone which balances it really well.  Big and bold, and I like it!
Draft Pours a medium dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of citrus and malt with a little bit of hops. Medium body...it is what it is...
Very overpowering hoppy taste, reminded me a lot of an IPA with its bitterness.  Hard to really rate it since its not an IPA, but decent nonetheless.

Dark amber pour with good head and lacing.  Nose is some really pleasant floral hops and alcohol.  Taste is overpoweringly, brutally hoppy, but with some good malt balance.  Honestly though, this beer is all about hopsbitter, floral, and delicious.  Pretty damned good.

From 220z botte. pours a ruby with a  big tan head.  The nose is sweet malt with a citrusy hoppy aroma. Malt, fruity flavor with lots of hops. Nutty, caramel, and lingering citrus round out the prolonged notes. Bitter lingering aftertaste.  A beer that I hope I am worthy of.
Pours a red copper color. Lots of hops in the flavor but not nearly as aggressive as Ruination. An enjoyable beer if hops is your thing!
Haha, fits the title perfectly.  Red-brown pour, strong floral/hops in the nose.  Flavor is what the bottle leads one to expect.  Bold and hoppy, lots going on but not busy.
Dark amber color with a nice beige head,  aroma is hopy with some floral notes, flavor is hoppy as well and mouthfeel dont let me lies, hop is everything in this beer! Good stuff!
arrogant bastard ale is a pretty harsh beer, makes that clear on the back of the 22oz bottle. high on hops, kinda bitter-sweet. i recommend this one if you like a dark beer

Very hoppy and a little harsh for me. I can certainly see the high ratings, yet for me this is way too biting and bitter. Have to give this a thumbs down, but that speaks more about what I like than the quality of the beer.
a red/brown color when poured. a longer lasting head. definitely some character to the taste (a tart beer, which I am not a huge fan of).  But overall it was worth the money.

Bottle pours very dark clear red color with off white head.  Head is frothy and lasts a little while.  Aroma is pine and some astringency.  Mouthfeel is smooth.  Flavor is pine hops and astringent grain.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Nice brew overall.  This is a brew I go back to every once and a while.

From the 1 pt. 6 fl. oz. bottle with no noticeable lot code or expiration date on the label. The pour is a dark amber-brown with a generous supply of frothy beige head that foams up as if it was poured from a nitro can.  The aroma is kind of special and best described as floral malts.  Tart hops tend to be the leading flavor which is bold overall.  Everyone seems to like this one and so do I.

22 oz bomber bottle.  This is quite good stuff, and did not dissapoint even with all the hype around it.  Aroma is full, yet well balanced.   A good amount of nutty grain maltiness, lots of thicker fruit notes such as apples, pears, and melons, a good earth of earthy and bold citrus hops.  It definitely smells stronger than 7.2% abv.  Pour was nice as well, with a medium sized creamy head, good retention, and caramel crimson in color.  The taste is well balanced, and the flavors come out quite nicely.  Lots of malty fruitness to back up the thick offering of hops.  Main players on the flavor notes include earth, nutty caramel cereal grains, a good amount of medium fruit salad, pine, and thicker citrus bitterness that lingers better than i was expecting upon initial sip.  Really a very solid beer that definitely left me wanting more when the bottle was gone.  Its nice when beers of this caliber live up to the hype.

Pours reddish brown with a medium sized, long lasting light brownish head. Taste is very assertive with big character; the advertising isnt kidding.  
Taste strongly of hops with a touch of dark cherries.  Aftertaste is very bitter and lingering.  This was an enjoyable experience, though I find some of Stones other brews more sublime and balanced.    Definately will come back to this one though.
It was a bit much for me to drink, kinda hard to find around the Colorado Springs area.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2009 IVE SEEN THIS BEER SEVERAL TIMES BUT NEVER PURCHASED IT, IT ACTUALLY TRYS TO INTIMIDATE YOU WITH ITS MARKETING  TELLING YOU YOU CANT HANDLE IT AND YOU WONT LIKE IT, WELL I FINALLY BOUGHT ONE TODAY AND HERES HOW IT WENT,
IT LOOKS LIKE DARK HONEY WITH BASICALLY NO HEAD, COMES IN 22OZ BOTTLES WHICH IS A SHAME BECAUSE I WOULD LOVE A SIX PACK OF THESE,TASTES LIKE NOTHING BUT HOPS WITH BARELY ANY AROMA BASICALY JUST A GOOD HOPPY BITTER ALE WITH DESENT ALCOHOL CONTENT QUITE DELICIOUS BUT IN THIS CASE THE BOTTLING AND GIMIC MAY ACTUALLY BE COOLER THAN THE ACTUAL BREW IS , STILL GREAT NONE THE LESS.

Not a fan of hoppy, herbal, aromatic beers, which this is. If you like that style this is definitely a solid choice. The Arrogant Bastard Ale (incredible name--reason why I bought it) is simply put...arrogant. Strong, hoppy, out of control with hoppiness, it is like an IPA. Not my cup of tea (or beer I guess) but it will grow on you and is a good brew.
Caramel malty aroma...Caramel brown in color... Flavor is sweet almost citrusy initially with a nice spicy bitter finish... Hints of caramel and biscuits... Freaking staple... Great beer

On tap at Coasters.  Light brown pour with a creamy tan head.  Surprisingly very little aroma; almost undetectable.  Flavor, however, is very noticeable; bitter hops balanced with some malty sweetness.  I suppose it is listed as an American Strong Ale because there is no real good category to list this one in.  Certainly unique in flavor even though it is hoppy.  A great beer.

Sampled many times before, this time poured at Made in the Shade 2009. Pours a deep red/brown with thick two-finger white head. Aroma of pine/citrus/spicey hops and some caramel maltiness. Taste is definitely on the bitter side, lots of spicy hop character pours through (chinook?). Big malt backbone to back up the bitterness. Not necessarily really drinkable, but pretty tasty. My preference would be for a less spicy variety of hop.

Bottle. Dark red pour with a moderate, foamy head. Malty aroma of nuts and toffee with some hop notes. Caramel flavors with nice spicy hops on the back end. This is a really well rounded big beer. Its the perfect starting point when youre checking out this brewery.

Pours dark ruby brown with a long lasting creamy tan head. Aroma is cherry, alcohol, butter, honey, citrus, and roast. Taste is bitter up front with hops and roast malt, then ripe fruit. Just enough sweet thick malt is present to offset the massive amount of rich hop. Very excellent beer and perfectly balanced.

Dark ruby red with a thick loose light tan foam.  Big caramel malt, toffee, apples, thin spicy and citrusy hop aroma.  Taste is toffee, fruity, caramel, huge sweet maltiness, light fruits and a big spicy hop finish.

22 0z. bottle.  Clear dark brown pour with a thick cream colored head.  Aroma is nice, toasty, caramel, nutty and some hop kick.   Flavor is more of the same with a nice bitterness in the finish.  Very good overall.
22 oz bottle.. hippies love this too, shout out to my first phish show, helped me rediscover this beer. The first 2 times i tried this i hated it. Funny how your taste changes... a good one

Appearance:  Pours a dark amber, with two fingers of tan, fluffy head.  The body is fairly clear, you can see objects through the glass and the beer.  There isnt much visable active carbonation rising from the body.

Aroma:  Buiscuity malts, earthy hops.

Taste:  Huge amounts of bitter, metallic hops head straight for the back of my tongue. Just a really minute level of malt sweetness is there, but most of the malt I taste is close to bready, rather than sweet.

Mouthfeel:  Heavy and thick for sure.

Overall:  Im worthy, but this is a tough sell. I can appeal to many audiences, all for different reasons.  I give this beer extra credit for hooking me on Stone.  While my intentions were to guzzle down a 7.2% beer at the time, I found myself intrigued with hops after having this a few times.  Also of note, this beer is great fresh on tap, and OAKED Arrogant Bastard is way better than this even.
A nice, smooth pour. Just the right side of bitterness. Medium-to-full body. Quite good for the price, really.

Exceptional hop flavor predominates over a great basic beer base. This was the first beer I ever liked with more hop flavor than Sierra Nevada Pale Ale. Many other beers from many other brewers seem to try miserably to mimic this. However, it is not as good as their Levitation Ale.

Bottle from Bottleworks.  Pours a dark amber with light tan bubbly head.  Honey, molasses and alcohol aroma.  Strong sweet honey flavor balanced well with light bitterness.  Thick, syrupy but a good finish.

Bottle. Large creamy like beige head that mostly lasted. Good display of lacework. Amber color. Aroma nice mellow pineapple, grapefruit, citrus. Over the palate came heavy malty and hoppy notes on a smooth mix, yet quite heavy feel. Full bodied with an average carbonation and dry texture. Moderated bitter and sweet flavor in balance. Lingering bitter floral and strong malty finish. Excellent beer.
Bottle at Patricks Pub Kristiansand.  Red golden colour with a beige head. Aroma is malt,roasted, hop, caramel. Flavour is sweet, malt, roasted, , hop, grapefruit, caramel. Full bodied nice beer.
Pours a deep red. Nose runs the gamut of american west coast hops and a mixture of sweet malts. Flavor is much of the same. Very bitter, but doesnt linger. Finishes sweet-ish and dry.

Rusty colored pour with a creamy eggshell head that left a significant amount of lacing.  Aroma is of caramel, sweet malt, and candied citrus.  Flavor is fairly well balanced, although not as aggressive/assertive/arrogant as its older brother...has a similar profile of dark fruit, hops, and alcohol.  Tasty beer...surprised I hadnt rated it before.

Hazy reddish brown in apperance, a decent tan head is produced with a good pour that produced some nice sticky lacing early on. There is a hell of alot strong, savoury fruity malts, fresh and warm aromatic hops and grapefruit. Very strong aroma overall. The malts come out very nicely after this bastard has warmed. I love malts and the malt taste here is amazing. Insanely tasty malts! Awsome. Peppery hops, what seems to be a bitter chocolateness and even some hearty bread. There is also a sweet quality to the flavour. Very soft creamy mouthfeel. Not sure if Im feeling the hops or the alcohol, but its all good. Heavily bodied and a very bitter aftertaste which is almost numbing. Excellent finish. I dont find any flaws in this beer. Its fresh, tasty and very enjoyable and even better closing in on room temperature.

Pours a  amber brown with a nice tan head.  Aroma is of very hoppy with hints of pine and grapfruit, but also has some malt.  flavor has a good combination of malt and hops with grapfruit, pine, and some fruit flaovrs, but also some nice carmel malt flavor is balance the hops.  finish is medium and is dry.  overall, a excellent American Strong Ale.
Beautiful head and appearance.  Feels really good in the mouth with a balanced finish.  Good beer!

Poured a dark, hazy brown with a small white head.  Aroma is strong of malt, yeast, and hops with notes of grapefruit, citrus, pine, and dark fruit standing out.  On the palate, the beer felt crisp and dry.  Perfect carbonation.  The taste brought out a hoppy bite.  The finish was a little dry.  Worth drinking again.

Nose was hops o plenty with some fruit and pine. Pours a nice brownish red with some good head. The carbonation and medium body is very well done and works well with the high hops... Finish is smooth.. Malty and hoppy with some citrus. I wanted to drink this again before I rated it and I am glad I did... a year ago I would of rated it a lot higher... still a good beer

Can you handle the arrogance? The brewers description of this beer on the back of the bottle is the greatest Iv ever read, funny and just insulting enough to keep the faint of hart away leaving more for the true beer drinker. The beer pours a dark, dark cloudy brown with hints of red around the edge of the glass, a thick but short tan colored head lasted the entire length of the beer and left some impressive lacing. The smell is yeast hops and grape fruit, it was a fairly subtle aroma and could have been stronger. The taste like the aroma was pretty simple yeast, hops, and grape fruit that blend together for a creamy taste. The moth feel is soft and tangy and there is a bitter after taste left in your mouth. You can tell this a high quality beer and is very enjoyable, its just pretty simple tasting and maybe a touch over hoped for the style.

Im not a hop lover and Ive been fixated on sweet/imperial stouts for a long time.  I cant believe how much I enjoyed this beer.  It seemed extremely bitter at first, but after a few sips I found myself enjoying a seemingly perfect balance of hops and malt in this fine American ale.  I enjoyed this one two days ago and Im still thinking about it.
Amber-brown color with offwhite head.  Medium-bodied, malty aroma.  Spicy taste with malts, finishes strong.  My first beer from Stone, and it definitely wont be my last.

22 oz bottle.  Never been my favorite Stone, which might just be my favorite brewery.  I could never get much flavor out of it; its hoppy, but I never felt there was too much else going on.  Good and reasonably priced, but never my first choice.

22oz bottle. Poured a rich brown with a small head.  This was the first bottle Id had in a few years - smoother than I remembered, with more spice by smell than by taste.  Smooth start with a hoppy, bitter finish.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2015 Bottle. First beer I had tried by stone brewing. As the description said it is an aggressive beer hopped and spiced. But i do like this beer and would recommend it for any person looking for a great beer.

22oz Bomber. Pours a brown color with a slight tan head. Smell of hops and spices, maybe even a hint of caramel. Taste is hops and malts with a spicy touch. Has a bitter aftertaste. This is a pretty damn good beer. Paid $4.99.

So first off this beer got me started on the whole craft beer obsession years ago.  Always consistent and very affordable.

Pours dark dark red with a nice amount of head that sticks around very well.  On the aroma I get hops, malt, almost a subtle fruit smell in there as well.  I would say more full bodied than anything else.  Nice mouthfeel especially when you have had a lot of other beers and gotten used to the more aggressive ones.  I have noticed this one to be a bit sharp for a newbie to craft beer.  Lingers around on your palate after the fact reminding you just how great it really is.  Highly highly recommended!

750 mL bottle from Seattle. Pours a dark brown with just a hint of red, with a thin but foamy head. Aroma starts out all resinous hops, but adds in some raisins and other fruit underneath. The flavor is mostly resiny hops again, but there is some maltiness lurking down there. Not much, but a bit. The finish is long and bitter. Palate is very nice, with very fine and light carbonation. Overall a decent beer, but quite one-dimensional.
Poured from 22 oz bottle.Dark Mahogony in color with medium tan head.  Nose of hops with a bit of fruit.  Excellent taste very well balanced between the hops and malts, with a dry finish.

Draft.  Dark mahogany color.  Mild earthy aroma. Average sized off white head.  Very good lacing.  Huge hoppy flavor, but honestly more bitter then hoppy.  The writeup is correct.  Most people will not like this.  But I loved it.  Its good and nasty, not for those faint of heart.  Nice dry finish.

Thanks to Daknole. Dark amber pour with a light tan head. Aroma of hops, sweetness, Dry taste, flavor of malt, mild sweetness, spicy hops, a little bitterness at the end. Slightly creamy mouthfeel. I wish this beer was available in my area.
Draft, Bottle, and Cask WHAT!   Amber body with an off white head.  Fresh sweet pine and hints of caramel with a light citrus and on cask the hop character was delicious.  Great beer.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2011 The Bastard pours a deep deep red amber hue to a nice frothy light beige head that laces your glass nicely..aromas of  spruce, resin hops, perfume coming through...taste of bitter spicy evergreen trees bushes plants flowers seeds hops hops hops, citrus, very nice I love it..this is what I expected from the bastard, nothing less, beautiful appearance, taste great..The Bastards worthy...

Pours a very murky, dark amber color with a very thick yellow, off-white head that leaves tremendous lacing as it goes down.  Aroma is very full of a great mixture of hops; citrus notes are very pungent, a nice piny background bitterness is present and a light spicy nose too.  Flavor begins with a very strong and full citrus and pine bitterness which lightens as it moves into a middle where the caramel and Munich malt sweetness and roasted notes really come out and the beer finishes with a deep bitter bite. Beer is thick but not as thick as I would of expected with the sweetness and it has a very creamy and smooth. I can honestly say I was a bit worried because this beer is sooooo hyped but in all honesty it stands up to expectations and one I could see being a regular beer if on tap at a bar in my area. This beer is honestly very well balanced and no one aspect of it stands out but as a whole they completely meld making a truly fantastic brew.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2012 rerate: 10/12 tried again in a bottle, enjoyable.  Nice balanced malty ale... not an ipa.  And ads such a very nice beer.

5/09 It is hoppy but not as hoppy and bitter as some beers.  Actually failry pleasant.  I would have it again, but not being a hop head, wouldnt be my first choice.

theyre right, im not worthy. this one is a classic, how could any man resist a beer called arrogant bastard ale? pours a dark red, strips my mouth of any senses except the wonderful bitter aftertaste.

Bottle:  Poured Dark reddish brown clear, but not easily seen thrugh.   Thin but consestant head.  Nice resinous piney hops smell.  Taste was smooth with a slightly toasty burnt malt under tone with a touch piney hops.  Ending is bitter but smooth.  Typical very good Stone brew.

Hazy orange pour with a small white head leaving some lacing on the galass. Small slow bubbles. Citrus and hops in the aroma. Full bodied with medium carbonation. Total hop explosion. Bitter floral and citrus in the falvour. Long citrus and floral finish.

Pours a deep reddish brown/mahogany with thick tan boulders that dissipated to a solid film and left great lacing. Pine hops were the strongest aroma with roasted malts clearly present. A delicious beer, strong resinous hoppy flavor balanced with strong maltiness that lingered in the background. Medium body with light carbonation that left a real good mouth feel. High alcohol content was not evident at all.
Had a reddish-orange color, with a decent amount of head and lacing. Great hoppy taste balanced by the malts, with a smooth finish. Another excellent offering from Stone. LC
Hoppier than expected  - oily, rough, pine, little citrus. Lovely dark amber hue. Wasnt feeling this style when I had it, but it wasnt bad.
UPDATED: JUN 28, 2009 BOTTLE: I am a tough rater. You probably wont like me. It is quite doubtful that you have the intelligence to understand comments of this quality and depth.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2009 (bottle from Weber St Liqour in Colorado Springs). Pours a cloudy dark amber color. Large tan head.  Sweet aroma. Heavy hop and malt flavors. Long duration. Slightly oily texture. Bitter finish. Good lacing. Moderate carbonation.

Bottle at Olympen, Oslo. Beautiful, hazy ruby red copper with a lacing, yellowish head. Fruity hop aroma with apples and lime in the lead. Bitter hop flavours, some toffee to balance. Green apples, grapefruit and grass. Well-carbonated, full body. Deserving the attitude.

Clear, burnt amber pour with a finger-and-a-half worth of creamy head. Aroma was a very hearty mix of malt, hop, and a citrusy sweetness. The taste didnt disappoint either--medium full to full body, quite malty-sweet with a touch of grapefruit and something else I cant put my finger on when it first hits the tongue, giving way to a malty-bitter finish.

Pours a dark amber copper with medium white head, lacing minimal.  Aroma strong of hops (a nice balance, no particular one evident), pine, and heavy malt balance.  Flavor is quite pleasant, the malt balances and makes it more complex than I was expecting.  Nice change from the IPAs, stouts, browns, and barley wines.  22oz is a bit too much in one sitting though, 12oz is good enough.

Bottle. A slightly hazy, golden to copper beer with a nice, dense, beige head leaving beautyful lacings The aroma has malts and hops in a nice blend, with some roasted malts in the back. Sweet, malty, slightly roasted flavor with piney and resiny hops giving a fine bitterness that lasts for a while. Full-bodied and slightly warming. A nice and balanced beer, but is is worthy the commercial description? That doesnt really matter, and it was really fun finding it at a Norwegian pub. (090403)

Tried it on draft in a bar. The beer is deep mahogany in color. Aroma is all hops with a slight hint of malt. When you smell it youll know whats going to hit you: hops, hops, hops. Earthy, woody hops assault the palate right away. Felt like my mouth is burning.  Finish is long lasting and all hops.  Wow, so good.
Love this stuff!  It is one aggressive beer.  This beer got me started on trying all kinds of new and interesting beers.  If you are looking for a one of a kind beer try Arrogant Bastard Ale.

Cascading full head that poured three fingers thick; this is something I expect only from the nitro-can stouts. Unfiltered cloudiness with an orange hue from a bright backlight. Maroon-brown in normal light. Very impressive sticky lace on the glass sides. 

Grassy dark malt aroma up front; strong molasses-like smells. Sweet like caramel candy or maple syrup. 

The flavor is rich and complicated. Strong carmelized sugar flavors in the beginning of the sip. The hops crecendo slowly and powerfully. I am fascinated with the experience after the swallow: the molasses sweetness returns followed by an intense IPA-like hop bitterness. This beer has a body like light cream. The higher-than-typical carbonation provides the perfect foil to nearly overwhelming flavors. 

This beer offers one of the best carnival taste rides: malty to hoppy to candy sweetness to dry hop bitterness. Id love to know how they made this beer. Its like drinking a symphony.

PS I notice that my reviews are longer when the beers are interesting and complicated. It seems that my ratings are proportionate to the length of the review.

Poured in my Alpha King pint glass a nice thick khaki head.  A very clear kind of tea color body.  Smell some good hops and hint of malt.  Lots of things happen as I take the first taste.
