Hops, malt, some other flavors all seem to battle for your attention.  This doesnt bother me so much...I very much enjoyed this beer.  Also noticed a kind of astringency to this beer at the end.  Kinda interesting...Very good

Brown foamy mess that tries to copy Fullers 1845 - wannabe brewer. Sloppy toffee notes all over the place piled over cocoa and chocolate, with quite a jangle of mixed-up hops following into the train-wreck finish. Way too heavy for the style, and the detailed dry hopping is all out of kilter. Wheres the main show?? I just dont appreciate this beer wasting my time at all.

little head, resembles a barleywine in pour.

Smells of light pine hops and memories of getting really drunk and hooking up with extremely questionable women.

Taste just doesnt do it for me anymore. Too sweet. Tastes are strong of pine hops and dark brown sugar and dark fruits.

All the flavors are just having a food fight on my tongue.
Pours a DARK brown with tints of amber.  Aroma of chocolate, cherries and molasses.  Taste is hoppy with malt to match.  Very good balance.  Slightly bitter finish.  Very good beer
pours deep amber almost brown with a head that fades quickly smells of hops tastes of hop with a malt balane. very nicely balanced.
This beer just assaults your taste buds, but in the best way.  At first sip it almost (almost) feels like its going to be to much, but after you get past that, youll be craving more.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2009 Location: First tried this one on tap at the Capital Ale House...lets guess 2002, have had it many times since then bottled and on tap.


Overall Impression: 
Really well done strong, flavorful ale. Love this one. This was really the beer that got me interested in the Micro beer movement and sampling new beers.  I remember ordering one of these on tap when the Capital Ale House opened in Richmond, VA, and just loving it, and I still really enjoy it today.  Since then I have tried many, many other beers, but I still come back to this one as the beer that forged my interest and corralled my taste buds down the beer drinking worm hole I may never escape (lets hope!).

Bottle. Pours deep amber with a medium sized off-white head. Extremely hoppy aroma, makes my palate go into red alert.
When this beer hits my tongue, my tongue implodes and try to escape the extreme bitterness. Well, I suppose im not worthy, this is simply too much........
This beer is certainly arrogant. Not for the faint of heart or those who do not enjoy their taste buds being suckered punched.
This beer is definitely arrogant. Not for the faint of heart, but man do I enjoy it! I find that this is great in colder weather.
This beer sucks in a really really good way. I enjoyed drinking this pint of malty goodness despite its lousy attitude. I would punch this beer in the face if it werent so damned tasty.

Big bottle drunk form a trappist glass. Served at a comfortable drinking temperature. Nice, lasting off-white head over a mahogany coloured body, with only a slight haze. Aroma of dry malts and dark fruits. Complex taste profile that starts malty and develops into a blend of berries and pine hoppiness. Bitter ending with hints of yeast. In-depth palate and soft natural carbonated. An hour of joy at Bar & Cigar in Oslo (28.04.2009).
I had it for the first time recently and it was amazing.  Definitly one of my top 5 favorite beers.

A dark amber ale, smell is overpowered by hops, with a hint of malts.  the darkness and heaviness of the beer suggest a lot of maltiness, however i did not taste them... the hops overpowered the beer.  If you like IPAs you will like this beer

22 oz bottle.  Chestnut brown color with beige head.  Head thins out evenly after a few minutes.  Aroma is citrus hoppiness with yeasty pizza dough.  Taste is a combination of coffee, toast, and hop bitterness.  Medium palate.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2009 1 pint 6oz bottle.  Pours a dark brown/amber with a lot of thick, foamy head that holds shaping.  Thick, medium body, creamy.  Fairly bitter, smoky caramel flavor, strong pine/grasy hop flavor. Aroma is about the same.  Finish is bitter.

After having a pint on tap at Fox & Hound I thought this beer had a much better flavor, the bitterness is more appealing, body was a bit lighter.  Better enough so that I had a second!

Nice ale, pours a beautiful dark amber red color with a thick head. Head lasts (almost) too long, giving you time to admire it. Excellent aroma of hops, grapefruit, oregano & and a pinch of cocoa. The first sip hooks me with a very quick sweetness, followed by hops, fresh hay and grapefruit. The end is long, with just enough hops to keep me satisfied & wanting more. A medium feel, it is very crisp and straight forward, it is what it is & doesnt try to push for more. A very good beer, made for sitting back and enjoying.

Im no arrogant bastard, but apparently that is one of the required personality traits one needs to even try to be worthy of the enjoyment of this particular offering from Stone Brewing. Of course, I am referring to the Arrogant Bastard Ale.


My Arrogant Bastard Ale poured rustic amber with copper hues, rather befitting an evening outdoors watching the burning crimson orb shrink below the towering mountains. A head peaks nicely with a mix of big and small bubbles striving for attention. Swift swirls inspire scattered lace along with a short-lived revival of her puffy head. Rising with the night mists is an embracing presence of sweet fruits, caramel and toffee, roasted malts and warm bread, grass, orange, peaches, and grapefruit. Carried away in a delirious fog of sensory delights, I savor our first quaff as I clutch her bounty close. Arrogant Bastard is definitely hop-forward, soaking my tastebuds in dry grass, hay, and bitter-sweet grapefruit esters. Faintly sweet and pleasantly sticky, my mouth waters after each hoppy quaff now overflowing with multiple varieties of ripe grapefruit. As she warms, pine needs and sap tingle on top of my tongue which, despite her rather sticky nature, is enjoying a growing sense of dryness. Offering silent support from the background is a quiet strength of toasted malts and rich whole-grain breads that are laced with faint notes of honey and orange. Arrogant Bastard that she is, our time is over when she decides and well, I guess her decision has been made considering my glass is empty. All that remains are vivid memories of fresh grapefruit, sweet pine, sticky sap, and dry grass balanced perfectly with toasty malts and honey.


A small part of me feels a twinge of guilt every time I say Arrogant Bastard Ale, but I swiftly squash that little voice with a flare of indifference. We all have our inner arrogant bastard which must be embraced from time to time. The brewers at Stone Brewing may embrace theirs at all times, but if such delicious works of brewing are the result, I really cant complain.

Bottle shared with Hophead22.. Pours dark amber with a creamy off white head... Smells great with piney hops and malt...Taste like it smells hoppy and malty, lingers with you to make sure you remember you just drank some Arrogant Bastard... Great Beer!!

Cask at the Rake, London this week. Dark brown pour with a decent head. Malty, sweet aroma. Starts off with a bitter hop blast and ends quite smooth. First time I tasted this about 6 years ago I could not drink it but I really love it now, what a fabulous beer, full of character. I like the pompous, arrogant comments on the side of the bottle. Another great beer from Stone Brewing Co.

22oz bottle shared by DuffManSW at his place. Dark amber with a little bit of red and a big off-white head. Piney aroma with some real nice maltiness. Flavor was very nicely balanced, not overpowering on either side of the malt/hop thang. Forgot what a good beer this is.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: A dark brownish red color, with a slightly off white medium sized head. Smell is sweet, nutty, and alcoholic. Tastes grassy and hoppy with a bitter finish. Great brew! Refreshing and complex.

1 pint, 6 oz. A mostly lasting dense yellow head upon a translucent, reddish-brown colored body.  Aroma has a strong earthy, grassy and piny hoppiness, (almost) balanced by some toasted dark malts and a scent of toffee/cream-caramel. Taste is dominated by earthy and piny bittering hops. Sour- sweet maltiness underneath. Notes of citrus and spices. Mouthfeel is quite sharp, bordering to astringency. Medium body strenght. A powerful and punchy one, and certainly rough on the palate.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2009 After trying a lot of these, bottled and on tap, Im rerating it quite a bit lower. If the beer is very fresh, its basically a heavily hoppy IPA... too hoppy for my tastes. As it ages about 3 months, it mellows and becomes very interesting and good. Then is seems to go funky or bad within another couple months. When its good, its great, but its way too inconsistent for me to rate it so high.

Pours dark brown and ruby with a good light tan head. Alcohol is present in the aroma but not overwhelming. At first taste youre met with immediate malts, hops and plenty of bitterness. Again alcohol is present but not overwhelming. Toasty malty and bitter. Great beer
Awesome beer,  Tremendously hoppy, to an absurd degree.  Crazy amount of malt poking through, like a scotch ale with a bucket of hops.  A bit of caramel, but mostly just bitter.

Bottle.  Put off rating this one for a while, not really sure why, as it used to be one of my go to beers prior to taking notes.  Pours a lightly hazy crimson with a voluminously large lightly tanned beige head, leaving ample lacing.  Aromas of citrus hops, grain, malt.  Medium bodied, malty and hoppy.  Ends with a very large amount of bitterness.
Draft. Poured an amber red with a white head. Strong aroma of hops. Strong flavor of hops. Strong flavors make this a pretty good beer.

Biggish beige lasting head. Deep dark red body. Strong fruity malty aroma with roasty wild berry notes. Dry-sweet malty raisiny wild berry taste with dusty roasty chocolate notes. Some alcohol, too. Full body. Sharpish mouthfeel, probably bitterness, with some alcohol heat. Dry peppery roasty toffee caramel malts aftertaste with citric notes. Very sweet. Excellent. Rather like a huge top-fermented doppelbock. The alcohol, sweet malts, and the bitterness crash together to some degree. (0.65l bottle at Olympen, Oslo.)

22 oz. bottle  dark amber,creamy full head, nice lace all the way down .
  fine taste,complex,  good hop and malt combo. good beer for good friends!

This beer is a dark ruby color, with a fluffy head.  the aroma is malty, with hops and fruits.  the taste is strong with bitterness from hops, and sweet, it is hard to depict flavors in this since the hops are over wellming, but i love the bitterness.. over all i think this is a really good brew

1 pt. 6 fl. oz. bottle, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 7.2%. Dark brown to ruby colour, big to moderate light tan head. Nice but surprisingly moderate aroma of floral and fruity hops. "Arrogance" shows its face in the flavour, with a distinct and aggressive hoppy bitterness from start to finish. There is a certain malty sweetness in the background, but I cannot say the Arrogant Bastard belongs in the "well balanced" category. It is probably not meant to belong there. Perhaps I am "not worthy" after all? My wife said she liked it, though. Spooky ...
I first had AB at Monks cafe in Philly. It was love at first sip. Complex, aggressive and weighty. Not to mention bonus points for the insulting packaging. Top Notch.

Bomber.  Pours an angry amber with a big, three-finger head.  Big bitter aroma of hops and malt, currant and sweetness.  Flavor is heavy, roasted, malty sweet.  Sugar and light licorice in the taste, with light carbonation and lasting body.  Good ale.  Feels like it will stick to my intenstines though...

(Bottle at Oliver Twist, Stockholm, on 2009-04-11) Dark red wine colour and hazy. Small white head. Berries, hops and roasted sugar in aroma. Full bodied and dry palate with medium carbonation. Malts, hops, black currant, sweetness, roasted sugar, bitterness, saltiness and lightly liquorice in taste. Long lasting aftertaste with malts, roasted sugar and bitterness.

I am not a hop head so realize that this is for my own records.  Hops were immediately apparent in the aroma.  I could get some sense of maltiness at the beginning but that soon became lost in the overwhelming hop bitterness.  Is it good? Not to me.

22oz bottle from Ryans PArty Store in Port Huron
Pours a nice dark ruby red with a small white head and fair lacing
The aroma is hops (maybe this should be an IPA) and citrus
The taste is bitter hops and malt
Very nice 
And i am so Worthy you arrogant F   ks

Bottle at Bar & Cigar, Oslo.
Dar red beer, off-white head.
Lots om malty body that picks a fight with the bitter citrus hops. A great beer.

75cl bottle at Bar & Cigar. It poured a dark reddish colour with a medium big creamy white head. The aroma is very hoppy with notes of coffee and some citrus. The flavour is bitter and hoppy, but also has notes of coffee. It has a long, lingering aftertaste.

On tap @ Deluxe. Pours a beautiful red mahogany with a thick beige head. Aroma smells of a lot of dark berries, bread crust, and fresh hops. Taste is very prominent with earthy hops, caramel, and some citrus. Mouthfeel is very nice and overall finishes with a crisp bitterness. Great beer!

Had many times, but this rating based on growler fill from brewery.  Pours a very deep and dark red, bordering on brown.  Three fingers of frothy beige heady that turns cavernous and leaves nice lacing.  Aroma is earthy (kind of musty) with bready malts.  Hops are there in the aroma but muted and less citrusy compared to most other Stone beers.  However, the hops become more prominent in the flavor, contributing much to the aggressive flavor promised on the label.  Some grapefruit.  The malt flavor is present as well and overall well-balanced, though the bitterness does win.  Alcohol well hidden.  Sharp hop bitterness in the finish.  Great name, great beer.

pours a nice ruby red color with huge mouthwatering head. aroma is big malty hoppy fruity citrus goodness.  man the taste is awasome hits you in the mouth, dry finish.. overall a great beer the savior..

Pours a deep, dark red, medium beige head. Aroma is big, caramel, dark fruits, berries, citrus, hops. Taste is nicely balanced between the caramely roasted malts and hops, with fruits and a hint of liqourice inbetween. Refreshing, yet full and round.

Its that kick you in the mouth beer that makes you say "thank you sir, may i have another?". An intense beer with intense malty and hoppy flavors. You either love it or hate it, and if youre the latter then you probably dont like beer.

Had this one after I have tried the oaked and the "double" version wich I both love. This was a bit of a let down though, started out too sweet and sticky and ended on a really harsh note. Still not a bad brew just came of as a bit too unbalanced for my liking.

Bottled 650ml. Courtesy of badlizard. Appearance: It pours a beautiful deep ruby beer with a creamy beige head. Good lacework. Aroma: A lot of celery and raisin showing up. Malt accented with wonderful hops struggling through. Flavor and palate: Huge amounts of raisins appearing. The malt is too appearant to my liking. Licorice in the finish which is rather dry. Overall impression: Not my kind of beer. Thanks a lot badlizard!

22oz bottle. Pours a polished red-brown body with a thin, beige to tan head that leaves a good amount of delicate swirling on the surface and runny lacing on the glass. The aroma is initially a wave of of earthy and spicy citrus hops before it opens up and concedes to sweet, berry malts. Lots of caramel. The malts are abundant, but never smell thick or syrupy. A touch of toasted toffee. Very nice. A light booze note reminiscent of most strong ales, but definitely hidden with the berries. Much more of a sweet aroma than anything else. The flavor is no where near as sweet as I thought it would be after experiencing the aroma. Starts off with a distinct, moderate earthy hop taste that never goes away. Lots of soft malts as well initially. The berries and caramels come through more in the middle and the hop flavor starts becoming very bitter and earthy. It conitinues to grow and becomes even more bitter in the finish and even more yet during the lingering aftertaste. The intense earthy hops kind of give it a "dirty" taste...not that thats a bad thing. A nice citrus, sour grapefruit comes through as well. The caramels are both sweet and toasty. A balanced combination of the two. Not boozy at all, but has that "strong ale" taste to it in the end...but maybe thats just the intense hop bitterness that doesnt seem to go away. Palate is medium bodied, extremely creamy and clean for such a bitter beer, and a bitter duration unlike anything Ive ever come across. Overall, an intensely hopped beer. I mentioned it tasting dirty earlier and with a name like Arrogant Bastard, I think they picked a damn perfect name for this cavalier. Pretty cool version of a strong ale for sure. I liked it a lot, but it just didnt rub me as much as some of the other highly hyped beers Ive tried lately. Despite that, it was delicious.

Poured from big bottle.  Overflow alert - almost drowned taking a whiff!  I do smell malt and spice.  Solid mahogany, rough tan head persists.  Just full of malt flavor, sort of half toasted and half sweet.  Hops in back.  Spice nut, and banana noticed too.  All that and ridiculously drinkable too.  Slightly heady, but that helps in this case.  Excellent.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Pours a deep ruby with a nice tan head... Aroma is mildly hoppy slightly citrusy with a sweet malt backing... Flavor of medium dark somewhat sweet malts with underlying citrus notes... Bitter, but not in a lingering way... Medium bodied..

bottle. Beautiful beige head over a nice brown body. Beautiful bitter hop aroma, a mix of floral and citrus hops. The taste had nice hop profile up front, followed by pretzel tasting malts and finished with excellent hop bitterness.

bottle.  poured a deep amber with a beige head and left some lacing.  aroma of caramel, pine, fruity pixie stick dust, and dark fruits.  flavor is pine resin, alcohol, caramel, and dark fruits.  med-full body and medium carbonation.  i have waited awhile before trying this one and i have to say i was a bit disappointed.  maybe the wait built it up to much, i dont know.
UPDATED: SEP 11, 2009 not too bitter, not too sweet.  just a great beer.  kind of a girly beer compared to the double bastard though.
Draft Pours a medium   dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of citrus and malt with a little bit of hops. Medium body.

Bottle 22oz .A deep dark amber color with a big thick off white head that leaves tuns of lacing as it slowly diminishes,some light carbonation. Aroma is piny,citrusy,and earthy,with some notes of the sweet malt waiting to be tasted. Flavors of  caramel malts,toffee,pine,cherries,smoke ,hints of maybe burbon or oaky vanilla, very deep and complex like and old ale. A medium to full body,velvety mouthfeel, hoppy aftertaste and burps, a little sticky around the lips (something to lick off later), damn this is good shit !  and yes I would drink this all night long or at least untill the 3rd or 4th time I fell down eh.

Pours a medium to dark brown with a large tan head consisting of both large and small bubbles.  There is a strong aroma of malt, hops and molasses.  There may also be hints of citrus hidden in the aroma.  This beer is hoppy enough to be an IPA, but it has more malt and molasses than you will find in any IPA Ive tried.  This beer is very clean feeling in the mouth, but definitely leaves a bit of a bitter taste around the back sides of the tongue.  This is a solid beer.
Good beer, chinook hops are a crowd pleaser.  After this one, me thinks a chinook IPA are in order.

Amber brown hue with copious head of white. Aromas of citrus and malt. Full body. Bold aggressive hops with some good sweet malt. Good long finish. This is all about the hops and bitterness of course. What can ya say about a classic.

reddish amber color with nice yellow head
aroma is sweet with hints of vanilla and malt
flavor is rich and complex, very nice.

22 Oz Bomber from Mintz on Main, TTown.I Loved this beer! Had my eye on it for quite a while. How can you help it with a great bottle like that? Wonderful pour with a great head! Nice and hoppy with a dark taste that was clear and flavorful! You will love it!

well well well what an interesting beer....reminds me of another beer i like....Mayhem! Mayhem is good dont get me wrong but this beer is bloody GREAT! 8/10 for flavour because it possibly could do with a tad more bitterness but to be honest this is pretty spot on! Still not as good as Armageddon but.....almost!
Aroma hops and sweet malt. Good balance of hops and sweet malt. Very good well rounded brew.
I love how this laces a glass.  Always perfect.  I love the big bold flavor.

I tried this beer after reading Greg Kochs interview with "The New Brewer" in "The Brewers Association Guide to Starting Your Own Brewery." I presumed that I would not like it based on its description but was astounded at how delicious I found it to be. It is high in alcohol content so be prepared for that. Great beer, the fame is well deserved.

Pours an iced tea brown with a thing mocha head. Very aggressive, hoppy nose with a smokey aroma. Taste is dominated by hops and hints of caramel. Thin, surprisingly sweet finish. Would like a stronger mouthfeel, but a very good strong american ale.

Bottle.  Sweet malty aroma with fruity, nutty boozy hints.  Murky brown orange body with a thin slightly wispu off white head that clings to the glass.  Nice lacing.   Bitter upfront, and very dry.  Body is floral sweet hops with grapefruit notes.  Finishes super dry leaving a lingering bitterness.  Hops seem to have faded in the aroma but remain in the mouth.

I have had this on numerous occasions but just realized I never rated it- This was the beer that started it for me with Stone Brewing.  Nice balance of bold flavor and drinkability.  It can be a little over the top in succession but to sit back and have one or two- enjoy its worth it.  The dialogue created for these beers are pretty good but by now I think we get the hint- Stone makes aggressive beers!
Had this at Hair of the Dog in Chattanooga, their "ten dollar beer."  Well, it was worth it.  Nice strong flavor, exactly what I was looking for in a beer that day.  Not as intense as I expected.

22ozBomber.
Why a score of 5?
Because,when i find a beer, that in my opinion,defines a style i give it a perfect score.Aroma is a mix of piney hops and roasted malts.In good light it is a dark ruby red with a nice tan head.
Flavor wise it is a solid mix of bitter hops and varying degrees maltiness as it warms up.Very tasty! Medium palate which makes it very drinkable.(maybe my taste buds are dead because of too much IIPA)As far as i am concerned this is one of the best beers in the world which fits the strong ale description perfectly.If i was stuck in an elevator and had a dozen of these i could stay in there for quite a long time before i would start to panic.
very strong,solid beer..very different..not a light hearted beer..fun beer though
Great strong brew!  Not for the faint of heart, this one will diffidently leave its impression on your palate.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2009 This one was too strong for me. The label said I probably wouldnt like it and they were spot on. Has a strong hop/pine taste. I wasnt worthy.
UPDATE: 11/11/09 On tap at the saucer. Pours a heavy red hue. Smell is of fat pine dripping with heavy heavy hops. Taste is right upfront hops, (no surprise) that fills the edges of the tongue and quickly envelops the palate. Some roasted malts also hold sway over the taste. Finishes dry and roasted with the bittering hops reminding you of their anger.

I love the bottle: "This is an aggressive beer. You probably wont like it. It is quite doubtful that you have the taste or sophistication to appreciate an ale of this quality and depth. "  Did I ever, this is outstanding, definitely on the hoppy side, graprefruit maybe?  Deep amber pour, almost red, great beer, 24oz. bottle, cant go wrong.
Nose is hops, color brown, creamy fawn head, hops and malt is a good balance. Bitter finish through a medium body. It was a pleasant surprise at the restaurant I visited this evening.

Enjoyed on tap.  While the nose of this beer is pungent with hops, the palate is somewhat of a disappointment.  While this is a well-crafted ale, the bitterness borders on being overly harsh, and does not have quite enough of a malt balance.  Still, this is a classic example of a thoroughly American style.

This is one of the best breweries in my opinion.  One of many great beers that they brew.  Deep brown pour, smooth mouthfeel, very hoppy but fairly balanced.  Satisfying bitter finish.  Probably a bit better than the Ruination IPA but not quite as good as the Double Bastard.

Pours an opaque brown with a one finger tan head that leaves some really nice lacing.  Aroma is slightly roasted malts, hops, and some dark fruit.  Taste is real nice, and I agree with Stone that their beer is aggressive.  Strong bitter and slightly hot finish

22oz bottle. Aroma is very hoppy and malty. Nice deep amber color. Rich in flavor with a good balance of malt and hops. Its rare to have a beer with as much body and hop flavor taste good, but this one pulls it off. Not my favorite Stone brew but unique and worth a try.

Pours a Deep Amber color with tan head
The hops balance out the sweetness of the malt very nicely. Medium Bodied. Goood Beer.

Had this one on draught at Stone Cellar in Appleton, Wisconsin.  Cloudy, dark brown pour, with a delicious piney hoppy nose, a potent, maple syrup and piney flavor, with a strong bitter finish.  Outstanding.

Dark brown amber reddish beautiful pour. With 2 finger head, that sticks to the glass tighter than spandex to Kirsti Alley. Smells wonderfully of hops and maybe some carmel and malt. Taste is a little sweetnes up front then maybe some carmel and rosted malt, then in the end getting a bit of that hop bitterness, pretty well balanced actually for such an amped up brew, and the alcohol is pretty well hiddden in this one for me also.

Overall I went into this beer hoping to love it, but truthfully expecting to hate it. I was very plesantly surprised with this one, I really liked it alot! and will have to get more whenever im done in TX. [or wherever stone might be sold]

With all the warnings of a beer you probaly wont like, it wasnt that aggressive I thought it would be a very hoppy brew but was surprised that it was quite a good american strong and it reminded me off my local breweys american strong. bottle thanks to Giascar poured a dark amber with nice sized off wiite head with a nose of lightly roasted malts and hops with citrus notes the taste was sweet and mallty and slightly bitter grapefruits cant wait to crack open the double bastard
Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a good sized tan head. Looks great. Taste is initially very good, a nice bitter hoppy bite to it. Aftertaste is strictly grapefruit. Not a big fan of this one.

Nice balance of hops and roasty malts with a hint of spicy sweet aftertaste.  Served in Trappist glass, poured dark amber with a medium light-tan head, lacing was definitely noticeable.  Nice ale that is not too sweet. Full of body and character with a strong finish.

Bottle.  Pours a deep amber color, and a medium head.  Aroma is lightly roasted malty sweetness and a good citrus flavor, grapefruit, bloodorange.  Taste follows, nutty and somewhat spicy malty sweetness.  Medium body, lots of residual sweetness.  Finishes with a decent hop bite.
Pours a dark amber red with a dense off white head. Quite a malty flavour. Quite strong with a very bitter finish. Good, but sort of hard to drink I thought.
Pours a dark amber with a decent sized tan head and little lacing. Aroma of sweet malts and clean hops. Great balance of hops and malts makes this one complex in flavor. Very good.
From the tap poured a dark amber with a good amount of head.  Nice sweet toasted malt flavor with a quick finish.

2009 Bottle - Pours a dark amber with a decen sized tan head...aroma is malty, piney and clean...flavour is aggressive piney hops with rough grain, dark malt...great hop character and balance keep this from being one dimensional...cant believe I hadnt rated this already...

22oz bottle from the Brass Tap in Wesley Chapel, FL. Pours a dark red-brown but still opaque. Thin yellowish head. My new favorite bottle. Aroma is mostly grapefruit, pine, and grass. Flavor is a bit of malt up front...and then tons of bitter pine sap dominating the rest of the way. Pretty damn bitter. Wow, bitter aftertastes are really growing on me..nice sappy, bitter aftertaste...Medium mouthfeel...This beer is pretty damn intense...It seriously kicks the shit out of your palate....but it is pretty damn good.

my first really really good beer, the first time i tried this the best beer i had to that point was heineken. This beer surprised the hell out of me because up till then i expected beer to have little taste if any at all. Remains one of my favorites right behind double bastard ale. Best served a little below room tempature

I neglected to take notes when tasting this beer, so this is all from memory.  My first impression was that this is an exceptionally intense beer with quite a bit of grapefruit.  I dont recall too much of anything else, but the experience was pleasant enough.  Still, I dont know if I would rate it as highly as many of the people have here.  I may have to give it another try, just to be sure.

Nutty caramel and pine smell with hints of bubblegum and licorice.
Dark amber color and difficult to see the action with an off tan head.
Heavy sweet bitter with roasted almost burnt malt taste and has a smooth finish of herbal pine and some grapefruit.
Medium to moderate bodied, very resinous, and has lively soft carbonation.
The drinkability is exceptional for the style.

Wow, I had wanted to try this for a long time finally found it on the east coast.  Definitely worth the wait.  Poured a clear reddish color, eggshell colored head.  Strong nose full of citrus.  Alcohol is somewhat aggressive with a slight nutty flavor and dry hops.  Pretty bitter finish.

read about it on the internet. had to try it and no regrets AT ALL. this beer is so intense and flavorful. the pour is very nice. nice dark red color. smells of hops. malts and very much like citrus almost grapefruit like. very strong up front. can really taste the hops. nice citrus finish. but all around VERY NICE. hats off. cant wait to try the double bastard

They dare you not to like it and I have to say I dont like it. Just too overpowering for me. Maybe when I get more hair on my chest Ill give it another try but for now this is too far in the deep end for me.
Really Strong but good taste.. Light beer  drinkers will not like it.. Nice strong aroma....

Bomber. Pours reddish-brown with a large, long-lasting sudsy beige head. Aroma is grapefruit hops and, oddly, maybe some fruit. Flavor is a whole lot of hops, as promised, although with some nice complexity, with resiny pine notes and nice malt backing. Excellent beer, and not as one-dimensional of a hop bomb as the branding might imply (although not a good starting point for craft-beer neophytes either).

A- Pours a clear dark ruby/brown hue, head is an off-white layer of suds-like foam that mostly sustains, swaths of lacing on the glass
S- Nose is caramel malts with grass/pine hops and alcohol
T- Initial taste is dominated by bitter dry hops which persist throughout, sweet caramel in the middle is followed up by a warming alcohol finish
M- Medium-bodied, watery texture, mild carbonation
D- Ah, I remember the day when AB was too strong for my delicate palate, now I find it smooth, balanced, and honestly, easy-to-drink; i usually have access to various forms of AB and other Stone special releases, so I am rarely going out of my way for the regular old AB, but it is still delicious!
Always a good decision. Just once tho. I cant handle two of these, finishing a whole bottle is hard enough. $5.49 for a 25 oz at Gulf Liquors, Miami Beach

Bottle: Poured a reddish orange with off white creamy lasting head. The aroma is a mix of hops, malts, and citrus. Taste is awesome, its almost like chewing on hops and caramel malts. I like it and wish I had more!

Wow!! This beer is intense very strong aroma... I would say that is probably to hoppy for myself. The taste lingers for quite awhile. I first tried this beer on the train going to SD and I had to throw it away and buy a corona haha.
This is a strong but good ale. There is a good flavor to it with a hoppy finish. People that dont like heavy beers will not like this one.

This is a strong dark beer with an extreme hop flavor.  It left a lingering bad taste in my mouth. I like the high alcohol content, but cant force myself to drink a whole glass of this stuff.  I think people like it because of the name... I dont blame them.

This ale has a dark amber appearance, and releases a citrus/hoppy aroma while pouring.  The taste is rich in malts and caramel.  Overall this beer is over-hopped, which prevented me from enjoying this ale.

pours a dark copper
taste of strong hops and is aggresive like the label says
good beer however not the most drinkable

Poured from a 1 pt. 6 oz. bottle into a pint glass. Decent sized cream colored head. Surprisingly mild aroma from this particular bottle, smells of malts and caramel. The taste is of malt and caramel, with a hops bite and the end followed by a lingering, in my opinion unpleasant, bitterness. I would have enjoyed this beer more without this lingering aftertaste. An all around solid offering
Deep copper color with a good sized off-white head. Aroma is of citrus, roasted malts, and caramel. Taste is of caramel, spicy hops, and a little bit of raisin.

Deep amber color, with a finger of white foam.  Aromas of citrus, like grapefruit or lemon, and piney hops.  The flavor is very IPA like, lots of hops with a bit of a caramel malt backbone.  Finish leaves hop flavor in your mouth, something that I really like.  Excellent

This Beer is pretty ok.  It is VERY hoppy in the finish.  The after taste is bitter its so hoppy.  Everyone talks about citrus and other notes but all you can taste in this is hops.  Its not a bad beer but not extremely note worthy either.  Ive had better.

It has a nice dark copper color which was very pleasing to the eyes.  A consistent foam and carbonation left rings on the glass but not too much carbonation when tasted.  Tasted slightly of cherries and citrus.  The hops gave it a nice floral taste but not overpowering.
Yum.  Smells great with sweet hoppy malty goodness.  Deep copper color with clean head.  Great movement of flavors.  Malty, hoppy, citrus sweetness.  Great beer.
Bottle.  Smells of pine and citrus and taste similarly.  Poured a deep red color with a small white head.
This is a strong flavored beer.  It has a citrus smell and taste which becomes very bitter and almost juniper/pine flavored.  This is just a touch too bitter to be really good.

A nice brew. Quite a bit maltier than I was expecting, it was a nice blend of bitey hops and some good roasted malts. Finish was bitter, but I couldnt tell if it was from the hops or the roastiness. Average carbonation, quite drinkable really. Enjoyable.

Smells grapefruit, pine...tastes the same.  Very good !  It has a long lasting grapefruit aftertaste.
The bottle is wrong,  I do like it!

This is my first rating so I wanted to rate my favorite beer, first.   Poured into glass from tap, an aggressive ale that will ruin the rest of your beers,  making  them all seem watery and boring.RESPECT.

Draft. Deep deep red brown with a thin white head that leave nice lacing. Nose is very malty and sweet. Taste is very malty with a solid hop background that leads to a bit of spice tone. Bitter finish. Good beer!!

UPDATED: APR 9, 2009 Appearance:  red, brown, hazy, a minimal head, tan foam 

Aroma:  well blended malt and hops but only mild in strength; roasty, chocolate, coffee, spruce; slight preference to malt aromas

Flavor:  Very good presentation of an overall enjoyable beer.  More of a hop presence on the tongue than on the nose.  Nice balance.

Palate:  Medium to full body; great silky texture; surprisingly long bitter finish.

Arrogant bastard is a good dependable ale.  It always pours with a nice fluffy head on top of its slightly cloudy golden amber color.

Good aroma of caramel/biscuit dough mixed with the strong piney hops.

Well-balanced flavor, not too bitter.  Good smooth maltiness up front is followed by the bitter hops.

The bitterness does stick a bit to the palate, which isnt a bad thing in this ale.  Not overly bitter and easy to drink, if you dont mind the high alcohol content in this brew.

Definitely worth trying at least once.

This beer is big hops all the way and can be overwhelming at first. It took me quite a few bottles over different occasions to finally settle in and appreciate this one. Cloudy pour with citrus and, of course, hoppy aroma. Tastes like it smells, with a long lingering hoppiness.

16oz draft poured at Rams Head was deep copper color with a slight white head.  Grassy, herbal hop aroma.  Nice bitterness but not too overwhelming.  Bit of caramel, toffee, sweetness, and some bread in teh body.  Medium mouthfeel.
Deep reddish brown, big hoppiness, very aggressive with earthy feel all around, will kick you in the teeth!

(11/3/08) Draught sample at the brewpub in Escondido. Lovely deep red-ruby color. Aroma of hops, some pine, citrus notes and some malt. Balanced flavor with a good amount of sweet caramelly, a bit bready, malt and rather big bitter hoppiness. Medium to full-bodied. Tasty but doesnt shine.

Realized I never have rated this, so football Sunday is the perfect time. Pours a cloudy dark brown with a thick off white head. Big earthy hops and a caramel like malt aroma. Taste is bitter earthy citrus hops, very forward, with a big malt body and hints of caramel. Leaves a bitter hop finish and many destroyed taste buds, giter dun!
Hoppy and aggressive, but very nice.  Dark with little to no head.  Nice aroma.  Taste of malts and caramel and a bit of pine.

Vitals: From: 22oz Bomber, To: 20oz Stem Glass (Harvey Porter or Celebrator style) Filled to Brim, Temp: 50F, Place: Backyard.  
Burgandy, burnished-red, with underlying brown tones and hint of green between head and liquid.  Tannish head with further hints of green.  Aroma of strong, bitter orange hops, fresh loose tobacco, carmelized fruit.  First impression on back of tongue is pits of dark fruit (especially cherries) and unsmoked tobacco, pithy with ruby-red grapefruit and whole flower hops, carmelized fruit in the background.  The lingering taste is reminiscent of chewing on a hop flower after it has boiled in the wort.  Full-bodied, yet very quaffable, texture of a full-flavored, organic Natural American Spirit cigarette.  Arrogant Bastard Ale is an American Strong Ale that sets the standard for the species.  It takes all aspects of a an American session ale to the extreme, thus balancing itself by its characturized  extremities.  A favorite that is always welcomed by this reviewer.

Poured a cloudy amber with no head and light carbonation.  The aroma was an interesting caramelly, malty aroma with some background hops.  At first this beer has a nice malty sweetness to it with a hearty background hoppiness.  As the beer warms the hops mellow out and the beer becomes more dominantly sweet.  The beer is definately big, but the alcohol is hidden fairly well, and waits until the end to come out in the flavor.  A pretty nice big beer, it was enjoyable.

Pours a deep amber/reddish-brown with off white head.  Highly aromatic, strong with tons of flavor, definitely a hop bitterness to it, but balanced with the malt and grains.  An in your face beer.  Medium body, pleasant, slightly sweet finish/aftertaste, with a little alcohol warming.

Pours a very cloudy nut brown with thick tan head. Aroma is malt and caramel nut with forest/pine notes. Flavor is fairly hoppy with caramel undertones to lessen the pine/hop bite. Malts present. Body is creamy with medium carbonation.
Bottle. Poured dark amber with a tan head. Aroma of malts and hops. Taste of caramel and roasted malts. Finishes bitter with a hint of grapefruit.

I always think that we, as raters, are truly arrogant bastards; well, unless you’re Man U or Chelsea fans, then you’re just unbearable.  Well, I should slim that down a bit. I should direct that at the fans who’ve never been to that side of London, nor set foot in Manchester.  Anyhow, the beer. What a beer.  Pours a nice dark amber colour with excellent head and carbonation. Nose is candied, malty, slightly hoppy, and bitter.  Taste is the same, with barley taking hold and adding a more bitter contrast of grapefruits and orange slices.  The hops tip the iceberg well, cutting through even the thickest steel Hulls. How about them Tigers anyhow? Way to go, though  would be cool to see more of that Dean Windass.  Excellent last name mind you.

Trappist.  Pours a black cherry with a thick, foamy, can’t-get-it-off-the-glass head.  Aroma of pine, ruby grapefruit, oranges, lemons.  Flavor blasts of citrus hops, some grass, dry on the finish.  Lingering flavor, kills the taste buds for anything else for a while.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2011 First ratingBottle at The Rover, Göteborg. On January 5, 2009. Clear dark copper to red color, tan head. Sweet hoppy bitter scent. Fruity, bitter, hoppy taste. Medium to a bit hoppy taste. Medium high bitterness. Very clean and balanced, I like!8/4/8/3/16=3.9RerateDraught at Moeder Lambic, Brussels, for Zwanze Day 2011 as well as the Moeder vs Stone beer festival. Sampled on September 17, 2011Clear dark brown color, fluffy lasting milk coffee head. Sweet, malty, hoppy, fruity scent. Sweet at first, though fast turns quite bitter, alcohol taste. Medium to smooth mouthfeel, high dry bitterness. Apricots, alcohol, bitter aftertaste.7/4/7/3/14=3.5

Bottle, Beer Ritz, Leeds. Poured a deep ruby red colour with a good lookin tan head. Big attention grabbing aroma of hops, pine, a lil malt and tropical fruit.  Full bodied, sticky and thick mouthfeel that seemed to balance the hefty dose of malt and hop in the flavour. Piney and resinous with a slight grapefruit tang that leads to a long lingering dry bitter finish. Slightly naff marketing guff and pointless bragadacious flannel aside this is pretty good stuff. Only in America and all that jazz.
Pours amber from the bottle with a creamy head of foam.  Smells and tastes of bitter hops, toffee, orange rind, and pine.  Aggressive and malty -- like a creamy IPA with teeth.
This is a big bold and agressive beer. For the hop head who wants something heavyer than an ipa. Pours dark brown with a cherry hue.  finishs with hints of alchohaul and citrus.

bomber from grape and gourmet poured into a snifter. pours a beautiful cherry wood color with hints of red and short, off white head and great lacing. aroma is huge, fresh hops, hints of orange, grapefruit, pine, and earth with a solid toasted malt aroma as well. flavor is big hops of course with hints of citrus but the roasted and somewhat sweet malt balance is wonderful. slight flavors of cinnamon, biscuit, pistachio also some through. mouthfeel is very smooth, medium bodied, and leaves a long lasting bitter aftertaste with a touch of alcohol. one of my all time favorites that too me way to long to give a proper rating to.
POURS VERY DARK WITH VERY LITTLE HEAD. THE TASTE IS EXTREMELY HOPPY. VERY STRONG AFTER TASTE.

Bomber from Willow Bend Liquors in Lutz, FL. Pours a deep amber brown with an off-white head. Laces the heck out of the glass. Flavor is lots of malt with caramel, hop wallop, and fizzy red grapefruit. Finish ius malt, hops, and lingering grapefruit. Nice, but not my favorite.
the first thing i thought about this beer was how much the malt and hop aromas and flavors stood out individually, in very big ways. also the hopping is wonderful! drink this beer
Pretty damn good. you have the hops that Stone is known for, but some nice maltiness, and a great hop finish. I love this beer!

A keeper! There are some flavors of pine and it is quite hoppy. A deep amber red color, not too much aroma, but flavor does this beer justice. Very smooth flavor but leaves a nice bite which continues shortly after the swig.  Minimal aftertaste, with slight metallic twist near the end.  Will try again.

22 ounce bottle split in pint glass.  Clear reddish amber with lasting head and lotsa lace.  Fresh hop and toasty brown sugar cake aroma.  Brown Sugar toasted maltiness with mild cherry fruitiness and bracing assertive lingering hop finish.  Medium-full body and medium carbo.  Very nice and satisfying.

This was the best beer out of the six I tried during my recent New Hampshire ice storm xmas trip second week of December 2008.  Very powerful.  Hoppy and citrus characteristics.  Full bodied and full of character.
bottle.  pours deep amber with a thicker tan head.  Hop notes mixed with some roasted malts that is full flavored and lively with carbonation.
UPDATED: APR 13, 2009 Bottle from UtoBeer. Ruby red color with a creamy fine head. Caramel,spices andnutty aromas. Roasted malt and hoppy taste with very bitter lasting aftertaste. Nice one.

Could not be more disappointed! Pours a beautiful deep red with a foamy head. Aroma is well balanced between malts and hops, with a little spicyness and a tad bit of alcohol. That is where my praise ends. This beer just feels weird in my mouth - there is no other description. There is a grassy flavor that leaves an incredibly dry, bitter finish. I could not get past the strange palate.

Bottle 66cl.Clear light to medium amber brown color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, caramel, moderae hoppy, grapefruit, citrus. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration. Body is medium to full, texture is oily - syrupy, carbonation is soft. (060808)

Bottle. Hazy deep brownish orange color. Big foamy head. Big woody toasted malts kick you in the teeth with the first sip, rolls into a mild caramelized sweetness and finishes with a blast of fresh piney hops. Medium to full bodied. This is a BIG beer, not for the weak of heart.

Solid stuff.  Malty with oak and great citrusy hops. Bitterness sticks with you. Great at the beginning of the huge bottle, but a struggle to finish it if you are drinking it by yourself.  Medium-full mouthfeel. Awesome write-up on the back label.
22 oz bottle.  Pretty much like the double only not so much of an alcohol note.  High drinkability and beautiful color.

22 oz bomber.   $4.99 at Total Wine.   Happy Birthday to me!    Stone came to Florida just in time for my birthday and I am celebrating.  My wife says its appropriate, but I dont care.   Amber brown  pour with a nice light tan head.   Sweet malt and hops aroma.  Caramel malt flavor is excellent, lightly sweet but not too much, and fully hopped, but not excessively.  Balance is perfect.   Medium heavy brew with full mouthfeel, plenty of alcohol but not so much that its boozy, and its totally covered by the flavors.   A splendid choice for my birthday!   Delicious.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2008 Aroma: Fruity caramel malt, grapefruit.  

 Appearence: Hazy, Reddish-brown with a creamy .5 inch head. Some lacing present.   

  Flavor: Complex. Sweet carmel malt at first with a fruity citrus hops right behind. Slight bitterness in the finish. Toasted grain aftertaste. Very nice.

  Palate: Texture is just right. Good carbonation and solid mouthfeel as one would expect from a beer name Arrogant Bastard. 

  Overall: I like this beer. Balanced flavors and good texture make me want more of this.

  Serving type: bottle

22 oz bottle...pours a crimson caramel color with a tan head that leaves some sticky lacing. Aroma consisted of a generous amount of piney hops, citrusy hops, tobacco, and molasses type notes as well. The flavor was a bitter sweet mix of toasted malts and the piney, resonous hops. There was a smidge of caramel/toffee to adequatley offset the bitterness. The palate was filled with lively carbonation, and a strong, lasting bitter aftertaste. A medium heavy ale, although it could make for a nice semi-session ale.

Bottle from Knightly Spirits. Pours a dark, murky amber with tight webs of lace and a thumbnail of tan head. The nose is deliciously fruity with notes of piney, citrusy hops and starfruit. Flavors are similar to the nose and include more pine tree sap and a metallic alcoholic bite in the finish. Carbonation is lively and the body full. Despite the amusingly insulting label, I was able to muster up enough sophistication to enjoy this fine brew by a great brewery.
Pours out deep red with foamy head. Taste is malty and hoppy. Very smooth balance. Sweet but bitter. Crisp and clean. Very drinkable.

Sampled at the Great Decatur Beer Tasting Festival in Georgia on 10/18/08. Amber in color. Pine hops on the nose. Taste is of pine hops and grapefruit. Definitely bitter, but there are some caramel notes to even things out.

Taste 12/8 Bottle. Looks: Lovely dark red body with a lacing head. Aroma: Tons of malts and yeast. Taste: Nice thick malt base with a good sour yeast. Finishes with a nice sharp hops bitterness. Unique, over the top and quite drinkable.

Bomber.  Glad this is available in FL now.  Pours deep amber color, with an off white head.  Very floral smell.  Big and hoppy.  Has the nice citrusy and evergreen flavor.  Definitely some caramel sweetness in there too.  Really good...in fact..I Was worthy

Pours a rich chestnut amber color with a creamy off-white head.  Rich aroma of citrus and floral hops, nicely balanced.  Taste is hoppy and fruity, with hints of grapes balanced with caramel hops, and a bitter finish which reminds me of a grapefruit.  Very strong lacing.  Overall, a robust beer that feels like a cross between an IPA and an amber lager.

This beer is available on tap at several places near me.  So, I drink a good bit of it.  Copper with a large head.  Taste of malt, hopes, and bitters.  Some alcohol taste as well.  Very pleasant aftertaste.  Recommended.
Poured a red color with light lacing. Mild taste of hops, but with bitter malts. Couldnt taste the alcohol, but rather enjoyed the aftertaste which was nutty with a little citris.

Bottle. The Rover, Gothenburg. Surprisingly red colour with a small off-white head. Aroma: complex, sweet, dark. Flavor: Hops, sweet and toasted malt, fruits, alcohol, caramel. Maybe a bit too much alcohol in the taste.

Bottle. The Rover, Gothenburg. Deep red colour with a small off-white head. Aroma: Hops, toasted malt, fruit, alcohol and caramel. Flavor: Hops, sweet and toasted malt, fruits, alcohol, caramel, citrus. Good balance between the hops and malt. Maybe a bit too much alcohol in the taste.

Pours a nice mahogany color with not much of a head. What little head it had dissipates quickly and leaves little lacing.

Strong grapefruity smell dominates.

The initial blast of flavor is of strong grapefruit followed by hops. The malts show up very briefly but are indeed present. The carbonation is a bit strong for my taste but works well with the tangy grapefruit notes.

Overall it is a fine example of the style. I could not have more than one in a sitting that is for sure. It is complex in many ways and is a must have for American Strong Ale lovers. I am more of an Imperial Stout man myself, but can definitely appreciate what this brew has to offer.

Reviewed on: 01-31-2007

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a dark amber with a thick, frothy tan head.  My nose is a bit stopped up, but definitely a hoppy aroma with hints of caramel.  Strong, malty taste with a great, bitter hoppy finish.  A beer deserving of its name.

22 oz. bottle - Poured a reddish amber color with medium sized head. Malty caramel hops aroma. Taste is malty, sweet and rich. Finish is bitter and leaves you with a bitter tongue. Stone is a kick ass brewer and I have yet to drink a beer by them that I did not enjoy. Yes, "I AM WORTHY"

Bottle.  Dark amber pour with a thick head.  Wonderful aroma!  Nice sweetness that seems to come from both the malt and hops.  Also, notes of caramel, citrus and floral hops.  More bitterness in the flavor.  Starts out with some caramel malt sweetness, but finishes with a strong hop bitterness.  Really nice thick, creamy texture.  Outstanding beer!  I had high expectations for this beer, and it exceeded them.

Pours amber/copper, beige head.
Aroma is malty/roasted and hoppy.
Taste had quite a good dose of hops and malts. Slightly under the IPA version with more malts. Fruit notes.
Gains in roasted / caramel flavors as it warms up, but keeps a good hoppy finish.

Had this for this first time out of 22oz bottle in Williamsburg VA and just recently found it on tap at Tyler’s Taproom in Durham NC.  

Looks like a nice, dark brown body with a medium brown color near the edges of the glass. A 1/2 creme colored head stuck around for a while, and faded slowly. The smell is of toasted malts and hops. The taste is fantastic. Its malty up front and then it hits you afterwards with the flavorful hops. Overall, a great beer.

Ah, numero CCC! What a great accomplishment, not! I still have a lot more drinking to do. I didn’t save this one for 300, it just happened to be in the fridge. The beer has a nice, almost opaque appearance. It has a deep caramel.brown with a nice head that sticks around. This beer looks damn good! The beer has a strong hop smell. Fairly pungent beer. In Atlanta, we have been awaiting Stone’s arrival, and so far some of their beers have met the expectations, and others have not. Slight malt aroma, but mainly this thing is giving off a lovely hope stink! Not the greatest smell, but pretty good. The beer has a nice creamy texture. Very nice palate! Nice flavoring, bittering, and aroma hop. The bitter touches the taste buds in the back of my tongue. The malts are not noticeable due to the bitter taste. I really like this beer a lot. I thought the Oaked Arrogant Bastard was not as good as this one, and that was surprising. I just love the bitter aspect of this beer. Very bitter, creamy, and aromatic. Pretty damn good brew.

I remember distinctly the first time I tried this beer. It was circa 2003 in Haines, Alaska. I hadn’t ever really had anything this crazy before. The copy on the bottle is hilarious, with the cap telling me I’m not worthy. Am I? Whew, I hope so. Flavor is mighty, lots of hops, citrus, dates, fresh fruit. Finish isn’t too cloying, if you’re determined, you can make it through a bomber in an evening. Just don’t plan on driving.

Bottle. Thanks Skinnyviking. Reddish brown colour with a long lasting white head. Fruity, malty and pretty hoppy aroma. Flavour is spicy, fruity with lots of sweet malt and caramel. A hint of alcohol is present. Soft mouthfeel. I love the arrogance from the label.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2008 bottle, thanks to skinnyviking!
ar: sweet, and alc.
poured clear brown.
palate and mouthfeel was great.
flavor is hoppy, and some citrus. comes off well balanced.

Surprised I haven’t reviewed this one yet.  There is an onslaught of malt, way too much malt flavor and mouthfeel, and the abv is fully on display (enough to be surprised that its only 7.2).  Hops are mellow well chosen, but with this much malt and alcohol, they could have used way more of them.  This beer is bold but the opposite of a San Diego hop bomb.  Also, it really benefits from the fake oak aging the do on the oaked version.
Contrary to popular opinion, I found myself to be worthy of this beer. I must be pretty damn sophisticated.

Botella. And live continues. I hate this disgusting terrible brew. Terrible rotten aroma . NO HOPS what so ever! Aaaargh,..... what did they do???! Water, just watr in the mouthfeel. And the flavour .. una mierda! The flavour is just so horrible.. I would almost  judge a Schaefer brew to be better. IWhy have they ver brewed this awful brew???!!!

Like most hoppy beers this has an excellent aroma. That being said I dont get the allure of this beer? I’m confused by the line on the label about how sophisticated and complicating the flavor is supposed to be? Its about as complicated as ’lets make a run of the mill ale, throw in as many hops as our machine will hold and there you go.’ There’s no balance, just hops!. I’m not a hop head by any means but I can appreciate big hop flavor as long as it has something else to bring that in harmony with the overall taste (see Bells Two Hearted Ale). Oh well, I guess I’m not smart enough to buy Stone beers.

great beer!  there are some flavors of pine and it is quite hoppy.  nice amber red color, not too much aroma, but flavor more than makes up for it.  very smooth flavor but leaves a nice bite which continues long after the sip, if you can hold on before another sip . . .
Draught. High creamy and lasting off-white head. Pitch black body. Weak malt caramel aroma. Very bitter salt & pepper flavor with high carbonation and a long bitter aftertaste.

One of my favorite beers! Haven’t had it in months though and this is my first chance to rate.  Pours a nice amber red with fluffy tan head.  Citrus and pine hops dominate the nose.  Taste is nicely hoppy and creamy smooth on the tongue.  Has a nice biting finish.
UPDATED: APR 9, 2009 Pours real dark red and a thin head forms which dissipates rather quickly.  This is a rather hoppy beer  The overall flavor is nicely complex with a dry hoppy finish.

On tap at Shallos (Indianapolis, IN). Pours a  clear dark reddish brown with little to no head. Aroma is strongly os citrus, especially grapefruit, hops, some wheat and a slight bit of spice as well. Flavor is much of the same with primarily grapefuit and hops flavors with a clean finish. Generally medium body with a bitter finish.

Pours dark brown/red with a substantial tan head and plentiful lacings. Aroma is piney. Taste is big pine resinous hops with a good malt backbone to smooth out the bitterness. Amazingly well balanced for such a "big" beer. Palate is smooth and full. Overall a beer deserving of the high ratings on this site. The 7.2% abv prevents this from being a session beer but it is hard not to drink too much. Oh yeh!

Great beer.  I can’t wait until I can get it in Florida.  Lots of hops with some pine, but not bitter in the least.  A good amount of carbonation dances on the tongue and a nice pine aftertaste is left behind.
Bottled and tap. Hazy copper color, thick off-white head. Malty aroma, bready, bit hop, caramel, hint of raisin. Great malty body, bitter. Nice!
Love it.  Nose of hops, roast, bread.  Intense hop bite.  Great roasted malt character.  This brew defines and or sets a standard for American strong ale.  Cheers!

Praise Bacchus that this great brew is finally available in Georgia! It pours a rich, semi-transparent, appetizing brown with a thick, tan, fine-bubbled head. Aroma is strong fiercely hoppy and has a pine undertone. Flavor is richly hoppy, a hops lover’s dream; it is fairly but not harshly bitter and has just a whisper of sweetness. Texture is lively and tingly, and the aftertaste is hoppy and piny.

This beer is classic, can be picked up anywhere for dirt cheap.  Having a bad day? Crack this arrogant bastard and your day will be saved.  Love this fuckin beer, always a good choice.  ****100th rating****

Caramel malty aromas.  Brownish amber colors.  Roasted brown malt with a bitter finish.  Hops are evident.  Good rich palate - strong malt profile.  Hoppy but plenty of sweetness and hearty reddish malt.  Good.

Poured from a 22 oz. bomber.  Dark amber brownish body with light brown / off white frothy head with excellent lacing.
Interesting aroma - Citrus, earthy, caramel, toast....overall gentle on the nose...but what a surprise thereafter!
Taste is predominant bitter and woody, some spice.  Bitter is not in a pale ale or IPA sort of way, and much more aggressive than smooth.  
Palate is moderatley thick and syrupy residue that lingers a good while.
Depth and complexity that leaves you guessing and wanting more...and I will definitely need more in order to put my finger on it.

This brew has earned the right to be arrogant. It’s the whole package. Pours a dark auburn with a huge resilient sticky beige head that leaves a graceful trail of thick lacing. Fantastic citrusy nose brings to mind spiced orange and evergreen. Nice full mouthfeel. Flavor is malty with the hops mixing in well, just a slight bit of sweetness, and a long earthy bitter finish.

A beautiful-looking beer--pours a nice reddish brown color with a creamy moderate head with excellent retention and lacing.  Aroma is moderate with piney hops and citrus notes.  Flavor is both stronger and more complex.  Lots of strong bitter hops, but with some more subtle notes of caramel malt.  Dry finish with some lasting hop bitterness.  Yet surprisingly smooth for a beer with such a bitter hop bite.  Very, very nice.

This beers catch line " You’re Not Worthy," is quite fitting for any casual beer drinker, as it is an aggressively flavored ale.  The pour is a decently rich amber, with a fair head.  Whilst it has a nose highly hopped with pine resin and grapefruit, and other citrus tones, it is also more delicately accented with malty caramel pitches.  An inexperienced beer peon may easily mistake this as an IPA, however it has enough balance and character to qualify as a strong ale.  Its flavor has a different depth and character, which is as quoted, "hated by many loved by few."  Quite simply if you don’t love this ale, you simply are not worthy!!!

A definite "gateway" beer for me.  Was the first beer I ever had with that beautiful hop bouquet.  Striking grapefruit rind, pine, and lighter citrus elements.  Quite different from alot of IPAs in that there is a strong malt presence, and I guess it’s really an American Strong Ale, well i differs there again in the strong hop presence.  A great balance either way, to be sure.  Weird rant on the back of the bottle.

Very dark amber color......slightly opaque.  Creamy head, with a faint floral aroma.  Front is filled with a sweet malt flavor......crisp mouthfeel.  Bold taste of hops hit the taste buds in the back......lingering bitter aftertaste.  Powerful ale with a wide range of flavors, though its crisp palate masks more than it should.

A beautiful beer with a solid head.  It’s strong presence and taste do not allow it to become a crowd favorite.  It is cleverly named for its bitter taste and incredible palate.  You will either like it or hate it.  I love it!

Bottle pours beautiful clear dark amber with thin white head. Lacing is pretty good. Aroma is floral and citrius hops and slight alcohol. First taste is sweet but the floral hops quickly subside the sweetness. There is also a hint of grapefruit and other citrus. The finish is dominated by the hops burn and there is a bitterness left on your lips. Very good.

Holy @#$%. Found this at the Bottle Shop in Carrboro, NC. This is intensely bitter and overpowering. It is quite hilarious just to pass this beer around and hear other peoples’ reactions. Pours a slightly cloudy, dark amber with a very good off-white head. Lacing here is fairly good as well. Aroma is intense. It matches the overall taste well, which in my opinion is almost like pine needles and sap with a floral hops invasion. Could be an IPA with pine extract. Aftertaste is extremely bitter and lingering. Very powerful and strong. This is definitely intense and can only be enjoyed sparingly. With that said, I liked it but would stick to the Stone Ruination.

From the bottle, finally available in NC, pours a deep scarlet red with a thick foamy off-white head.  Zesty aroma and almost citrusy, as well as some floral hops.  Taste is at first smooth and silky, with mild notes of caramel malt.  The aftertaste gives way to a bitterness of hops and tree bark, giving it a bit of a bite at the end.  I have a special fondness for this beer.  It’s a good one, and very drinkable for a strong ale, which has led to trouble on more than one occasion.

one of my favs for almost 10 years, but has lost some consistency. flavor profile of fruity, dark carmel richness with appropriate hop bitterness was great in years past whether it’s in the bottle or draught, but now not so much. maybe i’m dealing with pure nostalgia.

On tap at Regional Food & Drink in DC.
Ruby orange, off white head. Aroma is hoppy: kiwi, orange, very fuzzy and fruity floral. Flavor is hoppy, fruity, floral and crisp. Almost a bit too sweet and I would prefer more leafy bitterness.

Of the 4 beers I had this night, this was the least memorable, in fact....im probably going to have to give it another go just to be fair.  But I remember all of the others had, this one just seemed to be the most forgettable.  Just making this rating so I remember I have to try it again.

Dark copper color, low head, some lacing. Low alcoholic, nutty aroma. Flavor is an alcoholic, with some light chocolate and fruity hops as well. Light mouthfeel for so strong a beer.  Low carbonation. Reminds me of an IPA, bitter with sweet fruit undertones.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2008 Charlotte Octoberfest.  Rather dark red pour, fluffy head.  Some malt, pine, fuit in the nose.  Some malt, fruits, very well balanced.  Could have used more malt, roast or sweet.  Nice bittering hops, but not too much at all.  My friend tried to tell me this was an IPA, I found it somewhere between an ESB and an IPA, with the best of both.  Ive liked some of their darker stuff so far, but this was a little over rated.  Not bad, but Im guessing this has been toned down because of the "up" grade versions.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: In comparison with the oaked version, I would say this is more on par with what I like in a beer. The oaked variety just seemed a bit "muted" compared to this. This pours a dark reddish brown with a dense head, and good retention. The flavor is also on par with what I look for in an ipa, a little bit to smokey for me, but good nontheless. Cheers!

Very nice pour.  Dark amber with lots of red.  A big head that just does not go away and settles into an uneven tan foam.  Aroma is delicious.  It offers dark fruit along with roasted malt.  Flavor is a bit harsh with plenty of malt and, again, dark fruit.  Some tart grapefruit hop shows up.  Throw in some coffee, pear, grass, and chocolate, as well.  Got somewhat powdery towards the end of the glass.  The beer has the attitude of its name and you have got to love that.  What a good  beer!
22oz Bottle. Umber in color. Light head. Bitter hoppiness without the floral aroma. Wonderful Palate - a woody grapefruit to chocolate, well balanced. Long dry finish. Excellent.
Bottle. Pours light brown. very bitter initially but once it crosses your palate there is a long, light bitter and citrus finish.  Could be better balanced with its other flavors.

on tap.  slightly above average head into mahogany body.  aromas of moderate to stong grapefruit and light to moderate caramel.  flavor is initially stong bitter into moderate bittersweet finish.  good lacing present.  dry texture.  long finish duration.  Very good.  Well balanced.
Bottle.  Poured a dark red/brown with a three finger head.  Aroma of nuts, hops and fruit.  Flavor is caramel, nuts and maybe a hint of chocolate.  Definately a harsh beer.
UPDATED: OCT 10, 2008 Very dark beer that has a great taste. It is a little bitter but its great taste makes up for it. Excellent

same rusty amber apearance as the oaked with a large creamy tan head on top.  viscous pour.  sweet fruity caramel and hop aroma.  light notes of pear, pine, toffee, and even chocolate.  flavors of resiny orange pine hops and bready malt.  not as bitter and dry as the oaked but more sweet.  full bodied.  alcohol is well hidden compared to some ASAs.  finishes with a clean herbal-like aftertaste  both of these(bastard, oaked bastard) were excellent, if not my favorites, of the style.

At a Stone Beer Tasting at Priscilla’s in Morehead City, NC.  oured a golden copper color wth a short lived head that laced nicely.  Great nose.  Sweet malt with just the right amount of hoppiness and excellent bitering on the back side.  think I liked the oaked batter!

Poured a rich golden brown color with a short lived but thick off white head.  Drinkable, with standard sweet malts and grassy hops, with alcohol ever present.  Finishes with a short lived bitter aftertaste.  A very enjoyable beer, that I am glad to have tried, and would be happy to drink again, just not something I would go out of my way to find.
Nice rich color which seems darker than it tastes.  flavor consists mostly of the hop and the alcohol.  good beer but cannot say it is one of my favorites.

Pours an attractive rusty brown with just a tad of cloudiness and topped with a thick 1/2-inch caramel colored head.  First sip is spicy hot with sweet malts and then finishes very bitter with a slight whiskey taste.  What really stands out is this brews mouthfeel.  It is creamy almost bordering on milkshake like thanks to a fantastic malt backbone.  The 7.2% ABV is not well hidden.

Hops and alcohol alone do not make an IPA.  I equate Sierra Nevada Anniversary ale or Doghead as what an American  IPA should taste like.  Although this is good - It does not satisfy my IPA craving.  More like slightly ignorant then Arrogant bastard.

Bouteille brune de 22 oz. Arômes intenses de houblon américain, de malt caramel et de fruits rouges. Robe bourgogne, peu de mousse et légère effervescence. Très maltée, le caramel accompagne les fruits rouges et les pruneaux et mène à une finale relativement amère où le houblon (pamplemousse et résine) s’exprime. L’alcool est très bien dissimulé. Très bon !

Pours a translucent brown with a huge tan head.  Nice initial hop aroma with some sweet fruit and caramel in the background.  Can taste the alcohol in the flavor, kind of hides the other flavors.  Light malt flavor quickly disappears as the bitter finish takes over your mouth.  Good beer, but I may lack the sophistication to fully appreciate.

Bottle. Poured a hazy ruby brown with a frothy off-white head that settles to a thin layer that lasted and left some lacing. Sweet aroma of fruits and caramel malts with a hop background and light whiff of alcohol. The flavor is much the same, fruits, caramel and a hop background. More hoppiness comes out the more it warms. Light alcohol in the flavor also. Medium body that is slightly sweet up front but ends with a medium bitterness. Complex and excellent!
Pours deep amber/brown.  Big malt flavors and great hop flavor/finish as well.  Great beer.

Pours a dark red, almost brown with a tan head. Aroma is of malts, caramel, citrus, and bitter hops. Taste starts malty, but then the bitterness sets in. Surprisingly, the taste is well balanced. Lingering taste of malts and caramel. The presence of alcohol isn’t detected among the bitterness and malts. Extremely tasty.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2008 Hazy deep cherry wood pour, with a 20% stable tan head with large bubbles.  Aroma of raisans. malt and pine - nice.  Mouth feel is smooth and coating, taste is citrus, bitter with a touch of sweetness.  Wonderfully long bitterness in the back of the mouth.

Bomber.  Pours a hazy brownish-red witha  creamy light brown head, decent lacing.  Aroma is of caramel, nutty malts, and plenty of hops, spruce, and citrus.  Flavor has a sweet malt start, buttery, and very nice hoppy finish.  Very good all around beer, well balanced, and delicious.

Pours reddish brown with a light brown head.  Skunky aroma of citrus & hops with a hint of sweat.  Crisp, sparkly mouthfeel--but dont keep it in your mouth too long!  Taste is first of hops, which quickly turns sour, then bitter, flat out kicking your taste buds in the ass.  Case in point, Stone Arrogant Bastard Ale is proof that Americans CAN brew decent beer.  Bottoms up!
Bottle pour. Dark brown with tan head. Aroma is citrus hops, slight malt. Flavor is caramel, citrus, raisins. Very full bodied, slightly chewy, but still smooth.
UPDATED: DEC 27, 2008 Very hoppy... this ale has good color and nice body/mouthfeel.  Tastes of toffee, caramel, and toasted malt.  A little too many IBUs for me.

22oz bomber from a liquor store in Nashua, NH.  Pours a hazy copper-red body with a good half-inch of off-white head.  Smells amazing, juicy, citrusy, piney hops at the forefront with malt in the background.  Tastes citrusy and piney with a fair bit of caramel and toffee malt to back it up.  On the lighter side of moderate carbonation with a body bordering on viscous, slick.  A plethora of pleasant tastes all balanced perfectly.  Rich slick mouthfeel.  Alcohol is hardly detectable until you start to feel the warmth.  What a magnificent beer.  Glad I’ll be able to get this a bit more often.

Pours dark brown with a nice tan head.  Caramel apple aroma, smells really juicy.  Flavors of caramel and citrus around the hops.  Smooth body, bitter finish.  A nice all-around ale with a bit of aggression but not too over-powering.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2009 Amber brew topped by a tan head, this ale left me wondering the buzz is about.  No citric, yes to the caramel and malt, but a bit too bitter for me.
ON TAP YESTERDAY--much smoother and more complex

Dont let the name fool you. Nothing is arrogant or by-blow with this choice nectar.

This deep auburn colored ale lures you in much like that athletic tomboy girl next door  clad in her hoodie. And the stripped down head reminds you of how youd like to get her.

Once you raise the glass close to your face, your nose grabs onto her malty bread dough sweetness.

She baits you with her sweet-as-breath flavor and then hooks you with a light bitterness,  like a good wry Scottish wit leaves you slaked.

As she enters your mouth, her creamy thick
full body brings you to seventh heaven, wanting her kiss to last and last. And she delivers with her long finish.

This is one authentic Strong American Ale who you can fall in love with each time you date her.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2009 Aroma is mostly citrus hops. Mahogony color with a small but lasting white head.  Taste is caramel and citrus hops, smooth bitter finish.  Soft mouthfeel that is very smooth.   After taste is great; long and bread-like. Could be smoother, alcohoal is a bit too noticeable.

[Bottle] Pours a beautiful clear ruby/caramelly brown with a medium beige head. Aroma is citric hops, caramel, raisins and some grass. Flavor is quite raisin-y with a significant residual hop bitterness. Really a nice beer.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2010 Dark amber with big, foamy tan head / Soft, sweet, malt and bread nose / Medium body, a touch of sweetness, malty and a little tart, with a good bitter finish / Flavors of burnt sugar, coffee, grapefruit, and dry pine / Relatively unique flavor profile.
Kind of looks brown,. clear, and boring in the glass.  But the citrusy aroma and flavor packs quite a punch.   What I really like is the thick creamy feeling as it sets in your mouth.  Good brew.

Looks like Im rating 2000 for the Arrogant Bastard! 
Ive had the Oaked version, and loved it, im quite anxious to try this one out!
Deep amber pour, thick juicy, sticky head. Aroma is thick juicy aromatic hops. Some nice earthy hops mixed in with piney resins, and some citrus. The flavour is also very hoppy, lots of pine, and some citrus in the end. Good malt to balance out the beer. Wicked bitter finish that stick to the back of my throat, what an awesome beer!

From 22oz bottle. A good, solid ale. Not exciting, not disappointing, just a good, solid ale. The marketing shtick on the bottle is a little silly and would probably be better applied to a better beer, but it’s fun.
Bottle.  Good beer but the oaked version is even better.  Has strong citrius aroma although appearance was a bit cloudy.  Medium body with a moderate bitter taste.

Pours with a medium sized light brown head that is mostly diminshing. The body of the beer is brown, coffee like color with hints of red in it.
The aroma smells of dark fruits, some molasses, and some caramel.
Initial flavor is sweet with and finishes off with a bitter taste that lingers in the mouth long after the beer is finished! amazing!
It is creamy on the palate with light carbonation. Amazing beer to have with close friends during a labor day bbq!

Had this several times before but never got around to rating it. Reddish copper color, medium receding head. Abrasive hop bitterness - coniferous. Crystal malt. Either a little past its prime or Arrogant Bastard is slipping. Based on the last two samples, I’m not really digging this these days.

22 shared with Brie.  I have had this beer many times.  This time I am drinking it at cellar temp and it is sweet and flavorful.  I picked it up at a grocery store on my way home from hiking Mount Monadnock.  The flavors are molasses and pine tree hops. Yumarooski.

The folks at Stone Brewing Company certainly know how to market a beer AND make it taste great! I didn’t expect this beer to be so good simply because the bottle was so great to read. Well, it was good. Very good! It pours a nice dark reddish brown. It’s hoppy and smells pleasant. You can taste caramel and chocolate in it. The finish is slightly bitter yet very pleasant. This is one everyone must try at least once.
Dark red brown pour with some haze.  Hoppy aroma with raisins, caramel and chocolate.  Malt flavor with a ton of piny hops.  Creamy with caramel.  Bitterness and alcohol flavor linger on the tongue.

bomber from premier gourmet. poours deep reddish brown with a lovely tan head. big malty aromas. caramel, candy, fruitiness. big hops in the aroma as well: grapefruit, citrus. the flavours are well balanced and quite enjoyable. not really anything negative to point out and while i enjoyed it it didnt really blow me away. id gladly purchase this anytime.

500 mL bottle.  Deep rust-brown with a small but solid and sticky head.  The aroma is strong, and consists entirely of citrussy hops.  The flavour is beautifully (and surprisingly, considering the hops) balanced, if not terribly complex.  The solid caramel and roasted malt hold their own.  The alcohol is there, but doesn’t get in the way.  Nice bitter finish.  Very drinkable.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2008 this is truly an american strong ale. too strong to be an APA, too well balanced to be an IPA.  the malt is truly the star of this show -- it still shines through despite the intense IBUs, where lesser malts would be crushed.  this is very well put together beer  i could live with for a long long time due to its wildly intelligent balance.  

ive had this a few times over the years, but the last time i tried it i didnt really understand it. this is a rite of passage, tonite i am enlightened...and in love

Sampled on draught, pours a thick cloudy copperish colour with a medium sized white head. Aroma is hoppy, with piney notesm, wood, bourbon and smoke.
