Taste is astringent, again hoppy, citrusy and aggresive indeed. Tackles your palate right off the bat. I think if I would have had more then one pint of this I would have had trouble riding my bike home.

Pours clear reddish brown with light tan head. Aromas of caramel, bread, and some grapefruit. Big malt flavor with a hefty dose of piney hops. Full body with average carbonation and a thick mouthfeel.

Dark Brown in color with a average sized light brown head with great lacing.  The aroma is of hops with notes of citrus and pine.  The flavor is of strong hops, chocolate malts, nuts, wood, and a hint of molasses and citrus.  The texture is creamy.  Overall its a great beer with a very complex and aggressive flavor.  I love it.  Those guys at Stone have done it again!

22oz. bomber poured into English pint.
Pours dark amber with a dark tan head
that left a nice amount of lacing.  Aroma
is HOPS.  A clean, smooth palate with a
heavy taste of hops that lingers on the
tongue with almost a numbing quality.
A malt undertone works its way through
as it warms and as you get used to the
amount of hops.  A great, hoppy ale.

Pours a cloudy brown with a slight tan head. Smell was a pleasant mix of hops, malt, lime, and caramel. Tastes a little malty, with hints of citrus and smoky chocolate. The hops are present and pleasant on the tongue. The mouthfeel was smooth for a strong ale, which brought out the hops. The carbonation was minimal. I’m a very satisfied customer, and will return to Dilly Deli in Cincinatti for more!

Pours a devilish copper-brown with a sizeable tannish head.  Nose is not overpowering, just a decent dose of piney, grapefruity hops with a decent pastry malt backbone.  More similar piney, leafy hops on the smooth and full palate, certainly well bittered although not a total hop-bomb, with a delicious crisp finish and lingering bitter resins.  Really more of an imperial red, it seems to me.  But quite nice.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2008 Bottle from Andonicos Market. The bottle design is awesome- be sure to read the label. Aroma is complex and inviting, with malt, hops, and even citrus. Pours beautiful deep red with nice lacing and frothy head. Full syrupy body and medium carbonation fill the palate, followed by an impressively well-balanced and loud symphony of hops, bread, nuts, and a hint of chocolate. Alcohol hides in the background. Finish is long and detailed, with lingering hops and bitter grain. This is an impressive and thoroughly enjoyable beer. Its complex, well-balanced, and even unpredictable. A personal favorite.

Aromas of floral citrus hops and a clean solvent like burn.  Fruits include raspberry, plum, apricot, pineapple and pear.  Malt is in the background.

Sweet and woody flavor, with fruits hitting up front.  Good hops dose straightens it out in the mid.  Mildly bitter bisquit and chocolate finish.  Some nuttiness, kind of reminds me of a brown. 

Syrupy texture, astringent mouthfeel.  Fairly heavy, zesty palate with white wine bite.
The label doesn’t joke around.  Probably one of the strongest ales I’ve ever drank.  I pounded one and after I stood up I was like no way I’m tipsy already but I was.
user_location: New York City, New York, USA

text: When I read "you probably won’t like it" I knew I was in for something, but something this good, didn’t even cross my mind.  What a HUGE ale.  Get some!
Amber to red in colored with a nice tan head.  Smell is strong in hops with some pine and fruit notes coming through.  Taste has medium bitterness rounded out by some malts and a little fruit.

Tasted somewhere along my trip through the States.
Amber, brown colored brew. Sweet malty with some hops. Some hops and fruits and bitterness in the flavor. Good be more balanced.
Killer standard.   Deep mahogany color, clear.  Rich malty, deep, nutty, hoppy, a bit of everything in there. always a favorite

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2014 I was expecting much more from this...The double bastard is amazing. A good ale, but Ive certainly had better. I dont think theres much difference between this and the oaked version at least not to my simple taste. RERATE finally getting used to these aggressive american hops reated accordingly
Pours dark mahogany from the bottle with a slight head. Moderately hoppy with a hint of fruitiness.

Bottle pours a very dark reddish amber color with a foamy beige head.  Aroma has a sweet malt characteristic but plenty of hoppiness as well.  Quite an explosion of flavors with an excellent bitter finish that lingers for a while.

Pours a dark amber with a beige colored head. Aroma is first of cascades and sweet malt (brown sugar and maybe licorice). Taste is extremely bitter at the front and slowly trails off with a dry linger. I was disappointed with this one. It needed more malt presence and hop restraint. Its a shame because the color is so nice. Not as good as the Stone IPA, which is one of my favorites.

Pours deep red with a creamy off-white head.  First smells are of a resinous and piney hop bouquet followed by a malty base-note.  Unsurprisingly hop-forward but the malt is not entirely occulted, making its vanilla presence known as the temperature increases.  Finishes with an alpha tingle.  Medium body.  This really makes me want to try the other "Bastard" varieties out there (Double, Oaked).

Bottle at GBBF ’08. Copper colour with a small off white head. Rough vegetal malt aroma. Strong sweet taste with a currious suggestion of natural gas. Some honeyed malt and a mid bitter finish. Rough, tough aggressive beer that doesn’t quite live up to its billing.

This was my first big boy beer, so it always holds a special place.  Don’t drink this beer to have a good time, and don’t expect to throw down 4 of them.  

It’s very, very bold.  Starts sharp and bites on the way down.  I’ve heard Stone will fill growlers cheaper than you’d find this at the store...

From tap at Stone Bistro. Pours clear and golden yet dense amber with a creamy tan head. Aroma is mild breadish malty. Hoppy and mild spiced too. Flavour follows this closely and goes into a spiced and hoppy finish.
Clear dark reddish amber with large beige head. Sweet aroma with toasted malt, caramel and loads of hops. Sweet flavor with toasted malt, caramel, hops and grapefruit notes. Ends solid bitter.

poured into wide/deep mug.  The brew poured a clear deep red/brown color with a medium light head.  Aroma is sweet and bitter smelling.  Taste is hoppy with a bitter aftertaste.  Lots of great flavor.  Nice carbonation.  I will certainly try this beer again.

dark amber color with a nice head and nice lacing. complex smell, everything from chocolate to alcohol to roasted malts.  amazingly full flavor with lots of hops.  the bitterness stuck with me for a while, in a good way.  great beer.  i cant wait to try other stone beers.
This one tasted great but it was during a day of tubing on the eel river and I was already about 7 beers into the day. But god it was nice and hoppy just the way a beer should be

Had this beer on tap at magoos. Dark full bodied beer with plenty of sweet malt and hops.  Not much head but nice lacing, port wine flavorsand clean bitter finish with just the right level of carbonation
UPDATED: DEC 12, 2008 Dark redish amber, roasted malts, Hops, caramel, citrus, spice, alcohol, little piney, dry.

22 oz. bottle from Party Liquors (Steger, IL). Pours a dark reddish copper hue that is well hazed and has a big billowy tan head that sticks around in a solid mass. Aromas are largely sweet caramel malt and citrusy floral hops. Initial is similiar, a very nice balance between toasty caramel malts and citrusy spicy hops. Almost like an "Imperial Amber Ale". Very interesting and very drinkable. Smooth finish with the hop bitterness making its presence known throughout. Cheers!

The Brewer is definitely correct when they state this beer is not for beginners! The beer has excellent aroma, appearance and overall complexity of flavor. The hop flavor remains long after the sip is gone and its bold flavor stands up strong against foods and on its own. Well brewed and a beer for real beer drinkers.

RateBeer Rating, Style and Glass: 98, American Strong, Trappist
ABV, Volume & Calories: 7.2 % in 22 fl oz. estimated at 340 C
Purchased at: Circle Liquors Super Saver, Pennington, NJ for $4.50

Aroma: mild, inviting, quiet, present, grains. 7 out of 10.

Visuals: attractive, deep red, brilliant, clear, off white, wispy head, nice lace. 5 out of 5.

Taste: hops, roasted grains, maple syrup, leaves, hay, dust, delicious, well balanced, well crafted. 10 out of 10.

Palate: leathery, coating, sponge, amazing, deep finish. 5 out of 5.

Overall: Reminds me of the Oaked Bastard, but I preferred this by a mile, and I liked that one a lot. Id have it again, and I plan to. One of my go to beers from here on out, since I can get it almost anywhere. Well crafted - a very nice treat. 18 out of 20.

Stone always has quality products and this is their baby.  The description gave me a laugh because I bet they are right 95% of the time.  This brew is outstanding.  Bitter, almost tastes like a strong IPA with the hops.   Easy to drink and I’m glad I can get this year round.

Great beer. Very bitter and grassy with the first sip. The hops stays with you for a few seconds after you swallow. If you look at this beer with a light it has alot of crap flaoting in it (probably pure hops or ground grass) This beer is not for beginers. Whenever i have a little extra beer money i always buy a few of these. Oh and i like to put it in the freezer until just before it starts to slush then drink it (aaaawesome!).

Bottle.  Deep red color.  Big dark head that dissipates rather quickly.  Aroma very clean and refreshing.  Flavor smacks you upside the head with initial licorice, then widens to inscrutable complexity, braced by prominent alcohol.  Finishes very bitter.  Overall, very nice.  Goes well with cheese and lasagna.

This used to be my base beer until they raised the price. Pours a dark red and has a strong malty nose. k It used to be a kick in mouth for me but now it goes down like water. Overall, a great beer. This beer seems stronger than 7.2% abv giving the fact at how quick it can fuck you up. Definte boozy tatse to this beer, very complex. I would call it an Imperial Amber ale. ABA bitches!!!!!!!&

Bottle. Beautiful, thick, orange big head. The aroma is stunning - so fruity and citrus, sweet. Very deep flavour with pleasantly dry end. Lot of hops and so ’juicy’ as well. 
But I hate it! Why should I care?!

Pours mahogany with small white head. Nose is hop-bomb buried beneath some malts; citrus, peach, caramel, and pine rule the nose, a slight sweetness emerging within this combination. Flavor is a little sweeter but still with lots of hop. A little sticky and bitter. A good brew for serious hop-lovers.

This is a great beer.  Just the smell alone is enough to prove so.  the amazing floral expression accompanied the the hop presence and intense flavors brings this beer to a place i wish i could endulge with all beer that i experience.  nice.

Aggressive is right!  Like punching you in the jaw.  Loved it, very bitter but somehow very balanced throughout.  I want more.  Yes, very complex to where its hard to figure out all the flavors and aromas.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2013 Outstanding. Pours a rich red/amber, outstanding color. Head is carmel and healthy. Smell is strong of hops and a strong malt backbone. The complexity of the taste is almost overwhelming consisting of hoppy goodness backed perfectly by strong malt and few different fruits including grape and I do agree with pineapple. Complex yet balanced with a bitter but refreshing finish. Great beer and packs a pretty good punch. Have another? MANY!

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2008 Wow! A dark amber body with a tan head that dissipated quickly. I was smelling a strong pineapple/citrus nose with plenty of hops, but other people disagreed with me about the pineapple. A big, yet balanced, taste finished off one of the best beers I have ever had.

I absolutely lack the qualities of sophistication, palate, and taste to appreciate a beer of this caliber.  Very flavorful in every aspect (read: big but balanced), you are a vile waste of human protoplasm if you don’t like this beer.
Not much aroma coupled with a dark color.  Tasted like every other dark bitter ale I’ve ever had.  Nice ABV, but I’d go for the double arrogant to deal with the bitter taste for the buzz.

Pours a beautiful deep burgundy red to brown colour with a thick, rocky yellowish-tan head.  Smells of sweet dark fruits and creamy cirtursy hops.  Flavour is fairly intense, very malty and sweet.  Fades into some hoppy bitterness.  Very full bodied, and creamy.  A little sharp on the bitterness, but very nice on the whole.

Figured i better drink this bottle that I have had lying around since December, now that Stone is available a short drive away in Hudson. Little fruity, too sweet. Quite a bit of hop bitterness, not much in the aroma. Not bad overall, but not sure I will pick it up  at 6 bucks a bomber.

Bomber bought in Carpenteria, CA, this beer pours a beautiful dark amber-brown with a well-formed tan head.  Very attractive when sitting in the glass!  Aroma of caramel malt, citrus, grape, and wood.  Initial palate features bitterness, followed by a sweetish blend of Muscat grape, soft caramel, and gummy bear flavor.  Finishes bitter again of aggressive hops, some plum, and a hint of warming alcohol. This is really something special, very well rounded.
Poured from a tap a reddish color.  This brew really packed a punch.  The aroma is much sweeter than the taste which is a little bitter, but not overdone.  Overall a pretty decent beer.
One of the best. Great slightly fruity flavor for an ale. It also hits you hard.

Tap. Pours with a coper color and a smallish head. Kind of like an IPA. Flavors are a mixture of grapefruit and caramel, where hops and malts balance each other. Could be a good session beer, but the alcohol content, while not noticeable is too high for that.
Reddish/amber with a very thick white head.  This is a big bastard of a beer.  Malt makes a statement but the hops have the final say.  Very well balanced.  Thank you sir, may I have another?
Pours a deep red with a thick head.  Taste is bittersweet with burnt, fruity notes.  Commanding bitter aftertaste.  As fun to drink as it is to rant about.

Bomber. Pours a deep, deep amber red with a huge rocky head that diminishes slightly but last throughout.  Excellent lacing.  Aroma is a mix of light malty sweetness, caramel, and wonderful citrus, piney hops.  Flavor is initially sweet followed by a grapefruit bitterness and a finish that never quits. Medium to full bodied. Perfect carbonation. An awesome brew.

I remember my first impressions over 2 years ago...it was brutally bitter, times have changed and so many beers consumed since then, no longer do I consider this the hop monster, nonetheless after a dozen since then I still enjoy this beer.  Color is dark, almost opaque red, head is nice dark brown with mild lacing. The aroma is sweet hops, it’s the balance that is nice with hops winning over the malts ever so slightly and the tast and finish is just like the nose, with a slight edge to the hops, not as creamy feeling in the mouth as some others. Great beer however.
Bottled: Crazy beer that you have to appreciate. Pours a redish color with a white head. Smells of hops and pine. Leaves blasts of malts, pine, caramel, and hops. A very interesting beer!
beer worth your time and money, rich wooden malts and nice piny hops. keep with you all the way till the end. Enjoy
The aroma is very hoppy with pine and grapefruit. It’s also got plenty of caramel. The appearance is reddish with a nice head. The flavor is like the aroma. The palate is smooth. This is a good beer.

Poured a reddish brown color with a white head leaving a little lacing. Smell is full of piney hops, there’s definately a strong malt base, but this is hops all the way. Taste starts a little sweet with some caramel, but is quickly full of piney hops. Pretty good. Medium bodied, higher carbonation. Once again, pretty good, and is worth a try.
This was one of my first craft brews and honestly it was an aggressive beer that kind of kicked my ass.  Fun to drink and a taste that I’m working to develop.

Bottle:  I’m still trying to figure out why I’ve never rated this...oh well.  Pours a dark amber with a sizeable tan head.  Aroma hits immediately upon pouring with a massive pine and dark malt base, some notes of caramel and light floral hops accentuate it.  Malt dominant in flavor, some floral and piney hops absolutely kill on the finish.  Very good, solid brew that I can fall back on anytime.

Bottle, thanks to emagee and South Bay.  Deep amber/ruby pour with a tan head.  Nice lacing.  Battle of hops and malt on the nose and tongue, with both sides bringing out their big guns.  Some may feel caught in the crossfire.  Tons of malty caramel and citrus/resiny hops.  Some notes of wood, butterscotch, toffee, biscuit/cookie.  Ends with crisp hop bitterness. Despite the bottle’s challenge to make me feel man enough to like this beer, it really is over the top. Seems more like a Scotch ale than an American strong to me.  Pretty good, but definitely not subtle.  The Oaked Arrogant Bastard is far better.

Pours a beautiful red color with a nice light tan head. Mild hoppy aroma. Strong grapefruit hoppy flavor dominates from the beginning. Very bitter. Malt detectable underneath hops. Finishes bitter also

Bottle. Pours dark amber wiht a nice head. Heavy malt aroma. Thick and creamy to the palate. Flavor has a sweet start malt middle and a bitter chocolate finish. $15.00 a six pack...good luck with that.

Draught. Pours a hazy ruby brown color with a small creamy off white head. Nose is fruits, caramel and medium background hops. Initial taste is malty, red berries, caramel and nuts. Mid palate to finish displays an earthy hoppiness that balances the brew well. The flavors are still on the mild side. Palate duration is good, the hop bittterness is one of the highlights of the brew. Good head retention and spot lacing of the glass. Light to medium body.  Very drinkable brew.

Its true. Im not worthy. I bought this beer with very high expectations. Bottle pours deep cloudy amber, with almost no crown at all. Smell is good, with hints of slightly piney hop amid woody earthiness. Taste is the deal breaker. What is hinted at in the aroma knocks you back in the mouthfeel. Hops aplenty gives you a kick in the teeth with medium sweetness and a bit of citrus following. Bitterness sticks with you for a while. I dont think Ive had a beer this thick and hoppy at the same time since I tried Smuttys impy stout in the big beer series. Bottom line: Im not the guy that disdains everything that someone else likes so he can feel superior and elitist. Im the guy who appreciates the artwork but probably wouldnt hang it on his wall. Thats how I feel about this beer. Its a tremendous work in brewing, but its too much for me, you arrogant bastard.

Pours a ruby brown color with a large foamy off-white head that encapsulates the sides of the glass with lacing.  Aroma is caramel and hints of hops.  Taste is a big malt bomb - caramel, pine nuttiness, hints of hops.  Nothing special.
Deep rich amber in color.  Id agree that this is an agressive beer.  Flavors begin with malt but then progress to a complex bitterness.  Full bodied.
Pours a deep red color and smells of hoppy sweetness with a hint of alcohol.  Ours a great creamy head with nice lacing.  Very complex.  Fully body taste with a good malt/hop balance.  Good beer.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2009 The bottle poured deeeep caramel with ruby hues and sticky blonde head. Aroma mostly of dark roasted malts, mild chocolate notes. This is an incredibly smooth brew with lush body,toasty bitterness, and mild anesthetic, numbing hops.

Draft sample at Bier Tasting event at Bostons Bistro & Pub in Dayton. 
I guess Im worthy because I love this beer.  A wonderful American ale.  Dark in color and strong in aroma and flavor.  More bitter than you might expect, but great balance.
Well I did like it.  Burgundy pour with a lot malt character mixed very well with a lot hops as well.  Hard to dislike.

Dark red-Amber color, Medium head, Powerful oaky aroma which continued with the taste.  Bitterness and oak over powers the malt.  

Great name, but not sure Im in love...

First off, I love the right up on the bottles... I think they wrote it just for me.  Drank one five days ago from 22oz bottle poured into brandy-like Duvel glass.  Medium head, lightly colored, disipated slowly.  Dark red color to the beer.  Powerful floral aroma backed by citrus notes is amazing but washes out the malt aroma for me.  First taste was a slap in the mouth.  I can tell there is sweetness in there but its just so citrusy bitter (and I mean pith bitter, not the rind.)  The bitterness lingers, making me forget the mouth feel.  If you like french-pressed hop tea, youll love this brew...  Im just not sophisticated enough to appreciate it.
Nice deep red pour with a small head.  Aroma and taste are sweet and smooth and a slight bitterness that hangs on.  A nice malty citrus feel on the tongue.

22 oz bottle.  Crimson pour with smallish tan head.  Aroma of some citrusy hops and a little sweetness.  Taste is bitterness primarily, grapefruit hops, caramel, spiciness.  Lingering bitter finish.  Very nice.
Poured dark red with small head. Smooth taste, slightly bitter. Full bodied flavour with an even level.

# 200 Great, great beer. Clear, burnt amber pour with a finger-and-a-half worth of creamy head. Aroma was a very hearty mix of malt, hop, and a citrusy sweetness. The taste didnt disappoint either--medium full to full body, quite malty-sweet with a touch of grapefruit and something else I cant put my finger on when it first hits the tongue, giving way to a malty-bitter finish. If it has any shortcomings, it may be that the aftertaste lingers a touch too long. Other than that, its a strong, bitter, but very drinkable behemoth of a beer. One of my personal favorites.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2009 on tap @ four dogs. pours a dark orange-brown color with a 2-finger tan head. aroma is strong caramel and citrus with spruce and fig. flavor is a powerful blend of malt and hops....a blast of caramel with nut, spruce, lemon, grapefruit. the finish is a beautiful, lingering bitterness of grapefruit rind and quinine. seriously the longest finish of any beer, ever. like, 2 or 3 minutes later im still tasting it. seriously awesome beer. not for the weak of heart.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2011 Yeah, its a little hoppy.  This is one of the best gateway strong ales available.  The hops really shine through in this beer, changing the game for those unfamiliar with the world of American Strong Ales who know no better from darker ales.  No matter what your background, Arrogant Bastard is a nice change from the norm.  Sure, the distinctive wording on the label may seem, well, arrogant at first, but once you know Stone youll understand.  An incredibly decent, staple beer.  Great in the mouth and on the nose.  Hopilicious.  You cant ever go wrong when you pick up an Arrogant Bastard.
Im no hophead but this well hopped ale is done right. The malt comes through nicely. Appearance is a clear amber/copper. Aroma is light fruity and inviting. Good stuff.
This reminds me of a Barley Wine. But a hoppy one. Being a hop head, I obviously like it. The flavor and vapor is real nice. Andf the texture is smooth and rich. A well rounded strong ale.

Étonnamment sage au nez pour une bière qui saffiche sous le signe de pareille arrogance, malgré la présence dherbes terreuses et de cassonade sucrée. Au goûter, je dois mentionner que cest plutôt gommeux et collant, modéremment sec en bouche et dune amertume bien contrôlée, malgré le discours apocalyptique « à larrière » de la bouteille. Houblon-citron-boisé typique de chez Stone, on reconnaît bien la signature. Présence de bois, de menthe, de poivre (oops, je viens de cracher de la bière sur ma chemise) et de caramel.  Une très bonne bière à nen pas douter.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2009 Pours a great dark amber with a frothy head and lacing that almost coats the glass. Smell is lots of hops, fruit some sweet malt, some spice. Taste is huge hops, mostly citrus and pine, bready toasty malt. Finish is even more hops, with a full mouthfeel. Very complex, but very drinkable. Yes, this beer is as awesome as advertised.
Greta brewery that I visited on my trip to San Diego. Awesome big huge brew. Loads of hops and a slight alcohol bite yet it was quite pleasing. Rich huge finish.

I hate to keep being so nice to Stone but this was probably one of the better Ales I have ever had. Pours  dark brown/amber with a big, nice head. The aroma is fruity and nutty. The taste is sweet and smooth. It is so good on the palate that I found myself drinking very slow to make it last. The perfect spike of hops in there.

Appearance: Pours a clear, reddish-amber body with a medium, lasting, off-white head.

Smell: Sweet-smelling maltiness with a sprinkle of gooey brown sugar. Theres a slight oxidized quality present, leading me to assume this bottles a bit on the older side. Dark fruits smelling of golden raisins. Pine-scented, woody hops.

Taste: Toasty, bready malts with a medium sweetness and taste of brown sugar. Slight dark fruitiness. Hoppy pine wood flavor, a bit of fresh mint. Medium hop bitterness, though it holds on through to the bittersweet finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: A really delightful beer fresh or even with a bit of age on it.

I was worthy enough to have A.B. tonight at dinner. I poured it from a bomber into a pint glass. Its a deep mahogany color and has good clarity for a high gravity beer. It has an off-white head that sticks around for awhile, not frothy. Earthy hops dominate the aroma, smells nice.
It is very hoppy, a little more than I like, but it didnt overpower the malt, which still came through. Fruity esters come through pretty strong, but are not off-putting at all.
Its a good beer to sit back and appreciate. One bomber was all of the beer I needed for the evening.

On tap at Yard-House, Brea. Pours dark brownish red with a fluffy brown head. Aroma of hops with a hint of malt. Flavor begins complex and hoppy, then becomes spicy and intense. Palate is medium bodied and leaves a dry hoppy after-taste on the sides of the tongue and back of the throat. Hops definitely dominate, but finishes with subtle caramel malts. Nothing quite like Arrogant Bastard.

On Tap - The Big Hunt, DC.
Fantastic dark ruby color to this. Lacing all the way down the glass. Nice balance to this ale. Nice hops, nice bitter finish. Great caramel taste to this. Go and fine some.

Great appearance, fluffy tan head and good lacing.  Sweet appley aroma and hops, great mouthfeel and a bitter hop finish.  Complex, challenging, but most of all, awesome and gets better with every sip.  Could have something to do with the 7.2 ABV as well.
Brutal....definitely intense. But in a good way, if only more beers tasted like this. Definitely worth the 6 bucks a bottle.
A lovely confection, good balance, nice mouth feel, superb hopping. It was somewhat more carbonated than I enjoy.

A beautiful clear ruby red with a large frothy cream head that sticks around. The aroma is mostly hops, I get dark fruit and citrus, a little sweet too. The flavor is a delicious mix of roasty caramel malt notes with a lot of hop bitterness. Finishes dry and bitter. Overall a very balanced, intense brew.

Off Capital Ale House taps 05/20/08
Clear dark amber with fine persistent head. Was hard to initialy pick up any aroma in this environment, but some grassy hop aroma came out as beer warmed. Medium to full mouthfeel with rich caramel and roast malt flavors and some hefty hop bitterness and some grassy hop flavor. Finish was moderately sweet with a good deal of residual hop bitterness.
pours a deep amber color. taste  is a very nice mix of malt and hops. this really is an incredible beer

Available everywhere on the West Coast--Pours a deep amber body with a nice whitish head.  Aroma is piny, fruity, citrus hops with a big malt spine.  Great balance of hops and malts.  A little sweet, but not overly so.  On the verge of being to big, but like most Stone brews, this one walks the line.  Great beer.

bottle. pours deep orange red with a sizable off white head. leaves plenty of lace.  aroma is lemony and resinous hops.  taste is very smooth.  low carbonation, creamy malt backbone, and a moderate bitter hop. no hint of the high abv. sweetness is held in check just enough by the hops to keep from being cloying.  spicy hops become more distinct as you drink.  mmm.

"I am not worthy" to have this as my 100th beer but that doesnt mean I cant enjoy it!  Deep mahogany color with nice lacing right of the bat.  Taste is a mix of sweet/malt and hops which goes full blown hops in the aftertaste.  Great beer.

This beer is impressive, the aroma is a kind of berry sweet, kind of reminds me of childrens Tylenol and alcohol. The appearance deep red, my friend said it looks like blood. Flavor is simply amazing plenty hops, also a berry taste but not too much, dry maybe a little to dry but I like it a lot. Great feeling on the tongue. Overall this a great beer if you are worthy enough!

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2008 I really liked the aroma from the beginning- fruity and sweet. Looks fabulously, its a nice dark amber in a trappist glass with a nice red tint to it. The taste is the very aggressive, as stated. This is a good, very balanced, very smooth beer. Surprisingly easy to drink for such a strong, in your face taste. Its a malty taste, a little bit of dark berry with some bitterness, but not overly bitter. A bit of hoppiness as well. Lots of flavor to this beer. The finish was the best part for me, it sticks around for a while and thats not at all a bad thing. American ales dont get too much better than this.

Update (06.28.2008) - Had this again tonight, and its still as perfectly balanced as I remember. You really cant go wrong with this beer- super hoppy for an American ale and super enjoyable for anybody who enjoys beer.
fantastic beer, very complex - dark with malt aroma - first taste very strong, with increasing bitterness.  my #1

Arrogant Bastard is the true test of a man.  Its a strong brew, but more balanced than the hoppocaust that is Ruination (which I also love).  If you want to step it up further, consider Oaked Arrogant Bastard or Double Bastard.
I thought this wonderfully malty beer pours dark and smells great. It tastes like happiness. Its a bit bitty but sweet.
Aroma at first I did not like but the taste is GREAT. Gotta love the big 1 Pt. bottle and the not so bad alcohol percentage
bottle, dark amber color, winey fruit nose , the head starts off very foamy and diminishes quickly to a soapy ring with some lacing, nice malty flavor with carmel and hop highlights, excellent finish
Im not worthy.  I decided to drink my first arrogant bastard while I was eating dinner, not really the best idea.  The flavor basically slapped me in the face and completely overpowered the food.

This bottles got some age on it, i forget when i bought it?  Malty nose, some caramel with spicy hops.  Pours dark amber with a thick tan head.  Very smooth, i can taste some age on it but its still great, the hops of mellowed.  Its caramelly the hop presence is very spicy with hints of molasses.

This is one of the greatest ales i ever had. dark, hoppy, smooth, a little hint of bitterness. great tasting almost like grapefruit at times. reminds me alittle of seirra nevada, but a million times better. alot of complexicity going on in this bottle. 
goes down very easy. highly recommended
Nice brown color and a small tan head.  Good malt on the nose for sure.  Some hops on the nose and more on the tongue.  Pretty good damn beer.

22oz bomber.   Pours a brown-into-dark brown with a ruby red tint to it.  Tan head which lingered.  The smell is of caramel malt and pine hops, but not a strong or sweet nose.  Taste is pine hops and malt but it comes across as harsh and NOT well balanced.  Mouthfeel is harsh from burn with some carbonation and bitter, yet funky, finish that lingered forever.

Aroma: Hops. Alfalfa-grassy, grapefruit-citric, and rose-floral hops. An undercurrent of caramel malts comes through, but you have to really sniff for it. This has a a lot of what Id describe as "va-voom." A very alluring nose.

Appearance: Dark, bold, clear, rusty orange-red with magenta highlights and puffy parchment-colored head with great retention.

Flavor: Much more malty than the smell (but still predominantly hoppy); a well-balanced ale. The hops are mostly grapefruit pith with a grassy character. Finish could be a bit cleaner, but on the whole, this is one yummy beer.

Palate: The beers finish is ultimately crisp, dry, and hoppy, but it starts off strangely sticky and cloying. Other than that, no complaints. Smooth mouthfeel.

Overall: I should have bought the six-pack instead of just the bomber.
Brown ale with a small head, minimal lacing. Malt and hop aroma. Flavor very similar. bitter back end. Good beer, alcohol well hidden.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2008 Pours dark ruby brown with a medium frothy tan head that forms some craters.  Sweet vinous, nutty, hoppy aroma with some alcohol and woody notes.  First taste is very bitter and dark... deeply roasted/burned  malt and extremely bitter hops that arent particularly flavorful.  Some dark fruits, but mostly like eating burnt caramel on the bottom of the pot.  Nice sophisticated palate, fluffy medium/full body, slightly syrupy.  Its a well crafted brew, however, Ive never had a beer packed with so much flavor be so boring.... Im going to go burn a bag a popcorn so I have a flavor compliment...  ok thats harsh =p  I wonder how one of these would taste with 2 years of age on it?

The beer pours deep red brown with a thin short lived white head. The nose is light is a hint of hops. The flavor is a 2 fold mix of berries and an earthy grassiness that harkens back of the farm, the second taste is the tongue ripping dryness of the hops on the back of the tongue,

Excellent beer.  At first taste it is a kick in the mouth.  Another drink confirms this is a great beer that isnt afraid to be bold.  Hard to find here in Phoenix, but a very pleasing beer when available.

I tried this side by side with Oaked AB in a blind test.  The wife poured each in a trappist and didnt tell me which was was oaked.  I was able to distinguish the AB apart from the oaked version and it was alot easier than I thought.  Heres what I found with regular AB.  Pours amber with large off white head.  Aroma is of caramel, sweet malt and hops.  Flavor has a nice bite to it but not overwhelming.  My opinion is the Oaked is far better than the regular AB but I liked both.  The regular version is more agressive with its strong malt and hop flavor.  It also has a stronger alcohol flavor whereas the oaked is more balanced.  Carbonation is also stronger in the original AB.
bottle. hazy color,  aroma of hops and caramel. this is good! smooth malty taste, with a slightly bitterness that seems to surround it. pine and caramel lingers.

Yes, is what comes to mind after your first sip.  Bottle: poured dark carmel color with copper head, couldnt smell anything distinctive.  Initial taste is hop goodness with a balance of malt flavor slight caramel taste.  Aftertaste contains a gentle hop lingerance (if that is a word), which is the best part of the beer.  Medium to heavy carbonation.  Beer gets smoother as you drink it.

I cant believe I havent rated this beer (until now)!  Ive put down quite a few bitter and high-ABV beers in my time on earth (and hope to have many more in my remaining time!), yet I still find this beer a bit difficult to drink.  It is a substantial beer, and while I like the strong hop bitterness, there is a robust maltiness that when combined with the hoppiness feels like a punch in the mouth to me.  I might have enjoyed it more if I had not been having it with food, and if it were my first beer of the evening rather than my 3rd and final one.  Appearance is surprisingly red and head is sturdy.  Aroma is serious hoppiness (with some nice fruity under-tones) and a substantial maltiness that comes across as to me as metallic, caramel-y, and bitter in a non-hoppy way.

I had this on-tap at the Houston Flying Saucer Draught House and Emporium.

Pours a beautiful deep reddish amber with a big tan head. The aroma belies how huge the flavor of this beer is. Mild aroma of dry, floral hops and caramel malts. Flavor hits hard - this ones big. Well-balanced piney hops and roasty caramel malts. Finishes very dry and very bitter with resiney, grassy hops.
Bottle. Dark Amber, thick tan head. Hops, caramel, and light citrus/spice. Moderately bitter, sharp and refreshing. Very easy drinking. Love it!

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2008 This is the perfect beer... from the name to the logo to the way the taste punches you in the face, arrogant bastard does a lot of things right.  Some beers with this much flavor can be overpowering and are only good for one or two pints, but this has a nice balance that allows for more enjoyment...I guess you can say it has endurance
UPDATED: FEB 5, 2009 Always a good choice. High on bitterness, but well balanced with hops as well. Amber pour with light but well-laced head.

Thank you, Stone, for delivering this assault on the masses. This is one of the best examples of why it is better to be alive now than prior to the rise of the microbrew. Future generations should be grateful for this delicious beverage.

Clear amber brown with light brown lacy head. Floral aroma with a hint of melon when first opened. The taste starts out sweet and malty and finishes slightly bitter. A very nice ale that seems widely available, at least out here in California.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2008 Good tasting ale.  Honestly I drank this not knowing it had 7.2% alcohol and I would not have guessed it.  Can not taste it at all.  I had this on tap and it poured dark orangy red with a small tan head.  Not too much of an aroma which was disappointing but the taste more then made up for it.  Good job guys!
Great stuff. Bitter and balanced. Lovely lacy head with a great reddish-brown color. A classic. Love it!

Yep.  Clear amber brown with a rich aroma.  I smell some candy and spice along with the more bitter citrus/pine hoppy aromas that give the beer its strength.  The taste evolves from sweet and malty to bitter and tingly.  This beer was in instant classic from the moment it came out, and although I had tried it several times before, I was shocked to see I never rated it, nor the Double Bastard or the Oaked.  Those are next.
A total assult on the taste buds, this beer is one of the best Ive tryed from start to finish.

...well, this is a hardcore beer.  It is dark, it is alcohol filled, it is mean, it will make you mean and grow hair on your chest.  Caramel, roasted malts, with a alcohol finish.  Good malt flavors, but dont let it get warm, unless you want a mouthfull of dirt.

So here I sit with a bomber of an old favorite, and I notice I havent rated it.  Pours clear brown, bright amber highlights, thick tan head that hangs around a while.  Smells of pine, lemon and orange.  Tastes of caramel malt, lots of hops and lots of fruit on the finish.  Nicely balanced, the bitterness is big but doesnt completely overwhelm the malt.

Pours a deep dark copper amber body topped by a medium creamy tan head. Aroma is medium sweet with intense grapefruit and citrus. Flavor is grapefruit, chocolate, grapefruit and light chocolate. Perfect balance. Medium to full body. Somewhat long bitter grapefruit finish. Fuckin great beer, my hats off to Stone.

22 oz. bomber. Pours a magnificent reddish-amber with a thick beige head. Perhaps my favorite beer appearance-wise. It smells sweet, but the hops are present too. The nose also has a "burnt" character to it, and the malt also shows itself in the odor. If the aroma was just a bit more potent, it would be perfect. The flavor is extremely floral with loads of delicious hops along with raisin and pear. Some caramel sweetness is also present. Light to medium bodied with a little carbonation. Nice bitter, warming finish. This is actually one of the first craft beers I had tried a while back, and it really took me by surprise at the time I tried it. I was skeptical and didnt really like it as the label suggested I wouldnt. I was coming off of Molson Canadian as my favorite, and that probably explained the not-so-pleasant palate assault. However, I gave some other craft beers a try, got hooked, came back to this beast and now it is definitely one of my favorites. I buy it time and time agian. It is also the beer that sparked my love affair with the Stone brewery. Thank goodness I did not give up on real  beer...

a classic american ale style, this beer pours with a muddy amber color and a good-sized off-white head. Caramel is ever-present in both color and taste. Finishes with a somewhat sour, alcohol taste that is not, by an means, unpleasant

Aroma: sourish, hoppy fresh, slightly lingonberrylike malty profile. 
Flavour: malty, fresh & bitter lingonberry. 
Appearance: brown copper body w/ tan head. 
Palate: smooth & fizzy

Bottle. Dark amber pour; 2-inch light beige head. Sweet aroma of grapefruit. Taste starts slightly sweet with grapefruit predominant, also some honey and perhaps caramel. Ends in assertive sour-bitterness and astringent alcohol, pine oil aftertaste. Full and foaming in mouth. Nice but a bit much for sipping; needs food to tone it down.
One of my favs but i figure to buy the double arrogant because of the ABV. I recommend every one try this ale.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a small white head.  Hoppier than I expected (a blend of floral, citrus, and piney hops), but blended really well with the malt base.  The first time I had this was early in my beer palate development, so it wasnt anything special to me (especially since I didnt appreciate hops at that point).  Having it a second time (now a time when IPAs and ASAs are becoming my new fave styles), I was quite pleasantly surprised and blown away by this beer!  It was amazing and I cant wait to have some more again!  Also I love the commercial description of this beer--so accurate!

Bottle. Massive pine hops right up front in the nose (shocker!). Huge, rich malts arrive at first sip, raisin, fig, prune, but mostly just the rich, rich malt that mingles perfectly with all those pine needles. Simple and complex at the same time, perfectly crafted without the arrogance overriding the flavor, and undeniably luscious.
UPDATED: APR 21, 2008 Bottle.  Good stuff.  reminded me of a darker Dogfish 90min - but not as good.  Extreme hops and definitely arrogant!  i enjoy this beer and glad i tried it
A classic.  nice malty aroma and slight alcohol.  beautiful color with so many different hues.  flavor is malty and hoppy nd big.  I love this beer.

It is a good beer...but it is missing hop complexity and it just seems to be average in all respects...at least to my spoiled beer palate:)
would not turn it down though
1 of the best, not as good as the oked Arrogant Bastard<or the barly wine but damn itz good........!!!!MALACORE
resin, brown, cloudy, rocky head, medium bitterness, medium sourness, full body, thick feel, average carbonation, bitter, a very nice pour i think this a very clean beer with a clean taste

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2011 This beer is fabulous. First of all, I like the name. I think it really fits this beer. Deep amber color with a thick khacki head. Lots of lacing. A lot of caramel candy malts combined with a blast of bitter grapefruit hops. A little sweet but not over done with just the right amount of hop/malt balance. Rich and full. Finishes bitter and dry. I love this beer! I look forward to trying the Double Bastard.  Re-rate 3/7/09.  Sampled on tap this time and while still very tasty just didnt have the same wow factor.  Heavy rich malts, both caramel and toffee, bitter resiny and citrusy hops.

I wasnt all too impressed by this one. Dont get me wrong, its a damn good ale, but in my opinion doesnt live up to its 3.94 rating. Great if its all that theres around, but there are many better beers in this style...
Great American Strong Ale.  Strong hoppy flavor with just enough maltiness.  If I can find it again, Ill make sure to have on hand for company.

Poured dark amber. The menu called it an "amber ale" but I would call it something heavier myself.

You can smell the delicious hops from some distance away, luring you in.

The taste is strong, but not overwhelming. It feels great in your mouth and goes down smooth.

On tap and from the bottle, the Arrogant Bastard is always great.

Highly recommend!

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2009 Bottle....Poured a deep translucent red with off-white head that had excellent retention that laced the glass. Aroma of hops was very noticeable upfront, lets you know what your in for. Surprisingly enough, it was incredibly smooth, nice balance of aroma, malty sweetness, and high bitterness and alcohol presence barely noticeable, with a full bodied mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Good Ale!
Bottle. Orange and pine form the initial shockwave on my palate, then the bitter malty finish takes hold.  A big, full flavored brew that packs a powerful punch. Stone rocks!

On tap at a biker bar in Ocean Beach.  Poured a deep amber burnt orange hue with very a very aggressive hoppy nose.  The malts and hop blend together quite well and make this one a stand out in its class.  The abv is apparent but not overpowering.  Again, yet another kick-ass brew from the boys at Stone~

I LOVE Stone brew, but this one is just awful in my opinion. I really didnt like it. It was just too much. Too much hop, too much malt, too much alcohol. I felt like I was drinking rubbing alcohol with intense hoppy flavor. It did smell good though.

I dont think I am some sort of wuss, but I just dont understand this beer. There is just too much going on to actually enjoy it.

From a 22oz. bottle purchased locally. Aroma is sweet, orangy and fruity hops. Brilliantly clear deep red with a one inch almost tan head. Flavor explodes with hops, a little dark caramel sweetness and firm bitterness. Full bodied, but finishes clean and bitter. I love this beer. It is a standard go-to when I want something strong and bitter. The first two sentences on the bottle say enough. "This is an aggressive beer. You probably wont like it." Dont try it if youre not worthy.

Bottle. Pours deep amber red with a beige head. Aroma is hoppy, with notes of citrus, fruit, and caramel malt. Maybe just a hint of chocolate. Medium/full body. Very smooth. Flavor is very well balanced with fresh hops punching through a solid malt presence. Very good and quite drinkable.

Thanks to Odeed for this bomber. Poured an dark amber color with a two finger head that dissapeared quickly. Nice hoppy aroma with a malty presence. This one kicks you in the face with taste. Very heavy hop beginning with a bitter yet malty middle and some alcohol and hops bitter in the finish. Definitely a great beer.

The color is not what I expected at all.  Its almost the color of the bottle when its full.  The hops are a brownish white.  The stiff is very metallic when the head goes down.    I blew my nose, and well this still produced the same taste.  This reminds me more of a barley wine then an ale.  The taste is def a bang of hops.  The finish is very dry.  At first taste, I didnt think I would like this brew, but it has definitely grown on me.  The taste is bottle conditioned although I didnt read anywhere that it is.  Damn you Arrogant Bastard, you live up to the hype.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2009 750ml bottle.  Nose is of hops.  mouth is bitter and dry.. more hops.  Some sweet malts. I forget most of the details,  was drunk - this needs a rerate.  Rerate 11/14:  On tap at Pony bar.    Pour is brown/reddish amber.  A tasty little sucker.. lots of flavors going around..  malty, bitter hop, vanilla.  Nicely carbonated and sessionable.

Bottle at the cads piere party disco. The brewers told me this is best before 3 months of it being made, however this is at last 6 months old so perhaps noit soo hot. Alround rating: Does exactly what it says on the tin, huge malty beast, huge bittering hop, however still very drinkable.

Bottle at Magic_dave6s disco dance tasting. Clear chestnut, no head. Sweet with some sour hop balamce. Mouth is clean hoppy with some harshness and sweetness. Grassy hops linger, slightly water palate. Very good.

Bottle. A deep red beer with a beautiful head. The aroma is sweet with notes of alcohol and berries. The flavor is very complex with notes of cow berries, grass and enormous amounts of hops which makes the end extremely grassy and dry. A wonderful beer.
UPDATED: MAY 9, 2008 tastes like Im biting into a hops cone... not exactly balanced but nice malty undertones make this a thoroughly enjoyable beer.
Dark amber pour with no head.  Aroma of citrus hops and sweet malt.  The hops are very noticeable in the flavor and it is refreshing with the sweet malt.

Aggressive is a great marketing term and for that matter so is the name....on the other hand, I think that beer people would taste a English bitter that truly is bitter because its not a Belgian strong ale..First sip, I can tell that the brewmaster who came up with this recipe, was thinking how can I American-ize a Belgian strong ale, give it plenty of hop bite, but let it remain that somewhat subtle malt backbone that English bitters are famous for....well here is the finished product.  A very nice beer to buy a bottle of and slowly enjoy over some good conversation. Very well done!
I could sit here and try to tell you why this beer is better than the Ruination, but I dont think your simple mind could comprehend it.  Its funky and pungent and rich and delicious.

22 oz bottle. found this to have a sweet hoppy fruity nose. Poured a dark amber,liked the hop flavor and bitter finish, and the fact that the flavor lingered for quite a while, but just wasnt my favorite flavor.
Dark amber body with a faint funk to it, almost aged.  Very sweet malt body that was very hot.

Pours a delicate copper color with very little head. Aroma is light but certainly hoppy. Flavor is strong, quite hoppy. Slightly bitter, but not too much too enjoy. Goes down relatively smooth. Overall good but nothing too amazing. Try if you like hops.
I had a big bottle of this, when i say big i mean huge it was above my knees in height and had a key for a lock on it. It was good but not great.
Eh, pretty good beer. This is not really my style of beer so I may rerate eventually.

This was served on tap at Fatheads in Pittsburgh.
Not the most enjoyable drink I had that night.  I want to try it again, maybe along side of some dipas.
Tap @ BU Pub.  A very nice strong ale, hides its alcohol well.  Thick, heavy, strong, good!

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2009 Bomber 48F
Year old vintage. 

Raw malt extract aroma. Flavours of raisons and  roasted caramel. Very malty...I like that.  Huge, thick  mouth feel...I llike that too. Cloudy with light lacing. Warm alcohol feel.

Very Good Strong Ale.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2008 24oz bottle, poured dark brown with hint of amber/orange.  Off-white creamy head, with good lacing, mostly diminishing.  Aroma is moderately malty , heavy hops, and citrus, with a touch of smoke.  Flavor is quite bitter, with medium/full body.  Dry texture.  Very good beer, I can drink a couple of these!

awwhhhh nice beer this is like a nice malty ipa.Pours nice dark brown,wiht off whit head,nice piney grass hop arona very strong.Sweet malt up front nice bitter hopp present on sides and back of tounge,Leavs the mouth quickly making you want more.Wonder beer for the sophistated palete.

Pours a carmel color with half of the glass being filled with deep tan foam. Color turns darker as beer settles, and head settles down to 1.5 inches and lasts. Aroma gives off notes of sweet, sugary., malt and hops. The foam is thick and lucious. The beer really is delicious hoppy, bitter, flavorful, medium body. Clean, clean finish. Fortunately, I am sophisticated enough be enojy such an aggressive beer of this quality and depth.

Quite good, not as much as i expected though.The aroma had some plum present caramel malts and citrus hops, as well as some sweetness, the body was completely black, with a black outstanding head, the palate felt quite bitter. Nice but there is a lot better outthere.
Wow. I love this beer not only for its taste but for its class. Stone rocks.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2008 On tap at Pour 24 at the NY-NY casino in Las Vegas.  Pours a cloudy brown body with orange/red tones and a white head.  Aroma of pine, floral hops, and malts.  Thick mouthfeel with soft carbonation; flavors of caramel, toffee, green hops, and pine.  Bitter grapefruit finish and aftertaste with a hint of grass.

deep dark cloudy reddish brown color with a thick off white head that clings to the glass. sweet malty aroma with subtle hops. grapefruit and honey stand out, roasted coffee flavor floating in there. really sweet finish. 22oz bottle.

I hadnt had this beer for a long time so I couldnt even remember what it had tasted like.  I was pleasantly surprised.  Nice caramel color with a medium sized head.  Hoppy aroma with a nice amount of strong malt to balance it out.  Nice bitterness but sweet malt at the same time.  Good stuff.

Slight haze.  Caramel color with creamy straw head.
Floral hoppy aroma, some light maltiness.
Big nose.
Sharp bitterness but well balanced.
Some sweetness, round palate.

Bottle poured into trappist glass- poured slightly turbid brown-amber color, light carbonation, big off white head formed and stayed.  Aroma of hops, hard malt, and notes of brown sugar and pine.  Hits the mouth with a full medium body, the malt sucker punches you in the guts, then the hops sweep your legs from the back.  Finish has a warming effect and makes you thick twice about slamming it.
UPDATED: MAR 23, 2009 Pretty solid beer - lots of hops. FINALLY available in SC!! Picked my first bottle up today (3/23/09) at my local bottle shop. WAS SO EXCITED! It didnt let down even one bit.

22 oz. bomber. Active head on the pour does not hold too long, and leaves little lacing. Intriguing deep garnet color is just a little hazy. Even hop bite all along the tongue, with the sweetness of the malt arriving on the back of the palate. You could almost call this an imperial amber, just to hang with the current trends. Great blend of beer goodness going on in this offering.

Rich caramel malty nose, with plenty of resiny hops.  Murky brown with amber tones and a thick pillowy head.  Burnt caramel, with huge hop bitterness and aroma.  Has a full body with a smooth long finish.  This is almost like a hearty IPA.  Really, really good beer.
Drank it with Juancho at the Ginger Man in NYC.  Not for the wimpy.  Beatiful caramel color, warming and complex.
Thanks to Joe for sharing this bottle. Spicy aroma, nutmeg maybe. Deep oak in colour. Hoppy, malty ale. I also found it sweet, especially in the finish.  Not bad at all.

Deep amber beer with off-white head.  Aroma of grass, pine and litter box.  Very sharp, catty bitterness with a little malt background in the finish.  Resiny at the end.  I must be a mutant but I cant stand Chinook hops.  Just tastes like ass to me.

GREAT BEER FROM A LIL COMPANY OUT HERE IN CALIFORNIA. WORD OF ADVISE THOUGH....

DRINK IT COLD!!!!!  ICE COLD
From 22 oz. bottle... beautiful caramel color. Medium head. Fantastic spicy, sweet aroma.Somewhat creamy, but a little strong too.
If you like a swift kick in the tastebuds this is your winner.  Not too malty, not too hoppy, but long on flavor and balance.  I did like it and I do have the sophistication to appreciate this!

On tap at The Red in Santa Cruz.  Poured into a nonic.  Dark ruddy copper in color with a thick off-white head.  Tons of lacing.  Aroma is chiefly hoppy, with lots of tropical fruitiness and a big dose of pine.  Taste is again hop-centric, with mango and grapefruit chased with a numbingly epic bitterness.  Malt is also in full force, with lots of caramel and dark fruit.  This is a bona fide tongue-raper, in a good way.  Finish is long, dry, and very bitter.  Killer beer, only for the worthy.
Bottle:  Amber colored pour with medium sized white head.  Sweet malty, piney citrus aroma.  Sweet, florally, piney hops flavor.

Pours red amber with a yellow head. Lots of fruit and some hops on the nose. Taste is fruit, spice, and hops. Nice bitter finish. Its much less dry than I expected. Definitely an aggressive beer, but doesnt over extend itself like its brother, Double Bastard.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2009 Pours a dark amber almost ruby color with a thick and frothy off-white head, almost tan. Smells of nice spiced fruit and hops. The taste is similar. Fruity at first with hints of spice that eases into a really nice, smooth, and dry, piney hop finish. Leaves just a slight bitter taste on the tongue. Much creamier texture then I was expecting. Not as complex as the DB.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2012 aroma is assaulting but oh so good, immediately gives you the impression of a beer that outdoes most of whats out there. flavor combines malt with citrus, excellent mouthfeel and body. Little bit of a bitter aftertaste, but it fits the beer nicely. fantastic overall.
Has a very nice reddish brown color and a aftertaste that lingers quite nicely. Starts bold and finishes smooth.

This beer is very dark and topped with just a little bit of tan head that quickly left just some large bubbles on top.  The aroma is citrusy and malty, just as expected.  It is very balanced with a little floral aroma- maybe orange blossoms.  The flavor has a ton of malt with a kind of caramel, almost roasty flavor.  Whole Foods Red Bank, NJ

Pours dark red with tan head.  Aroma of floral hops and malts.  Taste is dominated by malt and has slight hop  bite as well.  One of the great brews that peaked my interest in craft beer.  Still as good as I remember.

Pours a deep, dark red with a beautiful light tan head. The aroma is a bit subtle, but very pleasant. A strong molasses malt backbone, with with some spicy, herbal hops. The flavor is great - very bitter, herbal/pine/lemon hops all throughout with some nice, but largely hidden syrupy sweetness. The mouthfeel is thick and relatively smooth - very good for the style. This is a really good brew.

Sampled at Cellars Wine & Spirits in St Paul, Minnesota. Supplied by a non-ratebeerian (Bill). Pours a semi-hazy dark amber brew with a fast dissolving off-white head that has a thin ring. Aroma of powdery caramel malt, abundance of citrusy and pine hops, with a touch of herbal spice. Taste is medium bodied, light carbonated with flavors of mostly citrus zest, some dark brown malt and a touch of caramel. Finish is slightly bitter with a slight caramel malt in the background.
Bottle. Pours brown with tanish head. Nice citrus aroma, nice bitter body, strong bitter finish. Aggressive is a good word for it.
(USA) Dark Brown color with Med-Tan Head. Strong Grapefruit Aroma with a Bitter finish. This beer was a bit of a suprise!!!

Pours from bottle a darker brown with a thinning tan head.  The nose is not very pronounced, having a light piney hop and malty presence.  The flavor is that of earthy pine and roasted malt.  There is a big malty taste that fills the mouth ranging at first sweet but quickly going to a dry bitter.  A good beer on most occasions.

Dark amber/red pour
Hoppy nose with some citrus/pine
Aggressive, malty mouth
Grapefruit, hoppy
Excellent
I tried Arrogant Bastard Ale on draft at Yogis in Bloomington. This is a great looking red beer with an appropriate head. The flavor is very nice with lots of hopps, grass and notes of berries.

Bomber purchased at Crown Liquors #15, in Fishers, IN. Pours a deep mahogany with a sizable, creamy/frothy, beige head that laces well. The nose is a fairly muted deep malt front with a piny hop backing. While the aroma isnt particularly "bold" it does hint at a solidly balanced brew. Full-bodied and creamy with a dry, bitter, resinous finish. This is easily the fullest bodied beer that Ive sampled with an ABV below 8%. The flavor is a dark, dry, malty front that is quickly covered by woody, resinous & piny hops. This is a sold, flavorful brew. From a drinkability perspective I think that I prefer Stones Pale and IPA, but this is a nice one for the this time of year.

Citrusy, grapefruity hoppy aroma.  Very attractive appearance, a mahogany red with a nice thick tan head, which dissipated relatively quickly. The flavor is very citrusy and hoppy, but the real hop explosion is on the finish.  The finish really, really lingers.  It has a medium mouthfeel, but sort of a chewyness to it.  Enjoyable beer, but this beer is really more like an IPA, and there are more enjoyable IPAs out there.
Bought this at Beers of the World, 3450 Winton Place, Rochester, NY.  Not sure whats more aggressive, the beer or the hype printed on the label.  Ill spend my 6 bucks/22 oz elsewhere next time.

Oh, man, this is a nice beer.  Pours a deep mahogany color with a tight, tan head.  The aroma is a biscuity malt, but the flavor is all hop.  Its an almost explosive hop bitterness and flavor.  An almost chewy hop flavor in the finish, strong enough it has a slightly licorice quality to it with just the right balance of alcohol warmth.  Did I say this is a good beer?  Why the heck cant I get this in Iowa?

Bottled, consumed 02/26/08.  Pours a  molasses/burnished color, plenty of carbonation, nice head that lingers a while.  Aroma is strong grapefruity hops with a note of barely-sweet caramel malt.  Flavor has more malt than I remembered, but only for a split second before the gigantic hop monster appears on the palate.  Massive bitterness and resiny grapefruit/pine hop character obliterate anything even close ot balance or subtlety.  Goes down with a huge lingering bitterness (traces of vegetable/earthy hop flavor as well).  Did I mention its hoppy?
Bottle:  Poured a very nice semi dark brown color with a minimal head.  Aroma of sugar and grapefruit?   Flavor is a bit bitter for my taste but great for a strong ale.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2010 1Pt. 6oz. bottle.  Healthy tan head.  Dark molasses/amber color; pretty dark tone until held to a light, when it turns almost orange.  Fresh outdoor, earthy hops aroma.  Heavy textured body that tastes precisely how it looks.  Heavy hops with a powerful nose bite that lingers in the throat after a swig; the alcohol flavor seems to come primarily after the swig.  Notes of grapefruit; oak-ey earthy flavor settles with the brew in the stomach. Descent lacing.  Im a bit disappointed, but only because of the hype.  Nonetheless, this  is a damn good beer.  Great for a pale ale lover.  The alcohol content is pretty warming after 22 Oz. too, which is nice.

[RE-RATE] Dont think I ave had this one since my initial rating over a year ago.  The appearance is great.  Dark clear mahogany/copper color with a tall pillowy lacing light tan head.  I think the aroma out weighs the flavor this time around.  Pretty bitingly bitter without the hop flavor complexity that I hope for in hop bombs. Bumping this one down from 3.9 to 3.4.  The flavor is a bit of a mess. Plus, I hate the name and corny "hook" attitude.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2008 Rerate- Bottle. Pours a reddish orange with a reasonalble off white head. The aroma has lots of pine and grain along with a bit of sweetness. The taste is a great balance of malt and hops. starts out with a bit of caramel sweetness thin the bitterness comes on strong. Finishes with a nice bitterness. Tried this time with other strong ales and this was the best. Upped the appearance ratingby 1

Origional rating 4.1
Bottle. Pours reddish brown with off white head. Aroma has lots of citrus from the heavy hops. The taste is quiet bitter but there are a few ohter flavors like grass and some malt sweetness. Long bitter aftertaste. Really good.

22oz bottle.  Pours a dark amber red color with pretty good head.  Tastes of malts, hops, alcohol and tart fruit.  A very dark, heavy and hop-dominated beer.  Im not a big fan of hop-bitterness, but I can tell you the quality of this beer is top notch, and if you enjoy that flavor you will love this.
Pours hazy, caramel red. Head is reddish. Tons of malt up front, hops even a little earthiness in this one. Creamy, good body. Great beer.
this is by far the BEST beer that has ever made contact with my mouth!! I LOVE IT!!

Stupid Illinois laws prevent me from having ever had this until now, which is a tragedy.  Darker than I expected, this is something that could become my mainstay if it were possible.  Also, probably the best bottle story I have encountered - the mightier than thou feeling we all have about beer and the general populace.

Ive had this a million times and cant believe I havent rated it before now.

Pours a dark hazy brown with a nice brown head. Flavor of hops, malt, hops, grapefruit, and did I mention hops. Lots of bitterness in the bastard, and I mean that in a good way. The label says it all. If you dont understand why this beer is awesome youre obviously not worthy.

Giant bottle sat on my table at the restauarant with funny comments to read on the bottle. Dark copper with a good sized head. Very hoppy flavor with other tastes mixed in.  Tasty beer with a good alcohol content!
Bottle-RI. Poured a ruby red with a white head.  Hops were very present and balanced well with the malt.  Much heavier than the gravity would indicate. Purhaps a high FG.

Im not a big fan of this style beer, but the quality is their for anyone else.  Its got a good amount of hops and a great array of flavors poured into a beer with a kick.  You have to like this kind of beer to want to try it first.  The warning on the back label is great though.
An all around great beer. It has a nice hop aroma and flavor. It has a very good bold taste, not for everybody. Great for if you are in the mood for a beer you can really taste.
this beer will try to drive you away, but dont be too scared.  a lilltle out of balance, but very tasty, especially if you love the hops.
22 ounce bottle purchased at Garys Wine Madison , NJ for aprox $4.00 Pink grapefruit?

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2009 ~Dark amber color with big creamy off white head
~Strong, rich scent of earthy hops. Smells like grass, in a good way. A hint of sweetness and citrus.
~The hops taste great, but I was expecting more after reading the reviews.... Actually as I continue the gulps, the hops are quite strong and bitter... I like. Has just the right of sweetness. Somewhat of a grapefruit flavor.
~Palate is dry. Bitterness is long lasting.
~What the hell! This beer made it to my #1 brew thus far! Escondido here I come! I cant wait to try this on tap!
Funny thing is, Im drinking this baby out of a wine glass because Im to cheap to afford a Trappist glass.
Works very well.

Not a big fan of AB.  Little bit to arrogant for me.  Has a big alcohol taste for it being 7.2%.  I have had beers that are 10% and I couldnt tell at all.  Not so with this.  Its just not a very enjoyable drink.
As advertised - over-the-top in all respects (save the aroma, which was rather mundane). Huge hops and malt flavors pack a punch. Great beer, but I couldnt imagine drinking more than a couple.
Not real subtle, but in a good way. A huge beer. Big malt.  Big Hops.  Big Bitter finish.  Freaking Big.
Arrogant Bastard Ale from Stone is excellent but I like Ruination much better

Bottled, many thanks Ian for sharing this. Chestnut with dying head. Unbalanced, bitter beer, pushes a dry hard unsophisticated hop to the fore with no refinement. Sharp, almost medicinal with a bite of alcohol and a touch of bath cleaner. Not a pleasant beer to drink or relax with. Poor side of middlling.

Deep clear caramel w/ creamy fine thick head. Piney sweet toasted aroma w/ tiny hints of nutmeg & ginger. I got some of that "biscuity" malt that Ive read about but not found up until now. After the swallow the hops whack you on the back of the tongue. A mouthfillin taste bud crushin sumbitch!

This one one of my Go-To beers.  Available in my area mainly in 22oz bottles priced around $5 I view it as a great value for the money.

You better be a huge fan of hops for this one...cause thats its main selling point.  

I could only descibe this one as an IPA that someone pours over a bed of hops and pinecones....yum!

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 Thanks to lb4lb for this one. 22oz bottle. Pours a dark red ruby. Lightly barely penetrates this beast. Cloudy as hell. Pillowy white head sits atop, with a crazy amount of lacing left on the glass. Aroma is full of piney hops and grassy malts. Swirling around the brew brings out the best aromas. Toffee, biscuit, and caramel. Flavor is an orchestra of finely tuned interwoven hops and malts. Raisin, caramel, engorged chocolate cherry bombs. Watery on the tip of the tongue and roof of the mouth. Gets grizzled and bitter as the session advances. Handles like a champ, though. Quite drinkable.
Woah.  Yes, like it says, an "aggressive" beer.  HOP.  Almost too much.  Then come the undertones: the malt, the pine.   This ones not for me to come back to for a loooong time.

This brew starts off tame, but increases its bitterness to match its name.  It moves from citrusy and slightly malty to bitterly hoppy and terminates.  This one has one of the most controlled flavors Ive experienced.  A must try!

UPDATED: APR 7, 2008 To me, this beer pushes the envelope, and in a good way.  its certainly not easy drinking, and not for everyone, but thats the way Stone Brewing Company clearly wanted it.  Its all too easy to simply make a bad, undrinkable beer.  They push the bitterness, a little too much hops for my taste, but the flavor is complex, and the color and the head holds up for a long time.  Its one of those beers that elicits a different reaction that says as much about the beer drinker as it does the beer.  I like what they accomplished with this.
The smell of citrus hits you right away. Definatley an excellent blend of hops and malt. Sometimes these types of beers finish to hoppy and bitter, but this one was almost perfect.

This is a true-to-form IPA.  Pungent hoppy nose with hints of pine/citrus. Not overly heavy body with light carbonation.  Definitely a kick in the balls, as are most Stone beers.  The hoppy taste remains long after you are done drinking (not always a good thing).  Overall a great beer to wake you up in the morning!

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2008 I was not as impressed with this as I was with its Oak Aged Brother. Aroma is nearly completely malt with citrus hops also coming on later to dominating that category. There is also a tad bit of something tangy and maybe some cinnamon. The pour yeilds a huge frothy head covering a clear amber/red body. The head lasts fully and retains a big soapy character. The lacing is spotty, literally leaving dots all over my glass. The taste is much maltier than even the aroma portrays. The muthfeel is watery with extremely soft carbonation. As I said before, I personally think that the Oak Aged counterpart is far superior. Re-rate on tap, beautiful ale, nice hop and malt balance in the taste. Great fruity hoppy aroma...decent alcohol warming. Great looking beer with plenty of lacing... Syrupy mouthfeel. Great!

Bomber shared with Illini08. Thanks! Poured a nice bronze color with a .5 finger width tan head that disappeared quickly. The aroma consisted of strong hops with light hints of fruit. The taste was also very hoppy but pleasant. It left a great hop aftertaste. As the beer warmed I started to smell and taste hints of citrus on top of the aggressive hops. Finished a bit bitter but was an overall great beer! I would definitely seek this one out again!

The aroma off this beer is wonderful. Wheat, malt, hops and spice. The taste is full body, hoppy very aggressive with the hops with notes of citrus and spice. 
The finish is lasting, make you drink more. Very well made beer

The only one of the Bastard line that Ive had and enjoyed. Fairly aggressive, but not overly so, it has a decent mic of citrus, fruit, hops, and a hint of pine. Medium sized head with a little lacing. Aroma has a nice complexity to it that carried over into the flavor. Could be a good change of pace session beer. Pretty tasty, but as I stated on my "oaked" review, I cant help but think that a lot of this beers high rating is because of the cool bottle, the saying on the back, and of course, the name.

22oz single from Total Wine, River Edge, NJ...pours a nice deep bronze color with a light beige head...nice rich floral aroma with orange-tangerine and pine...taste includes the same with malts and a crisp hoppy presence...smooth mouthfeel and good lacing on the glass...I have to disagree with cheapdark, I liked it...a lot.  :o)

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2008 This is an aggressive beer. You probably wont like it. It is quite doubtful that you have the taste or sophistication to appreciate an ale of this quality and depth. Absolutely. Nice aroma tho. Some carbonation but the tremendous amount of green citrus rind, turns me off more. First mellow then suddenly offensive. Quite rude and non apologetic. Excessively arrogant. Way too much for me and my sissy taste buds. Good example of this rude style.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: A tremendous beer. Very red with a beautiful head. This is a standard to be aspired to.
Very nice.  Dark, malty, with great complexity and a super hop bite, all in perfect balance.  This is a really great beer.

The beer is dark in color with tinges of brown/blood red/copper and a head that pours 1/2" and dissipates.  The nose begins with citric hops followed by tart cherry, orange zest, plum and cocoa.  In the mouth it is medium-bodied with good palate weigh and rich midpalate that fades to a dry hoppy finish.  This is a well-balanced beer that is easy to drink but also showing some complexity.  This appears as if it would age well.

Man, with a name like Arrogant Bastard, you want to hate this one, but its absolutely impossible.  This has got to be one of the best ales made in the continental US.  Just like the boiler-plate states, it is aggressive...hoppy aroma to a hoppy initial bite.  Beautiful amber-coppery/red and clear.  Lingering floral hop palate develops into rich malt undertones.  Finishes bitter and strong - leaving you thirsting for another draw...

I dont remember this one being so dark.  Typically, I drink it in an ill-lit bar, and in those instances my impression has always been that its sort of a well-balanced double pale ale.  Now I see that this puppy is pretty dark and malty.  The hops are still there, and its far from an extreme brown ale, but its tough to categorize the real balance of it between malt and hop.  Anyway its very bold, a bit syrupy, and powerful!
Strong citrus/grapefruit aroma. Pours a deep scarlet red to dark brown. Almost no head. Straight citrus flavor fallowed by a dark chocolate finish. Full body with an all around balanced flavor.
I love the label.  nice complex beer at a decent price as well.  good taste, but nothing too special about it

Despite the label, I wasnt ready for the taste. Its really quite good once youve grown accustomed to the aggressive flavour. I really enjoyed this beer, even if my wife said it was the worst piss shed ever had!

Great, great beer.  Clear, burnt amber pour with a finger-and-a-half worth of creamy head.  Aroma was a very hearty mix of malt, hop, and a citrusy sweetness.  The taste didnt disappoint either--medium full to full body, quite  malty-sweet with a touch of grapefruit and something else I cant put my finger on when it first hits the tongue, giving way to a malty-bitter finish.  If it has any shortcomings, it may be that the aftertaste lingers a touch too long.  Other than that, its a strong, bitter, but very drinkable behemoth of a beer.  One of my personal favorites.
I am not worthy of this beer...lol.  Love the floral hops and the powerful finish.  Great creamy head.
Good beer.  The super bitter finish almost seems like its trying to hard though.  With a name like that I shouldnt be surprised.

Bottle. Pours a clear amber with a one finger lasting tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of caramel, dark fruit, with citrus, floral, and pine hops. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium full mouthfeel that starts off malty and finishes highly bitter. Very good.
This is a solid beer. Great taste with meduim amount of hop flavor and malt. Pours with a nice head and goes down smoothly. Good color as well.

Pours a really beautiful golden amber color.  Hoppy through and through.  Was a bit drunk when drinking this, so I dont remember specifics, but it was good, very hoppy/piney, but still quite drinable.
a great beer, very bitter, and a nice sour aftertaste.  available at McGinleys in anchorage

Poured like a frothy beast- i got quite the huge head out of this one... tight too. Nice dark amber color complemented the look nicely. This beer has so much hype I just had to give it a chance. Aroma was very complex... a nice balance of malt, copious amounts of citrus and pine hops, and a fruity note. Stones marketers we definitely not kidding when they wrote the discription for arrogant bastard... the first sip of this brew literally attacked my palate. I wasnt expecting nearly the hop content as this beer had, but it was surely there. Despite an astringent first sip however, this beer mellows out significantly after a minute or two. It eventually evolved to be very smooth and drinkable. I would be interested to find out the IBUs on this monster, but I can only guess it to be 80+. Malt character is great too; very balanced and drinkable. Alcohol content is definitely present, but not as much as one would guess for the 7.2% abv. It remained well balanced throughout, and is another winner by Stone.
Poured darker then I thought. Not as big a head either. Lots of malt. No citrus odor for me. Lots of coffee odor. Very delicious all-around.
great smll of hops and malts. poured very dark amber with fluffy medium to small head.  Great noticable hidden citrus taste.  very solid, well...if your a bastard
Quite a bit of citrus hop. Some malty sweetness too. Falls flat at the start of the finish though.

It smells wonderfully and pleasantly hoppy with an undercurrent of malts.  Very nice.  Dark caramel hue to it with a nice one-finger head leaving lacing.  Very bitter taste without much malt balancing it.  Still good though.  Very thick mouthfeel and smooth.
Pours brown and hazy with fluffy beige head and nice lacing.  Bread and hops on the nose.  Close to full bodied with nice carbonation.  Malty up front, hoppy finish
Poured a light brown with a small head.  A good blend of malts and hops.  There are some noticeable citrus flavors as well.  One of my favorites.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2013 Lates rating is a bottle bought in Japan. Pours a clear red-brown with a small tanned head. Light sweetness and quite bitter. Lots of hops aromas.
