Hints of chocolate malts and alcohol. Leafy hops aroamas. Medium to full bodied. Fizzy carboantion. Bitter finish with hints of sweet licorice..
Hoppity hop hop hop!! Hops are the dominant flavor, although hints of sour citrus and grapefruit also linger.

Wow...  Reddish brown, big frothy head.  Aroma of of earthy vegetables...  celery maybe a parsnip?  Flavor is hops... imagine that.  There is a maltiness on the tongue but but the hops really get noticeable after the swallow.  Finish that lasts.  Will get this again, as it is one of the few that I can get around here that is this big.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2008 22oz bottle.   Brown.   Bone head.   Earthy and piney hop aroma, with some earth maltiness underneath.   Malty caramel with lots of bitter, piney hops.  A hint of citrus, and a rough bitter finish that sticks.   Medium body that is pretty drinkable.   I like the maltiness, but there is a weird roughness to the hops in the finish that Im not too keen on.   A nice beer, except for this one hang-up. (3.6)

Rerate: 22oz bottle.   Deep red color with a lasting beige head.   Earthy caramel, tea, pine, and grapefruit in the aroma.   The flavor has some soil, caramel and damp tea leaves, with bitter and piney hops in the finish.   The caramel almost overtakes the bitterness of the hops, but falls short in the end.   Pretty nice for a big, hoppy red ale, but not as clean and drinkable as when I first had it.
dark reddish brown hue, thick head, hoppy citrus aroma, bitter grapefruit after-taste, will look for other offerings from this brewery

Smells of citrus and hops. pours a dark amber color (slightly brownish) with a small tan head. Taste of fruit, but changes to a citrus flavor that leaves a bitter aftertaste. Multiple flavors. The palate isnt to thick. Overall a good buy, but not my favorite.
UPDATED: MAR 1, 2008 Yeah, it is bitter to taste. Taste is of cat urine. I guess I am a novice. I will re-rate it later and get back to you...
Deep red copper color. Sweet fruity hop aroma. Hoppy wheat grass hop taste. Good for an American Strong Ale, i must not be a huge fan of the style. Goes down much easier than the IPA.
UPDATED: FEB 26, 2008 Even though this doesnt compare to the double or the oaked its probably the best ale Ive ever had.  Very strong, dark, and overall outstanding!
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: definitely my choice out at the local sports bar in town, but falls short of being served at home. Not stones strongest offering but a solid beer nonetheless
22 oz. Pours brown red with medium light tan head. Strong taste, very bitter. Should be the standard for strong ales.
VERY STRONG, STARTING WITH THE AROMA, CITRUSSY, THE TASTE IS THE SAME, CITRUSSY, STRONG, MALTY AND BITTER AFTERTASTE

Bomber thanks to Eric. Pours a deep red that borders on purple with a great massive beige head. The nose is mostly malt and hops. The taste is subdued but really good; a smooth malt with strong hop flavors. There is also some fruit and smokey hints. A rich and balanced brew; I really appreciate this one and the oak-aged version. A beer I could drink everyday.

On tap.  Ive had this beer several times, but prefer it on tap more so than bottle. A great American strong ale with lots of malt and hops - with an alcohol finish.  Not my favorite Stone product, but good a good beer and easily obtainable.

Ive had this on tap and in a bottle. Pretty much a perfect ASA. Excellent hop balance with a nice light malt undertone. GOlden in color. Its hard to describe, other than just good... better on tap than bottle, but a nice session beer if youre up for a night of hard drinking. The hop character may put it a bit over the top, but its just nice in a glass and to nurse. (On Tap 12/27/2007 - multiple times in the bottle)

22 oz. bottle shared with kleyland and alexanderj at the GA-CA-VA-NY-MA NYE Extravaganza.  Pours a dark rust color with a thin, off white head.  Aroma of warming alcohol and caramel malt.  Mouthfeel of chewy malts.  Long bitter finish.  Something seemed off with this bottle.  Definitely want to go back and re-rate this.

How can you NOT like an ale with this name? Pours a very dark amber, with a substantial head and lacing that is, dare I say it? arrogant. First taste is a beautiful complexity of barley, hops and malt in a nearly perfect harmony. I would like to see the malt toned down a hair, but thats just me. In fact, the temptation is to just keep drinking this in order so enjoy the drinking/savoring/swallowing/aftertaste  experience, but, given the 7.2% alcohol content, this probably wouldnt be a good idea on a weekday morning if you are a school bus driver. An excellent ale. And yes, I AM worthy!!

Might not have liked this as much as others.   Good beer but not one of my favorites. 

Dark amber pour with a nice head. 

Smells faintly hoppy with some malt as well. 

Strange taste to this.  Would really like to have a fresh bottle.  This may be old.  Sorta hoppy and a little malty.  Most of what I get is kinda like paint thinner smells.  Pretty bitter finish which I do like but not as hoppy as I was led to believe.  

Still a good beer but I have to admit, I was a bit let down. 


RERATE!!  Im actually re-rating the same bottle here.  As this warmed, it got tons better.  Much hoppier, the acetone taste was absent.  Actually a very good beer.  I will definitely be getting this one again.

I have loved Stone beer for 5 years. I cant believe I havent rated this yet. What I love about this is its consistent. Big huge beer that is darker, maltier, and more thick and chewy than alot of run of the mill beers. This is also one that seems to be much better on tap but yet bottles are delicious as well.
Decent ale. Very bold in flavor and and in the finish.Local fav. at my local pub. It is the most arrogant bar in America. I prefer the oaked version better.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2008 One of the greatest session beers EVAH! Rich, full flavor with dark roasted malts, fully hopped noses and frothy goodness. Damn, I fucking love this beer. The first flavor does hit you hard - its an assault of balanced bitterness between the roast in the malt and the hops. But behind this, is a very complex, uncompromising flavor.
This is avery tasty beer.  I am new to rating beer so I am sorry for the lack of description about the hops or the finish.  But I drink a lot of different kinds and This is one of my favorites.

Orange red color with bubbly tan head. Some malt in the nose with a touch of citrusy hops. Hop bitterness all around, but plenty of malt in the taste, along with a bit of cherry.  Fantastic stuff - wish theyd distribute more than just this one and the IPA to Texas - Id love to drink more of their stuff here.
Bomber. pours dark reddish brown.  Beige head. Smells citrus hops and brown suger. Taste is citrus hops and dark fruit. Awesome beer

Pours a ruby dark red with a nice off white head that sticks around and has lacing with a python grip. Mild smell of dried fruit, hops and some sweet malt. Hops show up much more than the smell would indicate. Fig and malt stick around nicely and are washed out by tasty hops. Feels full bodied with perfect carbonation in the mouth. Minimal alcohol feel and a bitter finish. Could make quite an evening out of this brew. A classic in my book.

Bomber from Sicilianos, Grand Rapids, MI.  Hazy dark brown/red color with medium sized beige head.  Aroma is pretty nice cookie, dough and citrus hops, pretty sweet and nice.  Flavor follows up the aroma very nicely with a touch of dark fruit to round it out.  Medium to full body.  This was better than I imagined.

22oz.  Pours a deep, hazy red-amber with a small light tan head.  Nose wasnt as strong as I had remembered it but had a lot of citrus and florals with a slight sweetness.  Has some carmel malt flavor with pine and floral that hits you with some dank citrus in the finish.  An excellent beer.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2008 bomber.  Stone Brewing Co. is by far one of the best breweries in the country.... and Arrogant Bastard lives up to the marketing they have developed around it.  An excellent American Strong Ale... pours a deep red with a nice white head.  extremely smooth and complex... hoppy, yet not extremely hoppy (like Ruination), sweet and malty.  Many Belgian qualities make themselves known throughout this beer... such as the spice, raisin and sweet malt characters.  Nice medium body and smooth over the palate with a bitter back-end and finish.  A very high quality brew with a very unique name and story on the bottle.  Highly recommended... if Stone doesnt distribute to your state, get your hands on this stuff somehow.

Pours a caramel brown with a thin, tan head.  The aroma is complex, with hints of both malty sweetness and piney hops coming through.  The overwhelming impression I came away with is balance.  This brew looks like a brown ale, but it doesnt hit you with that overwhelming roasted malt flavor.  The predominant malt flavor is spice and caramel, and it is balanced very nicely by a subtle piney hops kick.  This ale is very smooth--I didnt even notice the 7.2% alcohol until I finished the 22 oz. bottle.  This ale is very expensive--$40 for a case in Southeastern Pa. where I live.  I enjoyed this, but I am not sure it is worth the premium price.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2008 1l. growler. Pours dark red, with a thick yellowish brown head. Smells hoppy out of the growler, way more so than out of the bottle. Tastes just like it smells, this beer is all hops. It coats the mouth and teeth. Very smooth, with that mouth pucker bitterness. This beer takes getting used to and is great no matter how you drink it, from a bomber or off the tap, but nothing quite compares to the extra hoppiness that you get when its fresh from the brewery.

this is a great brew.  Had this from bombers and on tap and its great either way.  Pours a dark reddish/copper color with light tan head.  Aroma is of hops and some malts.  Flavor is complex,  starts malty and ends with a great hop finish.  Left lacing all down the glass.  tasty, tasty brew.
dlunsford1 and I drank this stuff together and I really enjoyed it.  How dare he drink a Tequiza before this, I stay away from that Mexican piss water.

Pours dark with a thin tight head.  Thick, opaque copper color, with an aroma that draws us back to a private reserve we sampled last week.  Smooth, although very hoppy.  I believe that this is one of the better beers weve sampled in the past few months.  $4 for a 22 oz. bottle.  I must admit, after trying a bit of this, part of me doesnt want to finish the Tequiza that I started to pregame on.

Bomber bottle with an arrogant label informing the drinker that he is unworthy of the ale contained within - now there is a different approach.  Very impressive, complex flavor - begins with rich malt and alcohol, then the hops kick in and their flavor slowly changes shape, finishing with a sassy bitter nip.  There is a demon on the label, but somehow I picture a fat, tonsured monk sipping away at a tankard of this stuff.

22oz bottle -- pours a caramel brown, ruby when held to the light with a thick off-white head that lasts.  Aroma is hoppy with grapefruit notes.  Flavor is malty on the front of the tongue, and has great grapefruit hoppiness on the back.  Finishes relatively clean.  Surprisingly less sharp than the Stone IPA.

From San Diego tasting notes: Just starting to rate beer, but taste as I travel Canada, Europe and the US; This is top 10 so far for me: Dark amber and a little cloudy with a substantial head. Obviously heavily hopped with citrus and sweet brown bread aromas. Alcohol not noticeable upon tasting. I found it full bodied, well balanced with some dried fruit and a long finish.
tHIS IS MY FAVORATE BEER,I FOUND IT ABOUT SIX YEARS AND HAVE BEEN SPREADING THE WORD ABOUT STONE BREWERY EVER SINCE,AN INCREDEBLY WORTHY ALE,THICK AND HEARTY. I HAVE BOUGHT CASES OF IT AT  A TIME.

On draft, in pint glass.  Sharp pine aroma, with healthy amount of blossoms as well.  Beautiful in glass, with creamy, thick head and unbelievable lacing throughout drink.  Flavor of pine resins with only occasional sweet malts.  Oily & resinous in mouth.  Woody end.  Alcohol well-masked by everything else happening. More like an IPA or ESB than a strong ale.
Very smooth, hint of fruit, sweet taste with a definate kick.  No aftertaste very balanced. Very thick, light colored head. Personal favorite drank regularly.

orange brown haze, great aroma like
apricots. taste very smooth also a hint of apricots. no after taste. not sweet or bitter very well balanced not a hint of alcohol even though its abv is 7.2%.

Poured into a wide glass - color of RC Cola - smells a bit like pine sap - decent head.  Sweet with an appropriate bitterness following.  Alcoholic taste comes through - you can tell its got a bit of kick, and I drank mine cold.  Closer to a pale ale than I expected with the hoppiness shining through and through.  Good though...

No. 100. Ive had this many times, surprised I never rated it. Good one to save for No. 100! The aroma is a little sweet, molasses,bread a little citrus. The head is big and creamy, off white, excellent lacing and mostly lasting. The body is reddish coper and cloudy. the initial flavor is sweet and bitter, the finish is strong bitter back of the mouth and average to long. The body is medium, the  texture a lite creamy, the carbonation soft.

22 oz. bomber.  Pours red/amber color with quickly disapating, foamy head of three fingers to start.  Big ol hoppy nose.  Citrus and pine.  Great malt backbone, carmel and toffee.  A good biscuity feel.  Big hop bitterness.  Good hop flavor, citrus and piney, some floral notes.  Im such a fan of this beer.  I have no clue why it took me so long to rate this.  It should be a staple for everyones fridge.

My first Stone beer.....thought it was way too hoppy the first time I drank it (I guess the label was right), but for some reason I came back to it and liked it much more the second time (and third, and fourth, and....). One of the hoppiest beers Ive had, true to Stones style. Deep orange/red color, a bit spicy, but a good balance of malt too. Very good, especially at $4/bomber.

dark color with thick head that sticks around for a while. Hoppy with a nice flavor. I can almost taste pineapple. Think pineapple when you drink this one. Its not over powering, but there is a hint of sweetness, just ahint. I would definetly have this one again.

I have only had this beer a few times but Ill be honest and admit that I didnt enjoy it that much, but after reading about it I will definitely try it again.  I enjoyed the arome more than the taste.  Like the description says, I didnt like it and I guess I dont have the sophistication yet.  I thought the taste of alcohol came through the taste too much.

oily hop aroma with some alcohol. fluffy creamy thick head. dark red color looks black without holding it to the light. superb dark red ale that is strong and ominously redrinkable. hints of oak. firm but not heavy. great year round
On draft. Cloudy dark amber with an off-white head. Big malty aroma with lots of spicy, grassy hop notes. Great malty sweetness to start with a huge hop bitterness at the finish. Great beer.

On tap at Ale House.  Cloudy caramel color, light brown head.  A bit of a bit yet creamy smooth, hoppy, malty, great brew to have waiting for takeout.  Nice to find a place with more than Molson on tap.  Recommended.

Had this beer on 9/10/2003.  Aroma is rich with a fresh hop secent and a nice sweet malt scent.  Color is a deep rich amber with very good carbonation and tight head.  Taste is rich, hoppy and bitter.  Starting with a full strong body and bubbly feel, it goes down with a strong sweet feel. Finish comes on sharp with a hefty hop flavor and bold maltiness.  All of this is topped off with firm bitterness and finished with a lingering hop flavor.  Wow, this may be the boldest and fullest beer I have ever had.  They do hit what they where going for on the label, they use terms like aggressive, sophisticated and quality & depth.  It is the depth that really hits it here, this beer goes beyond anything Ive ever had it is malty, hoppy and bitter, all to an extreme but is very well balanced.

Bomber. Poured a dark reddish brown that looked somewhat like a cola. Rather thin head but, it did leave a nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of dark fruit with some hop presence. Nice flavor balance between the dark malt and fruit and the hop bitterness. Good mouthfeel. Overall, an excellent beer.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2007 Appearance is a dark clear redish brown with a creamy white head.  Nose is sweet, almost like a barleywine, not many hops here.  Taste is a well balanced mix of malts and hops.  Not the hoppy taste I expected; bottle may have a little age.  Mouthfeel is of medium carbonation.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2012 Finally!  Poured a dark amber with a nice tan head.  Lots of hops and pine in the nose,  hints of citrus.  Went down about the same way,  lots of grapefruit and a bit of malty goodness.  Hop bitterness lasted for ages with a nice dry finish.  Wish this could be a session beer for me,  maybe some day...


UPDATE! And today is that day thanks to Iowa finally carrying stone. This beer isnt that good. No grapefruit to speak of. Malty goodness in a strong hoppy beer? Gross. Minimal hop flavor, mainly bitterness. Ruby red pour leads me to believe this is an overhopped underwhelming double AMBER ALE. WS;SP only rating was 8x4x8x4x17

12oz. bottle. Pours a clear, dark amber color with a light grey head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is of citrus fruits, grass, hops and a hint of spearmint. Flavor is of hops, grapefruit, malts, and has a huge bitter finish . Mouthfeel is very crisp and sharp. Another great brew from Stone.

Has this from a 22 ounce bomber. Poured an attractive reddish-brown color with a good head that lasted a while. Aroma was fruity and very hoppy. Flavor was also a bit of citrus with very hoppy flavor. Very smooth and easy to drink. Mouthfeel was excellent. I would have again and again and recommend.
Reddish ruby brown with a medium head. Very smooth. Mouthfeel is substantial and feels great. Light carbonation. Some hints of juicy hops, ctirus, bitterness is evident but not overpowering.

Bottled from Solvang, CA. Deep red with foamy head. Nose is mildly hoppy with some spices and malts. Flavor is extremely hoppy and full, but not overly bitter. Hops are smooth and juicy, not piney bitter with only a moderate aftertaste. Pretty sweet and easy to drink actually with incredibly creamy and full mouthfeel with subtle and smooth carbonation. I cant say I was disappointed, because its an extremely nice beer, but I expected something more arrogant! Some yeast (?) was on the bottom of the glass.

Light reddish brown.  Good creamy medium head.  Mild aroma.  Hits quickly and lingers well.  Pretty smooth but some aftertaste.  Medium body.  Decent creaminess.  Smoother and creamier that the Oaked with no sourness, but just a bit better.

This beer has a strong balvarian noble hops flavor. Its pretty much the basis of the flavor, so despite it being ale, it taste a bit like a stronger sam adams boston lager. I love the hops, so this beer is really good to me. If you dont like powerful hops flavor, then the warning on the label will probably be correct.
Orange/Amber. Hoppy aroma and very intense citrus/herbal hop flavor. Aggressive is a good adjective, but not bad.

Im not particularly the biggest hophead but I do enjoy this beer. very nice pour and aroma. Super hoppy but the taste of caramel still manages to fight through it for a little more balance. You have to love the personality of Stones bottles, particularly the literature on the back.

Excellent beer here. Very caramelly but not sweet one bit. Very bitter taste of hoppyness, grapefruit and grassy/piney hop profile and light colored wood. Very carbonated but not enough to fill the stomach. Beautiful white lacing.
This beer was amazing.  It had a very sweat smell of chocolate and caramel that I could smell from two feet away.  Its flavor also had a strong chocolate taste.
Loved this beer - the aroma was amazing - very hoppy  - deep red color  - not a huge head -    - awesome taste and smooth finish
Bottle. Pourd a ruby color with a frothy head. Aroma is nothing but hops. Taste is great smooth with a hop finish.

Pours a dark cherry wood color with a nearly white head that is large and provides nice lacing.  The aroma is purely hoppy with spruce and grapefruit notes coming through the strongest.  The flavor is very, very bitter.  There isnt a whole lot of complexity here.  The finish is crisp, but the flavor sticks to your palate for too long.  This is just a brutish beer that makes it hard for me to say "Yeah, Id like one of those!"
I love this beer!!!!! One i can drink everyday. The very first beer to turn me on to Stone.
Bottle.  Dark almost ruby in color.  Good hop aroma and a strong Hop flavor.  Flavor sits on the tounge for a time after swallowing

Pours dark copper. Interesting aroma is almost non-existent (or maybe I have a cold). Flavor, however, tells a much different story. Drinking this is like a floral hop punch in the mouth. It comes on fast and strong, but leave pretty quick also. Alcohol flavor is present, but mostly hidden in the hop goodness.
This ale poured a dark colour of copper. Taste was very hoppy with grassy notes. the finish was also very hoppy. A hopp heads delight

Very piney, earthy hop aroma. Pours dark red with a nice velvetty white head. Mostly a hop dominated brew, it does have some roast and some super sweetness, but most of it is hidden by the bitterness in the hops. I have drank this beer a hundred times, but at this point, I far prefer the Oaked version.

Another impressive offering from Stone.  Pours a burnt mahogany color with a decent white head.  Smells surprisingly piney and hoppy.  At first I thought they bottled some IPA in the wrong bottle.  Afterwards you get a little bit of burnt malt and hints of chocolate.  The taste itself is very hoppy up front and the malt hits you when its sliding down your throat.  Very enjoyable.  Perfect level of carbonation makes for a great mouthfeel.  Just dont drink too many of these because at 7.2% ABV you may be acting like an arrogant bastard after 2 bombers.
Poors dark with a medium head, not too much carbonation.  Packs a good kick. Another great beer from Stone Brewing company.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2008 Often the (sorta) saving grace of a mediocre tap list.  Ive seen it called a Barleywine and an American Strong Ale; both imply what you get: an ale that is hearty without being thick, imaginative mostly for its characteristic Stone smoothness.

10-6-07 bottle.  Foggy rich brown color with thick head.  Nice lacing.  Heavy yeast, malt and alcohol in the taste and aroma.  Just not my style!  Thick and heavy on the palate. Easier to drink than I remember from years ago - but still not something I am dying to have another of.
Great beer. Very accessible. Tasty plum and caramel flavor. Well balanced hop flavor.

Poured out of the badass bottle into a pint glass. Has a very nice color with a good head that dissipates fairly quickly. This beer is very unique - but definitely tasty. It certainly lives up to its name as it is very in your face with all of the hops. I cant quite put my finger on any particular flavor in the taste, but it is relatively complex. Definitely glad I got my hands on this. An excellent brew.

Definitely packs a huge punch.  Has a look of dark brown with a brownish-white head.  taste comes in regular but almost immediately turns bitter...real bitter.  This one hits hard and then makes you want more.

This beer is damn well cocky because it can be. I drank it out of a fatty 1 pint and 6 oz. bottle and it tore me a third asshole. It has very well noticable hops and a definite full malty taste. Even fuller of a taste than the old granny pussy Ive been munchin on lately. Has a nice bitter aftertaste that makes you wanna beat the shit out of a baby. I would suggest trying it once, then waiting a year and trying it again. Then youll realize that youre not as big of a doosh bag as you once had thought....
Dark deep in taste with a lot of head in the pour.  Not a lot of hops or alcohol to be found, but creamy and a little caramel.  Very well balanced.  Could have used more alcohol in it.

Draft at The Gypsy Hut.  Dark brown color, strong piney hop aroma, creamy texture, intense but not over the top hoppy flavor moderated somewhat by undercurrent of sweet malt.  I have to add that Im intrigued by the commercial description but even a tasteless, unsophisticated slob like me (and many others on here, apparently) likes this beer.  Aggressive?  Yes, Stone, when compared to, say, Michelob Light.  Pretty wimpy when compared to Rogue Dead Guy Ale, though (just kidding!).

pours a ruby copper with a tannish head.  aroma is fruit, flowers, alcohol.  taste is bitter, with strong malt and hops flavors.  smooth mouthfeel, mid-bodied, bitter finish.  good lacing.  alcohol is nicely disguised.  bitter’s the name of the game here.  not overly complex, but it does raise some curiosity.  a nice ale, and it does live up to the ’aggressive’ description!
This shit fuckin rules...and, if drinking it everynight wouldnt turn me into a fat fuck, I would guzzle this shit until my entire life fell apart...son of a whore...maybe I will.

Smells thickly of malts. Pours a dark brown with an almost yellow creamy head. Taste is pungent hops with a nick malt back to it with a decent amount of alcohol presence without being overwhelming. Delicious.

I treat myself to this beer every so often, and realize everytime I drink it, why I dont drink it all the time...I dont want to become a friend of Bill W.

This beer is one of the better ones by Stone, strong strong and strong.  Shoot buy it just to read the bottle.

Beautiful beer... a nice amber-almost ruby color (looks red with a light behind it) with a still, 1/2 inch white head.  Floral aroma, can smell the hops as well as the alcohol.  Flavor of nice hop bitterness... not as aggressive as I was expecting, having read the label.  I dont lot of American Strong Ales because of the overpowering hops, but Arrogant Bastard does it well.  A bit of a citrus (graperfruit, especially) taste as well.  Grapefruit aftertaste.

1 pt. 6 oz. bottle.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2007 The first "aggressive beer" I ever tried, opened up my eyes to what beer could taste like, the first time I tried it it pretty much chewed me up and spit me out. But now Ive grown to love it. AWESOME.

Bomber. Dark ruby red with a decent, somewhat foamy head. Smells of raisins and rich malts. Interesting taste of brown sugar and burnt caramel. Fairly sticky finish and goes down really easy. Somewhat fizzy on the mouthfeel. Real good ale.

(22 oz. bottle from  <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/massachusetts/w target=blank>Julios Liquors, cellared for 9 mos. after purchase) A hoppy one for sure...Pours cloudy medium-dark amber with a firm one finger of lightly amberish biege head. Very good-looking beer when poured. Nose is caramel and vanilla, as well as pine and grapefruit rind. Mouthfeel smooth and soft, a little bit of heft. Heavy, foamy rings of lacing. Flavor is pretty much about the hops, quite bitter up front and on through finish. A good solid dose of pine and grapefruit over a lighter dose of vanilla and caramel maltiness. A little too heavy on the hops for me but nose, palate and appearance all very nice.

Pours deep amber with a nice off white head which leaves light lacing on the glass. Aroma is BIG with notes of citrus, slightly sweet, big grapefruit. Flavor is equally big hoppy with the same grapefruit flavor. Piney, citrus bitterness gives way to a dry bitter finish. Very aggressive, very nice. The grapefruit is the star of this show.

Pours dark murky brown, maybe somewhat red.  Aroma is of hops, resins, toffees and malts.  Flavor is of full bodied smoothness, sweet caramels, toffee, hops, malts, pleasantly smooth beer.  Kick ass from Stone!
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text:
Has a rusty color with a thin tan head. Nice toffee sweet and grapefruit hop smell. Medium bodied and lightly carbonated. 
Nice caramel malt flavor with a strong grapefruit hop bitterness to finish. 
This beer will keep your house mates from ever raiding your cellar stash again ! april 2003
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: UPDATED: DEC 14, 2007 Smells of big west coast citrus hops.  Thick mahogany color and cloudy.  Tastes bitter although not as strongly as I expected.  Heavily bodied and a little grassy for my tastes.  Full-flavored, full-bodied and lives up to the hype.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2007 An excellent strong ale.  Hoppy and bitter, yet smooth.  Gets better as the beer warms.  Tastes like a dark IPA.  Drink in a goblet at about 58°.  It tastes like it just came out of the tap.
This is one of my all time favorite brews, great hop flavor, very smooth finish, the aftertaste does linger for a little while.
Love this stuff,One of my all-time favorites.Very smooth,bitter malt,A+ .Great beer for the winter.
One of my favorites.  Love the texture of the dark malts.  Very smooth for a 7%+ alcohol beer, thanks to the restrained hopping not usually found in a Stone.  This is really great stuff.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2009 Yeah! An excellent, hoppy, floral, earthy, fruity, spicy beer with loads of character and body. Big, soft mouthfeel and very smooth and drinkable. The color of this brew is outstanding. Balanced and good.

I just love this freakin Bastard. Hell of a beer. Pours dark with a big head, what else would you expect. Strong aroma of dark malts and alcohol with some hopssss. Taste is wonderfully strong and hangs around but not in a bad way. Drinkable.

Very individual style beer. Your not going to find anything that taste like AB. Its got a sweet nose with a malty taste. The aftertaste hangs around for a long time. Maybe a little too bitter, but hey, thats stone.
On tap at Frisco Grille.  Amber dark brown with foamy head.  Malty hoppy aroma.  A little bit of malt with a strong hoppy taste.

Pour is reddish brown with a light head.  Smell is malty sweetness, with some hops showing through.  Taste is sweet but not overly at all, followed by a mild drying hop finish.  Thich, and rich for the style, while flavors are somewhat mild actually.  Nice bitterness at first, but it turned medicinal and aspirin tablet-like a bit.  Not bad, but wasnt too crazy about it either.

22oz.  Dark, hazy amber with an aggressive, off-white head.  Great aromas wafting from the glass, very similar to taste.  Bitter, forward hops with the malt and other complexities to back it up.  Slight notion of bitter fruit, and not as much pine or wintergreen as I expected.  This strikes me as a sweaty weekend hike in the woods, the pain and bitterness but the satisfaction that follows.  The finish is the best part, this one lingers for minutes.  Very tasty overall.

On tap-Dark Amber color w/a moderate tan head. Hoppy up front flavor w/a fair amount of bitterness. Had some carbonation to it as well. This is a big beer, not a smooth, easy drinker. Gotta take it easy w/this one. Had a long smoked finish to it.. Good after dinner/nightcap beer, very liquorlike, but I wasnt as crazy @ it as some folks seem to be. A little too "out there" for me.
This was one of the first big beers i ever tried, but im rating it now cuz i just had it agian a few nights ago.  Nice fruity/hoppy mixture, very complex and one of my favorites

Rather robust red with long lasting medium high head which surprised me right out of the bottle pouring into a wide glass. Aroma like an angel food hop cake mixed within a forest bakery, super intriguing. Malty start with a thick fat mouthfeel. Hops come on pretty strong but not in an offensive manner. Finish is a slight bit hoppy and even oily as well for my taste. Definitely not a detraction from the overall experience though. Pretty rad beer.
I loved this the first time I tried it and its still one of the best beers Ive ever had.  I live close enough to the brewery to get it fresh in a growler once in a while.  A classic!
Nice hop aroma with some cookie malt.  Carbonic medium mouthfeel.  Notes of burnt caramel followed by crisp to almost harsh bitterness that lingers.
22oz Bottle: Really good American strong.  Pours dark amber with a really good head.  Hoppy aroma and flavor.  Good.
This is part of a beer club. Had only one bottle but was decent for the price. Poured great and had a nice finish. Would do again.
Very stong taste.  I liked the colour a lot.  had servered on tap.  Smooth finish,

Glowing red colour, nice head, hoppy hop hop aroma with a citrus-hop flavour, it has a lemon like finish, I was tired the first time I tried it so didnt think much, but the second time I really enjoyed.
22 oz bottle..pours a deep brown with visible carbonation and a thick tan head...hoppy, citrus aroma like an malted IPA....lightly sweet mat taste with a great bitter/alcohol finish

draght at the horse you came in on, the oldest pub in america. pours a deep crimson hue with light tan two finger head. aroma of pine hops, some citrus also a very pleasant malt background. flavour is pine and earth bitter hop in th finish and a nice driess. it starts caramel and sweet in the front that flows into the hop bitter with nice malt character. pretty well balanced.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2008 Remarkably harsh and oily "old" strong ale. Too much malt for me and  bit too sweet. Some complexity but it all seems to clash so they decided to hype and spin with a brash name like brash brew is a blessing.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2009 Rerate: 22 ounce bottle from Wine Warehouse in Charlottesville, VA. Pours a slightly hazy dark red color with a medium head. Decent head retention and lacing. Big fresh citrus hop aroma with faint toffeeish notes. Taste is bitter citrus, resin and leafy hop notes. Toffee and nutty notes are also in the taste. FUll bodied. 7/4/8/4/16/3.9Bottle. Very faint, malty aroma. Took a sip or two to get used to. Very strong, very hoppy, with a nice smooth, creamy finish. Nice. 6/4/8/4/17/3.9

Excellent beer.  Strong aroma of beer (not too hoppy or malty), poured smoothly with creamy head, deep amber color.  Initial taste is quite bitter but nutty and slightly citrus flavors develop quickly.  Clever bottle too.  Wish  it was more available on tap around here since I drink a fair bit of it.
I was impressed, good aroma and hoppy. For a dark beer, one of my favorites.

Bottled. An inviting deep red beer with a creamy beige head. The aroma is hoppy with citrusy notes and some caramel. Aggressive taste of hops. some caramel and roasted malt. Also nutty. Nice body, inceredible bitter and dry finish. The aftertaste is hoppy and very long. A very nice hop monster, probably the symbolic beer of American beer scene. I want more, why stuff like this arent available in Italy?
Delicious, especially when from the tap. Stones best, in my opinion. Very hoppy, but not as overwhelming as Ruination.
Dark brown, smooth head - retains head well. Nose has some esters (almost a little taint of Belgian yeast?) and solid hop additions. Nose also has alcohol, but filled out with malty sweetness.

Dark brown color, with hints of ruby red too. Nice thick head that doesnt fall quickly when poured. Clean aroma. Not hoppy, not malty. Just there. Hops come through in aftertaste of beer. Alcohol in initial flavors, with warming in the throat after drinking it. Ive had this before (didnt rate it though) and it seems to me I remember it being more balanced, with a malty finish. Perhops that was just my imagination? Yes, there are a whole bunch of hops there, but the flavor isnt anything Id necessarily go out of my way to get on a regular basis.
bottle. was a very strong,bold taste. color was suprising to the taste.this is one I will drink again and again
I will never drink another beer on the regular unless it is Arrogant Bastard Ale! And im just happy that i live about 5 miles from the brewery...
Excellent strong ale, exceeded my expectations. Despite others comments and description on bottle, very drinkable. I will definitely get this again.

A Mes rate: 
Bottle at LCRBM3. Ive said it before and Ill say it again. For me, throwing loads of everything at you all at once does not a good beer make. All alcohol and aggresive hops. Overly assertive and no finesse. Just doesnt work for me.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2008 The bottles right, you probably wont like it...at first. But trust me, it grows on you. The more you drink AB, the better you get to know it and  the more you notice different flavours. Stones over-hype aside, this is undoubtedly a top beer. Just dont drink it so fast to truly enjoy the flavours.

Bomber. Pours very dark cloudy amber. Not much head, but what does appear doesnt dissipate but stays as a solid coating along the beer creeping up the sides of the glass. The smell is strongly of hops, mostly pine-oil and fresh cut grass. The taste is very malty, not nearly as much hops as I expected from the smell. The upfront taste is all caramel malt with a lot of sweetness, and then the hops hit you at the end and a couple seconds after swallowing the bitterness from the hops and the alcohol warmth lingers in the back of your throat. The mouth feel on this beer is medium thick. Medium low carbonation allows the beer to coat your entire mouth. This is really a delightful ale. I will definitely add this to my "celebration beers".

Bomber - Poured a quite dark reddish brown  on color with a hefty off-white head.  Some nice lacing.  Aroma was fruity... cherries, dark fruit... with a hint of the hops to come.  Flavor was massively complex, as other raters have pointed out.  The flavor profile definitely changed as the brew went down and as the beer warmed. Many flavor impressions... dark fruit, brown sugar/caramel, fruity hops, sour citrus... all with the undercurrent of alcohol warmth.  I really liked this beer and I am positive that it will taste different to me the next time I experience this challenge.
Bottled. Rather complex and enjoyable overall.  Maybe some dusty, coffee tones.  I agree with other raters that this beer grows on you because at first I was not sure what to expect.

Oct. 2005 - I can see the thrill here. Theres a lot of hops, a lot of malt, a lot of alcohol taste. I dont know...with all that taste, I just didnt like the WAY it tasted. Too sweet (alcohol sweet) and whatever that hop taste was, I didnt like it. It reminded me of a toned down in terms of sweetness DFH 120m IPA, but with more bitterness. I guess Im not worthy.
A bit of a punch in the mouth on the first sip if youre not expecting it, but boy does it grow on you.

3rd LCRBM. Aroma has the pine and grapefruit hops. Bit earthy as well. Clear, amber coloured with an off-white head. Taste bitter with loads of hoptaste. It has pine, grapefruits, flowers. But lets stop naming all these things or I just might dethrone him from his humble position. It is just a really nice, balanced beer.
3rd LCRBM. Earthy, oily, citric hops in the aroma. Oily, very hoppy flavor. Red berries and lemon. Long raw hopbitter aftertaste. Doesnt leave room for much other flavor, still a likeable beer.
They may be right I may lack taste and sophistication because I did not like this beer as well as most.  I am sorry I am not worthy

Deep chestnut colour, small yellowish head. USA C-hops, dry cookies, bitter almonds aromas. Hops cake instead of space cake. Sweet cake bottom, and again, over and over, just dried hops. Bit of wood, drenched in hops oil and a bit of molasses, spatted with orange marmalade. Medium bodied, lip-sticking ending. A classic, but since I tasted this as one of my first Westcoast bigunes, better have come up.
Bottle.  Earthy hops aroma with a hint of malt.  Nice tan head with very nice lacing.  Initial malt taste followed by strong hops.  Hangs together really nice.
I read the label and felt "Ah A challenge!" Decent strength to it flavour-wise. Decent level of hops. Just a nice, proper beer overall.

Pours a cherry brown with a lingering massive head that leaves a fair amount of lace on the way down. Nose at first seemed like blueberries, but calmed down after a minute. Taste is massively complex and thorough. Sweet edge follows a burst of hop flavor with a deep almost oaky presence, which turns into what I want to say is a slight alcohol presence on the end. Not for the faint of heart, or palate. This beer is complex and lacks mercy for those who are immature in beer.
UPDATED: NOV 1, 2009 Deliciously bitter ale. From the title to the little devil on the front this thing lives up to its name. Not for the inexperienced beer drinker!

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2007 I have had this on tap at Hydro Bar & Grill in Calistoga, CA, & in bottle.  It is wonderful, rich, flavourful stuff.  It has a great texture and head with a strong, rich flavour with a hint of sweetness offsetting the strong hoppy and bitter elements.  The result is a pretty good balance despite the fairly strong hops.  Its almost harsh, but maintains the balance, resulting in a tasty, memorable beer.

Wow this beer grabs you by the collar and holds on the whole way down!  Bitter, yet hints of sweetness just adds to the plethora of flavor.  Got this fro ma friend who owned a beer barn and definately wanting more.

(Draught at Oliver Twist, Stockholm) Dark ruby colour with frothy off-white head. Fruity, hoppy nose with dark fruit, grapefruit, pine needles, hints of rubber, balanced notes of dark hops. Fruity taste with notes of dark fruit, cherries, grapefruit, pine needles and resin. Dark, heavy bitterness in the finish. Great stuff.

This is starting to show up at the Giant Eagles around Columbus, OH, so its getting very easy to find.  That doesnt take away the fact that this is a terrific beer.  Great balance, but still aggressive, the result is something between styles.  Enough hops to get a good bitter finish, but still sweet.  Im more of a hoppy, non-sweet kind of hophead, but this is one is balanced ok, and doesnt overwhelm my sensitive sweet tooth.  I usually drink this as an after dinner drink, or after mowing the lawn.  Pours a deep amber with an off white fluffy head.  I can smell the sweet end of the malt, but its followed by fresh hops. Yum.  Drank this one at about 45 degrees f, and it was just about perfect.  Grapefruity finish, good hop bite that something with the title "arrogant bastard" should have.  Considering the ease of finding, and relative low cost, this is a no-brainer.

the ale stands up to its name, Ive had this many times but Ive been waiting to have it on tap before i rated it.. didnt happen i grew impatient. to the beer! hoppy sweet aroma, tanish white head dark ruby red body, i dont like sweet beers usually but this one is special, has a kick to it, hoppy malty bitter sweat taste, hints of citrus and chocolate. great beer. most beers taste good with some food but this one stands alone like the arrogant bastard it is.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2010 Bottle at home ... many many thanks to RIS101 for the trade. Red brown,high hop little sweet   ,sweet juicy malts again american high hop not all bad actually very juicy. much beter balance than others Ive had; grapfruit drying linger 3.7... bottle at musa ... dark copper ... thin white lacing ... soft rich fruity malys ... big hop front ... juicy hops ... light malt ... again overfizzy 3.8 ...

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2008 Date: 08/30/1998
Mode: Bottle
Source: Beverages & More, SF

Appearance: dark amber, frothy light tan head, sudsy lace, 
Aroma: earthy hop aroma, 
Body: big body, 
Flavor: rich malt flavor, lots of hop flavor, long bitter finish 
-------- />
Date: 03/23/2002
Mode: draft
Words: bardo

Aroma: fresh hop aroma, 
Flavor: big bold and arrogant flavor, a bit better than the bottle due to freshness
-------- />
Date: 03/23/2003
Mode: draft
Words: bardo

nice fruity malt flavor that is overwhelming leaving the hops and bitterness to take a back seat, now i see where the double bastard comes from, a bit of alcohol shows up after warming, best ab yet!
-------- />
Date: 10/10/2008
Mode: draft
Source: summits woodstock

Aroma: dry and earthy caramel malt aroma, 
Flavor: rich dark caramel flavor, lots of balancing earthyness, 

Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 3.5/5.0Score: **4
-------- />
Date: 05/19/2007
Mode: 3 liter bottle
Vintage: 2003

Aroma: strong oxidized malt aroma, 
Flavor: rich malt flavor, plenty of hop flavor and bitterness, the reduction in hops from age allows some rich chocolate emerge, 
Overall: becomes a balanced hoppy old ale, 
-------- />
The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Bottle. Lots of bright fruity hops. Bing cherries. Freshly cut wet grass. Some lavender. Very enticing aroma. Pours a rich deed cherrywood/mahogany with a nice creamy off white head. Excellent lacing. Lots of hops and malt on the palate. Raisins, cabernet grapes, pine, sourdough bread... A big beer for sure. Full bodied. Rich and mouth coating.

This ale pours out deep brown with hints of orange depending on how you hold it up to the light and has a very nice appearance to it and almost no head. The aroma is hard to detect but sweet and slightly malty. When it hits your mouth it starts out with a strong malty flavor that finishes with a bite filled with hops and a carbonated finished that leaves your mouth dry like a dry wine. This is a decent Ale with a complex mix of flavors. Ive been waiting over 3 years to try it. Thanks Mike D.

Very unapologizing. Strong and proud of it. Very complex tastes enhance the drinking experience. Not strong just for the sake of being strong, but rather because it allows for the brewer to take the drinker to a new level.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2008 Poured from a bomber.  Poured a deep amber/copper color with an inch thick off-white head.  Aroma of hops, some fruit, and spice.  Initial hit of malt with some fruit undertones lead to a stiff helping of piney hops that give it a crisp. dry finish.  I cant wait to get my hands on the oaked version.

you had better love IPAs if you buy this stuff! This may be the most grapefruity crap Ive ever tasted!!! Id have liked to be a fly on the wall when they made this junk...
"Lets just dump 10X more hops into this batch and see what happens"
UPDATED: DEC 9, 2007 strong ale indeed nice head and body  with a sweet taste at first  than strong alcohol taste love it!

Pours a lovely amber with a pungent butterscotch & sweet malt aroma. Strong malt backbone in this beer - again, butterscotch and nice nutty highlights perfectly balanced with aggressively present hops. Light taste of orange, too. My tasting notes taper of at this point, but I do not recall being disappointed by the body, but not blown away. I shall have to revisit this beer at some point, but for now I can definitely say its a winner of a beer. Many thanks to G for the taste!

Tap at RFD Washington.  Fairly clear pour of a dark amber hue.  Head is resilient.  Apples and oranges with a kind of dry cinnamon and sugar dust on the nose.  A touch of alcohol.  An intial taste of fat strawberries and cream is quite charming.  Massive resinous hops power through with a syrupy punch.  Toasted malts and sweet orange juice round a classic interplay of strong ale benchmarks - most intelligently executed.  Smooth, textured, green palate with a predictable hit of oaky heat.  This one certainly has enough foundation that it could sit for a while.  More likeable than most.

Poured from 22oz bomber - dark, clear brown/copper with highlights of dark amber and a huge tan head that leaves loads of lace on the glass and fades into a thin, persistent, unevenly bubbled pad floating on the beer. The aroma is hoppy, but is also very nutty and full of caramel. The hop smell has hints of pine needles tossed with lemon grass. The taste starts bitter and sweet - a nicely balanced, albeit firm, hop bitterness combines with a complex malt profile - some chocolate, caramel, biscuits fresh from the oven, vinous malts, and roasted grains. The middle of the flavor picks up strong flavors of roasted grains, nuts, and chocolate along with a mellow citrus bite.  The hop flavor grows after a few mouthfuls - a mix of earthy, spicy, and citrusy bitter flavors mix with the hearty malt backbone. The back of the tongue picks up more chocolate and nutty, brown malt with more citrus bitterness. A fruity character also grows as the beer nears the back. The finish is long and surprisingly dry, its very hoppy, and it leaves an after-taste that resembles the flavor: lots of hops and lots of dark malts. The mouthfeel is sudsy and creamy (though not quite "luxurious") and medium- to-full in body. Overall, an interesting and tasty beer.

On tap @ The Hopyard Pleasanton. Ruddy/ brown color, hoppy cutris nose. It lives up to its name. I can see how many wouldnt like it because of the citrus, pine, hop combo. One of the more complex Ales out there. Try it a year later if you didnt like it the first time. You may aquire a taste! Will have again.
Bottle. Aromas of pine, grapefruit, hops. Flavor was more of the same, but more pronounced. Piney, citrus, carmel, all there front and center.

Bottle, 1 pint 6 ounces, Oktoberfest evening at Marc Grattons, savoured on April 20 2007; eye: burgundy, slight effervescence, nice head; nose: caramelized malt, hops, grapefruit; mouth: dry hops, caramel, astringency, dry finale in hops with a nice astringency, full body, slightly harsh texture, quite carbonated and bitter; overall: served too warm, to try again

FRANÇAIS 

Bouteille, 1 pinte 6 onces, soirée Oktoberfest chez Marc Gratton, savourée le 20 avril 2007; oeil : bourgogne, très légère effervescence, belle mousse; nez : malt caramélisé, houblon, pamplemousse; bouche : houblon sec, caramel, astringence, finale sèche de houblon avec une bonne astringence, corsée, texture légèrement râpeuse, assez carbonatée et amère; en résumé : servie trop chaude, à réessayer

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2007 A very flavorful brew that is very potent. 

A strong hoppy aroma with a nice brownish, redish color. 

Cant drink too many of these but a great beer to be enjoyed slowly. 

Im not a huge fan of the MASSIVE amount of hops they have put into this.
Nicely well rounded ale here. Sweetness, freshness, sourness and palate. Solid, though not outstanding in any one aspect.

What can I say. I buy every bottle that my local store gets in. Ridiculously complex taste and outstanding coloring. The best compliment I can give it is my friend who only drinks light, flavorless American beers absolutely HATES this beer, just like the label hilariously predicts. This beer makes me glad my taste buds are more evolved than hers

Finaly something on wich i can agree with you louts. This is a GREAT ale. Just about the best thing you can get around here.

You are not worthy.
Amazing beer. Caramel smell/taste with a bitter after taste. Burgundy color that is as pleasant to look as it is to smell as well as taste. A

Bomber into pint glass.  Deep brownish red color with a nice tan head that leaves lacing all the way down the glass.  Aroma is intense grapefruit from the Chinook hops.  Taste is carmel malt at first, and then Im quickly hit with the aggressive hop flavors - grapefruit and pineapple.  Mouthfeel and carbonation are perfect.  This is one of my favorite beers.  I have a bottle just about every week.
Deep aroma, can smell the bitterness, slightly caramel.  Dark bown, head disipates quickly.  Good taste, bitterness in the finish.  Caramel as well.  Citrus.  Good mouthfeel, very full.  Nice.
Bottle into Pint glass. A heavy malty ale with a thick syrup feel. Intenste aroma of malts and hops. Pours a dark and cloudy black. Intense!
Dark dark brown.  Very hoppy.  Very strong and very intense.  If you have not had this style before be prepared.  This beer is Very intense.
Pours a deep mahogany, very thick, dense tan foam.  Aroma is a bit hoppy, maybe a hint of pine.  Taste is quite strong and hoppy, like a barleywine.  Good stuff.
Probably my favorite beer. Dark red/brown color, with a deep, complex flavor that fills up your palate.

Wonderfully complex aroma of thistle, pineapple, and maple syrup. Opaque ochre colored with a thick orange head, nice glass coating. Moderately strong flavor with hops dominating. Light smoke, citrus, and syrup notes are also present on the edges. Finish is hoppy and doughy, and a little bitter, but tastefully so. Great flavor and complexity. Not too heavy.
Fruity hop aroma; dark red beer; very distinct hop bitterness with a caramel malt underneath; finish is bitter with a slight touch of sweet malt.  Ill definitely have this again.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2007 Can we say bitter?  Yes we can!  This beer is unique in the way that the bitterness is sooooo tasty with that tiny hint of sweet and sour.  You can almost smell and taste it before you even open the bottle.  This is the first beer I tried from this brewer but it will not be the last.

What a wonderful beer.  Tons of everything!  It is BIG in every way.  Dark color, strong aroma and a flavor that punches you in the mouth and kicks you while you are down.  Give this the to guy who drinks Bud Light like it is part of his daily diet and watch him melt in his shoes.
UPDATED: AUG 24, 2007 Bottle... Ive tried many beers so far - many of which I had a good time drinking. However, when it comes to what I want in my beer, this is PERFECT. My favorite beer.
22 oz. I shared this with a buddy and ended up being dissapointed that I had to share. Great aroma and the finish is awesome. I had a hard time placing it in a certain style, though.
The standard stone brew. Taste much better fresh from a growler that came straight from the brewery. I LOVE THE STONE BREWERY.

Well, I am worthy of this beer.  If that means Im arrogant, so be it.  Im not afraid of the color, or the head, or the strong bitterness with a bit of a sour citrus note.  Im not intimidated by the lack of alcohol taste, and it is beneath me to comment on the clear finish.  This is a very good beer, and well worth the investment.
UPDATED: JUN 16, 2008 another great beer from stone, imagine that.  the alcohol is not strong at all and is just right.  im very glad that i tried this beer.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2008 22oz bottle into a pint glass.  Pours a dark reddish brown with a nice 1 finger light tan head that dissipates to a light covering, but retains to the bottom of the glass.  Excellent lacing.  Aroma is okay...something about it is a little off for me though.  Flavor is nice with grapefruit, piney hops.  Somewhat sweet, moreso as it warms.  Little bit of alcohol kick, but not too bad.  Smooth, full mouthfeel without too much carbonation.  A strong beer, it certainly gets your attention...
22oz bottle. strong taste of alcohol, sweat malt, and hops. large healthy head. thick menacing palate

Quite another surprise that I havent rated this beer for some damn reason. I figured why not get a bottle and get it done tonight? Aroma is huge grapefruit, slightly roasty, nutty and a bit fruity. Appearance is dark copper in color, with a small creamy one-finger thick head. Flavor is big, big hops with enough grapefruity hops to please even the most hardcore hophead and a good dose of raisny/caramel sweetnees to keep it all nicely balanced. While I personally enjoy Ruiniation as my Stone beer of choice, this is a damned tasty beer just the same. Recommended!
Beautiful looking beer, pours reddish brown.  Kind of smells like celery, and has a slight celery taste.  I agree that the hops and malts are even.  Leaves a nice hoppy taste in your mouth.
if bitter and slightly sour are your thing, this is the beer for you. the casual drinker will feel as if they were punched in the mouth

Appearance- deep red colour with a creamy white head. Smell is more sweet than hoppy which surprised me. Taste is a very balanced to me- the malts and hops are in synchronicity. I was expecting more of a hop blast- it may be that I have held on to this bottle too long and the hops has subsidided. No matter- still a classic west coast beverage. Or it the lack of hops could be due to my mouth being hammered into a submission by a Surly Furious a couple of hours earlier. Mouthfeel is rich with a medium to low carbonation. The head dissapated quite quickly in my pint glass. Overall- it would be a staple for me if I could just access it on a regular basis.

"OK. Not bad. Aroma was good, appearance was deep amber. Flavor was perplexing- to me the alcohol was a little too high over the other flavors. If this was subdued a little, the flavor would be better. 
after going for a few more, enjoyed this alot more-  definitely hoppy but malt sweetness doues come through in the backround

22 oz. bottle.  Pours amber with a white head.  Hoppy aroma with hints of caramel.  Flavors were a little disappointing for me, some hops toffee.  I was disappointed in this I may need to pick up some more and re-rate

Rated 7/28/07.  Bomber in Las Vegas, NV.  Clear, dark reddish-amber color.  Rocky off-white head that settles to a patchy film with a bubbly honeycomb appearance.  Nice lacing all the way down the glass.  The aroma is a very nice blend of caramel, herbal hops, toffee and biscuit.  As appealing as the aroma is, its the flavor that really steals the show here.  Simple yet intriguing, the taste tiptoes down the tightrope between overt bitterness and supreme craftsmanship, settling on the latter.  This beer has a very whisky-like profile in its masterful blending of caramel, toffee, and biscuit, three of the classic whiskey tastes.  The hoppiness of this brew approaches perfection, as any more or less would certainly throw off its near perfect balance.  Medium body that goes down smooth and leaves behind a lingering bitterness.  This is a very good beer in all respects, one that must be analyzed thoroughly to fully appreciate all that it has to offer.

rating from notes: pours a dark amber in color with a thin layer of head and decent carbination. smell is hops and fruits, grapefruit, all about the hops nose. taste is good, citrus and hops, nice mouth feel. will have to revisit this one.

So I made an appearance at Taco Mac last night. I walked to the bar with my head held high and looked down my nose at the redneck with his Bud Light...I then turned my head towards the bartender and ordered The Arrogant Bastard....my sole purpose yesterday was to enjoy Beer and get drunk. Reviewing was the furthest thing from my mind as I had #99 (Oak Aged Yeti) and #100 (Rodenbach Grand Cru) stored at home waiting to be my passage into Legend. ALAS! THE SCRIPT HAS BEEN FLIPPED!...I am now COMPELLED to rate last nights fare. The Quality I serendipitously encountered MUST be noted for future generations. Arrogant Bastard. I am You, and You are Me. WE...are One.
Sampled from a 22oz bottle. Pours a deep golden red color with a thin and quickly dissipating head. The flavor is overwhelming. Very hoppy with a a floral and citrus backbone.

Chestnut dark with smaller head.  Booming floral hops are present on the nose as well as pineapple, grapefruit and pine.  The taste mirrors the aromas only the hop presence is balanced well by quietly roasted malts, caramel sugars and syrupy toffee.  I like this beers attitude!

Pours an almost blood red with a nice beigh head that froaths down to some beautiful sticky lacing. Amazing and complex aroma of berries, citrusy grapfriut, strong fresh hops, and forest. A tasty treat, hops everywhere, at the start, middle and finish, mingeling with a bunch of other flavours with notes of malty caramel sweetness. Top Notch, nothing to complain about with this beer.

Tried on tap at the brewery in one of those tiny taster glasses after going to the tour.  The tour is great!  Greatest name for a beer, it has made Stone tremendously successful.  Enough about Stone and on to the beer.  1/2 finger head that quickly dies.  Deep amber color.  Small bubble carbonation as I swirl.  Aroma is surpisingly mild (possibly because I just had the IPA?)  Well balanced, but not as good as the IPA?  Huh?  Great beer, but I was expecting a hoppy punch in the face.  Maybe someone will give the punch to me after this review.
UPDATED: SEP 25, 2007 Excellent brew.  Very hoppy with good bitter finish.  Amber color and long lasting amber head.  I could drink this again and again.
Big caramel malt flavor.  Huge citrusy hop flavor.  The aroma is amazing, orange and lemon aroma.  The hop flavor is of oranges and lemon too.
A classic exceelnt well balanced BIG beer....hops and malt compliment eachother. Great BREW
Strong Hop Aroma. Good strong ale with hoppy taste up front, yet balanced.
Not the strong hop presence I was hoping for but was defiantly surprised by the caramel aftertaste. A very well balanced beer.

Pours a reddish-golden color with a prominent white head.  Aroma is almost all hops, with a bit of fruit thrown in.  Taste is hops up front, with fruit and malt included as well.  Alcohol content reasonably hidden.  Very good.

THOUGHTS: Hides alcohol well. Its there, but in a very pleasant way. Very well balanced. An unusual brew that can only be called great.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a medium to clear, dark red-brown with a small to average off-white head that mostly diminished and left good lacing. The aroma was heavey caramel malt and light citrus hops. The initial flavor was moderately sweet and lightly bitter, while the finishwas light to moderate sweetness and heavy bitterness (citrus hops) with a long duration. The body was medium to full and slightly syrupy up front and dry in the back of the mouth with fizzy carbonation and a metallic finish.

Best Ale EVER!!! This is good.  I drank at the end of the night after sampling some other brews at the shopette.  I said, "Oh my gosh, this iz GooooooooD!!" Couldnt believe the amount of flavors dancing on my tongue.  All of them were benevolent.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

Bottle.  My expectations were very high for this beer, but unfortunately I felt a little let down.  Its not that it was bad, but it wasnt as phenomenal as I was led to believe.  Anyway, it poured a deep ruby red/brown with a nice thick tan head.  Aroma was strong malt, roasty, some hoppy/citrus notes.  It was quite bitter with definite citrus hoppiness, but there was a very firm, sweet maltiness.  Some alcohol and oiliness.  There was something up front, the very first taste that hit me, but I couldnt place it.  Id drink it again, but I wasnt blown away.

Bottle via friendly neighbors nephews cousin or something similar, just nice to get something different.  Deep copper, white head.  Strong.... hoppy, good bitter, but also sweet and floral - grapefruit.  Good mixture of malt and hops.  A beer to drink with food.  A subtle kick to it and I wish I had another to compare to this one. And then maybe one more after that to get a better idea of how to rate it...lol.

this is the first beer had by the stone brew co. and it was pretty damn good. not for everyone tho. strong taste very hopped and bitter. good  head and color. once you try it you cant help wanting it again and again.

Pours a wonderful deep copper.  Lots of lacing and a great 3 finger head.  The aroma of this bastard was mainly piney, grapefruity, and even a little sweetness.  It tastes very sweet upfront, a mixture of different malts with that uniique stone yeast strain.  It then turns into a complex mix of hops and malts, which isnt too bitter, just right. The backend is very nicely accompanied by various hops flavors and bitterness.  I wish this bitterness was a bit sharper, and longer lasting.  If it was then a definite 10/10.  Still, very nice beer

Two fingers of head on this sucker. Lots of fresh grapefruity hops, oily and full-bodied, a bit flat. Alcohol notes, caramel malt and a long bitter finish...tons of hops as the label notes. Duh! Awesome.
UPDATED: AUG 24, 2008 decent ale - didnt mind the bitterness - it was tasty but didnt blow my hair back.  maybe expectations were too high.

Didnt this used to be called a spice/herb beer?  Anyway, had on draft in Portland Stadium.  Nice marketing, reverse psychology description from Stone.  I bet it was a brewers inside joke originally.  Pours brown.  Complex herbal, earthy planty floral notes in the nose.  And same in the flavor, lots of dirt clods, weeds, dry-brush, tumbleweed stems and roots, god, so many weird mixtures in the taste.  Palate was over carbonated. Not my type of beverage, but I guess if you can take impossbly gross ingrediants and make the taste "passible" to a group of tasters, then tell them whats in it, and in astonishment they hail it as an amazing brew, I guess that means the rest of us dont have sophisticated taste acuity.  I would rather have a something enjoyable in more ways than nappy taste combinations.  Wouldnt recommend.  BUT!  Doubler bastard is quite another story...  quite awesome.

Dark amber pour, nice aroma.  Taste is sweet, mild fruit tones.  This is one of the best beers going, and is one of my "go to" beers.  Part of the beauty is that its flavor is strong, but not so strong that you cant kick back a few at a time.  Stone really is the best brewer going.
Bomber...dark in color with light-color head. This beer has a distinctive flavor of pineapple, with extreme hoppy bitterness following. This is special and unique in many ways.

The color was hazy, amber brown.  The head was medium beige, thin, creamy.  Teh aroma was fermented fruit, sweet, raisin, and fig.  The flavor was fermented fruit, bitter/wax with an initial sweetness, and fig.  The palate was smooth.  The finish was a bitter waxy.

Bottle. Malts smell roasty and of dark bread. Hops smell of pine and citrus, and the yeast of dough and broth. In the background theres dark dried fruit and brown sugar. Head is frothy, off white with excellent lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is a nice clear, red brown. Flavor is moderately sweet and acidic, and the long finish is acidic and lightly bitter. Palate is perfect, light to medium, dry, with lively carbonation, and finishes lightly astringent. Stone really needs to find its way down to Florida.

650 ml bottle. Poured a slightly cloudy dark brown with red tint. Head was off white and initially quite generous. Aroma was citrus--oranges mostly. Flavor was complex and spicy and was dominated by bitter hops. These hops are as subtle as a brick thru a plate glass window. Mouthfeel is full and satisfying. Finish is bitter and  bittersweet. If you love bitter hoppy beers your gonna love this one.

Bottle @ Oliver Twist, Stockholm. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head. Sweet malty piney hoppy aroma with hints of grapefruit. Mlaty hoppy bitter piney flavor. Sweet malty finish with piney hints anf a long bitter aftertaste.

Popped the top..."low and behold"..the roasted smell lingered from the bottle with seriousness. Poured it in to a cold glass and and its dark brownish-red color was  tantalizing and complex when tasted. This beer is brewed right !  Strong "Roasted Hops" flavor with enough power to back it up..As it states  on the bottle "YOURE NOT WORTHY"...words speak for its self..and so does this beer...
wow. this beer purs with a massive, sticky head that never went away. the beer itself is dark red in colour. very smooth palate, tastes of citrus and cedar and hops. really outstanding

Bottle.  Pours dark ruby, pinkish head.  Aroma is phenomenal - loads of citrusy piney hops.  The flavor is a teensy bit robust.  Kind of syrupy to me.  Not that the mouthfeel is overly thick, but I think the malt bill could use a bit of tweaking.

Arrogant Bastard is a crystal-clear mahogany ale that is quite sparkling and is adorned with a small, rocky, light muscovado-colored head that is mostly diminishing and leaves tenacious lacing all the way down the glass.  The aroma is mostly of grapefruit from the hops, followed by rich malt that is slightly sweet.  There are hints of nuts, resin, plum, honey and vanilla.  It is medium-to-full bodied with slightly soft carbonation.  It is ever so smooth.  It is well-bittered, lightly sweet and perhaps a bit umami.  It starts citrusy and turns wooden.  The aftertaste is on the long side and exhibits notes of oak, pine and juniper.  The balance is superb.  This really hit the spot.  Its a great representation of how an American strong ale can be.

Yeah....I love hoppy brews and this one is no slouch.  Bomber from the local swifty swerve.  A full bodied hoppier than thou critter.  7.2 is vapor and hops hide it well.  Great with smoked chicken!   Hops are all encompassing but yet not overpowering.  This brew screams America loud and clear.
xxx Gotta love Stone in everything they do.  A great brewery and very rarely disappoints.  Great brewery.

[308-20070510] Bottle. Citrus hoppy aroma has notes of vegetable. Hazy, brown red body with a quick foamy brown head. Boozy hoppy grass flavour with veggie notes and a nice aftertaste. Medium-full body. Nice, well-blended.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2007 Draft at Coopers. This is a real sum of its parts near-sessionable beer--its considerably better than looking at the individual elements on their own merits might suggest. It starts off promisingly enough, dense and mahogany brown with a thick moussy tan head. Looks kinda beasty. Nose is virtually nothing at all, though; a little sweet malt, maybe caramelish. How they hide the hops in the aromatics is beyond me even as I sit and type this. The bodys full and the carb is there; the flavors are reasonably strong so the attack en toto is assertive enough. The mid-palate doesnt seem to carry much oomph, really; theres raisin and caramel and maybe a little light toast. The finish, though, is an awesome blast of rich resiny hop that just ties it all together. Every drink is satisfying, if not huge or complex. A little too heavy for sessioning, though they hide the booze well--but other than that you can drink this just about anytime.

650 ml bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy rich mahognany with a dense tan head.  Sweet floral nose.  Complex, medium to heavy body.  Bold malt base is offset by a hardy hop profile.  Lingering semi-dry finish.

On tap and bottle. Great nose. Hoppy and sweet like honeysuckle, caramel and cannabis. Taste the malt at first then let the hops glide over the tongue. Feel the slight alcohol vapor and savor the well balanced hop, malt finish.  This is a wonderful brew and is enjoyable every time.
UPDATED: MAR 22, 2008 Great beer, Good hops taste very hoppy ,strong but not as strong as one would expect. Tastes better at room temp. Would and have bought again
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: 1 pint draught, House of Brews, NYC. Dark reddish brown. Medium-sized beige head. Bold pungent green grapefruity hop aroma. Sharp nutty bitterness without being too harsh. Actually it is quite mellow. Burnt malt flavours. Quite vegetal. Chocolatey. Head clings to the glass. Smooth flavours and aftertaste.
Had on draft. Had a herbal hop and malted yeast smell. Taste was very spicy with a grassy, hoppy finish.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2008 Bottle. Wonderful hop aroma. Light citrus, lots of pine. Dark amber with a thin head. Perfect hopbomb. Bitter as hell with a strong flavor profile and the palate to support it. Nice one. 

Draught. Very clear difference in the freshness of the hops on draught. Much more clear grapefruit presence, particularly n the nose. Bright and lively citrus flavor. The bitterness is less aggressive and much more balanced.

Oh what a brew !  Both draft and 22 oz bottle.  Bottle pours an almost opaque, leathery brown with an almost solid head - extreme lacing.  You got some citrus fragrance there, maybe grapefruit, definite grain + malts smell.  Tasted really hoppy with a great blend of a little bitterness and grain + malt:  a keeper.

I prefer Ruination, but this is still excellent.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2007 Brought back from CA by a friend. Malt and hop mix of an aroma. Dark orange color. Medium off white head. A mix off bitter hops and malt start it off. Finishes with a nice hop bitterness.

pours burnt amber with nice head. nice hoppy grassy aroma and malts. big and hoppy up front with a sweet bready malt finish and a good dose of bitterness. good beer. interesting taste but balances well.

22oz bottle, no freshness date noted.  Pours a clear medium brown with little carbonation but lots of head.  Strong malty aroma with a good dose of hops on the nose as well.  The flavour is less interesting than I was hoping for.  Heavy on the malts and not as much hops as I thought there might be, although the hop taste does seem to grow as the beer goes on.  Im afraid I cant rate the Arrogant Bastard nearly as high as most people here - perhaps just not my type.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2007 Pine nose with hints of earth. Very fresh aroma. Brandy color, decent lacing, thin head. Excellent palate that is only slightly syrupy. Taste was thick grain/wheatgerm, bread, some hops, a little alcohol. Very unique flavor.

poors a burnt amber, a hazy look with a small white head.
smeels a little sour and grassy, and hoppy.
taste is medium bitterness, has a medium body, soft carbonation.
this is a very nice beer, bitter aftertaste that stays about nicely.  good beer
Pours the color of a trappist ale but tastes more like an IPA. Great hop character with an extremly bitter finish. I wish it was a bit sweeter. Great beer nonetheless.

22 oz bottle. Loved the bottle. To bad we cant give points for style Poured a dark, rich deep amber color. This beer is thick. I was drinking this on a sunny day. Holding my glass towards the sun and you cant see thru the beer. American strong ale indeed. Taste was over the top. The hops really hit you over the head at first, followed by roasted malt. Some fruit like flavors in here. Beer mellows out as it warms, but finishes with a hoppy bitterness. I will get this ale again for I am worthy.

Poured from a 22oz bottle into a pint glass.  This ale poured a darker brown with a thick, creamy light brown head that slowly faded.  Heavy, heavy  lacing.  The beer smells like grapefruit and some roasted malts.  The beer has a very aggressive bitterness that hits your tounge before you can discern any of the flavors.  I tasted grapefruit, toast, pine, and some dark fruit notes.  The mouthfeel is slighty resiny, medium-bodied, with a good amount of carbonation.  Another high quality brew from Stone.

Whoa! this one is bitter, though you wouldnt guess it from the dark appearance and deep tope colored head.  It has  that distinct hoppiness present in Stones Ruination IPA.  The alcohol content is well hidden making this a powerful brew.  I liked it and the taste was distinctive but I couldnt drink more than one.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2008 This is a hoppy surprise. Reminds me of a SN Bigfoot Ale. Great color and lacing. Pours  much darker than I expected with a nice light brown head. Great carbonation. Not picking up anything unique in the aroma, perhaps its still too cold. Similar hop bitterness to Bigfoot. Good beer.

Bottle at Oliver Twist (Sthlm). American Strong Ales are quickly becoming my favorite style.. this beer only reaffirms my affection for the style. Soo much of everything. Too bad its 18 Euro a bottle here in Sweden (only available at a few select pubs).

Dark color with a medium sized light brown head.  A bit sweet with heavy hops flavor.  I am not usually one for very hoppy beers so I cant relate to others of similar style, but it seems to be a very good beer.

nice dark appearance that has some thickness to it.  nose is a nice mix of sweetness and bitter hop character.  the flavor is superb with just a touch of maltiness then a huge kick of bitter hoppy complexities.  very nice.  only complaint is that as i let it warm to room temperature it didnt improve in flavor as i expected and actually became less enjoyable.
Sampled at Mondial de la Biere. Great hoppy, bready aroma. Nice malt flavor followed by a great hop finish. Definitely want to sit down again with this one.

bottle as a gift!
 Clear ruby color with bubbly tan head that laced the glass.
 Pleasant malty caramel nose with a touch of citrusy hops and alcohol. The caramel malt comes out again in the flavor along with some cherry and grape candy. Hop bitterness lasts from start to finish.
does exactly what it says on the tin!
bottle.  Aroma of roasty, grass, hay,  color is amber &  hazy, thick tan foam, rocky head, very bitter, full body, slick feel, average carbonation, bitter ending.  Bittering hops dominate.

Bottle pours reddish brown  and a nice foamy head.  galss laces nicely as I imbibe.  Flavor is very complex,  bitter with rich malt  taste and extremely agressive.  A tour de force of flavor!  This one is a classic.  I think my balls are hairier!

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2008 Pours a deep brown in the glass with a greenish/tan head.  Smells sweet with a huge piney hop aroma swirling in the glass.  The taste is as described quite "aggressive."  While the hops dominate the finish, there is a great toasted malt flavor that provides some nice balance

ruby burnt orange color with nice med creamy head. has nice floral nutty and grapefruits. thick and viscous, med carbonation. bold malty grapefruit and flowers. strong bitterness but not overpowering beautifully balanced deserves all the acclaim it gets
my favorite beer.  always out o 22oz bombers, have tried most of stones offerings.  ruby red, bitter grapefruit with malty mouthfeel.  the best beer (so far)

Molto grazie to dirty_martini. Pours a dark murky brown with reddish hues. The head is medium to thick depending on the pour, creamy, and light tan. The aroma  is sweet, definitely hopped, citrusy, some caramel. The flavor is sweet, lightly dry hopped, a tad bitter, caramel, and alcohol. Feels dry and a bit bitter in my mouth and it goes down warm. Not quite as good as I thought it was going to be, but more than solid above all.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2009 12 oz bottle. Pours dark reddish-brown. Complex aroma of citrus & hops. Nice and hoppy- a great way to enter the microbrew world.  Upon holding in mouth, there is a caramel flavor, changing over to some pine (?). Nice complex beer, and only gets tastier upon warming.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2016 Bottle as shown. Pours a dark red color with a small white head. this one had an interesting aroma with strong hops and toasty malts. Laces nicely and the taste was an arora of flavors a very overwhelming taste, like the label says youre not worthy.

I wish that every registered member of this website didnt fancy themselves as a english major or the possesor of a billion dollar set of nostrils. This beer is great.  gorgeous colour.A powerful taste. Perfect for anyone who likes a strong ale that will hang around for a while. But for real, you people need to stop acting like you can smell strawberries in chocolate milk.

22oz. Bomber

Arrogant Bastard poured a deep, dark ruby with a 2 finger creamy light tan head. The moderate lacing is good and sticky. This beer glows when held to the light. The glow of this beer adds a lot to the appearance along with the lasting head.

Smells juicy. There is a great big grapefruit bitterness smell. Its strange but I also pick up celery stalk. I never noticed that in other bottles Ive had.
