If you like bitter beers, here's a good one for you, but don't be intimidated - it's not *too* harsh.  Full-bodied, and a bit oily, goes down easy and has a nice long finish.
A little too strong and for some reason I just didn't enjoy this beer as much as other users.  Still its a decent brew that you will definitely feel later in the night.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2007 I go back and forth wether I like this or Ruination more.  

RARELY does a beer come along that is new and original.  Something that hasnt been done yet.  This is an aggresive beer, not for pansies.  Hoppy and bitter, alcoholic and deep. Color is somewhat amber and non flattering,  hiding the truth of the beer.  Head holds its own.  Buy this beer.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2004 I've had this a lot.  One time it resulted in me locking myself in the laundry room.  Right now it tastes excellent.  Sometimes the first one is a bit of a shock.  But the next always tastes like nectar.  Reddish brown with beautiful lace.  Just a little chocolatey with a medium bitter finish.  Stone has to be one of the best breweries in the country.  Rerate Oak Aged:  Very spicy compared to regular.  Kind of has a pumpkin pie taste to me.  More complex than the original.  Also had Oak Aged on cask once.  It was a little softer than the regular Oak Aged.  Overall, Arrogant Bastard is one of the most consistantly satisfying beers out there.  Great price too.
Good aroma, however, doesn't look so special in the glass.  Very strong taste that weighs heavily on the stomach.  I'm not sure this is worth the $4.30 a bottle, but I may try it again in the future.

The damn bastard grabbed my by the ears and pulled me down... "Lick this," he sneered. Now - hold on there. I can be a little wild now and again. O yes. I have been known to put stamps on envelopes upside down. I have even worn my underwear two days in a row. But putting my mouth to THAT! And DRINKING it! Now, that's going a bit too far. This is all Krisbierjaeger's fault. Now, there's an arrogant bastard for you. He sends me a bottle of this stuff and expects me not only to drink it, but to be somehow grateful? Grateful! Ha! I am clearly not worthy of being grateful. So, let go of my ears and let me breathe some clean air, the spicy fumes are just too much. I mean, this stuff smells like.... well, it's way too fruity for me. I'll just have a glass of low fat milk, if it's all the same to you. Or a nice cup of camomile tea. I mean, there's chocolate and licorice in that... Devilish flavours. Tempting flavours... Quite nice flavours... Well, maybe one little sip - after all, it does look rather fetching there in the glass. Sort of like a dirty raspberry colour. A rather naughty little raspberry that's been rubbing against a buffaloe's arse. I swear it just winked at me! O yes, that's good! Spank me! Spank me! Pull me down and let me nestle my nose in the bosom of your lupine delights. Tickle me with the hairs of your mighty orifice. Teach me how to drink in the glory of all that is life! Let me gulp down great draughts of marmite and the belching aroma of warthogs fed on the meaty droplets of behelzebub's farts. Let me... just stop a moment. Mmmm. This stuff tickles. It's arrogant, and it's laughing at me. Is it mocking my helpless indulgence in its sheer beauty? Or it is rejoicing in its own confidence? In its life affirming assurance? In its ability to open my eyes to a whole new world of assertive affirmation? Wow! I feel like a new man. Is this really my house? Is this really my wife? Is that really the tie I am wearing? And, o my god, are those really the underpants I chose to wear this morning? I feel like becoming an artist and going out to explore the world. I feel like... Hey, what's this stuff called again?

Tan head, good froth, not much lace  Deep deep red.  Aroaa is a big smackdown hop, very heavy.  Kind of a resiny pine with milder grain malt aromas.  Some fruit, maybe pear.  Awesome!!  Oh wow, dry start, dry sizzly finish.  Splendid beer. Thanks Beerprince!

Very dark and very heavy.  Not bad at all, but not something I'd want to sit around and drink a few bottles of.  One was quite sufficient when I tried this.  Still, it's not a bad brew by any means and certainly deserves its reputation.
dark dark dark color, strong aggressive flavor, huge tan foamy head, A+, a must have - must drink beer

Pours a beautiful red color with a nice light tan head. Mild hoppy aroma. Strong grapefruit hoppy flavor dominates from the beginning. Very bitter. Malt detectable underneath hops. Finishes bitter also.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2005 Its a prime example of an American Brown ale.
Malty, complex, hoppy, this beer has it all. Pours out a dark copper color, my guess is ~12 - 15 Lovibond. Plenty of head on
this brute, with malty aromas up front, and a hop backbone thatll crush any competition. Excellent balance of hops & malts
here.Long lasting lace that made it to the bottom of the glass. No small feat there. Caramel aroma, with a touch of fruitness, but
finishes very dry. Not sweet at all, in my opinion. Nice finish as its swallowed. If youre worthy, buy yourself as much as you
can, while you can.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2008 Gorgeous maroon-amber. Hop aroma was the best part.  The alcohol was well hidden and the body is smooth, tasty and drinkable, with a superb malt backbone. Excellently crafted and perilously drinkable.
Dark amber w/ finger of tan foam. Fresh, floral, leafy citrus nose. Firm & full bodied. An aggressively bitter beer w/ an excellent malt background. Extremely well-balanced & eminently quaffable.

I like the appearance. It pours a nice thick head, and has a good dark rich color to it. The aroma is nice, but you can tell going in that it's going to be a bitter ride. I think they tried too hard with the hops. There are other flavors there that are trying to get through to your taste buds, but can't because the bitterness is just too overpowering. They tried so hard to make it bitter that it cheapened the flavor of an otherwise excellent brew.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2003 Poured a beautiful dark amber color with a nice fluffy orangy-beige head. Piney, citrusy hoppy fragrance smells great. Very velvety feel, very smooth on the palate and tasting very bitter with almost an ESB type of bitterness to it that lingers for quite awhile. In fact it doesn't want to let go. A pleasant maltiness underneath, but obviously overpowered by bitterness. Name suits it well, arrogantly bitter. Bitter Bitter Bitter!
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: UPDATED: JUN 3, 2003 22 oz Draft My first experience (a long time ago, it seems) with the Stone Brewing Company, the striking packaging of this beer drew me in, and many bottles, pitchers, and glasses later its still just as strong, biting, and assertive. Excellent deep color, good head, wonderful depth of flavor, potent and hoppy. A fine beer from a remarkable brewery.
I'm sure what to think of this one yet.  It's good but the flavor changes. So far, so good, however.

Dark brown with a real pretty head on it. Aroma has a bit of fruitiness to it, carmel and hops.  A bit of a barley wine type fruitiness to this beer but then it is a big enough beer to be a barley wine. Hop bitterness is dominant but not overly so, carmel and roasted flavor are here as well. Big hops, big malt and a high alcohol punch this is just a big big beer. Call it beer concentrate

Very nice reddish amber color.Tall foamy head.sweet malty aroma,as well as a very nice sweet fruity aroma hard to describe the fruit but it has an almost bubble gum aroma,very nice,and a definate hop presence but not overly so just the right amount.The flavor is fantastic malty sweet with a mild punch of hops,with a strong taste of what i would say is grapefruit.kind of like an intense alcohol infused can of squirt.That leaves a citrus,hop after taste that is more then pleasant but fantastic.This is one smooth brew with everything i'm looking for flavor,hops and just a total all around drinkability  that i haven't run into until now.The double bastard was good but i think the arrogant bastard slightly edges it out.the taste is there the alcohol is there and they are fused in a manner that makes it very harmonious.what a trade this is the best ASA hands down.
hard to drink anything else once you've developed a taste for this fine hand crafted ale.makes serria nevadas pale ale taste like water.

On tap; brown/ruby color, citrus and hop aroma. I tasted some peach flavors before a dry somewhat bitter finish. Complex, thought it was a  little too aggressive the first time I had it, but since I've come to really enjoy this.
Big hop flavor.  Bitter and malty flavor.  I would of rated it better if it was a little more balanced in taste and finish.
UPDATED: FEB 1, 2007 Nice dark brown. Hint of hops aroma initially. Take the first sip--POW. Hello hops. But lots of dark malt there to keep it from coming completely unglued. Excellent.
Wonderful stuff. Sharp citrusy hops with bitterness out the wazoo, big fruity complex malt. Mahogany, with beige head.

Starts like a stout when cold.  Caramel, raisin, slight chocolate and hops.  Not much aroma when ice cold but this thing changes when it warms.   Tastes more like a Dogfish Head 90 minute at the finish, pure malt and hops.  Definitely a sipper and should be enjoyed like a Cuban cigar.  A very complex beer and one that changes so much in a short time.  Very enjoyable!  I have a keg of Stone IPA and Arrogant Bastard will be next.

Tasted on 03-22-2003. I definately like the 22oz. bottle. Wow, Nice thick tan head and good lace all the way down. Deep reddish brown color. Very unique fruity odor, like maybe peaches and pears. The flavor, although difficult for me to describe, is similar to the nose. Well balanced malt and hops galore. Great mouthfeel. I cant wait to try the double. This is like a party in a bottle, yet still, I deserve better ; ]

This beer is very reminiscent of Three Floyds Alpha King or is it vice versa? Oh well. This beer is all about the hops, bubba! Pours amber with a huge, lasting head with TONS of lacing. Aroma is all citrusy hops. Slightly sweet, acidic, creamy. Finishes with that hoppy bitter goodness. Excellent alcohol kick which is well disguised. Overall an excellent hophead brew

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2004 Just goes to show how much Californians know about subtlety. Nothing! This has to be one of the fattest maltiest ales you can get, but what really hits you is the crazy piney, grapefruity hoppiness, from the moment you pop the cap you can smell it and once it's in your mouth the peppery lingering bitterness rules out tasting anything for a week. It's a beer to show how tough your tastebuds are but I wouldn't drink something like this on a regular basis. It's over the top.

The local grocery store just started carrying this, which is kinda amazing since our college town tends to focus more on selling cases of Busch or Keystone or whatever cheap crap is popular at the moment...Hopefully this is one bastard that will stick around for awhile.

First things first, this is a Big Beer: Big Taste, Big Aroma, Big Hops, Big Deep Blood-Red Color. The scent hits you the moment you crack the bottle open- fruity, hoppy, INSANELY strong. Pours with a nice brown-tan head that quickly diminishes into a little top-fizz. Tastes about how it smells, monstrously hoppy with a strong bite and aftertaste that keeps going for ages. To be honest, I'm worthy enough to like this for the great, ultra-strong beer that it is, but I'm not worthy enough to fully appreciate everything that there is about this beer. Still though, a great beer, and well worth the $3.38 pricetag.
UPDATED: JUN 9, 2005 Deep ruby color with long lasting beige head. Caramel malt and hop aroma. Flavor is very malty, a little fruity and very stong in the hops.

Typical early American homebrew beer style.  Over the top on every front, especially specialty malts.  Still, if you are used to such a strong American Ale then perhaps this is right up your alley.  Personally I find no real faults.  Beautiful aroma and colour, but other big beers are far better.
My buddy calls it "The most unholy swill on earth" but I think it's great. You gotta be in the mood for hops when you drink this one. Deep brown color, nose is alive with malts and hops.

Nice  dark ruby red colour..great tan head.
Some malt tatse, though it is overwhelmed by the hoppiness..though some good chocolaty, coffee flavours show through..good beer

Wonderfully sweet and malty but definitely not overly so. Lots of hoppy aroma -- reminded me of Cascade. Rich as hell. This beer brought back memories of my first hickey. You start out kinda meek and then get into craving it...uh yeah.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2008 To start, this is one nice lookin bastard.  Dark reddish brown color and generous light tan head, make this a nice beginning.  The smell of this bastard is all hops, quite potent, and almost seems to challenge the drinker.  "Come on p@*%y!  You cant handle the s#!t Im gonna bring to this fight!"  Well, maybe the devil-lookin SOB on the bottle didnt count on a drinker like me.  This is some serious stuff.  Strong hoppy, bastardish flavor, that hangs around in your mouth for months and kicks your candy a$$ every minute of it, but with some nice caramel flavors in the malt, too.  THIS is a GREAT strong (bastard) ale!

A beautiful beer, clear dark red with a crisp tan head that fades to tan lacing.  Dark sweet malt with lots of North American hops, citrus, grapefruit, lemon, and pine.  Significant alcohol, and a barley wine taste with a very bitter finish.  Delightful.

Just came home from a satisfying day of work, sitting in the first spring sun, still warm - about 15 degrees Celsius - in the late afternoon. Kids playing in the back gardens, the first tiny green leaves on trees and coming out of the ground, announcing the flowers that will soon arise. The first little bugs crawling over the finally dry floor of my garden. Birds getting excited about the bugs and making love. Then the sound of a beerbottle being opened - pssshh. It pours a beautiful red-brown color with a light brown head leaving very nice lace. Smelling the beer gave me a feeling even beyond the extasy I already felt. A very very beautiful hop perfume with some caramel and raisin. This beer must be yummy! The first sip was so much in contrast with all surrounding me. A very harsh hoppy flavor but yet light sweet. A nice fruitiness, raisin, plum and hell I don't know what - complex. A nice body, full and filling my stomache but not like liquid bread. A medium long lasting finish with much bitterness that almost makes it acidic. You can imagine I had much trouble rating this beer objectively. But even though I tried my best to not like it too much I still did. Thank you mother nature for this afternoon and thank you aceofhearts for this beer.
Smells fruity, perfumey, citrus. Very bitter. Sweet and hoppy. Slight dryness.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2003 The arrogant bastards at Stone pulled a fast one!  This isn't beer; it's really fermented grapefruit juice!  Hops are dominating, and the grapefruit flavor is immediate and thick.  I love the color of this one too- it is dark amber/red, fitting for a beer with an arrogant gargoyle on the bottle.  Arrogant Bastard is a top-notch ale, and pleasantly strong!  Update...no change in score, but I found this on tap at Mac & Joes in Oxford, Ohio, a sign that the world is not yet ending, as there is good beer to be quaffed.

This beer has bite!  Brown/red color with a strong, spice aroma. Nice mouthfeel.  The flavor is strong and severe, just as advertised.  A bitter and hoppy taste.  Shows some strong similarities to barleywine style. A high quality beer best suited to when you have as aggressive an attitude as this Arrogant Bastard.
Ahh, this is a fine American Strong Ale! The head is gorgeous, the mouthfeel sublime and the taste is bitter, hoppy and malty. It also kicks ass to boot. This is by far my favorite beer from Stone.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2004 If you like cheap crap beer, stay away.  What we have here is a beer drinkers beer.  Thick sticky head, deeep brown in color.  Aroma of malts and hops.  Taste is warm heavy hops with a malt chocolate finish.  Quite fantastic.  If you do not like this beer, YOU SUCK!

Draft: Somewhere between caramel and ruby in color with an amazing beige colored head.  If you bake (or watch the Food Network) think stiff peaks.  Scent of grain and flavor of malt with a lingering hop finish.  Stone Brewing may be right, we may not be worthy!
I loved this beer and I loved it's whole story!  It mocks macros. Awesome. That's all I can say about it.  As for the other stuff, you better look at someone else's rating.

Great label and even better description mocking the macros.  Body was deep amber and radiated with aroma of spices and flowers.  Taste was floral as well and quite enjoyable.  Finish was great and dry.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2003 This was my introduction into the wonderful world of great beer! This was also my first Stone brew and my palate will never be the same! You can find this everywhere around here so its a regular pick up for me. Brownish/red color and hopped nicely. Good head and lacing. Excellent aroma of hops and spiced fruit. Alot of malt flava. A slightly thicker syrupy texture. This is one arrogant bastard to a BMC drinker, but for the rest of us, its not so arrogant! Just good!

Pours with a spicy aroma. Moderate Amber color slight carbonation nice size head very appetizing appearance. Very well balanced hits you first with the malt then finishes you off with a great hoppy flavour. This is trully an awesome ale!

Very different - peppery, like essence of chile peppers without the heat, and even somewhat sweet and fruity.  Yet the finish is delightfully dry, and perfectly bitter. The most impressive American Strong Ale I've had.  The aroma is intriguing - I can't quite put my finger on what's inside this beer!

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2008 [wow, glad I revisited this rating - yea, this stuff is good, but its pretty much nothing but highly sweet, with assertive hops] Hmm, quite unique and flavorful.  Nice deep amber color w/good lacing.  Very malty aroma, with some hints of plums.  Very thick body heavy with malts and with decent hops.  Oily mouthfeel.  Peppery and slighty fruity-sweet.  Very barley wine-ish, specifically, very much like Sierra Nevada Bigfoot.  This is better, however.  Im very thankful that we can finally get Stone beers in NY.

Tap:  Very nice bright red color with a slight head which disipates- probably from all the hop oils.  Very hoppy aroma and very bitter.  Lots of hop flavor and good malt balance.  Very good but could always use more hops for me.
Another Imperial IPA by Stone. A good overall beer, but simply too much for a standard beer. Good colour and great hoppy nose, as usual...but simply too much to process.
This beer is great!! And one 22oz. bottle will get you started in the right direction!

This dark amber beer has ruby glints and a rich off-white head with heavy lacing. The nose is of honeydew, papaya and light clove. The palate is full-bodied and agressive with a strong burnt grain presence, clove and rich, meaty papaya. THe finish is astringent with tannins and bitter hops, but it is well-balanced by subtle caramel and tropical fruit sweetness.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2004 Red/Brown with a big, tan head. 
Grapefruity hop nose with some caramel. 
Musty malt flavor is overlain by grapefruity hops. Quite sweet, but very bitter.

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2005 ReRate-Ya know, i have a really mixed feeling about this beer.  Sometimes i have it, its pretty good (tap and fresh bottles).  If you get an old bottle like most of them here in so. NM, then forget it.  I dont like Chinnok Hops, which is what is used here.  The hop profile here is oily, piney, resiny and really damn dry.  A good malt backbone i must say.  I lowered the score a few points.  I guess my palate is becoming more discriminating!
RERATE-22oz bottle-Damn, now i know what everybody is talking about in this one.  this beer is the most balanced beer by far from the stone line.  perfect marriage of hops and malts.  Im so glad this is available in New Mexico(im moving there in a month for graduate school)
Cask-RAF-2/28/03
The RAF guide said this was stored in an oak barrel, which may have given this brew a different taste than what i was expecting.  Also, i sampled this brew right after the 3Fs Behemoth, which may have mangled my palate for this sample.  Needless to say, what i sampled was very toned down from what i was expecting, but still very good

Pours very dark and the head is creamy but has an eerie yellow hue.  This is definately an agressive beer as it is stated.  I am not a fan of this type of beer and A.B. reaffirmed that notion. I did not enjoy it at all, but after sharing a pitcher with two friends, we hardly found our way home.

Hops, cream alcohol and winey malts with an oily tan head.  Cant believe I havent rated this yet.  Vinious malt, raison, grapefruit, with a background of resious hops.  Finish is full of winey/bread malt and piney hops.

What a great looking beer.  Huge rocky head over brilliant cherrywood body.  THe aroma has all the hops I hoped for, but the flavor integrates them beautifully with some sweet, full malt.  I did not expect to like this as much as I did.

Pours with an opaque deep amber brown/mohagony body topped by a very thick creamy head that overflowed the glass.  A good amount of lace was left behind.  Somewhat sour, yet sweet and fruity (similar to mango)aroma with good malty notes. Sweet and fruity (melon) malt flavor with a slight touch of alcohol.  The finish is smokey with coffee notes.  Full bodied and slightly dry with a touch of warmth.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2004 Second taste: Fresh bottle. Light aroma of alcohol and spice. Dark with hints of light. Foamy porous head. Beautiful balance of strong hops and malt. Deep fruity alcohol notes. Much like a barley wine with all the right notes without the heavy body.
First taste: The story: Tipsy's buddy had a 2-year old (+?) bottle unopened.  Tipsy opened it, drank half, corked it and the the next day I sampled.  Amazingly still a good starting head, smooth lacing.  Dark malt and hop aroma.  Dark dirty amber colour.  A beer you can chew, much to my liking.  Nice balance of hops and alcohol.  Slight nutty flavour.  Kicks the ass out of any macro ale.  Not a guzzler but a quality and complex beer. 8/4/7/3/15

malty, almost scotch-like aroma. Pours an amber red, a tad cloudy with a frothy head. Very heavy mouthfeel similar to a scottish ale. The commercial description is quite accurate. This beer has bite! Very strong hops...almost to its detriment as it effects the overall balance. Hops crush all other aspects of the beer. Once you get used to it, it settles down. Not a beer for the timid.
Deep red color and Strong full bodied flavor. Stone brewery is fast becoming a favorite of mine.

Beautiful bright amber/copper color.Rocky light brown head that hangs leaving a nice lacing all the way down.Malty,nutty,spicey hop aroma.Full bodied brew.Spicey hop flavors and sweetness up front.Bready,fruity flavors that work together very well with the hop flavors,balanced.Nice creamy,chewy big bodied brew with a balanced bitterness in the finish.An well balanced big beer.Incredible!7.2% alc. is nice also.Fantastic brew!Need some to lay down.Would age well i,m sure.
This is some good stuff.  Assaults the palate with a strong bitter taste unlike anything ive ever had.

Stck in a Holiday Inn in Flagstaff, AZ I wandered across the sreet to a gas station to buy a couple of beers. I bought this brew and what a find. This is an excellent ale! Nice dark copper color, a small head, pine scent, tremendous flavor, very enjoyable.

Want to chew a beer?  If you are a bud light lover, you will not like this beer.  If you however like strong bitter beers, this is your beer.  This is definately an agressive beer to quote Greg Koch.  One of my personal favs.

Dark red in color.  A strong, harsh piney aroma.  The bitterness is not balanced well in my opinion, or maybe I'm just getting fed up with beers that pretend to be great through high IBUs.  Assertive but not balanced right.  Not a big fan of this one.
Good stuff. Skunky aroma, a little bitter, yet easy going. This was very enjoyable to me. I give props to the fine brewers over at Stone for this one. Go so cal!

Wow, the best of the three Stone Brewing Co. beers I've tried.  A intersting red amber awaits you as the bottle is poured.  A interesting blend of citrus and and other bitter flavors are expierenced.  Would recommend this beer to anyone.  Thanks mwsf for the Stone's experience.

Pours a nice deep amber color with a nice white head. Aroma of citrus and pine immediately greets you. The flavor has as complex a hop flavor as any beer I can recall. Grass, pine, and citrus hop flavors all blend well on a background of malt sweetness. An excellent beer that hides it's strength well.
Long live the Bastard. Great beer. Just the right amount of hop flavor. Looked great. Poured great.
Great Ale the way it is supposed to taste. Good Finish great hop taste, very smooth, one of the best
What can I say?  I love hops and this is aggressively hopped.  It can be overbearing at times but what hopfiend doesn't like to be bullied by hop intensity.

seriously damn that description shit. if i dont have the sophistication to enjoy the taste of someone shatting in my mouth then thas ok with me. but, one good thing is the percentage is above average, but the price and the taste makes me feel like i paid for someone to crap in my mouth.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2004 Dark brown/red in color, with a large, tan head. Pretty hoppy aroma, with a bit of lime, faint hints of malt, caramel. Flavor is hoppy and slightly bitter throughout, some dark fruit notes, a touch of sweetness early on. A true consistently great brew.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2006 22oz. Bomber.   This one pours a bit "Thick".  There was a bit of an off white head.  The beer is a bit clear, and a reddish amber color.  Extremely malty with a nice hop afterbite.  Unique taste.  There is a bit of fruitiness in there.  It is very potent.  This is one my wife will definitely NOT like. I am Worthy!

Good, but not great ale. Lacks head, but still probably one of the best american beers out there. For a strong beer it is a good example of the style. It's nicely bitter with a crisp aftertaste and somewhat hoppy. I've tasted numerous ales similar to this. It doesn't stack up to belgian strong ales but is good in its own right. The alcohol manages to be filling without being overpowering and can't be tasted. It's a tad on the (over)pricey side and difficult to acquire outside CA. On an unrelated note : if you collect beer bottles this is a must as the bottle is hysterical. In short a good beer, but it doesn't reinvent the wheel.
Reddish Brown color with virtually no head. You can see the carbonation. Fruity...grapefruit...hoppy aroma. A bitter flavor with a fruity note. Of course a great beer.

the only other premium beer i had had before this was Delirium Nocturnum and Guinness. oh, can you imagine my surprise? i have to admit it, the bottle is what made me buy it, but the taste is what makes me love it. THIS STUFF IS DANK! i enjoy preceeding a bottle of this with a nice pisswater, just so i can laugh at the difference. does anyone else pick up a nice fruity aftertaste?

Dark copper pour with a decent tan head.Nice citrusy hop nose. Medium/full bodied with a big hop bite. Nicely balanced out by huge amounts of malt. Excellent brew and I would expect nothing less from the Stone Flagship!

(10Jan2003--22oz.bottle) 
After a couple disappointments with Stone beers, Id started to wonder if the brewery wasnt overhyped.
Im happy to report that Arrogant Bastard Ale lives up to any hype it has received.
This is real beer!
Attractive beer, perfect frothy head, fine bubbles, deep red/brown color.  Slight haziness is a bit offputting.
Complex, pleasing aroma; malty, hoppy, and strong bread/french toast as the beer warms.
Even more complex and pleasant palate; perfect full,creamy mouthfeel, sweet (peachy), appropriately bitter, with a strong peppery note. 
Also the same french toast as in the nose.
In summary, an unforgettable, highly unique beer.
The best Ive had in 2003 (duh), and possibly for the last
five years!
Very rich in taste.  It kicks you in the mouth but appologizes with a good finish.
This one is not for Pussy-cats. dark amber in color with a nice lasting head. full body with strong malty/hoppy flavor and nice malty aroma!
UPDATED: FEB 3, 2011 Malty grain aroma mixed with the big hops, the flavor is kinda boring... a little hops, some alcohol, but what else?  There should really be more going on in there.
Just a solid great beer that is a must try.
What more can be said about this beer, it"s simply awesome.  Dark, complex, strong, delicious

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2003 Poured with a huge frothy head atop a vibrant amber colored body.  Aroma of malt, hops, alcohol, and a variety of fruits.  Flavor was robust, with huge hops, malt, and some subtle notes of what I taste as grapefruit, orange peel, and pear.  Dry, bitter and sophisticated.  Good stuff.

2002: Sweet sugar plums dance from an off white head that rests atop a deep garnet body.  Hints of brown sugar and and raisins entice the taste buds to dive in futher and just when you reach the edge of sweetness, hops mix with some spice. . . then, just as you feel you may have this one figured out, the alcohol slams you in the face and reminds you who is in charge. . . The Double Bastard. . .then you wonder - is that so bad?

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2003 On tap
Dark body with a thick, everlasting tan head.
Aroma was of sweet malt and a hint of alcohol.
Taste was intially a sweet, wort like taste that finishes with a big hops bite.

Deep red pour, with a big beige head that laces all the way to the end.  Aroma fills the room with citrus and hops, much like the IPA and Ruination do, but a little stronger.  Light caramel is present initally, followed by a hops onslaught that never seems to let up.  Truly a fantastic brew.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2003 An exceptional dark amber ale fully of character and a striking amount of hops.  This is an aggressive beer says the label, and I"ll vouch that it doesn"t lie.  I had this beer on tap several weeks back and really enjoyed it but found that it was surprinsingly close to Mac & Jacks African Amber Ale.  Being able to sit back and relax with a bottle in hand and the time and place to actually take some better notes to review it, I"m guessing my notes were wrong, or I was poured the wrong beer.  (As such, I"ve resubmitted my review for this beer).

From the bottle, Arrogant Bastard doesn"t look, smell or taste like Mac & Jacks, it"s far superior.  AB pours a deep reddish hue with a big white rocky head.  Glass lacing is extensive.

Aroma wise, this one carries a very enjoyable hoppy kick, hints of fruit, and complex malts.  It doesn"t carry the pine hit that the Ruination IPA offers, which helps to make this a much more rounded ale which can be savored in more than one serving per sitting.

On the palette, the hops and malts are creatively balanced, providing hints of fruit, toasted malts and a slight peppery smokiness to it.  Despite its edgy hoppiness, the malt factor kicks in to really make this an exceptionally well rounded ale that can be enjoyed again and again.  

Great balance worth a closer look for those who have yet to venture into the grip of the Arrogant Bastard.

(ADDENDUM: 12/27/02 I had the opportunity to visit a place called Fogg & Suds on the outskirts of Vancouver, BC the other day, and to my astonishment this place is trying to fetch $30.00cdn for a bottle of this stuff. Buyer beware. Arrogant Bastard is great stuff, but it should be obtainable for less than 1/3 the price being asked for here.) <sigh>
1/3/03: on tap.  dark red color. strong flavors.  hoppy and a little bit sweet.  a fuller taste than double bastard.  i like this beer so much better on tap than from the bottle.  excellent label.
Very dark color, lots of aroma, lots of flavor. Man this was good. A bit heavy and strong to have one after the other, but savoring one on occasion is a definite must.
best part of my trip to las vegas was finding this beer there.

Pours a brilliant deep red/garnet color with little, but persistent, head.  The aroma is strong as hell, but just fantastic.  Hoppy (pine, citrus, perfume) with sweet malt (peaches, apricot, caramel, vanilla).  The flavor is almost equally as good, but not quite.  A long, warming finish with plenty of bitterness.  A great beer indeed.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2008 this ostentacious bastard sprang forth, a vivacious tawny torrent of lightly cloudy liquid bravado. the cashew colored head muscled through a quick and elegant kata of fluffy foam, then stepped aside as if gunfighters were approaching. then we went nose to nose, the arrogant one and i. the aroma struck fast--i’d scarcely lifted the glass--and slapped me with a blast of mango rich hop resin, linzertort and brandy, all raw and ready to flambé. i shook off the blow and sniffed again, but sinuous undulating notes of orange pekoe and hemlock sap left me reeling-- and yet strangely euphoric--like i’d been packed in a barrel of hop flavored massage oil with sandra bullock and rolled down a steep slope. i managed a sip, but again lost my footing as a huge caramel sweetness blew past my left and chattering tangy hops dragged their claws down my right. diminutive stars and cartoon tweety birds circled my head as a fogbank of alcohol descended on the part of my cerebellum associated with random cognitive recall, like what planet i currently reside upon. still flailing helplessly, the hops sprang on me again and bit me like a rabid wolverine launched from a catapult! texas ruby grapefruit on the tongue, a radiant buzz and a grin were what remained of my senses... i was pummeled and wasted by this encounter, yet blithely i still consider myself the winner. hic.

Nice copper color with a modest light tan head that clings to the side of the glass as you partake.  Orange citrus aroma with a hint of malt.  Sharp, somewhat citric, with a touch floral hops bite starts and carries throughout the quaff.  After that the malt comes to play and play it does.  Smooth caramel, toffee, mocha, and a bit doughy - just outstanding.  So few brewers understand the true importance of quality malts and hops.  Slightly warming towards the finish.  This is one of the few "heavyweight" brews that could be my everyday choice. Unfortunately, I have to send away to get this one on my porch step.  Thanks Mr. AB  for producing this quality quaff.
Money.  This beer has excellent malting, with a nice bit of bitterness.  Just excellent flavor.  Starts off a bitter and and finishes smooth.  One of the best ales Ive ever had.  Nobody is worthy.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2004 BAM!  Bitter hops that make your writhe in pain are the first impression that you get while drinking this.  This is one mean beer.  It's rich red in color with a thick fluffy head.  The hops are so hard that they hurt.  As a warning - do NOT drink this after another beer.  Make sure that your pallette is clean.  This is liquid bread.  If you like hopped-up American ales, then this is for you.  This is king.  If you prefer maltier, smoother tastes, then you will probably hate this.  Despite the hard-hitting initial taste, it finishes off with a fair fruity/malty taste.  Definately not for the weak.

Very dark amber with nice head upon pour. VERY nice flowery aroma from the hops. Verry bitter in the first sip. Leaving the classic sting on the sides of your tongue (as good strong ales do). The more you sip it mellows out in one of the most balanced ales Ive tasted. First a sting of bitter then a plesant sweet and fruity taste finishing off with with that long lasting after taste I love about ales. I definately rate this as one of the best beers Ive tasted. You will be amazed for shure for an American Ale.

This beer has a strong aroma with notes of alcohol mixed in with a hoppy nose.  Beautiful dark red color with a malty body to match.  This beer attacks your tongue, momentarily twisting it in directions that it is not normally prone to go.  What a bastard!  This beers flavor lasts, a hefty one it is.  Always good, never matched!

Great looker. Rich red, nice head. Maltier, nuttier nose than I expected. Somehow, its coming off a bit less arrogant and much more sopisticated than expected. Probably my favorite of the Stone big ales so far.

Sell my clothes, Im going to heaven. This pleasurable drinking experience starts with a nice dark cherrywood color, strong citrus and candy aroma. A nice head from start to finish (then again, I did drink it rather quickly). Your first sip renews your faith in using the alcohol to enhance the hoppiness instead of cloud it. Then, bring on the caramel malt and life is pretty close to perfect. Nice lingering finish. Now, if only it was more widely available.

This notably strongly hopped American is exactly what one likes (as I do!) for the non weak at heart.  The complexity of flavor to include grapefruit, caramel, freshly cracked malts, and dark fruits are exquisitely combined to produce this product.  I have enjoyed this several times at local pubs, or in the peaceful setting of my home and every time this beverage shines through. Relatively thick head, excellent palate, and an appropriate color are to be found.  It is consistent and only can be beaten by its bigger brother, Double Bastard!

Well, how would I put this... The beers name is perfect.  Its an Arrogant Ale allright.  The pour was nice.  The head was beautifully thick.  The color, a dark cherry was suprisingly murky, not as clear as I hoped.  Dark but not clear up to the light.  The first sip took me by suprise.  It was strong, rough and bitter.  Not my favorite.  But after the first sip or two the mellow under tones smoothened it out. I should have continued to simply drink this strong ale alone but I had it with dinner.  BIG MISTAKE.  I ate it with chicken and vegatables and it was almost undrinkable.  It made the food seem too sweet and the food made it seem too bitter.  Too bitter you say?  Is that possible?  YES.  I would say keep this beer away from food.  It was hard to finish the rest of the beautifuly illustrated bottle with my dinner.  Too bad.  I love beer with my food.

8/08/02: Gorgeous mahogany color (reminded me of the lobby of Portlands old Benson Hotel) accompanied by thick, rocky head with copious lace...Marvelous! Aroma is medicinal sweet--a little like some of my stronger homebrews...Hops hit in two...make that three waves: once at first sip, then a second that slides under the tongue and along the sides of the mouth, and a third which dominates the back of the palate in the finish. Warm, moderately sweet malt rides shotgun through all phases of the journey...This brew has (predictably) rough edges to it--(its supposed to, of course!)--but the robustness and complexity of the flavors makes this a rare treat indeed. Re-Rate 11/01/02: On draught...Same wonderful appearance...aroma seemed lighter than bottled version, but hops and brandy-like qualities came through nicely...the bitter qualities of this brew were also more in play this time, which to my palate wasnt quite as  balanced as my last visit with this, but again, the differences are so subtle that my ratings are not altered...Terrifically brutal!

I had this on draught at "Moose Malones".  I had it out of the bottle too, but I dont remember it tasting as well.  Both very malty and also having fair amount of hops.  Its an excellent brew, and you will probably like it!
Nice dark red color with good head. Interesting and difficult to describe aroma. Very citrusy and bitter. Very interesting, and would like to try it again.
UPDATED: FEB 28, 2003 almost as good as Bonesbeer,ahem, again this is not as good as bonesbeer, but fuckin close!

Big hoppy, biscuity nose.  This is a big beer that doesnt go too far.  Perfect balance of rich caramel malt and fat, chunky citrusy hops.  Very funny label. Really good, but I think I was expecting something more.  Maybe its just all the hype on here about Stones Ales!

Lots and lots of tiny bubbles, beautiful creamy soft head.  A boat load of hops in this bully.  Well roasted with hints of chocolate and nuts too!  Damn, the malts & floral notes on the tongue sing in chorus with each other.  Long finish, robust brew, solid all around.  Id love to keep these around for novice freinds.

Deep red-orange color with nice lace.  Full floral hop aroma with lots of pineapple and grapefruit in the nose.  Nice malt backbone with sweet grapefruit/citrus flavors.  It does taste like the Double Bastards little brother, but the DB is so huge that little brother is still damn good.
UPDATED: MAR 24, 2003 Honey orange color; honey orange taste.  high alcohol content.  Very, Very nice
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: Excellent beer for hop-heads.  It was hard to taste this impartially given the amount of hype there is about it, so perhaps someday I should re-rate blindly somehow.  In any case, no amount of hype can make crap taste good, so my taste buds werent lying when I took my first sip and I started grinning.  This was awesome!  Inital hop flavor (and aroma) exceeding that of Sierra Nevada Bigfoot, but less than Two Hearted Ale.  Following the hop blast comes subtle maltiness (caramel?) that you have to look for a bit - it might be easily missed behind all the hops.  Finishes nice and dry, and for the next half hour your burps will taste fantastic!
good strong beer, poured dark red amber color with a nice head, great taste, i wanna try more Stone products for sure.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2004 Re-rate: This bottle was aged about a year.  The hops have mellowed a bit in the aroma and given way to more complex bready crystal malts.  Good sweet caramel flavor blends well with the bitterness.  Still no sign of alcohol.  I think the aging has made this less "arrogant", but I enjoy it more.

Original Rating: This has a fresh citrusy hop aroma with hints of caramel malt.  Deep copper with a thick, lacy, cougar-colored head that coats the glass as it diminishes.  Starts slightly malty and sweet, almost chocolatey, finishes sort of sticky and astringently bitter, but remains pretty well balanced.  Another plus is that you really can't taste the ABV.  In my opinion, they used to many bittering hops, and not enough aroma or flavor hops.

Dark ruby brown with a fairly thick head.  Interesting aroma of cinnamon apples, allspice, orange pulp, ginger, and a big hop note that wasnt quite as brash as expected.  Spritzy texture, which is welcome considering gravity.  Lots of caramel malt depth and cider-like sweetness, drawing out nicely in a long, bittering finish.  Unbalanced or not, this beer hits all of the right taste buds...Im a big fan, and I wish it wasnt so hard for me to get.  Thanks Dogbrick.
Has a dark amber color and smell of hops.  Taste is of hops and finishes with hoppy bitterness.  Overall this stuff is pretty good, but then again I am not worthy to drink it so Stone can go screw...
I may not be worthy, but Ill never turn this one down.  A full frontal assault will leave you wondering how this beer fit in the bottle it came out of.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2016 Re-rate: My but things change. I wonder but rather doubt the recipe has changed - my opinion certainly has. More grainy and muddles than I had recalled and a beer I have rarely sampled in past years with all the other beers (even from Stone) ever hitting the market. Oh well, at least I do enjoy and appreciate some if not many Stone beers.
------- there wasnt as much that I havent tried, I would probably head back to this more often. Think the label is pointed to people that just dont like real beer as it isnt near as aggressive as it alludes to being. Just the hoppy side of a really great balance. Yum.
Easy to drink and not as aggressive as one would think.  Toned down hops and bitterness.  Ends dry and nose has some floral tones.  Good if a bit thin.
This beer has a beautiful color and a nice thick head. First tasting impression was WOW hops!!! This was quickly followed by a nice fruity and caramel aftertaste. This is a really great beer.

Pours deep red with light tan head.  Strong hop aroma.  Great hops bite when still cold that changes to a wonderful malt/hops blend as the beer warms up.  Finishes with hints of caramel and and a bit of a roasted flavor.
Strong hoppy fruity aroma.Dark red chestnut appearance with thick head.Fruity strawberry peach flavors followed by extreme radiating hop bitterness.
this is without a doubt the least appealing beer ive ever drank in my life.  it tastes bad, it smells bad, it is bad.  maybe im just not sophisticated enough.
Very nice strong ale. I must admit I poured out my first bottle...too strong. I came back for seconds though...and it has really won me over! Not for the weak beer lover ;-)
Super charged in hoppiness which tastes awesome.  The aroma is relatively weak for such a bold tasting beer.  Nice and smooth as it ventures into my stomach.
the perfect beer! not for pussys though

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2003 Having retried this a few times after the hundreds of beers I've sampled, I no longer think it's the extreme monster that I once did. Well, it is extreme but in no way a monster. Rich, full-bodied, complex and well balanced. I like it now more than ever.


Original Rating: Hops! Mind expanding amounts of flavor. Maybe too much of some but I think that's the point. A real killer. It's not my favorite beer but Arrogant Bastard is a definite must try, if only for the name and the cool bottle. My favorite part: the grapefruit finish. Avoid drinking this too cold; it throws off the balance of flavors. At refrigerator temp, it's a fist of hops straight to your face. Wait for it to warm and it's much more well rounded.

Ahh, a great beer! Got this bastard in the mail today. The color of this is dark amber with tones of red.  Reminds me of there pale ale just darker and stronger.   Ill have tom get more of this sent....

This beer is awesome. Dark amber in color, hoppy like a mother. At first sip it bites you big time. Second sip your almost ready. Third sip your ready to do commercials for this beer. Calling it aggresive still dosent do it justice. This is my favorite beer. You are not ready!

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2003 I've had this beer 1 million times..exactly..each time its been something totally and utterly different..which makes me come to one conclusion..this beer is the most inconsistent beer that i've had the motive to care about..sometimes its overly hoppy and out of balance..other times its completely balanced with nice carmelly sweet nectarine sweetness and super hoppy bitterness..sometimes its great...sometimes it sucks..I dont know what to say other than..ok.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2003 It's been over a year since I originally rated this - 2 new observations:  1. I now notice a very sweet thick malt in the taste and palate.  2.  My best friend Gina wants to have the top 3rd cut off so that she can use the bottle as a vase for flowers - would that be sacreligious, twisted and bent? or would it be a great new industry to get into? - the Beer Bottle/Flower Vase Industry?
  


original rating: Extreme beer should be a new category for beers that challenge you.  The first time I tried this, I hated it. (maybe because I was on a porter kick, not prepared for this Bastard's hop content?).  So, every week at the beer store it kept taunting me from the shelf.  Fine. bought 2 more bottles. Damn it - this is one of my faves. I like the initial bite of the hops followed by the full mouthfeel, finally you have to swallow, crisp, warming finish, how can it be so balanced in the end when it tries to hop you to death at the begining.  THis is not for beginners - you need a full appreciation of the beer tasting spectrum before you are truly 'worthy' of this beer.  I've actually warned a couple of friends away from this - when they are ready, I will buy them one and maybe walk them thru the experience like a shaman......can't say anymore about it.
This is one of the best ales I have ever tasted. Excellent yet complex taste. Very nice bitter finish.  Good head on this one. ;)

Dark brown, clear, medium-to-large semi-lasting head.  Looks like a typical brown ale.  Nose hoppy, floral, grapefruity, with a hint of figs and spices.  Flavor is excellent, really over the top on both the hops and the malt.  If I hadnt had a 3Fs Dreadnaught a couple of months ago, I would probably think this was "the shit" in the Am Strong category; as it is, it does most things right, though there is a weird heavy molasses-like quality to the body in the middle that Im not crazy about.  Caramel, grapefruit, vanilla, toffee all manifest briefly in the flavor before being completely overrun by the end hoppiness.  Very good.  Great, I dunno.
Bo ya, was this beer and experience.  More flavor than almost every beer comes close to.  Not a friendly beer to most, but that would explain why none of my college buddies like it.....

Another excellent beer that is a bit over-hyped. Dont get me wrong, I enjoy this intensely satisfying ale very much but I dont think its quite as good as its reputation makes it sound. Its not heads above a lot of other great strong ales.

This is a wonderful beer, nice garnet like color with a nice large head.  Wonderful Aroma is of citrus hops, taste is very complex, hops, hints of citrus and grapefruit, notes of caramel malt to balance things out a little, bitter hop finish, very complex. My first stone brew, but definately not my last. Got to give props to my brother for picking this up for me on his western trip

This is a Mans beer, it has a beautiful amber color. Very complex in flavor. Loads of hype but it does deliver!Re-Rate 10-8-02 Quality American. Strong Ale, citrus, malty,Yes let it warm up, and flavours kick in,  ! Widely available and highly Recommended
What I liked best was the dry bitterness to it.  I am a huge stout and porter and bitter fan, and although this is neither it is close in the bitter taste.  This is good stuff.
Just had one of these on tap and let me say man was it good. Stone knows how to brew beer and this is just another perfect example of that

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2004 This beer rocks.
What was I thinking with my previous rating? I rated it fairly high, but was way off with my description... I think. I described the appearance as a cloudy mohogany color. Ummmm, the beer I am currently staring at is as clear and sparkling as the Golden Dome in South Bend, Indiana. Mohogany isnt a bad description, but ruby is more accurate. The medium-sized head is off-white, creamy and mostly lasting. Excellent lacing too.
The aroma is left coast all the way. Malty, mysteriously spicey and very floral. A little buttery too.
The flavor is malty and bitter up front... leaning farther toward the left coasts hops than Londons toasted malts. Not balanced. Not supposed to be. Yeah, sure, there are notes of caramel and toffee on the tongue, but the hops beat the living shit out of them. Im glad that all dark ales arent this massively hopped, but I am rather enjoying this one. The perfect beer for a cold, rainy, November West Virginia night such as this.
This beer is full-bodied with lively carbonation. Creamy mouthfeel. Medium length, semi-dry, bitter finish. Notes of buttery toffee at the wee end of the finish. Great Beer! Have one.

Hops, of course. Also an earthy texture in the finish. If you pour it cold, drink it slowly and let it warm up (much like Stones Imperial Stout), the flavor becomes much more more complex as it warms.
I tasted this and immediately thought of SN Bigfoot, but then I hadnt had one in a while. It would be an interesting back to back taste test.
If you are a Hop Head you will like this beer.

Heavy hop/malt aroma. Bloody red color with beige light brown head that lasts. Somewhat bitter but plenty of malt to balance. Caramel/munich malt sweetness. I read the label before I drank it so I was expecting something a little more harsh I guess but it turned out to be quite pleasant. This is a fine ale. The first time I tried this beer was the first time I ever saw Taxi Driver, the greatest film of all time. Whenever I drink this, it makes me want to watch the film, and when I watch the film, it makes me want to drink this. May 10th. Thank God for the rain which has helped wash away the garbage and trash off the sidewalks. Im workin long hours now, six in the afternoon to six in the morning. Not a session beer, drink this on its own, or drink it before you drink the other beers.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2009  Shining ruby red color with a modest,inch,tan head floating like a cloud on it. Flavor is loaded with sweet malts and just as loaded with hops.It never stops.The alcohol shows it self at the end but by that time I didnt care.The malts lead up to the bitterness all the way to the end.The finish changes from a overly bitter to very appetizing leafy bittersweet finish.

Dark red color with a nice medium sized head. Hoppy aroma that is delicious, not as overpoweringly hoppy as the IPA. The first sip starts very hoppy but nice creamy malt comes through in the body, the finsih is fairly bitter. I agree with an earlier poster that the malt doesnt quite balance the hops, but a very good ale nonetheless. The alcohol is certainly present and adds to the aggression, its an exceptional get home from a long night at work and put you to sleep beer.

Dark cherrywood red color with a small tan head and lasting lace throughout the session.  Very nice, big aroma of citrus fruit - ie/oranges.  The body is very hoppy (almost one-sidedly so) with big citrus notes and a touch of alcohol.  Also a substantial amount of malt, but not enough for this amount of hops.  Fairly nice, but a touch unbalannced.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2003 I love this beer, cascade citrus aroma, pours ruby-brown color,roasted huge malty flavor with a balanced huge hop profile.This is a big ale with a great flavor, I love it, I could drink it daily.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2003 Garnett amber hue.  Nice beige head with some lacing.  Big aroma, of dough, flowers.  Big TASTE.  Sweet, pleasant first, medium bodied, chewy, caramel, big bitter hopped out finish.  This brew is incredible.  Too much flavor.  You probably wont like it.  This beer on draught is fn incredible, highly recommended.

DONT DRINK THIS ALONE!!! The sheer intimidation of this arrogant bastard will be enough to strike the utmost sense of fear into any beer expert. This beer will bitchslap, taunt, and beat you if you are not careful. Its strong, rare and served in 22oz bottles. So watch yourself...If you think you are worthy.
Great beer, but pretty strong and bitter.  Nice flavor once you know what to expect.
UPDATED: MAR 20, 2008 Until I find something better, this will remain my favorite beer of all time, despite not having the highest rating.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2003 This beer is the ultimate.  I love it and cannot get enough of it.  I wish that I had a tap hooked to the side of my head and a keg strapped to my back full of this stuff.  Definitely my new favorite.
I thought that this brew would be much more hardcore after reading the back of the bottle.

A citrus (grapefruit) aroma highlighted with a little raosted malt characteristics are the first things that I noticed about this beer. The beer starts sweet and finishes bitter. The flavor lingers just to let you know that your not drinking fizzy lemonade. Good stuff.
The malt (melanoiden)flavor is quite overwhelming but is backed up by plenty of hops a great session beer

Lovely creamy head, wonderful feel in the mouth--full marks in both appearance and palate.  The aroma took me back to English ales.  The bitterness, which one third of the way through was too much, became more tolerable and balanced later on.  Bold and interesting. (on tap, Flying Saucer, Addison, TX)

A very flavorful beer with a lot of character. Very complex.  Spicy and bitter yet smooth and silky. Excellent lacing just like all of the Stone beers.  Fluffy foamy brownish beigh head. Alcohol is well hidden with the exception of the end of the pint.

This cranks out tons of pine tar and flowers in the nose, kind of like you poured a bunch of it over a flower patch. Yet, its a good smell. I almost feel like Im in the brewery and a new batch is ready to go, a really fresh smell. The color of this beer is unlike any other. A deep magenta, almost on the edge of purple, rusty, orange brown, it is very clear , and very deep nonetheless. The head is a creamy beige microbubble soup that stays the course and laces up the sides. I dont usually base my ratings on the container, but I have to give this an extra appearance point for some of the best beer label literature around.  Yes, this is a big beer, but it balances like an elephant on the head of a pin, a move in any direction and it wouldnt work. Yet, it does. It starts of with a bit of black licorice sweetness and pine needles, the segues into a screaming hop finish, much like a meal of fresh flower petals. A classic and and one of a kind. The ending bitter kind of echoes back at you periodically, much like screaming across the Grand Canyon. Cheers, have an Arrogant Bastard, youll never be the same.

Tried this for the first time last weekend. Very Impressed. I generally am not big into extremely hoppy beers, but was interested by the fruity aroma (reminiscent of pineapple to me and my friends)and tghe rich, dark color. Was not dissappointed as the slight fruitiness was complimented by the sharp hop flavor for an aggressive, but not offensive taste. aftertaste was pleasant, and not overly long-lived. Overall, one of the best beers I have tasted

Ok, I shared a big 22 of this yesterday, and liked it.  I found it to be quite complex, which is a fancy way of saying not very "easy to drink".  It was quite hoppy i thought.  I will need to try this one a couple more times I think, but it will probably not be a favorite of mine.  Yet, we shall see.....

RE-RATE #2: Had to bump it up some more.  I mean, being able to be with a bunch of crappy beer drinking friends and saying to the bartender, Give me a pint of the bastard! and when your friends ask for a taste, they cringe at the intensity...how cool is that?  RE-RATE: How my taste has changed in about 6 months.  I gave this beer several more chances because I love everything else that Stone puts out and because its perfect to drink from my Arrogant Bastard pint glass.  I have definitely developed a taste for it.  The aftertaste still doesnt appeal much to me, but the flavor has a very strange and complex fruitiness - something that is hard to describe in terms of existing fruits, its as if it tastes like a fruit that God forgot to invent.  If I had to describe it, Id say lemons and grapefruit is about as close as one could get.  It seems to somehow make it into the malt profile and hoppiness.  Quite nice!  ORIGINAL RATING:  I find this stuff over-rated.  The flavor is okay but unremarkable (raisins, figs?) but the aftertaste kills anything else good about the beer.  I walked out of the pub a few minutes later wishing for some crackers and water.

“YOU’RE NOT WORTHY” Dark brown color, medium head. WOW This is a very aggressively hoppy ale, very bitter strong hop taste. Extremely bitter finish. Nice balance of malt and hops. An aggressive beer, nice taste but not for everyone. Nor would I want to drink this beer all the time. High alcohol (7.2%). Nice etched bottle.

Reddish body, thick foam, strong carbonation. Malty (crystal?) aroma with evident alcohol and heavy hopping. Toasty caramel malt flavor, great bitterness in the finish, extremely citric. Hops last well into the atertaste along with hints of chocolate.

Good god what a beer.  I had this one at the SMA hopfest in NC, and if it
had been a dog show this beer would clearly have been best in show.  Strong dark 
character, with a rich hop taste, with bitter finish that is damn near perfect.  It
is hard to put a label on the beer itself.  Close to a Nut Brown, but doesnt really
fit either dry or sweet style.  Generally, it was just damn good.  Unfortunately,
cant buy it in NC.

like a punch in the face. terrific. probably the most complex ale ive had. hints of citrus and ... smoke in the nose, a dark red-amber color with perfect carbonation. nice hoppy aftertaste, with a full on initial torrent of flavor. i really liked this beer! 

I brought this back from a recent trip to SanFrancisco. Found it in a corner-grocer and walked around town all day with it shoved in a brown liquor bag, looking like a hobo. however, it turns out, to be completely worth the humiliation of procuring it.
A hoppier version of Anchor Steam Victory Ale.  Dark carmel color, chuck full of hops and alcohol content.  I agree a little two dimensional, but worth a try.

22oz. bomber of this and you wont be worthy to drive.  This beer knocks you right out with a hop kick and a wonderful malty aftertaste.  Dark amber in color, off white head....thanks Stone for the great product.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2003 Pours a dark, clear deep brown color with a big, lingering off-white head. Nothing but strong hops in the aroma, so much so that it almost seems to burn my nose. Full bodied and not as bitter as the aroma leads you to believe. The flavor is magnificent, with a strong hoppiness that is countered by a wonderful malty sweetness. The finish is mostly hops with a lingering bitterness and piney aftertaste. I can"t wait to try the Double Bastard Ale.

This beer teeters between extreme caramel (Crystal Malt 120L) and harsh bitterness (Chinook hops).  In other words, two-dimensional.  I love almost all beer, but this one did NOT have me going back for more.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2003 Very strong, very tasty. The label boasts about the aggressive hops and krikey is it true. Red color almost looks like cherry kool-aid, but with a great head. This beer will kick your ass but like some bazarre beer dominatrix it somehow feels so good.
This is a big beer.  It extremely hoppy so make it the last one of the night.  Intense bitterness finds reasonable balance with the pronounced maltiness.  Heavily hopped.
when you pour a bottle of this, youre in true greatness.  every brewery should strive to be like Stone.
Love the attitude, unfortunately it looks like the bastard is right.  For me the bitterness ends up overwhelming the promising initial taste.
Tasted on tap in Columbus, OH and in bottle in Columbus.  Resiny hop flavor - very heavy on the Chinook.  Complexity between hops and malt profile.  Definitely a step up from their IPA.  Good stuff!

Deep ruby color. Large head. Floral hop aroma supersceded by strong caramel malt aroma. Quite bitter. Very malty. Strong caramel flavor. Very strong floral hop flavor. Very full bodied. Nice beer! Might benefit from aging to round it a little.

A temporary faux-Cascade floral nose, ebbing to pine, and then robust vine blending with candy sugar and when warm - some musk. The body is all all the rich dark color and hardy fine head suggest. Its medium-full, creamy and hoppy to the bejeezus. It finishes very clean and soft for such a hoppy beer. The 7.2% is clearly obvious as it warms. This beer gets great scores despite my personal preference for less straight up and more Cascadian brews. Well done!

I really wish I could have liked this beer, not because of its marketing (which is pretty damn cool) but because it is a great beer in almost every aspect. It had a beautiful dark red hue that is unusual for a beer not flavored with a berry. There was a complete lack of head, but I may have been overly careful after an experience with a bottle of Guinness earlier in the weekend. The aroma was nicely hopped and hinted of a complex flavor. The flavor itself was complex and very Belgian-like with hints of fruitiness and other hard to identify flavors. The problem came in the overwhelming bittereness. It was just too strong and ended up overwhelming all of the other flavors in the beer. This however may change, (originally all beer tasted this way to me, and I may have still been recovering my taste for beer after a small hangover from late in the previous week) so I may have to come back and rerate this beer later.

rerate 8-29-02: Its only been a few months since my original rating and already the overwhelming bitterness has changed to easily palateable bitterness. Nice creamy foam pitted head this time. Too dark to be called off-white. Body is reddish brown, nice but not exceptional. Aroma is some sweet malt and a slightly pine-liek hop bite. Flavor bites first, a little interesting maltiness in the middle and some fruitiness (I could have sworn it was peach there a couple of times, but it became more vague after that) It ends with a fairly short, bitter finish.

Now, I was told before I had this beer that it was the "worst beer ever" and Id have to disagree.  Not the best beer ever though, mainly because of its aftertaste, but not bad.  It is overrated at 4.08 though.
This is a real interesting brew.  Suffice it to say its strong!  The hops fade on the palate sooner than expected and are quickly replaced with a warming malty, almost nutty aftertaste.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2003 Nice hazy brown color with a thick tan head. The aroma and flavor of this beer are all over the place. At first, the aroma is very similar to a Stone IPA. Later, it becomes more sweet (sugary) and malty. The flavor evolved in a similar way with hints of alcohol towards the end. I'm still not sure where I stand on this beer, but I will say that I think the Double Bastard has a more direct, assertive character that best represents the idea of the Arrogant Bastard Ale. The Stone Brewery certainly has challenged the way I think about beer, and what my standards for a great beer are. Awesome!
Re-rate  I drink this brew about once a month or so, and I'm always struck by how tangy it is. I mean, it's sweet, tangy, bitter, and has a bunch of indescribable flavors in there as well. This is perhaps the most tangy beer I've ever had! AWESOME!!!
Floral and nutty aroma and flavour with an aggressive finish.  A big beer with a label that defines it well.

Loved this beer!  Strong is the best word to describe this beer, and I dont mean as in alcohol.  Strong, complex,and sweet malt flavor combined with a powerful hoppiness that surprisingly balances out this beer.

Re-rate same time.  (sorry, early in the morning, forgot about the 6-10 buttons)Though I couldnt drink it every day, this is my favorite beer.  First sip led to the comment this is the best beer Ive ever had.  The beer is an appealing dark amber/brown.  Complicated aroma, spiciness, hops and alcohol are apparent from beginning to end.  Someone picked up raisins and worchesteshire sauce.  There is a lot going on with this beer and at no point is your palate left alone without a flavor to discern.  This is an aggressive beer.
Ahh, a strong ale I can appreciate. Great strong taste. 7.2% rocks ya. Beautiful color unlike any other. A great beer.
Very nice, but as the label says, this one is not for everyone, and it knows it.  THe flavor is sharp and bitter, but complex and even as well.
One of my all-time favorites.  Dark mahogany color.  A strong beer with the perfect blend of sweet malt and hops.  Flavor is very deliciously unique putting this beer in a category all its own.
Deep amber/maroon colour with a well-formed off-white head.  Almost barley wine-like in flavour, but not quite as intense in alcohol content.  But in flavour it stacks up.
average at best.  great marketing, decent beer.  hops are not pleasant in this one.  a good way to introduce the world to the rest of their range, which is outstanding
The initial aroma and flavor are both very misleading. The flavor is very full and complicated. Every drink reveals a different taste and after-taste. It is very full and tasty!
Bottle.  A mahogany red color with a beige head.  A red fruit aroma with a dark, rich, grainy, caramel, vineous flavor.  A real treat.

Tremendous beer, dark amber in color, hoppy floral aroma mixed with sweetness malt, very smooth, kept a great head throughout the bottle, very hoppy flavors, spicy aftertaste, very rich malty flavors as well, awesome brew
Nice solid hop aroma and malt. Nice carbonation and good body to the brew. Flavors balanced in the middle with a strong hop finish. More like an IPA to me. A solid beer for hopheads.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2005 Excellent appearance, strong, flavorful taste, and a 7.2% ABV, how else can you possibly better this situation??? Flavor lasts throughout the drink...fine ale...worth the money

Rerate....when did i rate this..the ice age? Dark appearance, pine in the nose, hint of malts, nuts, and more piney hop coneness. Fizzy active carbonation, mouthfeel is full and thick, lacing evident all around my glass. Dry strong finish, piney and sticky.
Another great name,  another iffy beer.  They tried to do to much.  Flavors clash.
A very strong ale with a top-notch flavor.  Not a beer to go with every meal, but definitely good for a night out with the buds.  Double the fun with the double arrogant bastard.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2004 Nice blend of caramel, fruit and pine in the aroma.  Arrogant Bastard is a deep red color, with very fine carbonation.  More choice blending of hops and malt in the flavor.  Malt is almost sticky sweet, but the earthy hop flavors are right on top of it to make sure it doesn't run too far.  I like the hops that are in this beer, whatever they are.  I do have a preference for the piney, spicy hops over the citrusy or less complex ones.  Finish sees some tingle on the palate from the hoppiness, then both malt and hops mingle again.  Similar in profile to a Winter Warmer or English Strong style, but has a bit more bitterness than most of those.  Quite tasty.  My kind of thing.  Not yours, though.  ;)

Aroma is very sweet, and somewhat chocolaty.  The color is much darker then I was expecting.  It is about the brown of well worn brown leather shoes.    As for the flavor, the label pretty much sums it up.  Pretty good.  Definatly not an every day beer.

It is rare I find a beer that I MUST drink slowly.  Both the tase and the high alcohol make this a sipping beer for me.  The flavor is complex with lots of hops and sweet maltyness.  I must admit that the marketing is pretty agressive.. but the beer lives up to it fully I think.  The finish on this is about as long as it gets.
The attitude so agressively displayed on the bottle is carried out inside the bottle.  Beautiful color with a slight roasted flavor.
Nice deep amber color.  SLight hop aroma.  Body is ablend of malt, caramel, and a hint of roastiness and bitterness.  Finishes with somewhat of a hop bite.  Another great brew from Stone.

An excellent beer.  Cheers to Stone Brewing for this one.  Very nice amber color, strong hops presence with a complex malt flavor and aroma.  And the label on the bottle is enough to make it worth drinking.  Believe the hype, this is simply a great beer.

A delicious beer. I thought with all the hype, it wont live up to it but I was mistaken. A dark amber/brown with a cornucopia of aroma and flavor. I wasnt much for the hop heavy brews but this is very well balanced. I can appreciate the hop flavors without them overpowering my taste buds. Damned good!
Its all marketing.  They try to do too much with this beer and leave me empty.  I dont understand all the hype.  It wasnt aggressive it was mediocre.
Hops very present almost over powering sweet maltiness takes over the more I drank this beer the more I wanted
looks, smells and tastes good. an amazing beer. even if it werent, youd still want to drink it because its cool.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2005 A sweet initial taste that finishes with strong hops.  The reverse psychology ad campaign is a little patronizing, but theyve got a great beer to back up their arrogance.  Not just a catchy name, this stuff is good.
The more I come back to this the more I like it, along with all of Stones products.  Definately one of Californias best breweries.
fruity aroma and taste with a spicy sweet finish.  The farther along in the bottle I got the more I liked it.

i thought this was one awesome beer!  deep amber color, very thick and frothy head on my bottle that left lacing up the entire glass. nice hoppy and mild citrus flavors. the bitterness in this beer lasts forever (almost literally), but its very well-balanced in my opinion.

I wasnt ready for this one. Medium brown in color, with a bit of fizziness in a week head. First taste is an explosion in your mouth that can be unplesant if you arent prepared for it. Strong hop with snappy citris, coupled with a dark maltiness. Truly a taste of its own.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2013 Plentiful hop resins mingling with wise and chewy caramelized and bready cereals...Leafy hop bitterness develops peppery spiciness and citrus in the aftertaste...Nourishment and balance in assertive cleanliness for an engaging India Red Ale...
UPDATED: APR 29, 2010 Finally got to try this one. Strong hops (duh), that to me were nicely balanced with the malts. Definitely worth getting another bottle or two.
Very good beer...hoppy, but tolerable.  Very flavourful and malty.

Spicy, hoppy nose with a hint of cantaloupe. Deep caramel color. Citrus, grapefruit-like taste up front that turns real bitter and gritty towards the end. Supported by a heavy amount of malt and alcohol, which turbo injects the flavor into your mouth. Leaves a sweetness on your lips like a lollipop. Complex, long and varied profile. Certainly full bodied. This almost-barleywine is over the top, but is it balanced or good? I certainly enjoy the audacity – or better arrogance- of this beer.

This beer is a delightful onslaught of flavor.  I like how ratebeer has called this an American Strong Ale, because it does transcend the traditional strong ale category.  The hops in this kicked up several notches, and combined with malty sweetness of a strong ale, this is a very big beer.  Outstanding!
Arrogant with good reason.  Gives ya something to think about.  Definately not something I could drink every day but an interesting experience.

Taste buds get reasy for asn ass KICKIN! this is a big beer with lots of flavor, worth buying just for the comentary on the bottle, strong, malty, hoppy, what else could you want in a beer, excellent!

Malty nose. Less hoppy than its brother IPA. Light barley-wine or a big brown ale. However, I do find the beer to be chockfull of complex malt, yeast, and hop flavors. Its hot in Baltimore and I do not mind this bastard.

I loved this beer, which probably means I am a drinker of taste and sophistication, since I could appreciate the quality and depth of this ale. Lovely sweet malty aroma, dark brown color and beige head. The taste is at first sweet and malty, with a hint of smoke and roasted malts, much like a stout, and finishes brutally bitter and hoppy. This is the epitome of a perfectly balanced beer.. the malt and the hops are showcased beautifully, without one overpowering the other. I would classify this beer as a strong mutant altbier.

Big variety of banana, meat like, melon and nuts, barley and a grapefruit aftertaste, that gives all the varieties again. Nice red dark black color with a small head. Very interesting beer, that numbs lips. Keep refrigerated Numbskull!
UPDATED: AUG 11, 2007 Excellent beer. I AM worthy. Big bold hops, a some-kind-of-candy aroma. Rerate: seemed a lot more dry than it used to be and somehwat disappointing.

great beer that lives up to its boast.
ruby brown colour, fluffy beige head that has the texture of whipped cream,  sheets of sticky sweet lace.
sweet malty aroma with a plum note.
taste starts of as malt caramel and chocolate, the middle is mellow , fruity and alcoholic, finish is dry and has a surprising hop bite.
A big  beer in every sense of the term

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2003 The almost perfect beer.  This one suits my desire for hoppy character with a balanced (nice blend of the malt and the hopps for sure)compex but bold and in your face taste.  This is definately not for the novice beer drinker as its strenght might be a negative for those accostomed to yellow, watery fizzy beers.

A very deep amber/red colored beer that forms a decent head.
It has an interesting flavor to it. A bit stronger than I like my beers unless theyre heavier to offset the taste of alcohl.
Very hoppy, great deep color, and very complex. This is a must try if you havent yet.

Wonderful deep red color and a full head demands your attention from the very start. Very well hopped with a somewhat distracting pineapple/fruit aroma. Strong full bodied flavor that asserts this beers character. Well made overall, with a good balance of hops and malt. A great brew not to be missed.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2016 Can. Head is initially large, frothy/creamy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is clear dark amber. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain/seeds), moderately to heavily hoppy (grapefruit, resin, marijuana), with notes of black tea and alcohol. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, heavily bitter. Medium to full body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly astringent, moderately alcoholic. 

Not too bad for the style. Limited depth and enticement in the nose, but the flavor balance, appearance, and mouthfeel are all pleasant. Unremarkable but pretty solid for this brewery.

World-class ale with a dark amber/ruby color.Very well-balanced burnt malt/hop nose with citrus,caramel.What really sets this beer apart is its very unique and silky texture.Intense resinous taste with notes of grapefruit,burnt caramel,some smoke and a good bitter finish.I couldnt think of a better name for this beer.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2004 Ok, if you haven't tried this work of genius you absolutely must. It is probably the best beer I've ever tried under 9%abv and certainly one of the most complex brews out there. Hints of mulled cide and caramel abound. Absolutely delicious. 4.7
re-rate (4/12/04): Still a great beer, just not as good as I once thought in my noephite stage of beerdom.

wowsers... this is serious beer... very well hopped - which normally I dont like - but its balanced by a healthy amount of malt.  strong with an in-your-face flavor all around.  the color is a brilliant dark red.  excellent - if you can handle it.

Easily one of the best beers Ive ever had. The balance is clearly toward the bitter & hoppy side, but the malt balances perfectly! Its this razor sharp balance that allows the beer to finish clean and dry - not too flabby from alot of malt, and not too grating from back-of-the-mouth hop bitterness.
This is a very strong tasting beer, in a large bottle. It reminds me very much of a Shiner Bock in taste and consistency. A good beer, but not one I would go out of my way to order.
Nice color, nice head,nice body with sweet tones, nice hoppy finish... creepy looking bottle!
